text:
Dear friends and family, Thank you so much for the outpouring of love and support since
I had my 13 hour 'debulking' surgery for ovarian cancer at Johns Hopkins Medical Center,
where I received extraordinary care, on 8 May; I am so very grateful. Because you are all
so kind as to write, text and call me, and because I don't always have the stamina to
write individual responses, I am experimenting with this website, which will allow me to
provide some collective updates when I can't write individual notes. If you would like to
be removed from this list, please let me know. Also please feel free to *not* read any of
these updates!
I am coming along, feeling slightly more energetic, better appetite etc. and am able to
take walks in the nice weather. I still have a lot of pain in my core. I will return to Hopkins
next Tuesday for evaluations, especially concerning my stomach drainage tubes. I will
not be able to begin chemotherapy until the issue with fluid in my stomach, which the
doctors detected at the end of my stay, is resolved. Fingers crossed.
My mother returned to NY this morning but will meet me in Baltimore next week. And
Ben, who has my car in DC, will drive me back to State College next Thursday. Again, I
can't stress how generous and kind everyone has been as I try to direct my 'creativity'
towards helping regenerate my body and health. Love, Willa
label: joy

text:
Thanks fo my very dear friend, Gay Morelli, today I realized a small goal I had set for
myself in the hospital: to sit beside one of the many enchanting streams in Happy Valley.
We headed for Fisherman's Paradise, a world-famous site for fly fishing, and spent two
hours lunching (1/4 of an egg salad sandwich, some cheddar cheese and some fresh
strawberries for me, which thankfully agreed with me), chatting, walking a little bit, and
enjoying the gorgeous weather. The babbling sounds of Spring Creek were very calming,
the air was fragrant, the sun warm and we saw some ebony jewelled (?) dragonflies
dancing with one another! Anyone who knows me well knows that dragonflies are one of
my personal emblems. I even had energy after that to go to Meyer Dairy for a delicious
coffee malted, most of which I saved. I was pretty exhausted when I returned a lay down
for a while before another kind friend brought over some groceries.
My surgery was one month ago. My surgeon, Dr. Anna Beavis, compared it to 'being hit
by a Mack truck and then being rolled over again the other way.' I still have a lot of pain
in my core. I have a bit more stamina and energy but get very tired by evening. My
appetite is improved.
Photo of me at Spring Creek today. I'm trying to keep up my appearance as much as
possible; it helps me.
label: joy

text:
I may have tired myself out a bit from my outing yesterday, but I took a rest this
afternoon and felt better. I'm likely feeling a bit anxious about the upcoming trip to
Baltimore on Tuesday, with three days of appointments at Hopkins, CT scans, meetings
with my surgeon and liver surgeon etc. I hope I have the stamina for all of it. My mother
will be kindly joining me there. The best outcome would be to have my stomach drains
removed on the last day. We'll see.
Rabbi Ostrich nicely paid me a visit and we sat outside near my rosebush, in the sun.
Among other topics, we talked about the possibility of my learning something/s from this
difficult part of my journey (which is not the same as the 'everything happens for a
reason' idea, which I don't ascribe to at all). We also talked about a teaching I find
meaningful, from Rabbi Nachman of Breslov (an 18th/19th c. Hasidic rabbi): "The entire
world is a narrow bridge. The most important thing is not to fear." There are widely
varying degrees of peril or 'fraugthness' in many of our undertakings; the important
thing is not to look down when you're on that bridge and to stay focused on what needs
to be done.
I'll have company at dinner and overnight tonight (more kind friends). I also enjoyed
watching the exciting men's final at the French Open this morning!
label: fear

text:
Hello from Baltimore. My surgeon said I’m progressing ‘well,’ but my abdominal CT scan
revealed that the drains were no longer well positioned to drain the pocket of fluid that
needs to resolve before I can start chemo. So today I’m having a procedure to reposition
the drains. And then two more weeks of draining and antibiotics, and then back to
Hopkins in two weeks for another CT scan and drain check. Hopefully they’ll come out
then. This puts me ‘behind’ for the start of chemo, but fortunately the CT scan did not
reveal any new tumors. Thanks, everyone, for your well wishes. These ‘blips’ are not
uncommon. Patience is proving a virtue. 
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app
  
June 13, 2019
label: neutral

text:
Back in State College. The drain repositioning went well, and I have returned home with
only one stomach drain, which makes a difference psychologically in terms of the time I
spend flushing and draining the drainage bags. My surgeon also eliminated two of my
daily medications plus a daily injection I was giving myself to prevent clotting. So that is
good. Of course, many new medications will be added when I start chemo.
I also met briefly with the liver surgeon who performed part of my operation, Dr. William
Reece Burns, who thought everything looked fine. I can't praise the medical personnel at
Hopkins highly enough; they are superbly skilled, sensitive to patients, thorough,
responsive (via email, phone etc.). I feel so fortunate to be treated there. The surgeon
who performed my 13 hour operation, Dr. Anna Beavis, must be out slaying dragons in
                         
her spare time. She totally rocks.
I have to return to Hopkins June 25-27, hopefully to have the drains removed. This is
always a bit of a logistical challenge as I don't feel comfortable driving that distance due
to the medications I'm taking, but I will figure out a solution.
My mother, who was a super trooper while she was with me in Baltimore, returned to
New York by train and Ben (who had my car in DC) picked me up and drove us home,
where he'll stay until he leaves for a business trip on Saturday. Of course I was thrilled to
have three hours of car time with my son, and some time here as well. In what must be a
good sign, I convinced Ben to let me take him to Alvaro's, the fabulous old-school Italian
bake shop/restaurant in Harrisburg that is always my midway stopping point when I'm
driving to DC. Ben had a delicious chicken parm sandwich on homemade Italian bread.
My appetite is much diminished, but I did enjoy about 1/4 of a meatball sandwich, and
we shared a homemade gelato (burnt almond/pistachio). With my digestive tract
'rewired,' I'm nowhere near my normal levels of 'foodiness,' but hopefully I'll get back
there at some future point.
Thanks, everyone, for all the texts, messages, emails. Sooo appreciated. Big love,
label: joy

text:
Not too much to report. It was wonderful having Ben here for a few days (he's gone back
to DC now); his presence was immensely comforting and he helped me with shopping,
cleaning and other chores around the house. We also took a few walks and I was able to
walk further than I had previously. I had my final visits with the PT and visiting nurse, so I
am pretty much 'solo' right now, while many kind friends continue to bring meals,
flowers, and themselves as visitors. I think I'm managing ok, although I can start feeling
overwhelmed quickly. I have to try to stay 'on task' with exercises and walks, staying
ultra-hydrated etc. I did take a long nap this afternoon, though. My body likely needs
                        
that time to heal. Thank you, everyone, for the recent texts, emails and msgs.
label: sadness

text:
I have been 'solo' for a few days now, and am feeling a bit mixed about it. It's very
peaceful, and I've been sleeping a lot, both at night and in the afternoon. I guess my
body needs the rest. I'm finding it a bit hard to get motivated to do things, even take a
shower. I can't tell whether I'm depressed or just tired -- or both. A few friends have
come by to visit and that has lifted my spirits.
I'm feeling some tightening in my core, which I think may be muscle and tissue getting
stronger. At least I hope that's what it is. It is easier for me to walk than it was previously
- I twice walked ten long laps of my house today without much difficulty.
                        
I am getting connected to a network at Hopkins that pairs survivors with those going
through treatment, like me. I hope that will be helpful. I've also looked into a support
network here for women dealing with gyn cancers, run by one of my neighbors/fellow JCC
congregants. I realized that I recognized one name already on the list of members. Not
feeling too alone while on the 'narrow bridge' will, I think, be key for me.
Thanks, everyone, for the texts and emails, yummy food and other acts of caring and
kindness. XO
label: sadness

text:
Today I had a consultation with Dr. Hegstrom, the surgeon who will place a port in my
chest through which I'll receive chemo and fluids. While I'm assured by others that this is
a fairly simple outpatient procedure -- it takes about fifteen minutes and I'll be lightly
sedated -- the list of potential risks (eg a lung collapsing) is always scary to hear. If all
goes as planned, the port will be inserted on 1 July. While Dr. Hegstrom also expressed
some concern about my stomach infection not being resolved, which might in turn
impact the port placement, in the end he seemed to feel fairly confident (by looking at
the fluid in my drainage bag) that my remaining stomach drain would indeed be
removed next week. Let's hope so.
As the scale revealed that I've lost 10-15 pounds since surgery, and to take the edge off
the visit with the surgeon, I treated myself to a small Dairy Queen cone after the
appointment.
My wonderful friend Maria came over for tea and a good chat. Then my equally
wonderful friend Monique came by with a yummy and nutritious looking dinner of tilapia,
zucchini and potatoes, which I look forward to trying soon. The visits from friends are so
uplifting and so essential to my recovery.
A college friend who had just heard about my health situation from another classmate
wrote to tell me that she had learned that I was "very ill." This made me wonder if I am,
in fact, very ill. While ovarian cancer can be notoriously aggressive, I am preferring to
focus on the fact that I came out of major surgery very well (aside from the hopefully
soon to be resolved stomach drain issue), that I am moving forward to the next stage of
my treatment, and that I am receiving superb medical care from doctors fully committed
to giving me the best possible shot at a good recovery. Also: I'm a trooper.
My core has been feeling stronger the past two days. As a result, I feel less winded, can
stand taller because my ribs and diaphragm are not aching as much, and can walk with
more stamina. I hope this trend continues.
label: fear

text:
Not much new to report. Via UPS this morning I received a well chilled supply of
Neulasta, a drug that I will be taking after each chemo treatment to help me regenerate
white blood cells. I've also continued to start getting plugged into various support
groups/networks, one an online support group run by cancercare.org, the other a
'mentorship' program run by Hopkins. Today I was paired with my 'mentor,' a survivor
who lives in the Lewistown area, ie not far from State College. I hope to speak with her
soon.
As mentioned, my core continues to feel a bit stronger but I feel that I must push myself
harder to take walks, exercise etc. Not always that easy when I'm solo, as I'm not really
supposed to walk unaccompanied. Tomorrow, though, I am hoping to spend some time
with my friend Maria at the Penn State Arboretum, where we'll surely stroll through the
beautiful gardens.
But I did push myself to get to services tonight, and I'm glad I did. I was able to get rides
there and back. It was nice to be with my Jewish community and to see several people
who know about my health challenges and who have been expressing concern in writing
but not yet in person. I am not quite sure who in my congregation knows and that is
slightly awkward, but it's also ok. The congregation is another source of comfort, caring
and 'uplift,' and some of the prayers are as well. The line that always resonates with me,
from the prayer for a peaceful sabbath night is: "May you walk with good companions." I
                        
most certainly do, and am most grateful for that.
label: joy

text:
Grateful to several friends who provided cheer today. My friend Maria and I enjoyed
strolling and chatting in the beautiful Penn State arboretum on a perfect June day. It's a
gorgeous spot, and a real asset to our campus and town. We loved admiring the many
different types of flowers, plants and trees in magnificent summer bloom and also
cheered on a bride processing to her ceremony under a big tent in the arboretum. See
pics below. Having lost about 15 lbs (but yes, what a way to lose weight...) and feeling
increasingly stronger post-surgery, I'm probably wanting to preserve this image of me for
later visualization, as I'm sure I won't look this way once chemo starts. Sigh.
My dear friends/colleagues Kathryn and John not only cooked me dinner -- delicious
steaks from a new butcher in town, grilled to perfection -- but also shared the meal with
me so we could catch up after not having seen one another in a while. It was lovely to
spend time with them. 
Photos
label: joy

text:
I am headed back to Hopkins tomorrow for more procedures -CT scan and (pending a
good result of that and hopefully!) drain removal. I am a bit apprehensive about making
                        
the trip solo, but I think I'll be ok as I am no longer feeling overwhelmed by small things,
as I was in the hospital and for the first two weeks at home. When I realized today that I
must have an adult with me to escort me out of the PACU following the drain removal
procedure (as I'll be coming off sedation), my wonderful cousin Ilene, who lives in
Baltimore with her family (her husband, David, is my dear first cousin), very kindly said
she'd be there.
There are a lot of unknowns right now, as I expect there will be for months (years?) to
come: will I be able to have the drain removed on Thursday? Has any cancer reemerged
in the meanwhile, as the CT scan might reveal? Can I start chemo soon (ie next week)?
How will those treatments affect me? Will I be able to handle them? Should I start
investigating options for when my hair will (likely) fall out? Well, I'll try not to get too far
ahead of myself.
Lovely visits and kind gestures from friends Chris, Helen and Albert warmed my spirits. A
kind neighbor came by with a book of short inspirational texts for me to take to Hopkins
with me. I so appreciate the well wishes, texts, emails, and random (or actually not so
random) acts of kindness. :)
label: fear

text:
The drain’s not coming out. While the stomach abcess has shrunk from 12 to 9 cm, it’s
still producing too much fluid (about 38 cl a day and they’d like to see 10!). W/out going
into too much detail, I was frustrated with the radiation oncologist I saw, who made the
determination about the drain, and this put me in a stressed out funk. She had not read
the report on my CT scan (which I had this morning) prior to my arrival. She said she
would consult w my surgeon, Dr. Beavis, but Dr. Beavis’ nurse had said that Dr. Beavis
would defer to radiation oncology on decisions regarding the drain. She (radiation
oncologist) said perhaps I could start chemo even without the drain pulled (as the
antibiotics I’m taking would offer additional protection) but both Dr. Beavis and Dr. Patel
(medical oncologist in State College) seemed to me adamantly opposed to this idea. She
also mentioned that I might start taking an anti-fungal medication. The first way it might
be delivered could pose risks to my heart (!!) so it would probably be delivered via port.
The CT scan report mentioned no new tumor growth; that is good. I just hope that the
best informed decision can be made regarding next steps. These will obviously include a
return trip here before long - definitely not convenient, but I’ll do whatever is necessary. 
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app
label: anger

text:
I am feeling better following a long phone call w/my surgeon, Anna Beavis (who
continues to be wonderful and who explains everything very clearly and thoroughly to
me), and now knowing that Drs. Beavis, Mehta (radiation oncologist) and Patel (medical
oncologist here in State College) have now all consulted and that everyone is on the
same page. The one stomach drain will stay in for approximately 2+ weeks longer
(precisely, two weeks after I begin receiving, on Tuesday, an anti-fungal medication
called micafungin through the port that I will have placed on Monday and through which
I'll also receive chemo). The doctors hope the anti-fungal medication may help diminish
the amount of fluid my stomach abscess is producing. In any event, after about two
weeks they will make a determination about whether I should return to Hopkins for
another CT scan or whether chemo could start right away in State College. This will
depend in large part on how much drainage there is from my stomach.
I'm sure all these details are scintillating...
My wonderful friend Ruth brought 'lunch for two' from Wegman's to my house and we
had a lovely time catching up. She encouraged me to turn my disappointment about
things I'm not doing this summer, which winds up draining my energy, into a forward
hopeful look towards doing them next year. This does not mean denying the feeling of
disappointment and sadness, but not wallowing in it. I am sooo disappointed, for
example, to not be attending tomorrow the Pride Parade in Paris with my friend Randy
and often other friends, a day I look forward to all year as a celebration of diversity,
tolerance, love -- and as a simply fabulous, joyous, incredibly fun party all over Paris but
mainly in the Marais. Next year.
In the meantime, there have been the debates, the FIFA Women's World Cup (the USA
continues not to disappoint!), and lots of visits from friends. And Ben will be here
tomorrow for a visit!
                        
Oh, and I drove today for the first time since before my surgery on 8 May. It felt ok - I
drove myself to have some bloodwork done - and I'm encouraged to increase my
independence by driving more.
Headed to services soon. Shabbat shalom,
label: sadness

text:
Aside from driving, I accomplished a few more 'firsts' this weekend (since surgery): I
drove to the Saturday farmers market for the first time this summer. Anyone who knows
me well knows that, as a confirmed foodie, I love shopping at farmers markets (whether
in State College, Paris, New York or elsewhere) and cooking with whatever is fresh and
local. I also enjoy our farmers market as a social scene - it's always nice to run into
friends and neighbors and I was missing that. Fortunately, my dear friend Maria met me
at the market because it proved a slight challenge. I was fine for about half an hour but
then the heat (perhaps 85 degrees?) starting getting to me and I felt rather weak. Maria
scuttled me under a tent set up with chairs and brought me a very refreshing drink of
Pineapple Shrub from Tait Farm (a great local place) and sparkling water. After a while I
felt fine and drove home. And I did manage to nab some great looking red and golden
beets from local Amish farmers, some garlic scapes and four freshly baked donuts in
preparation for Ben's arrival later that morning.
Speaking of food, my cooking mojo may be returning. Not sure whether it's a 'one off,'
whether I like nothing better than to cook for Ben, or some other reason, but I prepared a
salad with the beets tossed with a good vinaigrette and goat cheese and also made
some tangy garlic scape pesto, which we slathered on penne. Ben cooked the mahi-
mahi. I'm still *extremely* grateful for the meals that friends are bringing me, as the
cooking did tire me out a bit and do not have the energy to do it every day, but I'm very
glad to feel motivated, for the first time since surgery, to cook some favorite summer
dishes.
Having Ben here for a short overnight visit was the best medicine. We talked, shopped,
cooked, ate, relaxed, and (re)watched Anthony Bourdain's episode shot in Lyon in
preparation for Ben and Sammi's upcoming trip there (Ben and I were supposed to go
together, but since I can't do so this summer I'm delighted to send him and his girlfriend
and to get a full report from them -- with lots of pictures).
I am anxious about having my port placed tomorrow. I hope the procedure goes well.
Between the stomach drain and the port, I expect to feel like a bionic woman by then.
I had a scare at Hopkins when, while trying to locate the infectious diseases unit, I
mistakenly stumbled into a waiting room full of cancer patients, many of whom were
wearing surgical masks, and many of whom looked to me quite ill (very thin, in
wheelchairs, bald, sickly, coughing etc.). As I feel (and look) relatively 'good' (or at least
better....) right now (and at least compared to right after surgery), I wonder if I have
lulled myself into a false sense of normalcy and complacency, trotting off to the farmers
market to schmooze with my friends. What's the line that separates me from those
cancer patients waiting to see their doctors? I have cancer too. The images made me
shudder and I needed to refocus and get back into the present and the task at hand of
                        
recovery and treatment. Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death...
Photos
label: joy

text:
I had my port successfully placed this morning. The procedure only took about 15-30
minutes (I was completely out from the sedation), but I wound up being at the outpatient
surgical clinic from about 9 to 1:30. I'm starting to feel a bit of pain/discomfort now that
the local anesthetic is wearing off, but nothing that a dose of Percocet tonight shouldn't
be able to alleviate.
Tomorrow -- in a scenario that is making me a bit anxious but that I am hoping will also
work out fine -- a nurse will be driving to my house from Akron, OH (!!) to administer my
first dose of anti-fungal medication through my port (which will hopefully help further
clear up the stomach abscess issue) and to show *me* how to administer it after that.
The medicine is supposed to be delivered to my home between 10 and 11 tomorrow.
These are the some of the inconveniences of living in a somewhat remote area, I'm
finding: I suppose a nurse skilled at giving infusions (and working for a home health
agency) could not be found closer to me. However "nurse Ruth" just called me and she
sounds extremely competent and 'on task' so I will go with the flow.
...and then it will be *back* to Hopkins next week for what I'm really hoping will be a final
CT scan and drain removal. Which means I again need to try to set up rides and make
arrangements. It is not convenient but it is certainly worth it for the excellent care I am
getting.
Meanwhile, the sun is still shining on this beautiful day so I think I'll go sit outside and
finish reading an excellent _New Yorker_ article about Emmanuel Macron's presidency.
One day at a time.
label: fear

text:
The past few days have been a bit frustrating but I'm focusing on the positive. I am
having an anti-fungal medication, micafungin, delivered via my port to hopefully help
clear up my stomach abscess (so far, I have not noticed any effect on the amount of
stomach fluid I've been draining). The goal is for me to be able to administer this
medication myself, through my port (through which I'll also receive chemo), but it seems
quite daunting (many steps, but I think I'll get there). So this morning I am having a third
visiting nurse come administer the medication and offer me a third lesson in how to do
it. Nurse Ruth, who drove here from Akron, Ohio (4 hours), was good humored and very
capable, but yesterday Nurse David actually helped teach me better (both were very
nice and to a certain extent helped alleviate my anxiety, at least temporarily). Nurse
Todd will, I believe, be arriving soon. The infusion, which drips from a bag hung up on an
IV pole, takes about an hour and I have to take this med for one month. I can move
around with the pole and do other things around the house.
I am also having a hard time arranging transport to/from Baltimore (an unanticipated
problem, partly because I did not realize that I'd have to be making so many trips
there!), but my wonderful friend Sandy is going to drive me there next Wednesday for
another CT scan, consult w/Dr. Mehta (radiation oncologist) and -- again, hopefully (but
again, it may not happen) - drain removal.
I had a great talk last night with Rhonda, an ovarian/uterine cancer survivor who was
treated at Hopkins and is my 'mentor' via a Hopkins-based program called Woman to
Woman. Rhonda was very validating about my feelings, shared her own experiences and
those of other survivors, and was also super-encouraging about the current treatments
and of course the world-class medical care at Hopkins. We are the same age, both have
one son (hers a bit older) and she lives just about 25 miles from here, in Lewistown (her
husband and son both work in State College). It feels wonderful to have this 'lifeline' (and
the reinforced mantra of "you are not alone"), along with a similar great connection with
Diane in New York (a member of my extended family and also a survivor) and likely soon
a support group in State College that is planning a picnic for August. I am so grateful.
I have been having a lot dreams about France. Of course, I'd love to be there and miss
my 'happy place.' In one dream, I was in the driver's seat of a car that I had stopped in a
dusty lot, somewhere in the US, with, above me, a maze of highways densely packed
with urban  traffic. I was trying to set my GPS to figure out how to drive to France but all
sorts of odd maps kept popping up. In another dream, I am in France and order a "Perrier
menthe" (my go to drink for very hot summer days in Paris) but the waiter instead brings
                        
me an Apérol spritz, only filled up about halfway, and I am disappointed (I am not a big
fan of Apérol, as many are, far preferring my spritz with Campari - miam miam). In 'real
life,' I've of course been avidly following the women's world cup matches taking place all
over France. And Ben and Sammi will be heading to Paris tomorrow, and I will be
enjoying their trip to Paris and Lyon vicariously. I can feel my own travel bug restless
within me and am already dreaming up some new trips - hopefully.
Grateful to friends John, Sandy and Ron, and Clare for recent visits, delicious food
(posole, flan, couscous, chilled asparagus soup!) and good cheer.
Warm thanks to friends who have written emails recently. I *will* write back soon! In
fact, I am in the midst of answering each of them, but want to give each the attention it
deserves, as I do my friendship with you generally as it is important to me. Sorry for the
lateness, then, but you'll hear from me soon.
Happy birthday, America.
Hugs,
emails
label: fear

text:
If I am learning anything on this journey it is to better identify, and be
grateful for, acts of kindness.
My sweet cousin, Raphael Noah Eagle, along with his dad, my dear first
cousin David Eagle, will soon be participating in a 90 mile bike race to raise
money for Friendship Circle, an organization that works to end the
loneliness of children and adults with disabilities (you can read David's
description below). Raphael and David are kindly making me the 'honoree'
of their race! I couldn't be more touched. Thank you, Team Eagle. And so
glad to know too that you are nearby in Baltimore, where it turns out I'm
now a frequent visitor.
Dear Friends and Family,
 
On July 18, G-d willing, Raphael Noah and I will be joining dozens of cyclists to undertake a challenging 90-mile ride in
support of Friendship Circle.  Friendship Circle is an amazing organization whose mission is to end loneliness for special
                        
needs children and adults through a variety of programs.  I just heard that they sponsored and accompanied 22 young
men and women with special needs on a trip to Israel, none of whom had ever traveled before without their parents.  True
"chesed" (kindness)!
 
I don't know if I will be able to complete the 90 miles in the heat of July, but I am planning to have a blast with Raphael
and our cycling buddies in support of a worthy cause.  This year we are dedicating our ride to our courageous cousin Willa
Silverman, who is determined to overcome the health challenges she is currently facing.  Raphael has added a nice note
and photo of Willa on his fundraising page (see link below).
 
The Talmud says that "charity hastens the redemption," which means both the universal redemption when the world will
leave in peace as well as our own personal redemptions that we all strive to achieve.  If you feel inclined to make a
charitable donation toward Raphael's gutsy ride for a very good cause, please click on this link:
 
https://www.teamfriendship.org/bikejerseyshore/RaphaelNoah
 
With love and appreciation,
David
https://www.teamfriendship.org/bikejerseyshore/RaphaelNoah
label: joy

text:
There is not much new to report. I am focused on my upcoming trip to
Hopkins on Wednesday-Thursday and hope that my CT scan will provide
evidence that my stomach drain can be removed; I guess I have to prepare
for the possibility that it won't be, though.This really is a marathon - yeesh.
Cheered that my friend Sandy will kindly accompany/drive me to/from
Baltimore. We'll both have rooms in the Residence Inn near the Hopkins
Medical Center (lots of out of town patients stay there, and the staff is very
nice), which has a lovely rooftop restaurant with panoramic views of the
city.
Nurse Todd came over today to change the needle in my port; this needs to
be done once a week. He also gave me a refresher in how to administer my
micafungin infusion as my previous two solo attempts resulted in either the
medicine and/or my blood spurting out of the tubing, which was stressful to
witness. Today I managed to do everything correctly, but after the medicine
had finished dripping I waited too long to proceed to the next step (flushing
my tubing with saline and then an anti-clotting med) as I was enjoying a
visit with my friend Maria, and my tubing (which I had forgot to clamp once
the medicine finished dripping) again filled with some blood. Oy. I think
tomorrow will be a charm. Then I'll need to throw two days worth of the med
                        
-- which I'm expecting to arrive tomorrow via UPS as part of my next weekly
delivery -- on cold packs for transport to Baltimore, along with my i.v. pole,
so that I can administer the med when I'm there. Nothing in life is simple :(
Tomorrow is the second anniversary of my father's death from lung cancer
and other ailments and of course I'll be thinking of him (and unless I'm
unable I'll also observe his yartzheit at synagogue on shabbat a bit later this
month). While it's awful for any parent to witness a child experience a
serious illness, I think it would have been particularly hard on my father in
his extreme ill health. My mother, thankfully, has a tremendous amount of
fortitude, is very pragmatic, and as a cancer survivor herself understands
well certain aspects of my treatment. She's been a great comfort to me.
Aside from a lovely visit with Maria, I enjoyed breakfast out at a local bagel
place with my friend Gay. After sitting for a while, my abdomen starts to feel
uncomfortable, but I was still grateful for the simple pleasure (and frequent
ritual) of having breakfast and catch-up with a close friend.
My college classmate and friend Josh sent me some koans familiar to him
from his martial arts practice. Per Wikipedia (!), a koan is "a story, dialogue,
question, or statement which is used in Zen practice to provoke the 'great doubt' and to
practice or test a student's progress in Zen." There is also sometimes an element of
paradox in koans.
Face hard times with an unshakable spirit.
Be patient with yourself and with others.
Keep a strong center.
Be grateful for each moment.
If you fall seven times, get up eight times.
Another koan Josh sent asks the question of which is stronger, a steel rod or a
bamboo stalk? Answer: the bamboo stalk, as it is more flexible and can adapt or bend
as situations require.
I think I may need, among other elements including continued excellent medical care,
both the perseverance of the Zen master and the gutsy badassery of a Megan Rapinoe
                        
to meet the challenges ahead.
Big love,
label: joy

text:
If all goes as planned, my remaining stomach drain will be removed tomorrow morning.
The CT scan of my abdomen, which I had taken this morning, revealed that the abscess
has again shrunk in size. It is not completely resolved, so I’ll continue to take two strong
antibiotics and the antifungal med for a few more weeks at least. But the radiation
oncologist, Dr. Mehta, thinks chemo should not be delayed further, even if there’s a risk
that the stomach infection could still interfere with the chemo (causing it to be
interrupted or even necessitating placement of another stomach drain). There is so much
uncertainty in this cancer journey, ie the ‘narrow bridge’ that I wrote about in another
post. I’m hoping and presuming that my other doctors will be on board with this plan.
No signs of new visible cancer in this particular CT scan - good news.
I’ll have to return to Hopkins in a few weeks for follow up.
So my chemo could begin quite soon, as early as next week.
I asked the doctor if I could have a celebratory glass of wine tonight but she advised that
it interacts badly with Flagyl and would make me feel sick. I haven’t had a drop of
alcohol since early May and it looks like I’ll need to wait longer to enjoy a glass of wine or
                        
a cocktail. It’s ok. My friend Sandy, who very kindly accompanied me on this trip, and I
will enjoy a nice dinner in the hotel’s rooftop restaurant. And I’m vicariously enjoying Ben
and Sammi’s food and wine adventures in the Lyonnais!
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app
label: joy

text:
Back from the quick overnight trip to Baltimore. Had another CT scan of my abdomen (I
am almost used to the yucky tasting 'drink' ingested before the procedure, but still could
not help spitting up afterwards the contrast dye injected into me, which filled my mouth
with a metallic salty taste and my body with a warm and unpleasant rush). Then I met
with Dr. Mehta, the radiation oncologist, who said that although the stomach abscess has
not completely resolved (it has shrunk by about half and is producing less fluid than
before), she felt that the better plan at this point would be to remove the stomach drain,
keep me on two strong antibiotics and an anti-fungal for 4-6 more weeks, and proceed to
chemo. Of course, the risk still remains that the infection could rear its head during
chemo, causing the chemo to 'blow up' (as Dr. Patel said), and in turn necessitating a
temporary stoppage of chemo and/or reinsertion of stomach drain. I will need to ask
what the chances of this are. I certainly hope it doesn't happen. The risk of waiting for
the infection to resolve further would be the possibility of new tumors forming. All my
                        
doctors are on board with the new plan.
As mentioned, though, little is straightforward in this journey. When I arrived the next
morning to have the stomach drain removed by in the interventional radiologists, the
doctors balked, saying that my stomach was still producing too much fluid and that they
did not recommend removing the drain. Needless to say, this threw me into a panic, as
this was my *third* trip to Hopkins in the hopes of having the drain removed. Only some
eleventh-hour discussions between those doctors and Dr. Mehta resulted in all the
doctors getting on the same page about drain removal. But of course this again made
me feel shaky about the decision to remove the drain, given the initial disagreement
among the doctors. It is hard for me to sit with this type of anxiety and uncertainty,
when I am really trusting the doctors to make the best decisions. In any event, the
stomach drain was removed -- to my surprise, I was not sedated and the PA simply
pulled the tube out of my stomach (uncomfortable, a bit painful, but not excruciating...).
I believe my chemo will start next Thursday, here in State College. Of course, I am
anxious (a recurrent word in this entry, I see..) and will focus on preparing myself
physically and mentally this coming week, while also getting out in the nice weather and
having some fun.
In a beautiful act of friendship, my friend Sandy traveled with me to Baltimore and back.
As paradoxical as it may seem given the circumstances, we actually had a a great time
on our road trip, and shared many laughs -- whether over the deafening din in the hotel's
rooftop restaurant, where the horrible acoustics made the rather pathetic musician
playing his guitar in a remote corner of the room sound like he was playing a sitar; or
over our somewhat madcap multi-hour interlude getting repeatedly lost in Harrisburg
trying to get to Alvaro's bake shop (closed), Little Amps coffee house (struck out trying to
find it at both addresses), and finally winding up at "The Sandwich Man" (see pic) in
Paxtonia, PA, for tuna sandwiches. Felt like Groundhog Day as we kept crisscrossing the
same highways and retracing our steps! In another central PA moment, a billboard at the
edge of Harrisburg raised the question of whether those reading it were going to heaven
or hell. Maybe I should call the number to find out? In any event, "cancer is hilarious" --
occasionally. A virtual prize to anyone who knows in what t.v. series that line is
pronounced.
In another beautiful act of friendship, my dear friend and college roommate Denise Reiss
and her husband Mike came to visit me briefly at the hotel and accompanied me to my
procedure! It was wonderful to see them and Denise has always gone out of her way to
be in touch with her friends when they are facing challenges. I wish we could have spent
more time visiting but I hope I'll get to see them in NY or PA before long.
Thanks too to my friend John who kindly drove me to his in-laws' farm the other day and
set up a lawn chair for me right by Slab Cabin Creek that runs through the backyard of
                        
the property. Sipping a big glass of ice cold lemonade (which John also provided), I
enjoyed a pleasant few hours reading in this idyllic spot, with ducks, roosters, dogs and a
horse completing the tableau.
Ben and Sammi, seen here wine-tasting in the Beaujolais, are at the end of a wonderful
trip to France, ending with a few days in Annecy. I'm so glad that they were able to take
this trip in my absence. This is great motivation for me to get back to France!
Photos
label: fear

text:
With chemo starting on Thursday, I find myself thinking about how my appearance may
change, especially with the predicted loss of my hair, possible changes in skin tone, and
weight gain or loss. Without wanting to seem vain (but I likely am a bit, but hopefully not
egregiously...), I've always prided myself on my appearance, and -- as many know -- am
all about the clothes, jewelry, makeup and accessories procured near and far that over
the years I've worked into a personal style. I love creating and accessorizing outfits that
suit my mood for the day, occasion or season. I am anxious that the loss of this part of
my identity will depress me. As various friends have pointed out, though, normally this
will be a temporary, reversible situation and I'll still get to inject a bit of signature style
into my look or experiment with new styles (I'll just need to find the right scarves and
hats to rock; I saw some cute ones on Etsy, made from kimono fabric). And *of course* I
realize that losing my hair is a small price to pay to zap those cancer cells. As my dear
grad school friend Vinni and I discussed by phone today, chemo is the crucial next step
in the healing process, as debilitating as it may be. I am grateful to my mother for
coming to State College on Wednesday to see me through the first chemo cycle. She's
been down that road too.
But that song from _Rent,_ though, that's been going through my mind recently. It's
haunting: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=okMdC9-YqrE&list=RDokMdC9-YqrE&start_radio=1&t
=0
It is difficult to know what to say to someone with cancer. For me, what proves helpful
are encouraging words, positivity re outcome, or simply 'holding space' for whatever
thoughts or emotions I may be feeling or wish to express. What proves less helpful, again
for me, are questions about prognosis, expressions of worry over my being 'very ill,' and
mention in list form of women who died young of ovarian cancer. I don't intend to sound
prescriptive, or dictate how people should react to me, and I also have to not be so rigid
as to deny people their own feelings, but I am learning what my triggers are around my
health situation.
Random (and not random!) gestures of kindness are so uplifting and healing -- there
continue to be many of them from all of you (I thank you for even reading my blog, a
kind gesture, and thank everyone for the texts, emails, cards etc.!). My cherished group
of grad school friends ("les filles") sent me a care package that will enable me to read,
watch, listen and doodle my way through the next few months. My college friend Richard
sent me a short video of him and other friends playing the Fleetwood Mac song
"Songbird" because he knew I liked it. And walks around the arts fest with several friends
this weekend were lots of fun. I bought a very pretty 'cigar band' type ring with an opal
in the middle (see pics - I always wear purple nail polish at least once at the height of
summer) and a pretty hamsa, the protective hand that one sees all over the Middle East
                        
and that is reputed to bring good luck, happiness, good fortune and health. I always wear
one when I travel and now I will wear this new one through the upcoming weeks. I should
scarcely be buying stuff for myself right now but well.... I couldn't resist. 
Photos
label: fear

text:
My love of both Art nouveau and Japanese art attracted me to dragonflies. In Art
nouveau, dragonflies often boast a distinctly human and female body, as in Lalique's
spectacular "Dragonfly Woman Corsage" brooch, shown to great success at the 1900
World's Fair. They are symbols of the beauty of the natural world (and of women's
relation to it, from the perspective of these creators), but also of transformation and
rebirth -- the dragonfly emerging from her cocoon. You'll find representations of
dragonflies all over my house. So as I head to chemo tomorrow and think about both the
power of my body to regenerate (more white blood cells, hopefully, and fewer cancer
cells) and the persistence of beauty in the world, I was delighted to receive two
dragonfly-themed gifts! My father's longtime partner, Jane, who knows all about me and
dragonflies, sent me a lovely tote bag (pic above) that I'll pack with my iPad (Kindle), ear
buds, hand and face creams, snacks and water as I head to my first round of chemo
tomorrow morning. My friend/colleague, Bénédicte, brought the right touch of bling with
a beautiful dragonfly pin. Vive les libellules!
Among the many descriptions of the experience and effects of chemo that have been
shared with me, the most striking (lyrical? humorous? affecting? real?) was that provided
by Richard, my beloved professor, dissertation director and mentor (whom I've known
since I was an eighteen-year-old freshman at Harvard in 1977), who has just finished
cancer treatment himself. Here's what he wrote me: "Chemo will be like this weird brief love
affair, with its periodic “trysts” as you are infused in the hospital.  All the steroids they give you for the
first days will make you feel oddly enhanced, and then you will slope into this weird, mushy place
after a day or two, semi-stunned and nauseous. " I was of course enthused by the initial
comparison of receiving chemo to a love affair and trysts, but then it became clear that
we may be talking about (in Gaga's terms) a "bad romance." "Semi-stunned and
nauseous" seems far less appealing, along with Richard's warning that "everything you
eat tastes like shit." So I've loaded up the fridge with yogurt and almond milk for
smoothies, come what may. One day at a time.
                        
I've also been reading some Jewish prayers for beginning chemotherapy (although I
understand that my cells may well have a mind of their own and that the 'power of
prayer' in my mind is simply akin to a positive and hopeful attitude). This one features
the protective imagery, from both the Torah and Kabbalistic mythology, of angels. I also
like the thought of compassion for the caregivers, as well as self-compassion:
“I sit here and I wait, while the medicine drips into my body. I am afraid, and
I am hopeful. May the medicine that has the power to heal or destroy be
gentle within me. Give me strength over the next few days, weeks and
months to endure the effects of the drugs and illness. While this disease is
part of my body, help me to feel powerful and in control of how I live my life.
“Give me compassion for my doctors, nurses, carers and most of all for my
own body. May I know that I am encircled by Your love. May the ancient
spirit of the angels Michael, Gabriel, Uriel and Raphael bring me a sense of
Your presence, strength, a light at the end of the tunnel, healing and hope.”
Going to lunch with my friends Mar and Jessi at the Corner Room downtown
then will head to pick up my mother at the Megabus station. 
Big love,

text:
Today, with my first round of chemo completed, my treatment really feels like a full-time
job. I didn't sleep too well because of the five steroid pills that I took last night to combat
nausea; they ramped me up. I had a classic work anxiety dream: I was on a dissertation
committee but had not read the full dissertation and was racing around frantically trying
to finish up some tasks and/or figure out how I was going to deal with my lack of
preparedness. I could see the numerous other members of the committee assembled
and looking primed to begin the defense. I won't venture an interpretation here but work
is never far from my thoughts if sadly less present in my actions right now...
My friend Clare drove my mother and me to Dr. Patel's office at 8 a.m. I had blood drawn
and then met with Dr. Patel for about 20 minutes. Unfortunately, my white blood count
was lower than he would have liked, which is somewhat concerning as I need those
fighting cells! As a result, he decided to proceed but to give me a slightly lower dosage
of the chemo medications. Calculated risks are often the name of the game in this
process... I was in a room with comfy recliners and other 'amenities' - blankets, pillows,
snacks and water, t.v., magazines, a basket of knitted chemo caps for the taking. No
windows, though, unfortunately. There might have been about five or six other patients
receiving treatment at the same time as me, and three or four nurses were always on
call. The nurse who attended to me during the day was extremely kind and experienced.
First, I had to have three 'pre-chemo' meds administered through my port to counteract
nausea and a possible allergic reaction; this took about an hour and a half. Then, after a
short break, I had the chemo meds administered, also via my port: Taxol (three hours)
and Carbo (.5 hours). I felt fine during all of this. While the Carbo was being
administered, the nurse affixed a patch containing Neulasta to my left arm; it will
activate after 27 hours (ie at about 7:00 p.m. tomorrow, when I am hoping to be at
synagogue to observe my father's yarzeit - we'll see). The Neulasta helps regenerate
white blood cells; the downside is that it can also cause bone pain, so I will take a Claritin
tonight that supposedly offsets this reaction. Dr. Patel stopped in several times to see
how I was doing. Based on the blood work done this morning, he told me that my ovarian
cancer (CA125) marker was still "high," although of course lower than before my surgery.
The hope is that the marker will decrease in number after each treatment. On the other
hand, the marker for colon cancer was completely normal, which is good news as I had a
small portion of my colon removed during surgery. Dr. Patel suggests that I not get too
fixated on both the marker number and prognosis at this point, which (as I've seen in
various chat rooms for ovarian cancer patients) can get easily fetishized, becoming the
object of either hysteria or jubilation. The 'one day at a time' m.o will be key. By the time
we were done it was 4:15. My friend Nan, who now lives in Philly but who spends July in
Bellefonte with her husband, my former colleague, Allan, picked my mother and me up
and, in my desire for "instant gratification" in the form of sugar, drove us to Meyer Dairy,
where I had a delicious small Mocha Chip and caramel sauce sundae, following the
                        
mantra of "life is short; eat dessert first."
As of now (6:00 p.m.), I feel no ill effects from my treatment, but this may well change in
a day or two. I'm tired, though. I am praying that I don't develop an infection, cold or
anything else that might interfere with my treatment. I'll return to Dr. Patel's office next
week for blood work and then in three weeks for the next round. And I'm supposed to
return to Hopkins soon to see if my stomach abscess has shrunk further, but Dr. Mehta
and I agreed we'd see how I'm feeling and if I'm up to travelling to Baltimore. As I write, I
am being 'infused' with micafungin, which I continue to take to resolve the lingering (but
much smaller) stomach abscess. So yes, a full time job for now...
There was one serious downer during my chemo session. I was seated next to a very
vocal Trumpiac, whose ideas were making me as anxious as my treatment, if not more.
He was ranting about the sins of the Democrats and pronounced: "In the worst kind of
way I want to put a Rebel flag in my truck." There were also references to "brown
people," contrasted with the 'good' immigrants who came through Ellis Island (including,
apparently, this man's ancestors), and rants about decommemoration efforts (ie removal
of objectionable statues and state flags in the South). "It's history," he kept proclaiming
flatly, as if history was immutable and could never be questioned or reinterpreted or
learned from. As poison was coursing through my veins, I simply did not have the fight in
me to take him on (as I've done at a flea market in Belleville where Rebel flags are
proudly sold). I simply asked the nurse to move me to the other side of the room. Living
in my nice progressive bubble of State College, I can forget that we're surround by deep
red rural areas -- prime MAGA country. Definitely stressed me out.
So I was on the 'narrow bridge' today. I wrote about this teaching attributed to Rabbi
Nachman of Breslov in another post, citing the translation as "The whole world is a
narrow bridge, but the essence, (really… the crux of the matter), is not to be afraid." I've
since read another translation that makes more sense to me. It stresses that what is
important, rather than not being afraid, is not giving in to the fear, not despairing. It
would be unnatural to *not* be afraid in difficult situations, especially ones involving
facing one's mortality -- as a side note, the absolute *fearlessness* of Alex Honnold,
who 'free soloed' 3,000 feet up El Capitan in Yosemite, without ropes, seems positively
unnatural and there is something downright feral about Alex (see the documentary!).
However, it now seems to me that holding the fear but not becoming paralyzed by it
will be key -- a delicate yet necessary balance for the days and weeks ahead.
A thank you to Michael and Sue for making me my 'last supper' before chemo - per my
request, a delicious grilled Hebrew National hot dog and part of a hamburger, fresh
tomato and potato salads, watermelon. Yum.
                        
Thank you, everyone, for your emails and texts today, rides to and from chemo, and for
simply keeping me in your thoughts.
Love,
label: sadness

text:
As predicted might happen, massive fatigue hit me today, along with some nausea and
an occasional metallic taste in my mouth. I spent a large part of the day resting in bed,
with breaks for meals. Ugh. The heat and humidity were oppressive outside, so I was just
                        
as content to be inside in the A/C, but I do hope to regain a bit of pep after a few days.
Not much to do for now except to roll with it...
label: sadness

text:
On day three post round one of chemo, I'm feeling better than over the weekend, when I
was in that "weird, mushy," and "semi-stunned place" described by Richard S. and
needed to keep clawing my way back into bed to rest/sleep (I attribute the fatigue not
only to the chemo drugs but also to an anti-nausea medicine, Compazine). The weekend
passed in a bit of a haze, although I did manage to drive us to Kohls and Wegmans on
Sunday in the blazing heat, which did not treat me kindly. Today, I woke a bit earlier and
-- in between brief rest periods -- answered some emails and texts, paid bills, sent a baby
present and card, took a walk outside with my mother, drove us to Meyer Dairy for an ice
cream cone (I've lost twenty pounds so I'm not counting calories too rigidly), chatted
with a few visitors, and made headway editing the collective written reflection (now
eighty pages and counting) that my students and I wrote after our Holocaust-focused trip
to Paris over spring break. Of course, in my 'normal' life I'd be doing ten times more than
this -- working on articles and book projects with gusto, going full tilt with professional
and personal correspondence, taking a long walk, likely cooking something summery
(pesto, beets, a cobbler, borscht, tomato sauce, stuffed zucchini, caprese salad...), and
anticipating an enjoyable evening with friends over drinks or dinner. Admittedly, I need a
few extra measures of grace to be ok with giving at least some of this up for now,
because I enjoy it so much, as I do with renouncing for the time the kind of
adventuresome travel I like to do, including with my son. It's summer, and Facebook,
which I should likely avoid, abounds with pictures of smiling friends vacationing in far-
flung locales that I'd love to visit or revisit  (Greece, Norway, Taiwan, Italy) -- and of
course there is Paris, my 'second home.' I truly do not want to begrudge my friends their
happiness - on the contrary. Rather than envy, my feelings shade more into sadness and
'flatness' (the opposite of a feeling, I suppose, more likely depression). I need to keep the
long term goal in mind and commit myself to it every day-- treatment, recovery, ridding
my body of disease. The choice is obvious, but no less difficult.
As a modest travel goal, when I get better (or better-er) I'd love to spend a long weekend
or week with Ben in the condo my friend Jim is kindly offering to lend me in Austin. I've
only been there twice, and think it would be a great short term destination for a few chill
days of music, friends, Tex-Mex, and barbecue, perhaps with a day trip to San Antonio
and even some research at the Harry Ransom Center. I'm sure we'd like the vibe.
Paris is never far from both my conscious and unconscious. I've been having tons of
strange dreams, a few violent, many collapsing and conflating different eras of my life --
my childhood growing up in the Gramercy Park apartment (where one dream featured a
college classmate whom I haven't thought about in years), Ben's childhood (another
confronted me with about a six-year-old Ben), college (where I was being marginalized at
some sort of social function, with many college classmates dressed chicly in black and
myself walking sheepishly around the perimeter). The "France" dreams were actually
"French" dreams. I had to answer one of three comprehensive exam type questions. I
                        
remember two of them: the theme of "Amazones et économie" in 18th c. France (on this
CB site the other day, my friend Jane, flatteringly I felt, compared me to an "Amazon")
and the theme of "ordre" (order) in eighteenth-century France (this second theme is
actually quite interesting and I think I'll store it away mentally to use on a future exam
for our students!). Who knew dreams could have such practical benefits!
Sitting here in limbo -- until my blood work on Thursday and my next chemo on 8/8. Will
my white blood count have gone up? And did my Neulasta patch activate as it was
supposed to, to further boost my while blood count? Will my blood pressure still be low?
Is my stomach abscess in check? Shrinking? I should find out when I return to Hopkins in
late August. When will my hair start falling out? "Sitting here in limbo/Waiting for the dice
to roll/Sitting here in limbo/Got some time to search my soul." 
As to my hair, tomorrow I'm getting it cut very short in anticipation of losing it. I can't
predict how I'll feel. I've never considered my hair my best feature (v. eyes, lips),
although it used to be quite lustrous when I was younger, so perhaps my locks will be
easier to part with (no pun intended) for now. My stylists certainly 'know the drill' as far
as clients' hair loss is concerned, so I'm sure they'll be sensitive. And an eyebrow powder
has been recommended to me for when those go too. I've gathered a number of scarves
from my collection and will see what works. Should I be a vamp? Une élégante? A hippie
chick? I have a vintage Peter Max 'psychedelic' scarf w/zodiac signs to pull that off (and
yes, I received it as a gift in the early 1970s! - see pic). Maybe I'll just pop on my
Yankees cap and call it a day.
label: sadness

text:
I was apprehensive about the trip to the salon (the unknown, as usual), but all worked
out well, largely because the wonderful staff at J. Stephens, where I've been getting my
hair styled for years, was so caring and intent on making me feel good. Instead of going
for the full-out bald effect, which seemed radical to me at this point, I opted for a cute,
summery transitional bob. It both feels attractive and, because several inches were cut,
will likely soften the blow psychologically when my hair does fall out. In comparing a
picture of me sporting a bob at age three, I wonder if I am simply regressing in my look
and tastes -- soft comfort foods like pb&j for example are now back at the top of my list
of mealtime requests. I completed my outing with a visit to Ulta, where I bought some Ka-
Brow! eyebrow power that will hopefully help create a look that goes Ka-Boom! Since I
didn't sleep very well last night, I was too tired to do much else today (had wanted to get
to the Boalsburg farmers' market), but visits from friends Mary Kay and Gay were
cheering, and I read a long _New Yorker_ profile about Kamala Harris. Have taped
today's stage of the Tour de France, taking place in Provence just before the dramatic
ascent into the Alps, for evening watching. XO 
Photos
label: fear

text:
Today was a good day, which unexpectedly provoked several mini-laughing jags from me
(is this an inappropriate reaction? cue exaggerated stage whisper here: "She has...
cancer..."). While in the waiting room at the oncologist, I texted with a friend about
cringe-worthy/sleazy/weird online dating profiles we've encountered, and she shared
that she once read a profile that included the following: "I admire a woman who can use
sh-t and f-ck in a sentence" [Horrified guffaw #1]. Good thing I've forsworn online dating 
�� Then, I received an incredibly vividly written email from my friend Randy, describing
his valiant yet ultimately failed efforts to muddle through the horrific 108 degree heat in
Paris, where a/c is in scarce supply. It sounded nightmarish, yet his descriptions were so
full of grim humor and brimming with insightful contrasts regarding how French and
Americans deal with extreme heat that I felt I was reading a _New Yorker_ vignette. To
wit: "As I regaled in the last, cool, comforting waffs of air conditioning--an all too precious
commodity in this town, as you know--a friend (or rather, a fellow Etoile gazer) began
complaining that the A/C wasn't strong enough. Luckily, I caught myself before snapping,
"You just don't know how good you have it, do you?!!" Instead, I just smiled as I headed
out" [Laugh #2]. Then, a friend who stopped by recounted how a friend of hers lost her
hair from chemo and opted for a Willie Nelson wig (think two long blond 'man-braids'
running down one's back). [Chuckle #3].
But there was more reason to take heart, at least for today. My bloodcounts came back
"fab," according to nurse Kayla, with the white blood counts significantly boosted since
just before chemo. This means that the Neulasta worked well. Hemoglobin, kidney
function all good. As a 'reward' (but I'll take it), I'll get the full dose of chemo at the next
round (on 8/8), instead of the lower dose I received this last time because of the lowered
white blood count. There was no new news on the ovarian cancer marker (CA125) post-
chemo, a marker that Kayla and Dr. Patel both encourage me not to fixate on. I also
learned that I will likely have a scan (CT or PET) between rounds three and four, which I
wasn't anticipating. There again, I was encouraged to focus on the positive (ie "this
treatment generally yields a good result") rather than all the 'what ifs?' scenarios. I really
think I'm getting better at living in the present moment, a self-protective measure to be
sure.
After two cheering visits from food-bearing friends, my mother and I headed out again,
to see "The Hair Lady," aka Katherine Fagan
(https://www.mmhairfashions.com/index.html),
a lovely woman who provides a valued service to women struggling with hair loss for
varied reasons (and others who simply wish to purchase hairpieces). I initially thought I'd
only consider a human hair wig (if I do purchase a wig, which I likely will), largely based
on my outdated image of synthetic hair wigs as very unnatural looking. I noticed
                        
immediately, though, that the synthetics are very far from wigs of our foremothers'
generations. They are lightweight, comfortable, and look great! With Katherine's help, I
had so much fun trying them on and seeing what I'd look like in different hair shades
(like playing dress up), that I almost forgot the reason I was there. �� Again, living in the
moment may be key: "There's only us/There's only this/Forget regret/Or life is yours to
miss/No other road/No other way/No day but today."
Should you care to, please let me know which style(s) you prefer (but no obligation!).

I still puzzle about whether I should be complying with tacit expectations that I be a
'cancer victim' - a colleague I have not been in touch with since late April wondered how
she might "brighten my day" -- when, on weekends such as this for example and perhaps
somewhat in proportion to the reality of my health challenges, my heart is brimming with
gratitude and hopefulness.
Ben is my best medicine. His visits feel healing. Why? Because we talk, laugh, share,
enjoy activities together, and simply feel the comfort and ease of being around each
other. He has shown himself to be incredibly compassionate and courageous, when
avoidance or paralysis by anxiety might have been more understandable reactions. He is
ok with meeting me where I am right now. I just hope I can still be the mother he's used
to having. Alright, Ben, I'll stop embarrassing you now! :)
Every time Ben visits, my cooking mojo seems to return, which I equate with creativity
and energy directed towards one of my favorite activities. For dinner last night, I made a
trio of summer salads, drawing on the late July bounty of central PA: an Ethiopian potato
and beet salad I first sampled at a restaurant in DC (onions and jalapenos, in a lemony
dressing); a tomato, mozza and basil salad, with a balsamic glaze I made (the Trader
Joe's brand contains too many preservatives); and an heirloom cherry tomato salad with
homemade pesto. Add some crusty baguette, a runny slice of Brie, and voilà.
As mentioned in another post, my Zen space of late is to be found along any of our many
local creeks. Ben and I enjoyed Spring Creek, a prime destination for fly fisherpeople, at
two different points - Spring Creek Park and Fisherman's Paradise. The creek gurgles, the
sun dapples the water, hummingbirds dance, dense foliage sways, and anglers cast their
fly lines, forming arabesques. Dangling my feet in the chilly creek was divine. It all felt so
peaceful, and made me think about a line in one of our prayers at services recently --
something about keeping "hope in our hearts and eternity in our thoughts." To me,
'eternity' does not connote, for example, heaven or hell - which I don't believe in - but
rather some sort of immanence or transcendence.
The peaceful scene also conjured, somehow, these lines from William Blake:
"To see a World in a Grain of Sand/ And a Heaven in a Wild Flower/Hold Infinity in the
palm of your hand/And Eternity in an hour [...] Man was made for Joy and Woe/And when
this we rightly know/Through the world we safely go."

text:
My hair started falling out last night, right before I went to bed. It was certainly
disconcerting, an OMG moment, and just felt *wrong* - like I should have been able to
figure out how to stick the hair back in or 'fix it' some other way. I lost no time this
morning ordering a wig. I settled on the short red one, but may order it in a shade closer
to my natural color; if I buy a second one, I may well go bolder, but maybe not as bold as
the pink 'L'il Kim' wig Samantha sported on _Sex and the City._ And I guess I'll have to
YouTube scarf folding techniques, as I can't seem to figure out how to to turn them into
anything I'd feel comfortable having wrapped around my head.
Thanks to my friend Aileen, I have now made contact with a group of about five *local*
ovarian cancer survivors (including one currently undergoing treatment). They call
themselves the "III Cs," after the stage at which all of them were diagnosed. I was also
diagnosed at this stage, apparently a common stage for ovarian cancer, which can be
largely asymptomatic (as was my case) and is therefore often diagnosed late. As I
understand it, three of these women are at least twelve-year survivors; I've also come to
understand that in many cases ovarian cancer can be a chronic disease that people live
with -- and live *well* with -- for a normal life span. There has been tremendous progress
in the treatments. In any event, I can't wait to meet these women!
The President's incendiary tweets about Baltimore struck a nerve with me, as over the
past three months I've become very fond of this city. A shout out here as well to my
Eagle cousins, college friend David Miranda and his partner, Peter, and other
Baltimoreans I know and love. True, the urban blight one encounters driving through
Baltimore can be shocking, even scary. It always strikes me as a sad cry for help in a
vibrant city of such historic import, world-class institutions, and great potential. The
good, dignified men and women of Baltimore changed my sheets every morning for
three weeks in the hospital; greeted me kindly on several stays at the Residence Inn,
many of whose customers are patients being treated at Hopkins; Ubered me to and from
the medical center, wishing me a blessed day on arrival; poured me lemonade when I
was thirsty; and continue to provide me with life-giving medical care of the highest
quality. So stay strong, Charm City! I'm coming for you in late August, and will be sure to
                       106 / 1.901
express my gratitude then.

text:
No news is good news, as far as I'm concerned (it's a different story for the woes
continuing to befall our country, of course...). Just a normal, pleasant summer weekend,
albeit a bit less active one (especially in the evenings) than I'd be used to in my life 'b.c.'
On Thursday my friend Gay and I strolled the arboretum, then returned to Gay's house to
have lunch on her deck overlooking a lovely lily pond stocked with koi fish. That night I
watched a new Netflix film,"Otherhood," about three moms (played by Angela Bassett,
Patricia Arquette and Felicity Huffman), who, miffed that their twenty-something sons
have forgotten to send them Mother's Day cards, decide to show up unannounced at
their apartments in NYC (havoc followed by self-discovery and bonding ensues). There
were some chuckles, and a few tears at the end (for example, when a son writes his
mother a list of things he knows about her -- eg "You love irises" -- having failed at this
task on demand from his mother a few weeks earlier). It was good fluff for a Friday night
but mainly pretty "meh." Saturday morning, my friend Helen and I checked out the
farmers market in all its August glory; I was tempted by corn, cherry tomatoes, fennel,
cantaloupe, and eggplant. We then had lunch at Wegmans Cafe and finished our grocery
shopping. Today I browsed/shopped at Tait Farm and Pier 1 Imports, where I saw a
dresser that would look great in my bedroom, if I only I can figure out how to get it
home. Funny how, given the question marks around my health, I'm feeling nesting
instincts. Have all kinds of ideas for redoing certain rooms and areas of my home that
could use some sprucing (although I still love my condo!). Did some walking, reading,
writing, finished editing and compiling the blog (86 pages!) that my students and I wrote
about our Holocaust-focused trip to Paris in March. And my longtime house cleaner, Liz,
just dropped off, unexpectedly, a scrumptious looking eggplant parmigiana that her
husband, Phil, a talented home cook (esp. of Italian classics), wanted to make for me.
While I continue to be really sad about missing several milestone events in the lives of
friends this summer - three out of town or country weddings to be precise, which I
couldn't/can't attend due to the timetable my treatment and recovery -- I am so grateful
for these simple yet meaningful pleasures and acts of kindness closer to home.
                       113 / 1.901
I am returning to my therapist tomorrow after a three-month hiatus. I have spoken to her
twice by phone (once when I was in the hospital, once when I was at home recovering
from surgery). I look forward to seeing her, but there's been such a "paradigm shift" in
my life that we'll need to figure out how to best proceed.
Have a good week, everyone.  
  
August 7, 2019 - I Am...Emma Fierce

First stop: back to the "Hair Lady" aka Katherine Fagan to pick up my wig, which I love.
I'm not averse to wearing scarves and turbans, but my hair's tied up with my femininity
somehow, so it's part of my identity. It's a bit tricky to care for it but I'm sure that before
long I'll get the knack of shampooing, conditioning, brushing, and transporting it with
some products made for that purpose. The wig's name is "Emma," so perhaps Emma is
my new alter ego. I'll go one step further and announce, with a hat tip to "I am...Sasha
Fierce," Beyoncé's third solo album presenting her own alter ego: I am....Emma Fierce.
Second stop: Lunch with some pretty fierce ladies, two of the "III Cs." Helen and Deb are
OC survivors (over ten years in both cases, although at different places in terms of
ongoing treatment). They were both very open in sharing their stories, generous with
helpful practical information (I went right to the supermarket afterwards and procured
ginger tea and oranges), reassuring, and understanding. They get it. Most importantly,
they are vibrant, living their lives to the fullest each day. So maybe a corollary to
Groucho Marx's "I wouldn't want to be part of any club that I was a member of" is "I am
happy to be a member of this club, even though it's a club most people wouldn't choose
to be part of." I look forward to seeing these women again, and hopefully to meeting the
other two "III Cs." Now we are five. A sorority! Ht also to my friend Aileen, who was the
initial facilitator of the group, and who connected me to it.
Third stop: a picnic with another group of resilient, lively women, all breast cancer
survivors, to which my friend, neighbor and fellow JCC congregant Carol invited me, even
though I do not have breast cancer. The message I got from all my convos with survivors
today: no day but today. Also: while being on the narrow bridge can be very scary, once
you're on it and the precarious situation has been normalized -- as I found today from the
completely matter-of-fact exchanges -- it can really become much less scary. It's often
more frightening for those looking on from the outside.
Second round of chemo tomorrow. Kind friends are driving me to and from, and I hope to
have at least two visitors, to break up the monotony of the long, boring day spent
hooked up to the drip. I've packed up my dragonfly bag with some snacks, face and hand
creams, books, iPad, coloring book (yes!), music etc. And I'll pull on my supersoft pink
Penn State hoodie, some yoga pants, and one of my cute new caps that arrived today,
and hunker down for six or seven hours. Hopefully the effects won't be too much worse
than last time.

Everything went well with my second round of chemo today. My blood work all came in
at normal/good levels and I was therefore able to receive all the meds (Benadryl, an anti-
nausea med, and some other med, then the chemo meds, Carboplatin and Taxol). Total
drip time: about five hours. I then had the Neulasta patch affixed to my arm, which will
boost my white blood cell production, but which can cause bone pain (I will take some
Claritin to help counteract this reaction). So far so good - I just feel tired as I took
Compazine, an anti-nausea med that can cause drowsiness. There will certainly be a few
bad days ahead, but hopefully not much worse than last time, and I did rebound pretty
quickly.
I had a minor freak out when Dr. Patel would not tell me my CA125 (ie ovarian cancer
marker) number when I inquired. I presume that it's still high (then again I did not
receive the full dose of the chemo meds last time), but I think his point is for me not to
fixate on this number - which is only part of the story - nor on prognosis. He wants me to
focus on this needed treatment and to stay strong and positive (which I am doing). I
honestly think that, in the end, this is the best strategy for me, as even on my best days
I tend to be a worrier. He said he'd tell me the marker number after the next treatment.
He also helped me better understand how the chemo works, and how sneaky cancer
cells can fight against the treatment in various crafty ways. This is why chemo does not
necessarily provide 'immunity' during the treatment period, although it certainly, and in
the majority of cases, can be very effective. Let's hope so.
Believe it or not, the ranting Trump supporter who during my last session was warning
that he was "this close" to putting a Rebel flag in his pickup was back today!! He walked
in with his wife when I had already been seated for a while (I had preemptively chosen
the treatment bay on the side of the room opposite the one where I had been seated last
time). When he entered the chemo room and was looking for an empty recliner, he
loudly announced to no one in particular: "Last time a lady asked to be moved across the
room because of me!" I waved to him wanly, and said, semi-jokingly: "Please no political
rants today,!" and then wished him good health. His wife then came over to sort of
'make nice' with me. I took the high road and again wished her husband good health.
Nary a rant to be heard from him, just lots of talk about 'hauling' (this is the operative
verb in these parts) the Amish in his truck to their various construction jobs and buying
peaches in bulk at the local produce market. Cancer's an adventure, let me tell ya.
Today's monotony was broken up by two lovely visitors: first Rhonda, my 'mentor' in the
Woman to Woman program at Hopkins who happens to live about 25 miles from me in
Lewistown, and who is often in State College. I knew from speaking with her on the
phone that we had a great rapport, and this was confirmed today (picture attached). She
is very kind, upbeat, encouraging, and knowledgeable. Her visit really uplifted me. I am
understanding that these kinds of connections will be crucial to my recovery. Then my
                       122 / 1.901
friend Maria came by bearing a coffee milkshake for me from Meyer Dairy. We had fun
chatting as always, and then she deposited me at home (my kind neighbors Pat and
Dennis drove me to my appointment early this morning).
Onward.

I've spent the past two days in a stupor. My reaction to the second round of chemo is
similar to the my reaction to the first. On the day I receive chemo and the following day,
I feel fine (had sushi lunch with my friend Clare; entertained a doctoral student receiving
his degree at commencement this weekend, with his family in tow). But by Saturday the
Mack truck has rolled back into town, flattening me in its wake. I can barely get out of
bed, and feel weak and achy in my legs, neck etc. Think bad flu symptoms. Minimal
nausea, though, and I even refrained from taking an anti-nausea med because it makes
me very groggy. Somehow I managed to get to the farmers market yesterday morning to
pick up some zucchini to make a frittata for dinner -- despite my taste buds being all out
of whack. Today I was able to sit outside for a while and send some texts and read for
just a bit. The rest of the time I was horizontal. If things proceed like last time, I hope to
feel somewhat better tomorrow, although I'm told that the effects of the chemo can be
cumulative.  The weather is gorgeous -- slightly cooler, mellow sunshine, with just a whiff
of 'back to school' in the air (I will not be heading back to school, though, as I'll be on
medical leave in the fall). It would have been a perfect day for a hike or long walk, for
going to a greenhouse and puttering around my mini-garden, or hanging out in a park
with a friend. Or even doing some work! That makes me feel sad/mad/depressed. But I
                       124 / 1.901
need to simply roll with this... 
My 'life preserver' this weekend, aside from my own resilience, has come in the form of
many caring texts, emails (including from France!), and phone calls from friends, family
and neighbors. My friend Sandy came over with both some scarves for me to try out as
well as some delicious Middle Eastern rice pudding with cardamon, honey, vanilla, and
pistachios that hits the spot in terms of taste and texture. So many people have been so
kind, and it gives me such motivation to pay it forward...
Hope to have a better report before long. Love, Willa
