text:
"Was it doubted that those who corrupt their own 
  bodies conceal themselves?
And if those who defile the living are as bad as 
                       125 / 1.901
  they who defile the dead?
And if the body does do fully as much as the
  soul?
And if the body were not the soul, what is the 
  soul?" 
The human body is amazing. The human body urges to heal. The thirteen-hour process
of 'debulking' my body in May in an effort to rid if of all visible cancer was at the same
time turning my body into a lean, mean, cancer-fighting machine. I had multiple organs
removed and could barely get out of bed the first weeks in the hospital, but I have
relatively little residual abdominal pain now. The pesky abscess in my stomach that
delayed my chemo for several weeks was neatly cordoned off, as if willing itself not to
spread further (I'll find out if it's completely resolved when I go to Hopkins next week).
And if two days ago I was in a stupor, with aches radiating through my legs (still feeling a
bit 'neuropathic' in my feet...), today I am definitely on the rebound! There will be crappy
days, and there will be better days, without doubt. And just because the body
instinctively reaches for healing, of course, doesn't mean it will heal, especially in the
face of disease. But the instinct is there, and that is reason for hope.
So I wonder with my favorite American poet, Walt Whitman, writing in 1855 in _Leaves of
Grass,_ whether the body, rather than corrupting the soul, "were not the soul" itself. It
certainly seems as pure and divine and miraculous sometimes.
I don't know why I scheduled a (routine) 7h15 dermatological checkup but I made it
there just fine. Everything looks good, and the dr. says there is nothing to suggest that
I'm at any greater risk for skin cancer than I was before. It was so early (at least for me -
not an early riser...) when my appointment ended that I went to a nearby coffee shop for
a cappuccino and a muffin. Then I got to some emails that had accumulated while I was
wiped out the previous days, and a bit of reading. I took a drive to Pier 1 Imports, where
I'm very tempted by a dresser on sale, and on an impulse bought some fun Eiffel Tower
LED 'gimmer' lights for my little back patio. I'm thinking tapas party. Yes, a hopeful sign!
Tomorrow morning going to my stylist to be officially 'shorn' as my hair is sort of
clumped onto my head at this point. Will also get the bangs on my wig trimmed.

My longtime hair stylist and friend, Sarah, showed me such compassionate care
yesterday, cutting most of my remaining hair off and trimming my wig so that, in the
end, it approximates my usual hairstyle (so much for looking like a blond bombshell or a
silver fox...). To top it off, she gifted me with my choice of a Disney Princess brush --
quite a hoot, but it turns out these are the brushes with the best bristles for brushing my
wig! I chose Snow White (I don't even know who Princess Jasmine is...). Like Snow White,
maybe I'll wake up from a long slumber and realize this was all just a (bad) dream.
Maybe there'll even be a Prince Charming awaiting. And some dwarfs. Who knew a brush
could be so beneficial?
Today I received a lovely gift box full of goodies my brother and his family picked out for
me during their recent trip to Israel and Jordan. Most significant to me is the scarlet
string bracelet that my family had blessed at the Kotel in Jerusalem. Kabbalistic beliefs
and Jewish folk customs hold that a scarlet string knotted seven times and worn on the
left wrist (ie the receiving side of the spiritual body) can ward off misfortune caused by
the evil eye. Red string bracelets exist in other folk cultures too. So now the bracelet is
tied firmly on my wrist, next to a thin chain with a hamsa. In Hebrew, hamsa means 'five'
and images of open hands containing a turquoise or aqua-colored eye are prevalent
throughout the Middle East -- again as a protection against the evil eye. So between
these two bracelets and a hamsa pendant (plus several other hamsas and similar
amulets scattered throughout my home), I think I am pretty well 'covered.' Somehow the
image of the Crusaders, who literally covered themselves and their horses and weapons
with crosses (croix, cruces etc.) as protection came to mind. Am I a religious zealot?
Heck, no. But I'll gladly be a zealot against cancer!
I registered for, and am seriously thinking of attending, a conference organized by
Hopkins on Sept. 14 (at a hotel in the Inner Harbor) on "Gynecological Cancer
Survivorship." It draws together medical professionals (including all those on my care
team), survivors, care givers and others. There will be talks about the latest research
and treatments, Ted talks, a panel featuring five survivors, and breakout panels on some
cool topics. The three I signed up for are on "Spirituality and Cancer," "Nutrition and Diet
after Cancer," and "Writing through Cancer" (!!). As always, I'll need to figure out
logistics and whether or not I might have a friend or relative attend with me (which

text:
This time of year, I (and doubtless others), as if on cue, begin having anxiety dreams
about school. In my latest one, I am taking a very difficult history test for which I'm
woefully unprepared (lots of other 'busy-ness' had interfered with my plan to reread the
course textbook cover to cover). The test consisted, in part, of twelve short
essays/analyses (with a word limit) based on images. The one image that I knew I could
write of ton about what that of Vercingetorix, the Gallic chief who resisted valiantly yet
ultimately unsuccessfully against the invading Romans (a metaphor for fighting the
                       132 / 1.901
'invading' cancer cells??). I planned to write about V. as a shape-shifting signifier,
portrayed as either a 'national' hero by Plutarch or a brave yet undisciplined barbarian
by Caesar. Another image featured a woman's hands reaching into a case where pies
were displayed (like in a diner), which I thought I could link to post-World War II
American middle-class consumer culture! In any event, I was making check marks by the
images I thought I might write about (and struggling to identify twelve), when Lynn Hunt,
a very prominent American historian of France, leaned over to me and said: "There really
are a lot of good choices this year, aren't there? It's a good exam." Yikes. A second part
of the exam was a long, DBQ (document-based question), involving synthesizing and
analyzing a lot of information and documents about...coal. The third part consisted of
many short identifications of extremely specific names, places, and works, most of which
I hadn't a clue about. I thought I recognized a section of quotation by Victor Hugo, about
the plight of the urban poor during mid-19th century industrialization, but I couldn't
remember the title nor the date, and knew that I'd need to fudge it. Good grief.
While I have had variants of this dream many times (yet few as vivid), this year I really
*am* unprepared. Normally at this time, I'd be writing syllabi, setting up reserve reading
lists, arranging visits to the Rare Book Room and Palmer Museum of Art, meeting with
students, preparing for our new graduate student orientation, and getting caught up in
the adrenaline rush of back to school. But I won't be doing any of that because I'm on
medical leave until January. So naturally I feel woefully 'out of sync,' 'off course,' my
natural instincts foiled or rerouted. It's depressing, and I am working on coming to peace
with my 'new normal' once school begins. I'm also figuring out how to structure my time
meaningfully and thinking about what kind of work (ie writing/research) I may be able to
accomplish. And of course I need to keep in mind the bottom line - ie my treatment and
recovery - which will allow me to get back to all the rest as soon as possible. And
focusing on my health requires a lot of time and energy.
Getting ready to go to Baltimore tomorrow (I'll return on Wednesday). I'll have a CT scan
to determine whether my stomach abscess has completely healed. If so, I may be able to
stop taking both the two antibiotics that have been shredding my stomach for at least a
month and the anti-fungal medicine that it takes me over an hour to administer to
myself daily. I am crossing my fingers here. I'll also get to meet briefly with Dr. Beavis,
my surgeon who is overseeing my care, and Dr. Mehta, who is treating the stomach
abscess. In much better news, Ben will come from DC so we can have dinner together on
Tuesday and he'll also spend the night at the Residence Inn before heading back to work
on Wednesday morning. I'm scouting around for restaurant recommendations and am
thinking red-sauce Italian in Little Italy, as long as the food is good!
Last night with my friend Helen I saw the film "The Farewell," about the matriarch of a
Chinese family who is diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer. The family agrees to hide this
news from her, and everyone is "all in" except her Chinese-American granddaughter,
who lives in New York. It's a quirky film, and I haven't yet decided if I liked it (although
                       133 / 1.901
I'm definitely glad I saw it). It seemed to not be able to make up its mind about whether
it was a comedy or a drama. The decision to not tell the grandmother that she was dying
was presented as culturally determined (is that really the case?), and the entire family
seemed to trade in many forms of keeping up appearances, 'good lies,' and denial. I
definitely don't think I'd want to be kept in the dark about a terminal cancer diagnosis
though (one character in the film points out that in the States this might be illegal...), as
traumatizing as that might be.
Have a good week, everyone.

text:
I am rejoicing in two pieces of good news today, both related to the CT scan I had
yesterday at Hopkins. First the scan revealed, for the time being, no evidence of new
cancer. Among other things, this means that I can 'stay the course' with my treatment,
again for now, as opposed to the doctors having to think about new chemo drugs if the
current ones were proving ineffective. Second, the scan indicates that my stomach
                       135 / 1.901
abscess has healed! This means far less risk of an infection compromising my potentially
fragile immune system, with consequences for my chemo regimen. It also means that I
can stop taking the two antibiotics and one anti-fungal medication that I've been
diligently taking for about two months and that are wreaking havoc on my stomach! And
so, for now, goodbye to the iv pole that's been my companion every day for over an hour
as I administer the micafungin.
So all in all, a good visit to Hopkins. I was clearly anxious ("scanxious"), as my back
started to spasm every time I started thinking about receiving the scan results. I am very
glad that I was able to speak with Dr. Beavis, who is overseeing my care and who
performed my debulking surgery. We resolved some practical issues, such as whether I
can delay until December my yearly mammogram for fear it might irritate my port
(answer: yes) and the timetable for our next appointments. She also helped me
understand much more clearly the 'fluidity' of the notion of prognosis. She's been over
the aggregate data with me several times, ie 80% of women with ovarian cancer go into
remission after standard chemotherapy treatment. On the flip side, most ovarian cancer
patients will have a recurrence at some point following initial treatment. The averages
for patients treated at Hopkins appear to be more favorable (not unsurprisingly) - these
are averages. But then there is also each patient's individualized path, including whether
or not certain 'milestones' are met (ie patients whose cancer recurs during treatment v.
those whose cancer does not; patients who mark x months/years without a recurrence,
with each increment being significant). Down the road options with recurrences (likely in
the abdominal area again) would include more surgery and/or chemo. Sooo... while I
realize that I am still very much 'on the journey,' and while there will certainly be many
more scans upcoming, I was still happy for today's news. Every bit of good news counts.
Better than the alternative, certainly.
After a very good talk with Dr. Beavis, I had my CT scan. I was glad to have a highly
experienced technician I like (I think his name is Bill), who administers the contrast dye
slowly so that I don't feel the sudden freezing cold "whoosh" of the injection, which
immediately fills the mouth with a salty, metallic taste. The two times Bill was not my
technician, I got sick to my stomach after the scan. Bill also knew to position my arms by
my sides (rather than over my head), which also helped. And he's a PSU wrestling fan
too!
I don't know what possessed me to walk about half an hour back from the hospital to the
hotel in 95 degree heat, but somehow I managed to do it, slipping into the air
conditioning of a Starbucks for an iced cappuccino along the way.
Today's meeting was with Dr. Mehta, the infectious diseases specialist, who gave me the
good news about the scan.
Last night Ben took the commuter train from DC to Baltimore so we could have dinner
                       136 / 1.901
and he could stay in the hotel with me overnight. We had a great time. We opted for
classic Italian in Little Italy and chose a restaurant called La Scala, which did not
disappoint in the least! We split a Caesar salad (grade: A, and I'm a hard one to please),
with a tangy homemade dressing infused with lemon, anchovies and high grade
Parmesan, and ultra-crisp Romaine. I opted for spaghetti (more like bucatini) carbonara,
as my taste buds are tending to favor creamy (yogurt, ice cream, avocados, cream) and
sweet over dry and savory (eg a hamburger) these days. Although my taste is clearly a
bit off, I could tell it was delicious, and I ate most of it. Ben had shrimp Fra Diavolo, which
he loved. After dinner we walked to Vaccaro's, a legendary Little Italy bakery, and picked
up some cannoli and cookies, which we indulged in while watching two episodes of a
new (?) cooking/travel show with Gordon Ramsay. Ramsay is no Anthony Bourdain (but
who could ever be?); nevertheless, Ben and I enjoyed watching him cook with unusual
ingredients (camel, anyone?) while travelling around with the 'locals' in Morocco and
Hawaii.
My efforts to try to make amends for our President by telling Baltimoreans how much I
appreciate their city met with (very) mixed success. The first person to whom I
proclaimed "I love Baltimore!," the front desk manager at the hotel, simply smiled and
said "thank you." The second, a maintenance worker at the hotel, said in response: "I
hate Baltimore. I can't wait to get back to California, where I'm from." The third person, a
clerk registering me for my CT scan at Hopkins, gushed enthusiastically about Baltimore,
his home town, and the fourth, an Uber driver, simply responded "Crickets" (ie no
response/enough said). Ben wisely encouraged me, despite my well-meaning instincts,
not to try to 'save' Baltimoreans single-handedly. As I can attest, they're doing just fine,
thank you very much.
On my return from Baltimore just a while ago, I found a gorgeous bouquet from my
friend Cheryl (to whom I will write to thank shortly). What a kind gesture, and what a
lovely gift to come home to after a whirlwind trip!

text:
I spent part of yesterday at the hospital in Lewistown (about 25 miles from here), to
meet with a genetic counselor, Tara Schmidlen, and then have the actual testing done. I
was annoyed that the counselor did not seem to know if I even needed this 'germline'
testing (as opposed to the tumor testing done following my surgery) because she could
not access all the pertinent records from Hopkins. I imagine that this frustrating situation
arises when several doctors in several facilities are involved in the care of one patient,
but still... When I was having the bloodwork done, however, Tara came racing down to
the lab to let me know that she had spoken to Dr. Beavis' nurse and I did, indeed, still
need to have the germline testing done. So the confusion was resolved in the end.
Testing on this panel of 20 genes (and ultimately as many as 84 genes, should I choose)
will help my doctors determine which drugs will be the most effective for my post-chemo
maintenance treatment. Further, the testing may even impact my current chemo
regimen. Given that my mother is BRCA negative (ie her BReast CAncer does not appear
to have been inherited but the result of a genetic mutation), chances are that my
ovarian cancer also resulted from a random genetic mutation as well... which is why I
sometimes say not "Why me?" but rather "Why not me?" Cancer seems such a Russian
roulette sometimes.
I rewarded myself for that trip over the mountains to Lewistown with a mint flake ice
cream cone (ice cream being one of the staples of my diet now, it would seem). And I
had to rest when I got home. A fifty mile round-trip drive would not normally tire me out,
but I do tire more easily than usual these days. I rebounded sufficiently to make it to
services, where the phrase "steadfast spirit" stuck with me from the evening's readings.
This morning a nurse came over to deaccess my port as I am no longer administering the
micafungin daily through it. So for now no more large, unsightly patch covering my port
but a simple bandaid. After that, I shopped at Trader Joe's and the farmers market,
where I ran into a Jewish Studies colleague who didn't know I had been diagnosed with
cancer (holding his understandably troubled reaction caused me some stress). Then
                       139 / 1.901
home to prepare a few things for a lovely lunch with a colleague, Cheryl, who had also
shown concern when she learned about my health challenge and was kind enough to
visit. Again after that sequence of events, I needed to rest a bit but am supposed to go
out for dinner and music later with my friends Mar and Jessica.
I went to school last week for the first time since May, when I left my office in a panicked
flurry after receiving my initial diagnosis by phone. I received a very warm welcome from
staff, a colleague or two (although none of my own departmental colleagues were
around), and a grad student. Big hugs all around. My plan is to stay connected by
attending defenses, book parties, lectures and other events on campus, as my health
allows. Fading away completely this semester will be too depressing, and it might even
be helpful for my colleagues to see me too.
Looking forward to a few nice lunches this week, including with the remaining two "III
Cs," Jan and Jackie, whom I didn't meet the first time when I had lunch with Helen and
Deb. So grateful for the nearby presence of these 'sisters,' all long-term OC survivors,
and eager to speak with them. Next round of chemo: this coming Thursday.
label: anger

text:
141 / 1.901
                       142 / 1.901
Today brought lunch with the remaining two "III Cs" (local ovarian cancer survivors thus
self-named because of the stage at which they were diagnosed). Like Helen and Deb
whom I met over lunch a few weeks ago, Jackie and Jan (see pic) were both very kind,
generous in sharing their experiences, affirming, and encouraging. Both are long-term
survivors, full of pep, who lead extremely active lives (Jackie, originally from Scotland,
takes yoga, Zumba, cycling and strength training classes at the Y while Jan walks daily
and winters in Florida). Both had recurrences of their ovarian cancer -- which will be the
likelihood for me as well -- which meant more chemo, but both got through it. And at
least one of them also had breast cancer following ovarian cancer. Both appear to be
fully in remission now, and for quite a number of years. They both seem to be living their
best lives, embracing and practicing the 'no day but today' message.
I was especially grateful to have lunch with them today as it's the first day of the new
school year and I feel a bit sad and depressed that I'm not part of it. The lunch helped, as
did a visit from my friend and colleague, Nancy. I look forward to two more lunches with
friends before chemo on Thursday. I'm sure once I get into a new rhythm with some
structure-providing activities (I'm looking into a new gym), I'll feel better. And I definitely
think I made the right decision taking a medical leave this semester, giving myself ample
time/space to devote to my treatment and recovery. It's hard for me to imagine how I
would have handled the rigors of my job with my ongoing chemo treatments,
procedures, medical appointments, fatigue etc.
I asked Jackie and Jan what it felt like to be 'on the other side' of their cancer journey.
Jackie said that she now views the active treatment phase as "another life," firmly in the
past. Both of them seemed to me clearly anchored in the "new normal," or the "new old
normal," slipping easily from accounts of their diagnosis and treatment into more
present concerns and pastimes: gardening, travel, grandchildren. A friend suggested --
and this hadn't really occurred to me -- that I may be, ironically, in a sort of "love" stage
of my journey, marked by both an outpouring of love from those around me that feels
like a healing balm and my own narcissistic love of -- or perhaps rather obsession with --
my own disease, which feels all-consuming. I can't even imagine what it will feel like to
be on the other side of this. I suppose -- and I hope -- that I'll find out.
label: sadness

text:
144 / 1.901
                       145 / 1.901
Three down, three to go. Unless anything goes amiss, of course. This could include
notably high/low numbers on the lab work I have done right before treatment;
indications that the treatment is ineffective; a bad cold or infection (such as the recently-
healed abscess in my stomach). There is so much uncertainty on this journey, and it's
hard to sit with that, although I am trying extra hard to take good care of myself with a
healthy diet, lots of sleep, avoidance of big crowds and of kissing/hugging anyone with a
cold etc. Common sense measures.
But today things went smoothly, although I was not pleased to wake up at 6:15 a.m for a
7:15 appointment, to which my kind neighbor Janis drove me. My lab report looked good
overall (I'm especially encouraged by good white blood cell counts), so I was able to
proceed to my full treatment (benadryl, an anti-allergy med, an anti-nausea med, then
the chemo meds, Carboplatin and Taxol). The seven+ hours went pretty quickly between
some time to rest, read and send texts and heartening visits from friends. In the
morning, my dear friend Gay came to chat for a while. I also got a quick hug from
Rhonda, my wonderful mentor/friend/angel/fellow survivor from the Hopkins
Woman2Woman support organization for OC survivors and those beginning or going
through treatment (see pic). In the afternoon, my lovely friend Helen came to visit,
bearing a vanilla milkshake from Meyer Dairy. Actually, I was not really supposed to eat
this as my glucose level is high (a result of taking ten steroid pills last night and this
morning). But when the nurse said "everything in moderation" (partially overriding what
my doctor had said), I couldn't resist the soothing, creamy, sugary deliciousness of the
milkshake. Mea culpa. So much for healthy diet thus far today but I'll compensate at
dinnertime with some broth-based carrot soup and an avocado.
The rabid Trumpian was not there today. As a precaution, like last time I selected a
treatment bay that is set apart from all the others. Also, all the nurses are extremely
capable, solicitous and caring, which helps reduce anxiety around the treatment.
After I had finished, Helen and I made a quick pit stop at the Amish produce stand on the
way back to my house, where I bought some beets, zucchini and eggplant to buttress
other healthy/healthier food choices. By the time I got home I was tired and needed to
rest for a while.
Heartfelt thanks to friends and family members who sent notes and texts of
encouragement and left a goodie bag for me on my return from chemo (!). In no way
whatsoever did I expect this, but I very much appreciate these caring acts. Thanks to
everyone indulging me by reading my journal, which is proving quite therapeutic for me.
Lunches with my dear friends Kathryn (Tuesday) and Clare and Lisa (Wednesday) and a
visit and dessert exchange (plum clafoutis for peach compote) with Chris were also lots
of fun!
                       146 / 1.901
I did, in the end, buy the dresser at Pier1 that I thought would be perfect for my bedroom
and much more proportional than my previous dresser. It also matches two little end
tables in my bedroom also purchased at Pier1 a few years ago. So, living by the mantra
of "life is short; buy the dresser," I enlisted the help of "Team Truglio/Fox" (my dear
friend Maria, fiance Greg and son Anthony) to move this *large and heavy* dresser in a
truck I rented for this purpose (the store would not deliver). Their combination of muscle
power and logistical savvy allowed them to pull off this feat without a hitch. And I'm
loving my dresser! Planning a few other upgrades to my condo this fall as well.
Can't wait to see Ben and Sammi this Sunday-Monday as they are coming up for the long
weekend. I will most likely be crashed out from chemo (if I follow the pattern of days 3-4
post-chemo being the worst), but I've already cooked and frozen some cream of tomato
soup and will make a few more dishes ahead of time. I know that they will be
understanding and helpful and it will be great to spend time with them. 
Photos

text:
As if on cue, I started to crash yesterday morning and spent nearly all day in bed, mainly
sleeping (my friend Maria kindly brought me some dinner). I felt well enough on
Thursday evening and all Friday, and made it to services on Friday night. But yesterday I
was hit with crushing fatigue, accompanied by tingling in my fingers, aches in my neck,
arms and legs, and an upset stomach. I took some anti-nausea meds but don't feel that
nauseous. All in all, I think the symptoms may be worse this time than the two previous
                       149 / 1.901
ones. Today I got out of bed at around 9:30 and feel marginally better, but still quite
wiped out. I'm looking forward to seeing Ben and Sammi later and hopefully they'll be
able to help me a bit. I wish they didn't have to see me this way.
I'm trying to just roll with it - there's no choice - but the situation is depressing and
makes me really hate this disease. I would much rather have been out enjoying the nice
weather and festive atmosphere around town with our first home game taking place, or
else in Arizona at a conference I was supposed to attend with many of my former
students (who nicely sent pictures of what looked like a great gathering). These crashes
are a bit hard to manage without a 'caregiver' but I'm bearing up. And I'm
hoping/expecting to start feeling better tomorrow, if the usual pattern holds. Clawing
myself out of such a deep hole of fatigue seems daunting, but I trust in my capacity to
rebound and will allow myself as much space as I need to rest.
Thanks for the good thoughts, everyone.

text:
152 / 1.901
                       153 / 1.901
Some people seem to find me courageous, even inspiring. I'm sure to many that's the
more appealing version of my 'cancer self.' I certainly don't always feel courageous nor
can I or anyone else always expect me to be. Not when I was wincing in pain yesterday
because my lower GI track felt inflamed and throbbing (seems better today after a diet
of yogurt, a banana and some cheese but Dr. Patel says if symptoms get worse I should
go to ER for evaluation). And not when I read the many harrowing accounts of women
dealing with multiple recurrences on a Facebook page called Sisterhood of Ovarian
Cancer Survivors. It's been hard to gird on a shield of courage the past 3-4 days because
the effects of round 3 of chemo were so wretched, leaving me feeling not only exhausted
but also vulnerable and deflated. I realize that in my last post I may have been pulling
for some sympathy. Thank you for indulging me.
Ben and Sammi, visiting from DC, were extremely kind, understanding and helpful,
although I felt badly that I couldn't host them in the way I'm used to. I had done some
cooking before chemo, but they also cooked up some eggs for breakfast, washed all the
dishes and tidied up the kitchen. I had just enough energy on Sunday to take a drive
along a pretty country road to The Hummingbird Room, a local restaurant/caterer
situated in an old farmhouse in Spring Mills. The co-owner, Eric Sarnow (formerly of Le
Bec Fin, in Philly) is a fabulous chef and every so often he and his wife stock up a big red
barn behind the house with some of their specialty items for purchase. We bought some
delicious salmon roe mousse, to-die-for chocolate sauce for ice cream, and granola, and
snagged a bag of peaches for free on the way out, which later I cooked into compote. On
Monday, we enjoyed ice cream cones and sundaes at Meyer Dairy (perhaps no wonder a
stomach ache resulted?). The rest of the weekend was mellow -- I rested, Ben and
Sammi went to the game, grocery shopped at Trader Joe's, and went for a run. In the
evening we watched episodes of The Great British Baking Show. It was very comforting
having them here.
Today my stomach was hurting in the morning, so I stayed in bed late, annoyed at
myself that I couldn't get up earlier. I have to keep reminding myself that self-care has to
be my priority, whatever that takes. With that in mind, today I luxuriated in a hot stone
pedicure and spa manicure at a local day spa that Ben had treated me to for my bday in
March (thanks to a gift certificate). The technician spent over two hours indulging me in
paraffin treatments for my hands, rubbing my legs with hot stones (which really helped
my bone pain!) and my arms with bergamot-scented oil, and painting my nails a pretty
'orchid' color I had picked up in Paris and that I thought worked well for late summer. :)
When I came home I took a walk. I need to build up my strength after being so wiped out
for several days - and the weather's beautiful.
I'm really hoping to continue to feel better tomorrow.

text:
Because my lower GI upset/irritation/pain has persisted a few days, my Hopkins doctor
                       157 / 1.901
(Beavis) and my Geisinger/State College doctor (Patel) consulted today and ordered
abdominal and pelvic CTs for tomorrow afternoon. The unpleasant prep includes drinking
two bottles of a barium solution before my appointment at 2:30. Cause is unclear: effects
of chemo drugs? inflammation noted on a previous CT scan but that is in my small
intestine, not my lower GI track (that CT scan did not reveal evidence of a fistula or
adhesion to abdominal wall, which would be much more serious)? Infection?
Hemorrhoid? Continuing effects of the 'mother of all surgeries' that I had performed in
May? New cancer (Dr. Beavis noted that chances of this happening during chemo are
actually <5%)? So.much.uncertainty. Ditto for treatment options: at one end of the
spectrum, whatever the issue may be may resolve on its own. On the other: surgical
intervention might be needed (please, no). I understand that the scan is being ordered
out of an abundance of caution, to rule things out, and I am very grateful for how
thoroughly and well Drs. Beavis and Patel (and their nurses) are taking care of me. Yet I
can't help feeling anxious.
Fortuitously -- the advantages of living in a college town -- at the supermarket this
evening I ran into Jackie, one of my fellow 'IIICs' (local OC survivors). She promptly
validated my feelings of anxiousness, said that she had shared them when she was
receiving treatment, and noted that time (over the course of her treatment) had seemed
to help her anxiety abate. She urged me to "pick up the phone anytime" I needed to talk.
Grateful to have had this 'sister' placed in my path at Wegmans, shortly before I ran into,
on exiting the store, Art and Nancy, a lovely couple from my synagogue who own local
clothing stores and whom I've known nearly since I arrived in State College in 1988. They
had heard about my cancer diagnosis from our common hair stylist, Sarah (again, the
small town effect...), and provided warm hugs and encouragement.
September is Gynecologic Awareness Month. Learn more below. Dr. Wethington is one of
the superb doctors who treated me at Hopkins:
https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2018/09/28/md-doctor-speaks-about-gynecologic-cancer-
awareness-month/

text:
As I wrote in my last post, some stomach discomfort led my doctors to order an
abdominal and pelvic CT scan, which I had yesterday. That scan revealed, as I learned
today, a new abscess in my stomach. What I was not expecting was to be told by my
doctors that they were recommending a new hospital stay of 5-7 days so that I can
receive IV antibiotics (first, they will have to determine what type of infection it is) and
have the abscess drained. Obviously, I was pretty shocked by this news and dismayed by
the thought of another hospital stay. I was initially given the choice between staying in
the hospital here in State College, where I have a large support network, or going back to
Hopkins. In the end, though, it turns out that the local hospital does not have the kind of
specialized personnel that may be needed. So tomorrow it's back to Hopkins. I am very
much hoping that my next chemo infusion on 9/19 will not need to be delayed but that
remains to be seen. If the abscess does not resolve with antibiotics and drainage, a
surgical intervention is possible, in which the abscess would be removed surgically.
The situation sucks, but I'm soldiering on. There's no alternative. I do know that I'll be
getting the best possible care at Hopkins. Thanks, everyone, for keeping me in your
thoughts.
label: surprise

text:
Feeling very deflated when I wrote my last post two days ago, I thought ahead to titling
this one “Back to Black,” after a particularly grim song by Amy Winehouse. But since I
tend to be pretty resilient and am in a better place today, I’m calling it, simply, “At
Hopkins,” which reflects the reality of the situation.
                       161 / 1.901
I had what I’m describing to myself as some shade of PTSD-ish symptoms returning to
Weinberg 4B yesterday, after I was admitted to the hospital: flashbacks to 2 a.m.
procedures, having my lung drained of 2 liters of fluid, waking up in the ICU after a
thirteen-hour surgery, and pain, pain. But as soon as I got to my room I was greeted by
Kendall and Delores, two of the outstanding nurses (Kendall) and technicians (Delores)
who took care of me so well last time. They complimented me on my nail color and we
immediately started dishing about my nails and rings. They said I looked great (and
compared to when I was last here in May, I do). Today another favorite nurse, Kris, is
here. She loves the Tait Farm harvest shop in State College so today we talked about
recipes we make with their products! Nurses are extraordinary professionals, and
Hopkins’ are some of the best.
My medical team had a plan in place for me by the time I arrived. I am receiving two
antibiotics via IV drip. A doctor from infectious diseases came to see me and explained
certain things to me very thoroughly (eg how the abscess may have formed). Tomorrow
I’ll meet with doctors from interventional radiology. I may or may not have a drainage
tube placed in my stomach (again) to help drain the abscess, which is smaller than the
last one and in a different location. But they also need to get a culture from the abscess
to find out which more targeted antibiotics I might need. It takes a few days to grow and
test the culture. My blood was tested and thankfully no infection was detected in the
bloodstream.
Beyond that, though, much is uncertain. Can antibiotics (whichever ones I’ll be taking, in
the end) be taken orally, or will they need to be administered solely via IV? This may
have repercussions for how soon I can go home...How long will it take for the abscess to
heal? Will I develop another one? Most importantly (for me), will I be able to have my
next chemo infusion next Thursday, as planned? Will my white blood cell count hold
steady (those cells are fighting both the cancer and the infection at this point)? How long
will I be here? I’m holding out for 5-7 days but none of this seems straightforward. I’m on
the narrow bridge, for sure (or maybe a secondary narrow bridge that is an offshoot of
the primary one). But the most important thing is not to *give in to the fear, not to
despair.*
 
My day was wholly redeemed by a visit from Ben. He took time out of his busy day (he’s
leaving for a business trip tomorrow) to come spend a few hours with me. His hugs and
just his presence made me feel so much better. He is, without doubt, a mensch (and has
had a few excellent models in this area). We had a snack, chatted, and watched sports –
Giants-Cowboys (Ben’s choice), US Open men’s final (my choice). My dear brother,
                       162 / 1.901
Ethan, is also coming from New York tomorrow to spend a few days with me. I asked him
to bring me a raisin bagel from the city.
Getting to sleep was a bit hard last night, anticipating several ‘wake-ups’ throughout the
night. I miss my bed, and my freedom and autonomy. But this is where I need to be now,
and the care I’m receiving is, as usual, first-rate. To fight off insomnia, I
decorated/renovated each room of a fantasy country house and then planned fun social
gatherings there.
Please excuse any typos or even minor grammar errors herein. Am only practicing ‘light
editing’ on these posts!
This song is kind of my anthem these days. Please listen if you have a minute. Maybe it
will mean something to you, too.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D3Hhky1yLkM
Love and hugs,
label: sadness

text:
I spent a frustrating day yesterday waiting to have a stomach drain placement
procedure. This involved my fasting, in the end, for nearly 24 hours! Around 5 p.m.,
however, one of the gynoc doctors came to my room to tell me that, despite my being on
the schedule, the procedure couldn't take place as planned: interventional radiology had
become too backed up over the course of the day, in part with emergent cases. As a
consequence of waiting all day, however, I was at that point "higher up in the queue" for
the next day (ie today). There is so much waiting involved during hospital stays, I've
learned. Fortunately, I am patient but this experience was unnerving.
My recompense was to be taken to interventional radiology for my procedure at 7:30
a.m. today. I was lightly sedated for the short procedure, which went well, and awoke to
find a drainage tube and bag dangling from an incision in my stomach, as I had towards
the end of my hospital stay in May. Not the most pleasant memory. The procedure also
brought some unexpected, and not welcome news: while doing a sonogram during the
procedure, the doctors discovered a fistula or hole/perforation between my bowel and
my stomach. This could actually be the cause of the abscesses I've been developing and
is therefore an important diagnostic piece of information. But the fistula, although
pinpoint sized, has to be repaired, and apparently there are several ways of doing this. I
                       164 / 1.901
do not yet know what the 'plan' is; my surgeon, Dr. Beavis, will consult with
interventional radiology and likely other doctors and come up with something workable,
taking into account the other variables (my chemo timetable, distance that I travel to get
to Baltimore, timing of the two procedures relative to one another etc.). I should know
more tomorrow morning.
Of course I feel frustrated and like I'm 'backsliding.' I feel somewhat deflated by the
'bumps in the road' I've had to deal with, while knowing that chemo treatment is not
always straightforward and can be interrupted by low white blood cell count, infections,
colds etc. I'm committed to staying strong and maintaining a forward-looking attitude.
And the medical team is fully behind me on this. 
I feel badly to put such strain on my mother, brother and Ben. I feel guilty about
generating so much worrisome 'trouble.' I wish it could be otherwise. It's such a drag.
A bright light through all this was the opportunity to spend two days hanging with my
brother, which I rarely if ever get to do. Over the course of many hours, we moved easily
between catching each other up on our lives and kids' lives, and reminiscing about the
penny candy store in Amherst, MA, where we spent a few summers growing up; Auggie's
(as Ethan thinks it was called) was the source of root beer barrels, dots, hot balls and
many other childhood treats. I'm so grateful to Ethan for being here the past few days.
p.s. Dr. Beavis and another doctor came by about 6:30 p.m. and we talked for about an
hour. As she always does, she laid out very clearly the various options and scenarios
regarding repair of the fistula in relation to my chemo. I will know more over the next
few days. This will not be convenient, nor pleasant, and the logistics will be tricky, but it
will hopefully bring me a few steps closer to healing and should also not compromise my
chemo schedule significantly, which is the most important thing. I felt better after
speaking with them.
label: anger

text:
After a week here, I am being discharged tomorrow! Dr. Beavis, in consultation with
several other doctors (Mehta, the infectious disease specialist; Patel, my oncologist in
State College; Lyons, the interventional radiologist; and Stone, another gynoc surgeon
who told Beavis she had had a patient who presented a case similar to mine), developed
a new (or revised plan): the fistula will not be actively attended to until I finish my final
round of chemo. The reasoning is that I should be 'covered' between the two antibiotics
I'll be taking daily through IV (micafungin and Invanz) and the tube that is draining the
abscess in my stomach. This means, of course, that I'll be back to self-administering the
antibiotics and draining the abscess daily, for the next ten week. This is time-consuming
and laborious but I'LL TAKE IT. Hopefully, the fistula might close on its own. Conversely,
it could also get bigger (but hopefully will not). If it's not resolved by the time I finish
chemo, I may well need a procedure in which a small plug is inserted subcutaneously
into the fistula, to close it. The other option would be a more invasive surgery, which I
definitely want to avoid. Fortunately, my next chemo treatment will only be delayed four
days, until Sept. 23rd and should not interfere with my Rosh Hashana plans. All in all,
then, I think this is a very good outcome, especially as I can have my next chemo
infusion a week from Monday.
As usual, Dr. Beavis was thoroughly on top of the situation, coordinating its different
parts into a well-thought out plan. She is thorough and careful, smart, empathic and
upbeat. She also spent about an hour with me two evenings ago and half an hour or so
today, in my room, explaining all angles of the plan clearly and answering my questions.
I continue to feel grateful for my great good fortune in being under her care.
I find being in the hospital difficult. While hospitals are places where miraculous
developments occur, where people are cared for, survive and thrive, and show great
strength of spirit even in their weakness and vulnerability, on my worst days I felt the
prison analogy -- loss of freedom and autonomy, restrictions and constraints, lack of
                       168 / 1.901
comfort, separation from the 'real world' -- more appropriate. I find it hard sometimes to
keep my spirits up, although the nurses are all extremely kind and skillful, and texts and
notes from friends certainly helped (not to mention visits from Ben and my brother
Ethan). I do not mean to sound ungrateful as I feel unbelievably fortunate for the care
I'm receiving, and usually manage to remain chipper. Yet I will be so relieved to be home
tomorrow and certainly hope there will be no cause for another trip here before my next
scheduled appointments on on Oct. 22nd.
I did distract myself by plunging into an excellent book that my reading group will be
taking up next week (happily, I should be able to make that meeting after missing a
couple of previous ones): _Educated_ by Tara Westover (an astonishing memoir about a
young woman's struggle to craft a new identity following a highly singular upbringing in
a survivalist family in rural Idaho). I also welcomed visits from Rhonda, a wonderful
chaplain here. I believe she's a Methodist pastor but her approach is ecumenical. We
joined in prayers for healing and for tomorrow's travel, extending them over my 'loving
family,' friends and colleagues. It felt very cathartic, a bit of release during a difficult
week.
I have fallen behind in responding to emails this week - did not feel up to it or was
distracted by procedures and doctors' visits. Hope to respond as soon as I'm able.
Sincere thanks to friends, family and colleagues who took the time to write. Hopefully
you'll next hear from me in State College. I am bummed to be missing the ovarian
cancer survivorship conference here on Saturday, but it's logistically tricky for me to stay
here for that -- and I'm eager to get home.

text:
170 / 1.901
                       171 / 1.901
I'm immensely relieved to be back home after a week in the hospital. While I'm sincerely
grateful for the care I received at Hopkins, and while it was hugs all around with Kendall,
Lynne and some of the other wonderful nurses in Weinberg 4B when I left yesterday (see
pic), the hospital stays are wearing emotionally and psychologically. They are, simply,
hard. The ride back to State College took much longer than usual, due to a combination
of Friday rush hour traffic, construction and what seemed to be some traffic in advance
of the PSU-Pitt game today.
I went to bed around 11 p.m.and slept until 11:15 a.m! Such a relief not to be woken
throughout the night to have vitals taken, medicines changed in the drip, and to talk to
the doctors on their rounds (usually at 6 a.m.). While the game was going on this
afternoon, I took advantage of the quiet in town and drove to Wegman's, where I bought
the 'fixings' to make chicken soup with matzah balls, to get a start on my Rosh Hashanah
cooking. Nothing screams 'home,' 'comfort,' and 'zen' to me more than chicken soup, so
I'm going to dump the chicken, carrots, celery, leeks, parsnips, onion, turnips, parsley,
garlic, ginger, peppercorns, cloves, salt etc. in a big pot tomorrow and let it simmer
throughout the day. I'll likely reserve a bowl for myself and save the rest for the holiday.
Yum.
I will definitely be needing some extra measures of Patience and Fortitude (incidentally,
the names of the two lions at the entrance to the New York Public Library) to deal with all
the meds I will be administering to myself for the next ten weeks: I flush and drain my
stomach tube twice a day (it's currently hurting me at the insertion site but I hope that
will abate), then change the gauze dressing, and administer two different antibiotics
through an IV drip, using a different system than the one I used before. Am also taking
eight potassium pills a day, in addition to other medications. I can think of a million other
things I'd rather be doing and hope that this is not all screaming 'invalid.' Need to keep
my spirit strong and focus on my core vitality. All this laboriousness will be worth it,
though, if it gets me through the final three rounds of chemo. Fingers firmly crossed.
If all goes as planned, my next trip to Hopkins is scheduled for Oct. 22. I always welcome
rides there, to relieve some of my dependence on the car service I've been using as I
don't feel up to making that longish drive myself. Please let me know if you know anyone
who might help with this.
Thank you for your comments on my posts. They are all meaningful and encouraging to
me, and I'm sorry I'm unable to respond to each one.
While I was in the hospital the leaves started changing color and falling. I can't wait to
take walks and drives on these mellow days. Fall is my favorite season.
XXOO

text:
As challenging as it is adjusting to a hospital stay, returning home can be difficult too.
The rhythms, schedules, faces and spaces are so radically different. I tried to preserve
some sense of 'normalcy' in the hospital this time by wearing my own clothes (as
opposed to a gown), including sleeping in my own p.j.s. And I've attempted to get back
to normal since I've been back by repeating familiar gestures -- making chicken soup,
grocery shopping, taking walks in the beautiful weather and reading by Spring Creek.
It's been quiet here since I've been back. I have to spend an inordinate amount of time
flushing, draining, administering antibiotics, changing dressings, and taking medication.
It's frustrating and boring, but if this is what is needed to enable me to claw my way over
the finish line with chemo in early November, I'm in for sure. I'm already nervous that
the fistula (hole) between my bowel and my stomach that was detected in my last CT
scan might get bigger and result in sepsis, which would of course be dire (on the other
hand, the hole is microscopic and may heal on its own; the doctors will attend to it once
                       174 / 1.901
chemo is done). And I think the doctors may have decided not to give me another chemo
drug that might help me, Avastin, because of the stomach infection issues. So I really
have to hope and pray for the best result over the next ten weeks or so, and must
believe that my treatment is not being compromised in any significant way.
In more encouraging news, I actually feel better! The impetus for this last hospitalization
was my stomach feeling out of whack - I hardly had any appetite, and it felt as if my food
was not being digested properly -- perhaps a result of the abscess. The past few days
I've had what might pass as a hearty appetite, and I can taste my food! At lunch today at
the Ale House with my friend Kathryn, I consumed my Thai chicken salad with gusto and
treated myself to a mid-afternoon ice cream cone yesterday. I'll take it.
I'm trying to arrange lunches, coffees, and other outings with friends but feel a bit
isolated. People are working, busy with school - it's understandable. I'm generally ok with
alone time and also have some small projects to work on. But sometimes the silence is a
bit much for my fundamentally extroverted self. Happily, my mother and son will be
coming to State College for Rosh Hashanah next week, which I look forward to spending
with them, my congregation and other friends. Such a hopeful holiday, with its message
of renewal.
Finally, a very dear friend whom I've known since grade school has offered to drive me to
my next appointment at Hopkins! She lives in CA but may be coming here from NY. We
are working out the details but I am so touched by this act of friendship. Of my grade
school friends (32 of us graduated together from our Grade 1-12 school), at least five if
not more are following my page and showing extraordinary love and solidarity dating
back to when some of us were...six years old!
label: sadness

text:
Thankfully, my stomach abscess seems to have been held in check this week between
the IV antibiotics and the drain. Consequently, I've had no stomach pain and I do have an
appetite (which will undoubtedly disappear for a few days after chemo this Monday).
All this made for a comparatively 'normal' week, for which I'm immensely grateful, as I
am for the beautiful mellow end of summer weather. I pushed myself to walk a good two-
mile loop in a nearby park and will try to build on that (because I still don't have a huge
amount of stamina, I usually have to rest for a while after such an exertion, which of
course would not have winded me at all pre-cancer). I returned to my book group after
about a four-month hiatus due to my health situation: smart, interesting women, wine
(none for me, alas) and cheese in abundance; and a spirited discussion of Tara
Westover's _Educated._ I spent a good 5-6 hours on campus yesterday, first meeting
with a graduate student whose dissertation I direct; then attending the dissertation
defense of a student with whom I've worked closely over the years and of whom I'm very
fond; and finally attending the post-defense reception. It felt great to be back 'in the mix'
temporarily, within the cocoon of our wonderfully supportive and intellectually sharp
department. Several students and colleagues told me how much I am missed, which was
touching. I spend likely too much time these days torn between worrying if I'll be ready
                       176 / 1.901
to tackle the demands of my job in January (right now, my body needs *a lot* of sleep)
and very much missing my professional life and the people who make it so rewarding.
One day at a time. I was also able to do a large shop at Wegman's for Rosh Hashanah
dishes I hope to make in the next few days (honey cake, kugel, matzah balls) and then
I'll do a second shop this week for the rest (brisket, tsimmes, chopped liver, a compote of
some kind).
My friend Katarina and I enjoyed a coffee on the porch of Cafe Lemont, in the sun. Her
parents live in Israel and are visiting now. They kindly brought me a beautiful hamsa to
be hung on the wall inscribed with a prayer for healing (including a prayer for
*caregivers,* who are often also in need of healing). They took the hamsa to the kotel
(Western Wall) and said a prayer over it there. They also brought me a very delicate
hamsa pendant, with silver filigree. So very thoughtful.
I am praying that my chemo infusion goes well on Monday. Specifically, I dread a repeat
of last time, when the chemo either triggered or aggravated a stomach abscess. I am
praying that this time I am 'covered,' but I don't think having chemo while being treated
for an infection is ideal. I want to be well for the holiday, and hope that I'll be feeling
better by Friday. Please send good thoughts my way. I will have a visitor (or two or
three) to keep me company at least part of the time and will try to stay calm.
label: joy

text:
Four down, two to go! Everything went smoothly this morning. My kind neighbor Janis
drove me to (and from) the Geisinger facility where I receive chemo (a convenient ten-
minute drive from my house). I had blood drawn, vitals taken, and then met with Dr.
Patel, my oncologist. My blood work looked fine, thankfully. He confirmed that I will not
be given Avastin because it might aggravate/cause a fistula, like the one I have now,
which will need to be attended to after my treatment is finished. He said it was fairly
uncommon for patients to receive chemo while also attending to an infection such as
mine, but I simply have to be hopeful that I can get through these final three treatments
without a setback.
                       179 / 1.901
As I've mentioned before, the likelihood of a recurrence with ovarian cancer is quite high,
so I may not be done with chemo (nor surgery) after these six rounds are over. A
recurrence could happen after several months, a year, two years, or in a minority of
cases, never. At the risk of sounding like a broken record: one day at a time.
I was infused from about 9:00 to 2:30. It is pretty straightforward. No raving Trump
supporters this time, although the place was full. I wish it had windows. Around noon, a
new friend, Jackie (one of the "III Cs" I've recently met) came to visit, bearing the now
traditional vanilla milkshake from Meyer Dairy (delicious). Jackie (who is Scottish) is
delightful, interesting, active, youthful (at 73) and very kind. Her visit, and her long-term
survival, were both very cheering. Otherwise, I was engrossed in an excellent book I'm
reading for next month's book group, _Where the Crawdads Sing._ The drip doesn't hurt,
the nurses are solicitous and skillful, and once I get into a zone, the time passes fairly
quickly. Like much else on this journey, what initially seemed daunting or frightening has
now been normalized to some extent.
I got home around 3:00, took a nap, then made a big lokshen (noodle) kugel for Sunday's
holiday meal - sweet foods for a sweet new year. Cooking will continue throughout the
week, in between the home treatments, reading, working on some small projects,
emails, walks etc. Anticipating a brutal W-TH post-chemo crash, but hopefully not as bad
as last time.
Thank you for all the support and well wishes. They really mean a lot to me. XO
label: fear

text:
Just a short 'sign of life' two days out from chemo. Extremely exhausted: Monday night I
went to bed around midnight and slept until 5 p.m. on Tuesday (ie seventeen hours).
Then when back to sleep around 11 p.m. and slept until 10 a.m., in addition to most of
the day today. No pronounced nausea but body aches. Mainly crushing fatigue that I
have no choice but to succumb to. Of course, it's disorienting and depressing, especially
on a beautiful day, but at least I'm fortunate to have the opportunity to take care of
myself. Fortunately, no stomach ache so far - fingers crossed. I'm out of bed now, read a
                       181 / 1.901
bit outside in the sun, and will likely have some soup in a bit. Hope to rally over the next
few days. Thanks so much for the expressions of concern. XO

text:
Today is the birthday of the world, Jewish tradition teaches, a time of renewal and hope
for the year ahead. We've fully entered the month of elul, which coincides with early
autumn, and the "Days of Awe:" Rosh Hashanah, on which our fate for the new year is
written, and Yom Kippur, on which it is is sealed. Our lives are depicted as being in the
balance during these days before the 'gates close:' "who shall live to a ripe old age and
who shall lie dying on a bed of pain?" It's an existential state; we're truly 'on the narrow
bridge.' We beat our chests as we catalog the sins that we've been guilty of the past
year. Yet we are told that teshuvah (repentence or return), tefillah (prayer) and tzedakah
(charity) can temper the harshness of God's decree.
Having had to confront my own mortality over the past few months, the spiritual side of
my journey has come into fuller relief, including during the holidays. I'll welcome the
opportunity at dinner tonight, while blessing a round challah, symbol of the cycle of life,
and later at services, to tap into feelings of hopefulness, renewal, and immanence. To
                       183 / 1.901
Emily Dickinson, hope is "the thing with feathers-/That perches in the soul-" that can be
heard in "the chillest land-/And on the strangest Sea-" I've indeed felt glimmers of hope
in the 'chillest land' and 'strangest Sea' where I've found myself struggling over the past
few months. As for my fate, it surely lies somewhere at the intersection of the designs of
some nasty, aggressive, microscopic cancer cells, the skills of my medical team, and my
own fighting spirit. 
I am spiritual, yet agnostic. I apologize if this offends any believers who may be reading
this. But I do firmly believe in the manifestation of 'godly' qualities in people, animals,
and nature, whether it be loving kindness, graciousness, mercifulness, or compassion. I
have seen these attributes displayed time and time again since my diagnosis, whether
through friends coming to spend time with me, text or call me, send me thoughtful gifts,
volunteer to do errands for me, cook for me, drive me to Baltimore, or just 'hold space'
for me. It is quite wondrous. 
It is a wonderful holiday this year because my mother and Ben are here. My mother and I
have been cooking up a storm; I'm not quite sure how I managed to pull it off as at the
beginning of the week I was completely wiped out from chemo, but I was searing brisket
and frying onions in pomegranate molasses early this morning. I was hoping that Ben
might take some interest in the holiday cooking (he certainly does in the eating), as I'm
not sure who will continue the culinary traditions after my mother and me. 
Mitchel and Paula, I will be in touch w/you soon. I am catching up on other emails. The
week started out as a 'week from hell' but it's ending on a much better note. Sending
love,
label: neutral

text:
186 / 1.901
                       187 / 1.901
Gray skies and chilly temps today presage fall, not the autumn of "mellow fruitfulness" but the
"season of mists" that can tend to make me feel gloomy and isolated. I turned the heat on for the first
time. I also slept a good part of the day, which always annoys me as I feel that I should be up and
about, being productive. I suppose I need to 'listen to my body.' My stomach has also been feeling a
bit 'cranky' and achy the past few days, although it often doesn't feel quite right. Always hard to know
if it's 'something' or 'nothing.' Because of my recent history of stomach abscesses, the last one
necessitating an unexpected week-long hospitalization, I tend to project a lot of anxiety onto my body,
and am now also fully aware of the perils of *late* detection. On the other hand, if I ignore whatever
seems to be a bit 'off' with my stomach, I will be assured of receiving chemo on the 14th, which is the
ultimate goal. So it's an abundance of caution v. potentially magical thinking. I am inclined to write to
my medical team tomorrow to let them know about the symptoms and see if they'd like me to have a
scan done here next week (I will definitely be having a scan between rounds 5 and 6).
I may be tired because of all the activity around the holiday, which nevertheless was lovely. It was
comforting having my mother and Ben here, and we enjoyed dipping apple slices in honey and
observing other holiday rituals. I sauteed fresh spinach from Tait Farm in delicious olive oil from
southern France that came to me in a stupendous 'goodie box' from my dear college friend Mitchel,
full of both culinary products (honey, chocolate, tapenade, olives) and perfumed items from
Fragonard, all from around Nice, where he's lived for many years. I am not used to being pampered
this way, and I was very touched! I managed to pull off a big multicourse meal, as I love to do, but by
the end I was really tired and my mother and Ben had to help serve/clean up. Michael and Sue had a
party after services on Monday, where I was able to catch up with some other friends over bagels and
lox. That gathering bumped up right against the tashlich service, and so I didn't make it there this
year.
Many friends and acquaintances whom I saw at services extended wishes for my return to good
health - kind of them. Despite what I wrote in my last post, I too was praying pretty hard to be
inscribed for a healthy and peaceful year (w/that prayer extended to all my family and friends).
Things continue to be pretty....quiet. I did attend a lecture on campus by the political commentator
Andrew Sullivan (whom I've been reading since his _New Republic_ days), on "Democracy in the Age
of Trump." Fascinating lecture with a grim message (basically: we're screwed). Also read another
book I greatly enjoyed, _Where the Crawdads Sing_ by Delia Owens. Happily, I have a book party to
attend tomorrow and a few get-togethers with friends planned (and welcome even more), but my
voracious social (and physical) energy are definitely down a few notches right now. Hopefully, they'll
be back before too long.

text:
In another strange twist on 'nothing is predictable anymore,' I had an active day on
Saturday -- farmers' market, shopping at Wegmans, scenic drive to Brush Valley, with its
big swaths of farmland, produce stands and Amish buggies, soup making (veggie this
week: green beans, potatoes, tomatoes, leeks, carrots, corn). I was so tired (or out of
sorts?) on Sunday, though, that I slept most of the day, which is very disorienting.
Cold, rainy weather set in on Sunday and Monday, which, in addition to darkness arriving
earlier each day, contributed to my gloomy spirits and feelings of isolation. I found
myself venturing to morbid places I try hard not to enter -- wondering whether cancer is
trying to make quick business out of me, pondering the particular aggressiveness of my
form of the disease (which Dr. Beavis tried to explain to me very clearly but which I'm
                       197 / 1.901
still not sure I absorbed entirely), wondering what might be going on in my body right
now to cause me some stomach discomfort and questioning whether additional imaging
should be done before my next chemo on Monday. On that note, I am going to see Dr.
Patel tomorrow so he can examine me and determine whether imaging is desirable (on
the upside, my appetite is healthy and I have no fever). There are days when I definitely
need a few extra measures of grace to handle my health challenge.
Spending time with friends/acquaintances helped get me out of my funk. A very nice
acquaintance from synagogue, Deena, picked me up for a "life is short, eat dessert first"
date at the Creamery, where half a tuna sandwich each was just an excuse for the
gigantic ice cream cones each of us indulged in after that. This morning Gay and I had
one of our ritual breakfasts at the Waffle Shop (mini-platter for me...); I reveled in the
'normalcy' of such a get-together. Friends and family are usually my lifeline in glum
moments, so I very much appreciated these get-togethers (plus other texts and emails
this week).
I'll go to Kol Nidre tonight and services tomorrow (for most of the day). Although I usually
fast on Yom Kippur, I will have to forego that this year. My doctor thinks there is too
much risk of dehydration, which would put strain on my kidneys and imperil my chemo
treatment. I wish I had more control over whether I'll be *sealed* in the Book of Life for
another year but only part of the outcome is in my hands, in the form of self-care,
attitude, being proactive with my treatment etc. I'm not sure how this realization makes
me feel. Wishing everyone who observes an easy fast and a good "sealing" for a year of
health, happiness and peace.
label: sadness

text:
200 / 1.901
                       201 / 1.901
As I was walking to Yom Kippur services Wednesday on a brilliantly sunny autumn
morning, the sun highlighting all the beautiful leaf tones of green, yellow, gold and red, I
said to myself: "Next year on Yom Kippur morning I want to be doing exactly the same
thing I'm doing today." I suppose that passes as my prayer to be inscribed in the Book of
Life for another year.
I found an interesting meditation on the Reform Judaism website for 'one who cannot
fast.' Apparently, Judaism proscribes fasting for those under thirteen, pregnant women,
and those who are ill. My oncologist was wary of my fasting, as I most always do on YK,
because I need the hydration. So instead of fasting I reflected on this excerpt from a
longer meditation:
You know, dear God, that it is not my intent
to be apart from our people and our tradition.
My current state of health makes it unsuitable for me to fast
So, dear God, I turn to You now in sincerity and openness:
Help me in the coming year to do my best in guarding my health.
Help us, Your children, learn how to protect our bodies from harm.
Help us support others in caring for their , their Image of God.
Teach us to help one another grow and thrive in Body, Mind, and Spirit.
Guide caring family and health care professionals in their partnering with you
to bring healing if not cure, support and strength if not an end to symptoms.
And if there is an opportunity for me to help others who suffer
by doing something they need or by being attentive company —
Grant me the ability to do this mitzvah with love and devotion. 
The spirit of compassion, community and connection seemed to move several members of my
congregation to reach out to me, very kindly, with renewed offers of rides, meals, errands etc. I
was quite touched. I also received two spontaneous chicken soup deliveries! I am well-stocked
with soup to get me through Monday's chemo and its aftermath.
During a break in services I ran over to my oncologist's office to get his take on whether he felt
I might be 'brewing' another stomach abscess. He pressed on some tender areas near the
drain insertion point but felt that it was minor inflammation and nothing to be concerned about.
Whereas Dr. Mehta (infectious disease specialist) at Hopkins felt that I should definitely have a
CT scan, Dr. Patel (oncologist) seemed confident that chemo could proceed on Monday. Who
is right?? I noted that in today's blood work my red blood count is rather low, and I hope that
that -- or anything else -- does not interfere with chemo. I am anxious. I'll have at least one
friend, Jackie (one of the 'III Cs'), visit with me for a little while. I'm prepared for a wretched
                       202 / 1.901
couple of days post-chemo but maybe I'll be surprised.
As a friend pointed out in passing recently, I inhabit a strange space between 'normalcy' (or
some semblance of it) and its complete opposite. I am grateful for the 'normalcy' of a lovely
lunch with my friend Kathryn; morning coffee with my friend Clare; dinner and catch-up with my
friend Maria; and a good chat with my friend Helen while basking in the late afternoon sun in
the arboretum, decorated with gorgeous seasonal displays of gourds and pumpkins. Far less
normal, or rather the 'new normal,' are two hours' worth of infusions per day, twice daily
drainings of my stomach abscess, nurse visits to change my port, and managing peoples'
reactions to my cancer news. It's sometimes hard to navigate life in these 'two worlds...'
Please keep your fingers crossed for an unproblematic chemo infusion for me on Monday and
for a not too awful aftermath.
label: fear

text:
My infusion went smoothly today. Happily, my blood counts were in the normal-ish
range. My liver function was a bit elevated but Dr. Patel said that it's because it's
working 'overtime' now to process the various drugs in my system.
I was at Dr. Patel's office from 8:15 to 2:15 and even dozed a bit this time, wrapped up in
a blanket, as I didn't sleep much last night and was also given Benadryl before the
chemo drugs. No ranters this time, thankfully, but rather several skilled, calm and
solicitous nurses. Four angels (in addition to the nurses) brightened my day. My friend
Gay picked me up at home bright and early (dropping off some homemade chili and also 
pumpkin pie for the Canadian Thanksgiving she's observing today), and stayed with me
for the first hour of my infusion. At around eleven, Jackie -- one of the "III Cs" and a lovely
person -- stopped by with the now traditional vanilla milkshake from Meyer Dairy. A mild
cold prevented her from staying with me as planned, but she blew me a big kiss.
Sometime in the early afternoon (I was snoozing), Rhonda, my mentor from the Hopkins
Woman to Woman program who lives in nearby Lewistown, stopped by to visit briefly.
We had a great talk about how to stay positive and keep going despite all the
uncertainty and legitimate reason for sadness and depression (which it is also important
to acknowledge, but not wallow in). That talk did me a lot of good. Finally, when I was
done my kind next-door neighbor Janis was waiting outside to take me home. We talked
about her losing a five-year-old son to cancer -- something I had not known --and how
she managed to get through that. She was gracious to confide in me that way. I was
tired on my return so I rested for a while. Sorry to have missed the glorious weather
today but I may be able to catch more of it tomorrow. Thanks so much to friends and
family who sent texts and emails today- I'm feeling the love!
My last chemo infusion in this series is on Nov. 4th. It is unclear what will happen after
                       204 / 1.901
that. I will need to have the fistula repaired at Hopkins. Much will depend on the result of
the scan I will have on October 22nd, also at Hopkins. This will reveal a lot about how
successful the treatment has been. In this context, I have mentioned the CA125 marker,
an ovarian tumor marker that is normally supposed to go down as treatment continues.
In July, after surgery, my marker was 164.5, which is considered high. For the next three
treatments, to my surprise and even annoyance, Dr. Patel did not request that the
CA125 marker be included in my blood work, so *there is no data for those three
treatments.* As mentioned in an earlier post, he does not want me to get fixated on the
number, as the scan is the most revelatory indicator of progress and as, as he said to
me, "I still need to treat you no matter what." I still think, though, as a patient it is my
right to know this information. But now I won't. Oh well. 
Today's CA125 number is 57.4. It's dropped a good deal but is still listed as high. The
normal range is considered 1-30 (I note that in August 2017, way before I was ever
diagnosed with cancer, my number was 4.6). So the good news is that the number has
dropped significantly (Dr. Patel seemed to think so), and perhaps will drop even more
next time. But as predicted, the fact that it's still considered a bit high is causing me
anxiety in terms of what follow-up treatment I will need (More chemo? Parp inhibitors?
More surgery? None of the above)? I will know more after I have my scan and discuss
with Dr. Beavis. So for now, one day at a time. The whole world is a narrow bridge, but
the most important thing is not to give in to despair. These mantras still work for me.
Daydreaming about a little getaway with pals to mark the end of this round of chemo,
probably in my neck of the woods, and have a discussed with a friend or two.
Suggestions? Interested? Spa day? Overnight in the city (likely not my hometown, which
I expect/hope to visit in November, but... Pittsburgh? Good museums, good food, not
far...). Finger Lakes? More than one celebration possible. Fun to think about!
label: joy

text:
If you find yourself in hell, a friend said to me over coffee Sunday, just keep going. Or in
my case, sleeping, as I have for the better part of the past two days. Of course I am
beating myself up for feeling slothful, listless, unproductive and the opposite of vibrant,
but unfortunately there is no alternative in this case to simply...succumbing, while the
chemo drugs work their way through my system (hopefully killing lots of cancer cells
along the way). I have no more than mild nausea, no vomiting, a mild upset stomach,
some mildly puffy glands-- but mainly crushing fatigue, which makes it challenging to do
some of the 'basics' (administer antibiotics etc.) -- but I managed. Some red lentil soup
made by my friend Esther was soothing and nourishing.
I trust that, following the pattern, I'll start to rebound fairly soon. I will make every effort
to respond to emails I have not had the stamina to answer the past two days - my
apologies.
Many thanks for your texts and emails - lifelines - I need them. Love, Willa

text:
Writing from the ER at Mount Nittany Medical Center where I’ve spent a mind-numbing
eight hours or so. This morning, the visiting nurse who came to deaccess my port
thought the discharge from my drainage site looked disconcerting and advised I go to
the ER. I had also discussed this possibility, by phone, the night before with an infectious
diseases doctor filling in for Dr. Mehta. So I headed to the ER around 1:30, knowing that
I’d likely be stuck there for hours. To make a llloong story short (partly because I’m
typing on my iPhone), I had bloodwork and cultures done (sepsis is always a worry...),
followed by a CT scan. Then the ER doctor here, who seemed quite competent, conferred
by phone with the infectious diseases doctor at Hopkins. They decided that they should
keep me here in the hospital for a night or two to make sure nothing untoward happens
with the infection. My heart rate was also high when I got to the hospital and my blood
pressure was low; I didn’t feel great.
So here I am. I’m praying I can go home tomorrow. I’m a bit weepy but am just trying to
get through this short-term situation. And probably best to err on the side of caution.
While the standard of care seems adequate here, and the staff has been kind, it can’t
compare to the world-class care I receive at Hopkins. Also, nary a brown or black face
here; welcome to central PA...
It’s been one of those days when I hope I’m not becoming my disease, a mass of
unpleasantness. How I would have liked to be striding through big piles of leaves today,
in the sun!
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app

text:
Immensely relieved to have been discharged from the hospital at about 8 p.m. last night,
only to be unleashed into the zany traffic patterns around the stadium (holding over
110.000 last night), as the game had just started (I caught the final three quarters at
home). It would have been preferable for someone to have picked me up at the hospital,
but with the game traffic that was not feasible.
I am feeling better today, freshly pumped with two units of blood due to my
disconcertingly low hemoglobin count. Of course, this wasn't what had initially brought
me to the ER, ie some suspicious looking discharge from my stomach drainage site. In
the end, though, from what the the doctors told me, this should not be a cause for
concern. But straight lines and clear-cut solutions are infrequent in this journey.
My weepiness yesterday morning at feeling isolated and caught off guard, missing a
beautiful day etc. didn't seem to resonate with the nurses. But I got myself out of my
funk, partly by visualizing scenes from Ben's birth at the same hospital nearly twenty-
five years earlier. Kathryn and Bénédicte, two dear friends who are also my colleagues,
brought good cheer and culture high (_The Economist_) and low (_People Magazine_)
when they visited me.
In dozens of ways I noted throughout my 30 or so hour experience, the care at MNMC is
way below that at Hopkins, not surprisingly, although I'm grateful to the staff for its care,
and the ER doc was sharp. Lesson to self: always try to target best health care providers,
if possible (given the real real concerns regarding insurance etc.). Also: if you can, give
blood. Much gratitude towards whomever donated the blood that reinvigorated my
chemo-depleted hemoglobin last night.
I will go to see Dr. Patel tomorrow morning at 9 for more tests. Unclear yet whether I'll
be going to Hopkins on Tuesday to see Dr. Beavis for a consult, as scheduled, or not (we
may postpone until after my final round of chemo at which point I'll have a scan).
Looking forward to seeing my grade school friend Jill, who will either be my 'wing woman'
on a road trip to Hopkins on Tuesday and/or my house guest for a long overdue catch
up! She'll be driving here from visiting her daughter in Princeton, NJ.
