It's been a very chaotic week-ten days and I feel wiped out. I think I did not report here
that last week (or perhaps ten days ago), a few days after my transfusion, I walked into
my kitchen in the morning and noticed that a medium sized patch on the ceiling above
the fridge was wet and 'bulging;' it looked like a water-filled 'sac' of paint had dropped
down and was about to burst. I called the managing agent for my condo complex
immediately and two of their guys came over; they reported that my water heater was
busted and leaking into the kitchen ceiling (as I do not have a basement, my water
heater is in a utility closet on the second floor). They recommended two plumbing
companies, which I called immediately; as the first was tied up for several days, I made
arrangements for the second to come assess the damage and hopefully do the repairs.
In the meantime, I also called the construction company that I had used the previous
time this happened (leak from upstairs bathroom...) and my insurance company. I am
thankful that the benefits of my transfusion were starting to kick in and I had the
wherewithal, for the most part, to handle the aggravation.
Long story short: I had to endure five days of of cohabiting with three ginormous
dehumidifers that made it feel and sound like a blast furnace in my home; am out $3K to
pay for a new hot water heater (insurance won't cover it but it does enhance the value of
my home a bit); and had to deal with plumbers who were both incompetent and total
*gonifs:* their work was so awful that they had to come back the next day and redo it
entirely; the hot water in my kitchen sink is no more than a trickle, so I'll need to have
them return next week. And the owner of said plumbing company (Allied Mechanical and
Electrical: State College friends, do *not* use them!) promised me pie in the sky (free
inspections for several years; a stern talking to the plumbers who messed up; no extra
payment; and all of this in writing -- which I've yet to receive). So I will definitely be on
the phone Monday morning w/stern words and demands.
Oy.
Maybe this is the universe telling me to move to NY (or stay here) and become a renter.
I have a lot of work as we get towards the end of the semester, not just for my class but
for the department (evaluations of colleagues, all sorts of reports, budget stuff,
proposals to be submitted before I retire etc.). I'm running a bit late on some tasks partly
b/c of the chaos of the past ten days. And taxes!
Oy.
                       670 / 1.901
A friend with whom I took a walk on Sunday with a group of other lovely women (we
meet once a month) tested positive for COVID, along with several family members. I feel
terribly for her. This prompted me though to hastily schedule a COVID test for this
morning. Even though I'm fully vaccinated, even though we were walking outside and my
friend was fully masked (I took my mask off a few times to inhale some extra oxygen), I
want to be extra careful for *Ben's* sake, as he's coming home tomorrow to spend a
week here. I'll get the results in 2-7 days. Further, I queried both my PCP and my
oncologist here; both consider me 'low risk' to either contract or transmit COVID. The
CDC guidelines confirm this: vaccinated people (vaccinatees?) apparently can be around
people with COVID if they follow precautions (masking etc.). The CDC would only advise
testing if I became symptomatic.
But it's all in the scheme of things. There is better news:
Did I mention that Ben is coming home tomorrow for a week??! Which means, among
other things, that we may be able to have a little seder together, like we did last year,
for Passover. He'll be very busy with schoolwork, as will I, but it will be terrific to have
him here!
Of course as all this chaos is occurring I am also running weekly to the lab for bloodwork,
sending messages to Dr. Patel's nurse via the Geisinger portal, debriefing about my
bloodwork with the pharmacist who works with Dr. Patel and who calls me every time
new results come in (she's specializes in cancer meds such as Zejula), setting up
delivery times for my Zejula ETC. ETC. A job in itself.
So Annie (the pharmacist) called shortly before I both went to get my COVID test and
greeted the contractor assessing the kitchen ceiling damage. Thank God my numbers
are still stable overall, despite being slightly low or high here or there. My hemoglobin
level is inching back up to normal range (it had cratered as a result of my taking 200 mg
of Zejula [which caused me to be very winded], now cut in half to 100 mg daily). My
kidney function number was a bit off but we both feel certain that it was because I was
dehydrated; I distinctly remember leaving my drink in the car by accident as I walked
into the lab and thinking to myself: "I'm thirsty, and I know it's going to affect my
numbers." Next labs in two weeks.
Finally, my all-important CA125 number is considered stable. It's risen from 13.4 last
month to 17.1 this month; an increase of 3.7. Of course I worry about that slight upward
trend two months in a row, but Annie reminded me that anything up to 38 is normal, and
I'm still more than 50% under that. The drs. start to worry with very notable increases
(such as doubling), whereas a slight variation like this can be due to any number of
factors (stress, dehydration etc.). So I will simply decide not to worry about this for a
month, until my next test. Thankfully, all my numbers have been generally stable for the
past 5-6 months. I'll take it. Every day a blessing!

It's been quite a while since I've written. Everything's accelerating as we hurtle towards
the end of the semester, with four weeks to go. That means it's the season for reports --
pre-tenure review reports, senior faculty review reports, annual faculty evaluation
reports (following hour-long meetings w/most of my colleagues), graduate student
evaluation reports, an external tenure and promotion review to complete, lots of grading,
and a whole bunch of other work -- plus my paper to revise for a virtual lecture to the
Council of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts next month. I'm trying to be fairly single-
minded in my approach to checking items off my list -- for the last time. Eight more class
sessions left and then it's over and out. This class has been a joy and I'll be sad to leave
the students. Work will likely extend through May -- preparing next year's budget,
finishing up some admin work -- and cleaning out my office!
I'm feeling pretty well overall. My blood counts have been relatively stable (a little high
here, a little low there), my energy is pretty good (a mile walk is no problem, for
example), stamina good, appetite robust (I've gained about five pounds of the twenty
I've lost over the past two years, but no worries), sleep better since the dose of my parp
inhibitor was lowered. I will see Dr. Patel this week for a check in, then have my CA 125
level tested in about two weeks. The sword of Damocles is always hanging over me,
though. Try as I might to 'be in the moment' (and I've gotten pretty good at that), there's
always that niggling fear: "Is cancer trying to make quick work of me?" "I'm only as
healthy as my last blood test/scan" "Ok, I guess I know how I'll be spending my summer
now...." Because of course my cancer could recur at any time, as advanced ovarian
cancer does. The "honeymoon periods" might be considered feints, a tease, un leurre, a
bait and switch. And that sucks. But each day at a time, yes, yes...
Easter is of course the day I drove myself to the ER in a panic two years ago because I
knew something was wrong; I had never had constipation that severe, compounded by
that slight yet persistent bloating.. Thankfully, the ER was my default option when I
learned there would be a several hour wait at MedExpress, where I'm convinced they
would have simply sent me home with some Mirolax. I knew something was up when the
radiology technician looked at me quizzically and said "How long have you been feeling
this way?" followed by "Good luck" -- rather ominously, I thought -- when I left. The
imaging was a mess, of course: lesions in my colon, likely presence of a malignancy,
abnormalities in several spots (I've actually blocked out their names -- oh yes, the
omentum --  but eventually Dr. Beavis either removed those areas or as many cancerous
bits as she could from them). That was Easter 2019; so much for redemption.
But I've only given that a passing thought because Ben is 26 today and that is wonderful.
So glad that my body was able to help create, house, nourish and give birth to him well
before it came under attack. He's doing so well, and I loved hearing about his foodie
adventures in the city -- a day of sampling dumplings and noodles in Flushing yesterday;
                       675 / 1.901
Israeli brunch in Park Slope this morning. He was also home for a week recently and we
were able to enjoy a simple seder together. I had the stamina to make chicken matzah
ball soup, sweet and sour brisket, matzah stuffing, tzimmes, and lemon macaroons.
Somehow I also managed to pull off a Passover meal last year, right after I had my fistula
operation. Don't quite know how I did it (this year I felt much more peppy), but I do know
I have a strong life force. One of my retirement projects is to compile all the family
holiday recipes (some barely legible through the food stains) and pass them on to Ben.
I've taken to exploring backroads around here; it's so very pretty and peaceful in the
spring. The trees are about to bloom (I counted three nests in them on my walk today)
and it reminds me of when Ben was born: spring was coming into life and 'blooming,' and
so was my baby boy (we were jolted into a harsher reality a few weeks later when I sat
down to nurse him one morning, turned on the t.v., and witnessed the horrifying
aftermath of the Oklahoma City bombing). In any event, there's a scenic road along
Penn's Creek that delights me; yesterday, people were fly fishing in the creek (some of
you may know about my strange obsession w/fly fishing and my long-held desire to take
it up) and the Amish buggies were rolling down the twisting and turning road (just ignore
all the Trump signs.....; the flip side of 'quaint' and 'rural'). Stopped at an Amish farm to
pick up local eggs, honey, horseradish and a bunch of pussy willows; drove to another to
buy their maple syrup.
I'm all vaccinated and yearning for a change of scene. Hope to get to the city next
month. Longing to plunk down in a beach chair by the ocean or even a pool w/a good
novel. Anyone want to join me? I would even consider going myself - the Jersey,
Maryland and Delaware beaches are within striking distance.
P.S. Also participated in a virtual reunion w/my freshman dorm mates, which was
fabulous! So very happy to reconnect with several people I used to like -- as 18-year-
olds, anyway. :)

I met w/Dr. Patel a few days ago for my three month check-in/check-up. He spent about
30 mn w/me so I did not feel rushed. Bottom line: as of today, I am stable; "you're doing
good," he told me in his lilting Indian accent. When I ask him for predictions or detailed
                       681 / 1.901
prognoses -- I should know better at this point not to do so -- he won't go there with me.
It's enough for me to hear his reply when I ask him if there's any reasonable chance that
my cancer *won't* recur: "That's not the likely scenario." I know this too, of course; it's
not pleasant to hear, but it's a needed reality check. Dr. Patel's m.o. is all about keeping
me grounded in the present: "Don't worry about what you can't control;" "Enjoy the good
days" [implication: there will most likely be bad ones to come]; "Go spend time with your
son" (Dr. P will even give me a 'pass' if I want to skip blood work for a few weeks). So I
recalibrate and refocus on what I can control: take the Zejula (oral chemo med) daily, try
to eat healthily (but have gained back nearly *ten* of the twenty pounds I had lost since
my first surgery; blame my now quite hearty appetite, I suppose...); try to sleep well
(doing a bit better on that front recently); hydrate, hydrate, hydrate (it's crucial that my
kidneys function well, just as it's essential that my bone marrow remain robust );  stay as
emotionally and psychologically buoyant as possible. Recenter myself in the present;
cultivate gratitude; carpe diem. I'm actually doing pretty well on all these fronts, but the
annoying thing is not being able to make plans (eg for travel, now that us vaccinated folk
are starting to circulate again), as I could have a recurrence *at any time.* The key may
lie in spontaneity: look into last minute travel deals; hop in my car and head to a cute
beachfront bnb for the weekend; set my sights on New York as soon as the end of
semester frenzy eases.
Blood work coming up on Friday, including testing CA125 level. Praying for another
month-long reprieve if those results look good. Nervous about the slight upward trend
(11>13>17) of the CA125 but hoping that creep is not significant (if it inches into the
20s or certainly the 30s it's time to see what's going on, which likely will mean a scan).
But I'm getting ahead of myself again. Stay in the moment. Refocus. Breathe. Rinse and
repeat.
I'm powering through the last weeks of the semester with a lot of juice; worked hard all
day today except for a break to take a leisurely stroll w/two women friends. Time now for
dinner and pre-bedtime decompression (=junk t.v.). Forgive my somewhat telegraphic
delivery here. More soon.

It's been quite a while since I've written. I'll blame it on a frantically hectic end of
semester. Health update first: thankfully, I've been enjoying a good stretch (five
months?) of feeling pretty darn well. The liver numbers seemed somewhat disquieting to
me, but Dr. Patel and two of his nurses feel that, although higher than they should be,
the liver counts are not a major cause for concern at this point. I'll have my blood tested
on Thursday, including for my CA125 number. I feel well, but know that those aggressive
cancer cells (not sure if that's the 'carcinoma' or 'sarcoma' part of my diagnosis) could
rebel at any time. "Is it possible that my cancer won't recur?" I asked Dr. Patel, meekly.
"That's not the likely scenario [once you've already had one recurrence, as you have],"
says he (which of course, I tell myself, entering the realm of magical thinking, doesn't
mean that no further recurrences is *an impossibility...*)  . So I continue to lead two
lives: my everyday life, in which I go about my business, grade the papers, grocery shop,
make plans to meet friends for coffee, and - at least recently, as I found myself saying
out loud to myself one day -- feel "almost normal" (how exotic) and my "shadow life," the
one in which I'm consumed by thoughts of my mortality (I'm now super intrigued by the
idea of a "living funeral," although apparently I'm nowhere near that point yet), fixated
on counts and numbers, hyper-focused on my body, shaken when a survivor/subscriber
to an OC chat room I belong to "gains her wings" (in online parlance). Must stay in the
moment. Must.stay.in.the.moment. MUST STAY IN THE MOMENT.
But for now, it's (almost) summertime, and the livin' is eas (-ier). I am in the city for the
first time since Dec. 2019 and it feels great! First, my apologies to any NY friends and
family whom I won't get to see on this initial, relatively quick trip back, during which I am
choosing to spend time with immediate family (it’s been well over a year) and a few
close friends. If my health remains stable, I definitely plan to make a return trip over the
summer and will arrange to see other dear ones who I couldn’t meet this time.
The hugs are terrific. All over the city, people are hugging. Long, tight embraces after
months, if not years of separation, hugs full of love, joy and relief, as if to say: “It’s been
an unreasonably long wait, getting through the pandemic was hell, but we made it, and
this time I’m not letting you go!” But there seems to be ‘first hug’ etiquette. I leaned in,
instinctively, towards my college pal Bryan, whom I hadn’t seen in a year and a half,
before he stopped me to make sure that my immune system could handle a hug,
offering an elbow bump instead. When I assured him I was both fully vaxxed and feeling
well, we fell into the tightest, longest squeeze! Ditto with my grad school besties, whom I
last hung out with on a pre-pandemic yoga retreat in the Berkshires at the end of the
year before last. A beautiful reunion.
The gorgeous spring weather is bringing New Yorkers out. Diners pack ‘huts’ taking up
several parking spaces outside restaurants, and spill into the street. The Union Square
farmers market bustles. The number of bikes seems to equal that of cars. Most everyone
                       689 / 1.901
is masked (certainly indoors) but some remove their masks outdoors. Lots of empty
store fronts, though. And homeless. I can’t imagine how desolate midtown is. The city is
rebounding but it will take time and effort. I’m a city walker. The rhythms and vibes of
my city resonate with me. I may need to move back sooner rather than later.
A wonderful cousin w/whom I’ve recently reconnected has lent me the fabulous floor-
through loft apartment she and her husband own in Flatiron. Staying in this stylish place,
full of interesting books, artwork, and objects presumably collected from my cousins’
travels, is good for me.
So there’s been a happy family reunion lunch at a Spanish tapas restaurant, followed by
a swing by Eataly and a family hang in Madison Square Park (abuzz with sunbathers!); an
equally joyous reunion w/my grad school friends over brunch off Washington Square
Park, amidst our NYU haunts; pizza w/my mother and Arnold; tomorrow, a picnic in
Central Park w/a few college friends and dinner w/my mother and Ben’s girlfriend,
Sammi; Wednesday, lunch and gab fest w/my cousin Julie, who lives in FL but who

greenhouse and a farmstand or two?" My NY 'life' (and my Paris life) seem more
amenable to that type of spontaneous outing.
So I'm back to a sort of existential state: I have a whole free day ahead of me (but rest
assured, I do have a good amount of work still to tie up before my official retirement
date of 6/30); how do I want to spend it? I've also been spinning travel fantasies:
watched a great cooking/food show called "High on the Hog" last night (on the roots of
African-American cooking); the first episode was set in Benin, which suddenly  gave me a
wild desire to go to Benin -- those gorgeous patterned fabrics! the food looks really good!
They speak French! Those fabulous floating markets! And the dolorous history that I
need to know more about. Then I was concocting a trip to the West Coast to visit
everyone I know there -- rent a car and explore the coastline. Then I was planning an
asap trip to Paris. And a return visit to NY. But June is so pretty here in central PA: why
not stay here, throw out all the files I no longer need, relax, read, cook, hike, enjoy...
First-world problems, for sure (yet always compounded for me by that irksome sense of
"time's wing'd chariot hurrying near").
So I feel like I'm in a bit of free fall right now. I knew it would happen as retirement
nears. It brings to mind a passage from Georges Perec's _W, or the Memory of
Childhood_ that my students and I read this semester in my course on France and the
Holocaust: "I was plunged into nothingness; all the threads were broken; I fell, on my
own, without any support." I've also been loving John Mayer's acoustic cover of Tom
Petty's "Free Falling:"
I'm gonna free fall out into nothin'
Gonna leave this world for a while
And I'm free 
Free fallin' 
The song's not about my current state, but yet it resonates. I'll leave you with it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sKzoEwQaF7Y
Enjoy.

text:
698 / 1.901
                       699 / 1.901
It's been a wondrous weekend, marked by the convergence of Stride&Thrive, the
fundraiser for Hopkins' KGOS (Kelly Gynecologic Oncology Service), for which I've been
rallying the troops the better part of the past year, and the two events (virtual this year)
that form the emotional core of each of our college reunions: "Glimpses" and the
Memorial Service.
Stride&Thrive took place this morning, bookended by the reunion events. Bright
sunshine and heat; I needed to make sure to take two full water bottles before driving to
meet my #willapower teammates at the Pump Station Cafe in Boalsburg, across the
street from the Military Museum path along which we also walked last year. I've spent
much of the past few days trying to raise my fundraising total: I had set a perhaps
unrealistic goal of $10K but was thrilled, thanks to a flurry of last minute donations, to
report a total of $8.168.00 from *108 donors,* up from about $7K last year (my total was
fourth highest out of about twenty-five participating teams). And each $ will help fund
Hopkins' remarkable survivorship services: mentorship programs (which paired me with
a wonderful mentor two years ago), services for caregivers, discussion groups,
programming, gift bags for survivors (that crocheted afghan came in handy during
chemo...), an excellent web page, virtual yoga classes, classes on journaling etc. It's
possible that some of the funds go to basic research too -- also very important -- but in
my experience the 'aftercare' of survivors (ie those surviving with gyn. cancers) is crucial
as well. I had to ask Ben at some point in the last day or two if I seemed like I was
'groveling' for $, even pestering a few of my neighbors who have helped me over the
past few years and outright asking a few college classmates to please contribute. As I've
said elsewhere on this blog, however, I will beg, borrow and steal, and grovel if need be,
to be a crusader against cancer. 
My team totaled twenty-two altogether: proudly wearing our #willapower t-shirts, nine of
us, all women, walked/ran in State College, with seven of us walking a mile at the
Military Museum, one walking (her dog) separately, and a ninth running a 5k early this
morning. Others (all wonderful former grad students, now friends) ran in a)Philly;
b)Winston-Salem, NC; c)the Sonoran Desert in AZ and d)E. Lansing, Michigan. A college
friend ran in Baltimore. Sammi, visiting her sister, ran/hiked in LA. The picture Ben texted
me of him and his *grade school buddies* - Joe, Nikhil, and Kyle (+ Nikhil's gf), now all
living in NY -- before (or after?) their 5K in Prospect Park and all wearing their
#willapower shirts, made me beam. I flashed back to the time when, 5-10 years ago (?), I
explained to Ben the importance of his playing in a golf tournament to raise funds for
(ironically) another ovarian cancer charity, from which the mother of one of his friends
was suffering (she eventually succumbed). So Ben is all in now, and that makes me one
proud momma. Thank you, Ben, for the mitzvah you and your friends performed today.
You're good men (and Irene is a good woman!). And thanks to my awesome State
College teammates, fellow 'Amazons'/warrior goddesses Maria, Mary, Jackie, Jean, Tracy,
                       700 / 1.901
Helen, Bettina and Carol. And to the rest of my far-flung crew. I wish you could have
joined our State College team for our post-walk coffee, a lovely moment of friendship,
caring, laughter, and sisterhood.
p.s. We did not win the 'spirit award' as we did last year (I personally thought we had
TONS of spirit!), but no matter. 
As mentioned, Stride&Thrive took place the morning after "Glimpses," a reunion tradition
(which may or may not be specific to my class) during which classmates who volunteer
ahead of time briefly (5 mn.) share something important about their lives -- a challenge,
accomplishment, pleasurable activity, experience etc. It's all very 'unplugged' and raw
(and in that sense, very 'un-Harvard;' my jaw dropped during the very first 'Glimpse' I
heard, several reunions ago, which began: "Hi, I'm [name of classmate], and I'm an
alcoholic"). At our last reunion I shared a "glimpse," in the form of a letter to my hot
mess of a college self from my older self, weaving in the trove of letters I wrote home
during that time, and which my parents saved. In any event, virtual 'glimpses' (with
about 160 attending) may not have the same visceral punch as they do when we're
sitting side by side in the Science Center auditorium, but many of these vignettes were
still affecting. I could have done without the one about why this particular classmates
loves loons (apparently the bird watchers loved it), but was moved by a classmate's
heartfelt account of the challenges of navigating a gender transition with her child, which
ended "I'm so proud to be his mom." Others spoke about the nature of home, the awful
experience of being a [Black] lawyer and poll watcher during the 2016 election, teaching
prison writing, the passion for kimonos as related to culture and identity on the part of a
American classmate who's lived in Japan for many years. Fascinating, real, gripping. One
classmate, the attorney for the city of Ann Arbor, MI, wove together three stories, one
involving going to the store to buy face cream for his wife, also a classmate, ill with
metastatic breast cancer. When I sent my well wishes to her in the chat and mentioned
that I was facing a cancer battle too, at least three classmates reached out to me via the
chat (and two later emailed me), offering their support and empathy. I was so touched. I
must say, since graduation and especially over the past fifteen years or so, this
classmate network has not ceased to surprise me in the best ways. We've all been
tested. We’ve all grieved, lost parents or siblings, faced death and divorce, experienced
serious illness or have given care to someone who has. Just about every classmate I’ve
met or re-met in the past 15-20 years – and I’ve actually made some new friends among
classmates I didn’t know in college – is totally over any pretense cultivated during
college, when we were young and trying to figure out who we were and what we wanted
from life. But whho are we kidding now? It’s time to get real. So the empathy extended
toward me (and which I tried to let flow towards others) was welcome indeed.
The “Glimpse” that moved me the most, I believe, was somewhat obscure, based on the
imagery of broken pottery (the classmate has recently taken up ceramics) as a metaphor
for his painful estrangement from his daughter. Life and death were woven through his
                       701 / 1.901
story too: “Death is present in the midst of life.” Although told in the form of an allegory,
his story affected me greatly and I could sense his pain.
After Stride&Thrive, I crashed on the couch for a while, then zoomed into the memorial
service for classmates who have died since graduation. The list, of course, gets longer
every reunion. Five years ago we were in Memorial Church on the Harvard campus for
the service and I remarked to a classmate: “One day, none of us will be here.” Today I
sat there watching on my computer screen, and wondered: “In five years, will I be here?”
Statistically, I know that the odds are about 50/50, maybe better than 50% b/c I receive
stellar care at Hopkins. So I felt myself sinking down in my chair, dabbing at my eyes
while weighed down by that thought and by certain memories of Harvard friends and
lovers who have passed on. But other forces kept me in equipoise: the previous day’s
sense of bonding with other survivor classmates, the beautiful poetry, singing, and
dirges played on a violin that several classmates contributed, the insights brought by
two classmates who are spiritual leaders (one a rabbi, one an ecumenical minister
[United Religions Initiative]). Their words were calming, healing, bringing a metaphysical
perspective to my worries and really tying together all the strands of this great weekend.
“Time and space are not the measure of all things.” “…life that knows no death.” “..love
everlasting.” “the wondrous quality of each breath we take.”
What will my legacy be? And yours?
Or to quote Mary Oliver (as a classmate did):
“Doesn't everything die at last, and too soon?
Tell me, what is it you plan to do
with your one wild and precious life?”
Photos

text:
An entire month has elapsed since my last blood test (and I wrote my last CB entry about
that time as well). Since then, I've officially retired from Penn State, hosted my mother
for a fun week-long visit, drove to NY w/her and spent a few days there, which included
dinner w/Ben and Sammi at a yummy Israeli restaurant in Park Slope (Muriam) preceded
by cocktails (a mocktail for me) with my grad school friend Shanny at a cool cocktail bar
called Blueprint (also in Park Slope); lunch with another close grad school friend, Harriet;
and some essential spice/condiment shopping at Kalustyan (several varieties of salt,
peppercorns, za'atar, a few "I can't resist" pieces of halvah and Turkish delight).
Today's blood counts aren't revealing much. The hemoglobin and liver count numbers
are high, but that's par for the course, and they are not substantially higher than they've
been (a few have even come down a bit). But obviously too much stress on my liver and
red blood cells is not good. The CA125 number will be the big test (I'll see Dr. Patel
tomorrow morning), and I've been feeling very anxious for the past few days for several
reasons: a)I've had some discomfort on my right side for a few weeks. No sharp pain, but
discomfort at bottom of rib cage (liver??), compounded with mild nausea (I do stress
mild) and maybe (??) some lower back discomfort (something? nothing? result of two
five-hour drives to/from NY + two nights bad sleep? stress? cancer in my back and/or
kidneys?). On the 'plus' side, I should mention that my appetite is normal, ditto for my
energy level, and I don't look visibly 'ill' but I've come to understand that serious illness
is not always signaled visually; b) I intuit that I may be 'due' for a recurrence, as Dr.
Beavis told me they usually occur at regular intervals (my first occurred after six months
and it's been about another six months since I finished chemo to deal with that first
recurrence; on the other hand, there were 'complicating factors' during the period of the
first recurrence due to my fistula surgery, drainage procedures etc.). Hopefully I'll know
more tomorrow. Admittedly, I'm having trouble staying calm, imagining the worst
('defensive pessimism,' my therapist calls it).
What lifted me up today was a *wonderful* zoom convo with Brenda, a college classmate
whom I did not know in college. Rather, I found out via another classmate (another
Brenda!) that this Brenda, who lives in Chicago, is also combatting advanced OC, since
2017 it turns out. She's been through several runs of chemo, radiation, debulking
surgery, and more, but seemed upbeat (is very much about the 'being in the now') and
looked quite glam to me (we share a passion for jewelry, which she likes to buy at
auction). She gave me her rationale for making long(er) range plans, which I've been
resisting b/c of all the uncertainty generated by my condition. Consequently, she's been
                       705 / 1.901
traveling up a storm, w/trips to Paris, Hawaii, a cruise in the Mediterranean etc. She
simply plans for contingencies, buying trip insurance, renting a hotel room to rest in if
she doesn't feel well when touring etc. Her encouragement to celebrate my half-bday in
September or October by planning a trip to Paris (which I've been thinking about
anyway) has had me scrolling through vbro and Airbnb listings since I got off zoom with
her! I look forward to keeping in touch with her and wish her wellness and peace of mind
(which she appears to have in abundance, in parallel w/a strong faith). Talking to her was
so helpful. I look forward to lunch with two of the "III Cs" next week, another source of
support.
The title of this entry was the last line of a dream I had a few weeks ago, related to my
retirement. I will try to relay the dream in another entry, but it's time for dinner so more
soon.
For anyone who might not have seen this, Penn State News published a nice story about
me on my retirement:
https://news.psu.edu/story/661863/2021/06/18/academics/french-and-francophone-
studies-head-retires-after-33-years-penn
A feel-good moment for sure. :)

text:
My CA 125 number is 31.1 this month, up from 18 last month, a significant jump after six
months of stability on Zejula marked by just a gradual upward creep (the graphed results
show this starkly). While you will read online that 'normal' range for CA 125 is up to 35,
38, even 46, *my* normal is in the 11-13 range (at the time of my first, debulking
surgery my CA 125 level was over 200). I wasn't entirely surprised by this morning's
result as I have been having concerning symptoms for several weeks, as I reported
yesterday: discomfort on my right side; mild nausea; now a little bit of a 'tugging' feeling
in my lower abdomen and achy lower back, some weight gain. So when I opened the
Geisinger portal this morning and saw the result (after talking myself down to a rational
state), I simply said: "Yep." Then my thoughts and emotions started spinning out of
control again: fear, panic, sadness. "Hmm - cancer is trying to make quick work of me." I
drove to my three-month checkup with Dr. Patel in a bit of a daze, after sending Dr.
Beavis the results.
I felt much better after speaking with him. He and Dr. Beavis concur that I need to be
scanned, and this will happen a week from tomorrow (I'm going to see if I can move it
up, but I presume I may not be able to). Dr. Patel examined me and felt no lumps or
masses. My lungs sound clear. He determined that there is no blockage b/c although I
have some mild nausea I am not vomiting, am moving my bowels etc. (sorry to be so
graphic!). A blockage would not be good. He also feels my blood counts and liver marker
numbers are all fine, very important for what may lie ahead. Beyond that, Dr. Patel
doesn't linger on hypotheticals; he wants to scan first, then make a determination about
next steps if they are to materialize. As always, he's very focused on my 'living my best
life' in the present, encouraged me strongly to attend my friend Maria's wedding in NH
later this month, make other longer-range plans for the 1-3 months ahead etc. (he
doesn't want to discourage even *longer-range* plans, but prefers I not get too far ahead
of myself right now!). He also told me he would never venture to pronounce definitively
on prognosis, as in "you have two years" etc., which is what the college friend I zoomed
                       707 / 1.901
with yesterday was told. Each case is different. Dr. Patel was kind and matter of fact,
asked about Ben and my mother, gave me a hug (which I initiated), held my hand when I
started crying etc. (in a completely professional way).
When I worried that I had again moved too belatedly on this after several weeks of
symptoms, Dr. Patel reminded me that deciding when to treat (cancer) is something of
an art; if you intervene too early, you may quickly exhaust treatment options.
It also appears that a pattern *may* (and I stress 'may') be emerging, my pattern: six
months of 'honeymoon' (as I've experienced this Jan-June), followed by a treatment
cycle. If it turns out that cancer is the issue here -- and if I were a betting woman I'd put
my money on that -- this will be the second iteration of that pattern. Dr. Beavis told me
OC can work that way, but it doesn't always.
Also wanted to add (sorry for the choppiness but I'm a bit scattered today), that
'recurrence' may be something of a misnomer as my cancer never fully disappeared,
despite Dr. Beavis' valiant efforts to remove all the visible cancer during my debulking
surgery. Some always lingered, new cancer cells emerged that are not daunted by
Zejula, that may be what's happening now and if so, another line of treatment may be
needed. I *hate* the thought of having my body host these nasty uninvited guests. Wish
I could kick 'em to the curb... or worse.
Meanwhile, Dr. Beavis had emailed me very quickly, also saying "we need to scan." "This
may be nothing" she wrote,"but the symptoms are concerning." She offered to place the
order for the scan but Dr. Patel had already done so. She's on it. I will send her the
results so she can consult with Dr. Patel.
Dr. Patel prescribed a low dose of oxycodone if I'm feeling uncomfortable. I haven't slept
well the past three nights and the discomfort on my right side actually does hinder my
getting into a comfortable position. I'm yearning for a restful, peaceful sleep.
After seeing Dr. Patel, I had my chemo port flushed as I do every six weeks. The nurses
are extremely kind, and I stopped to chat with one in particular whom I like a lot. I must
say that the staff in Dr. Patel's office is kindly. No harm in being called "darling" by the
receptionist or "Miss Willa" by the intake nurse! The chemo nurses themselves have a
much more extensive skill set, of course, which is reassuring.
I was glad my friend Helen and I had arranged to meet at my office to pack up boxes of
my books both because she's a wonderful, empathic, caring friend and I love to spend
time her and because focusing on a rather mundane activity helped take my mind off the
other stuff. Although I need to refrain from heavy lifting at this point, we still made a lot
of progress. 
                       708 / 1.901
I feel pretty drained right now so will try to relax this evening. Then I suppose I have a
mini-reprieve until my scan next Friday. I am glad to have two lunches planned for next
week, one, coincidentally, with at least two of my 'teal sisters' or "III Cs," as we call
ourselves, local OC survivors, the other with my friend Kathryn. I'd be happy to 'fill up my
dance card' a bit more next week to discourage me from fixating on worst case
scenarios, so if any State College friends reading this would be free for lunch, coffee, a
walk, a drive etc. next week I would welcome that!
What else do I need or not need right now? Not need: pity; questions in hushed voices
about my prognosis; conspicuous avoidance of my medical condition; conspicuous
avoidance of me. Need: contact and communication (quick notes, emails, texts, hugs
welcome - if you can); prayers; laughs; being treated normally; empathy combined with
a matter of fact attitude, veering not towards pollyanna-ish optimism nor towards
doomsday scenarios (however, if you must choose I prob. prefer option #1 over option
#2). Feel free to ask questions. And please let me know what I can do for *you* in my
not entirely 100% but still semi-vibrant state: some homemade pesto? A ride
somewhere? A pep talk?

text:
Back home, thankfully. Was discharged at about 4 p.m. Ben was with me and Sammi was
waiting in the car. I just took a hot shower as I felt really grimy (no shower in my room
and toilet in the corner...). Ben plugged in my laptop and brought me sparkling water
with ginger to drink as I lie on my bed, typing. The kids are watching the Euro soccer
final in the sun room.
I woke up Friday morning vomiting bile, which I don't think I've ever done. Bile tastes
vile. I could not identify the cause. I wrote both my oncologists to ask if/when they
thought I should go to the ER. Neither responded for quite a while, which is unusual.
Finally, Dr. Patel wrote that if my symptoms worsened I should go to the ER. When I was
already in the ER, having decided I need to get myself checked out there, Dr. Beavis'
nurse called me to say that Dr. B. wanted me to go to the ER ASAP (she had been in a
meeting all day but they were able to get a message to her, to which she responded). I
also called my brother because he gives very good advice and is very rational, and he
also counseled me to err on the side of caution. So I asked my kind neighbor Janis to
drive me, which she was happy to do, in addition to praying over me once we got to the
hospital. I wasn't feeling great, nothing ultra-specific, just not great.
Once in an ER bay, it was quickly determined to do a CT scan. As is, I was/am already
scheduled for a CT scan this Wednesday, as warranted by the significant rise in my CA
125 number this past week. But as it turned out this was expedited. In the meanwhile, a
nurse or two were doing various things, I don't remember what -- taking blood, certainly.
When the ER dr. came (back) in, after I had the CT scan, he sighed and said "there's a lot
going on here" (I had updated him that I was in treatment for OC, to which he said "I'm
sorry."). The immediate problem/lower hanging fruit was an impaction of stool causing
constipation, which actually came as a surprise to me. That also explains why I was
vomiting bile (I think), as 'things' were forced to come up rather than go down and out.
So during my hospital stay that got worked out, thankfully. As a result of all the bile I
vomited (and there was a lot), my electrolytes went out of whack, especially my
potassium, which can have damaging effects on the heart etc. So that also got worked
out with big infusions of potassium and potassium pills, which I'll continue to take.
The more concerning news of course involves apparently new mets (metastases) of my
OC onto my lower lung (three nodules on one lung and then this fluid issue on the right),
peritoneum, and a lymph node on my belly, plus some tumors. At least this is how the
doctor described it to me. The radiologist, I think, did not compare this CT to the
previous one but to an earlier one, so it's not exactly clear to me what has progressed.
But I surmise there's been progression, perhaps significant. N.b. that my OC has been
metastatic since the very beginning. The hospital dr. (once I was admitted) messaged
Dr. Patel to let him know what was going on. Dr. Patel messaged that he wasn't surprised
at the finding given my elevated CA 125 number, and that he would consult w/Dr. Beavis
                       716 / 1.901
tomorrow. It wasn't really until then that I though to myself: "Duh. Of course, we've been
waiting for a recurrence all along." OC is a recurrent cancer, and I've already had one.
It's rather the extent of the recurrence, as far as I can tell, that scares me. The hospital
dr. reassured me somewhat by reminding me of all the tremendous advances made in
cancer treatment in recent years.
I was admitted for observation and that didn't go too smoothly. The first nurse
immediately asked me, "Where's your husband?" I felt my second nurse was treating me
like a sack of potatoes rather than a person, and had to beg her to show compassion
given the news I had just received. She sort of barked at me: "I understand, I had
leukemia and survived it. Then I knew that God had a plan for me." (aside: I too believe I
have a purpose to fulfill in life, which I may or may not live to fill out -- just sayin'). That
nurse eventually softened and we wound up on ok terms. My hunch is that the staff is
really burned out post-COVID. Many patients died. A new hospital administration
replaced a large portion of the staff. So the vibe at MNMC is not the best...unfortunately.
My mind was racing and all the stages of grief were crashing down on me simultaneously
-- intense fear, intense sadness, anger, frustration, gratitude (no acceptance yet). My
mental circuits were completely overcharged in this alien environment. Sobbing.
Careening wildly between my past and my future. Big-time FOMO. Trying to imagine
what the docs will say tomorrow (surgery? chemo? radiation? we can't do anything for
you?). A psych liaison and then a psychiatrist came down and simply listened to me and
validated all my feelings. That helped. II took some Ativan. The cloud lifted a bit more
when I made touch with family and a few key friends to let them know what was going
on. Yesterday morning my angels Ben and Sammi rushed to grab the 10:30 Megabus
from the city and were here by 4:00. Being able to hug them significantly lifted my
mood.
While I didn't sleep great the first night (not easy when being wakened every few hours
to have vitals taken and with staff yakking in the hallway), the second night I actually
slept pretty well, from 8:30 to 6:30. The jovial male night nurse who complimented my
hamsa bracelet and told me not to snore too loudly made me giggle.  Oddly enough, my
mind made space for some pleasant images: large flat shifting planes of sea green and
blue, almost like an abstract ocean seen from above. Calming. Also nice images of the
men I've loved (truly loved), with lots of long-ago details (like the dress I wore on our first
date) and some of the background theme music that I forever associate with each one
(such as Joan Armatrading's "Love and Affection" for one who has passed on...). It was
very pleasant, romantic! Such a reprieve, such beauty in the midst of my despair.
Speaking of despair, I was also holding on to the title of this blog, "On the Narrow
Bridge," which cautions, per Rabbi Nachman of Breslow, that although the entire world is
a narrow bridge, the most important thing is not to give in to despair. And speaking of
Nachman of Breslow, my rabbi called me in the hospital, which lifted me too; we'll be in
touch again soon. Michael also came to visit briefly. I am so thankful for our solid
                       717 / 1.901
friendship which has made it so much easier for the whole family, and Ben especially, to
weather this storm.
I'm in a calmer place now, but feel rather drained. I feel badly that Ben and Sammi have
to tend to me; I'd much rather be taking them out to dinner in Brooklyn, as I did about
two weeks ago. They're a great team.
Tomorrow's a new day, hopefully with a new plan. I know that Dr. Beavis is a dragon-
slayer, and hopefully I'll be ready too.
I can't thank you enough, each of you, for your kind words, offers of help, genuine
expressions of your feelings, outpourings of love, even some welcome sauciness. I have
cried copious tears of gratitude the past few days. I may not be able to answer individual
mails immediately, but I'll try to keep everyone updated. Much love.
label: sadness

text:
No word from my oncologists today. Dr. Patel is out of the office. And so I wait.
Frustrating.
I feel rather slothful. I don't have much pep. My side is sore. I did manage to write a
letter of recommendation. And I received in the mail two copies of the French history
magazine, _Historia,_ in which a short article of mine appears. So the day isn't a total
wash. My compulsion to be productive.
Sammi and Ben are giving me the immense gift of a calming, normalizing environment.
Right now they are cooking shakshuka and heating up my tomato soup. They take stock
of what I need around the house and will order it for me (eg a new can opener, a wooden
cutting board as I only have a glass one right now, perhaps a bagel guillotine). Sammi
picked up a cappuccino for me. I had enough energy to cook beets and Ben and I
collaborated on a beet, mozza and basil salad, with basil I grew (I think it's my first ever
success w/beautiful robust basil, two varieties). My mind is on cooking, which is a good
sign. I am itching to watch either "Ottolenghi and the Cakes of Versailles" or "Summer of
                       721 / 1.901
Soul" tonight. It's been storming on and off today but now the sun is out. I feel so much
calmer than during my hospital stay.
I did sleep well although I still feel tired today. I had an epic dream, or a dream that was
an epic. I was out for a night of clubbing, solo, in some dark, lively underground club(s?).
Looking good, wearing stiletto heels and a dress with a tight bodice, cinched at waist, full
flouncy skirt [note: in the hospital I was texting pictures from our thirtieth reunion to a
friend/classmate; I was wearing a killer black dress for the Saturday night party, which
was fantastic fun]. Don't remember too much about what I was actually doing in the
club, but there was a subplot about two young women who looked up to me/wanted my
approval. One was my niece, Maya (niece on Michael's side), who strangely in the dream
was named 'Clotilde,' the other was a young woman (both 20-somethings) who was
strolling with her boyfriend but was showing off her brown suede boots to me to garner
my approval.
The significant part of the dream is that I lost my black purse, which I had taken with me
to the club. I had put it on a ledge so as not to be encumbered by it. The purse had
*everything* in it: cell phone (communication, contact, mobility), cash (freedom,
possibilities, survival?), id card (identity), more. If the purse was lost I risked losing all
those things, as I suppose I do during this latest health setback. Btw, I don't believe the
purse was stolen, but maybe it was. There was just so much commotion in the club and
so many black purses that mine simply went astray.
Initially, I accepted that the purse was lost. Then the self-question became: "How much
effort are you willing to make to get all of this back?" I decided that I couldn't give up so
easily. So I walked through the club to a lost and found (?), where I saw several black
purses similar to mine as well as several handbag straps that looked familiar. But none
of the bags were mine. At a certain point, I simply gave up on trying to reclaim the purse
and its contents. So I left the club empty-handed, also aware that it was 1 a.m. and that
someone, I don't know who, needed to be alerted to that fact or was waiting for me as I
was out late.
The strange end to the dream: exiting this netherworld of clubland at 1 a.m., I was
blinded by bright sunshine, as if it were a sunny summer morning. People were walking
the streets, the city was abuzz. I was stupified. Since I no longer had my purse, I debated
walking to my destination but was constrained by my stiletto heels and also by the
thought that it might be dangerous if it were really 1 a.m. and I was somehow being
lured into thinking it was daytime. Day for night in this topsy-turvy, Alice through the
Looking-Glass World. Curiouser and curiouser...
My therapist pointed out today that in my real life an army of supporters would likely
have been helping me find my black purse and its contents, essential in some sense to
my survival. Please help me find my black purse!

As of right now (6:35 Tuesday), I haven't spoken directly with either Dr. Beavis or Dr.
Patel, but the emails were flying fast and furious with the nurses this morning. This is
what I know so far: 1) Dr. Beavis is going to discuss my case with the 'tumor board' in
her service, where she can receive the most expert advice about what may be the best
treatment plan for me (this is why I go to Hopkins...). 2) One possibility, all things being
equal (eg if I'm eligible, location etc.), is for me to enter a clinical trial. My longtime
impression that a clinical trial is a wacky last-ditch effort has since been proved totally
erroneous. Clinical trials are based on the most cutting edge research and always have
to meet the standard of care of more standard treatments. They can be quite promising,
but there is less data about their success rate. 3)More chemo with a new (for me) drug
combo is also a possibility. 
That's pretty much all I know. I don't know if there are other options other than clinical
trial/chemo. My hunch is that nothing will happen before next week, but after that it's a
series of question marks. Ben and Sammi are still here (bless them), but may be leaving
on Thursday. I have no idea what my needs may be going forward; it will depend on the
treatment plan.
I'm feeling calmer, despite the potential seriousness of the setback (which was not
unexpected with OC). The hospital stay was awful; aside from the trauma of learning of
my recurrence, I really think our local hospital has worsened a few notches since COVID,
a major change of staff, and the arrival of new hospital administrators. I went to the
farmers market today and may do some cooking, but carrying the heavy bag from the
market tugged on my abdomen, so I must avoid that. I am so happy to be at home, at
my kitchen table brightened by a vase of sunflowers the kids placed there. Was able to
do some work today, including making good headway on providing (overdue...) feedback
on a dissertation chapter by one of our grad students -- a very interesting read.
I am certain that the 'dragon-slayer' and her team will come up with the best possible
treatment plan for me.
More updates as I have them. Thanks to each of you for your concern and love. In such
trying situations, it's amazing how such elemental emotions as love can come to the
fore.
I think the image above sums up my situation *perfectly,* don't you?

727 / 1.901
                       728 / 1.901
Just as I pushed the 'publish' button on yesterday's entry, Dr. Beavis called me. V. glad I
published right before a crazy storm hit, killing our electricity and internet for four hours
and leaving the three of us to sit in the dark playing "20 Questions" by candlelight, while
the sky outside hissed and crackled with electric current and the sky turned shades of
apocalyptic red and dark gray. The power returned about 12:40 but today -- wait for it --
the air conditioning is out (until it can hopefully be repaired on Friday). Nothing like
sweltering in an 80 degree house. Oy vey. When it rains... (and boy, did it ever).
In between pressing 'push' and the onset of the Apocalypse, I spoke with Dr. Beavis for
about 30-45 minutes. As ever, the Dragonslayer was upbeat, thorough, patient,
supremely knowledgeable. She thinks highly of Dr. Patel and the two of them apparently
work very well together. Here is what I know: a) Surgery is not a good option for me and
could actually hurt me as it works best if it's been at least a year since last recurrence
(for me, it's been over seven months, which fortunately puts me over the fateful six-
month mark under which treatment becomes significantly dicier). Hearing that my future
portends no surgery was a relief; b)Radiation would not be helpful; c)she will consult
w/the Hopkins (gyn) tumor board on Friday to see if her colleagues can suggest plans
that make more sense than her own; d)it's unlikely I'll be eligible for a clinical trial right
now (I think it might have to do with my BRCA negative status), but she was checking
one final piece of information to confirm; she gave me the link enabling me to read
about all the clinical trials currently being conducted around the country, in case a new
study emerges for which I might be eligible (at Sloan, for example) down the road; e) it is
likely, although not definite, that I will receive a new course of chemo combining
carboplatin (which I've had before) and gemzar (which I haven't). f)A PET scan is not
warranted at this time; Dr. Beavis would only pursue if there was any suspicion of cancer
having metastasized to my brain (if I had persistent headaches and nausea, which I do
not). However, today Dr. Patel ordered a CT of my lungs for Monday to see if there any
findings that need evaluation. So I suppose that my treatment plan will be finalized next
week sometime. In the meantime, I'm 'detoxing' from the parp inhibitor (daily chemo pill
that I did quite well on for seven + months), clearing my system for the next series of
drugs.
If more chemo is in my future, Dr. Beavis said I would experience hair thinning but I've
just read that this combo makes you in fact  lose all your hair, which in the scheme of
things is not my ultimate concern, by any means. She explained two different timetables
for receiving this chemo, but I need to know more. The spread of my cancer around my
abdomen and pelvis is not uncommon. The nodules on my lungs are tiny; the amount of
fluid on my right side is tiny; she doesn't understand why I have discomfort there but
prescribed megadoses of ibuprofen and Tylenol. She is performing another test on my
tumor (a piece of which was saved during debulking!) to gather further information
about possible genetic mutations.
                       729 / 1.901
I was also very happy to hear Dr. Beavis mention two other chemo regimens that she is
keeping "in her back pocket" for future recurrences. She and Dr. Patel are being very
mindful of the sequencing and types of treatments for  this chronic recurring condition.
After speaking with Dr. Beavis and then enduring four hours of a power outage, I found it
really tough to sleep -- but not in a bad way. I felt so reassured after speaking with this
wonderful doctor. I was simply feeling intensely carpe diem-ish, and even contemplated
getting out of bed and laying into my to-do list. Sometime around 2 a.m. "time's winged
chariot," per Marvell, was hurrying at my back, but the mantra speaking to me even
more loudly came from a book I used to enjoy reading Ben: Dr. Seuss' _Marvin K.
Mooney, will you please go now!:" "Please go, go, GO! Please do, do, DO!" So I am back
to going and doing. Around 3 a.m. I was mentally recording in the wonderful blank recipe
book I received as a retirement gift the chicken soup recipe I have perfected over the
years, w/dozens of little hints and tips that I want to pass on to Ben when I eventually
'bequeath' him the book. Around 4 a.m. I was hoping I could get to my friend's wedding
next weekend and planning how to accessorize the dress I ordered to wear to it from my
favorite store in Paris (still sitting in the post office; hope it fits).
Despite the insomnia I was actually in a very happy place mentally and emotionally,
feeling that my doctors had snatched me back from the depths and set me back on the
practical path of treating my disease. So while ovarian cancer is undoubtedly an awful
disease, you should not imagine that I'm anywhere near 'the end' - at all. That was
totally the message from Dr. Beavis as well -- who knows that I don't want to hear about
'timelines' or anything like that until we've reached the end of effective treatments, at
which point she'll be candid with me. But I reiterate that this is nowhere in my near
future, should you be imagining the contrary.
Cancer is so strange.
Things that made me happy/grateful today:
>Receiving a gorgeous bouquet from a very dear, special and beloved 'ame soeur'
[=soul sister] (circumflex accent over the 'a' plus the Latin alphabet grapheme oe>don't
have the right keyboard with me!), whom I will thank personally v. soon. The gorgeous
sunflowers, pink roses and lilies are glorious to behold and have been in my view most of
the day as I work at the kitchen table.
>Lunch with two of my 'teal sisters' or "III Cs," as we call our group of OC survivors who
meet up once in a while to trade news and updates. One of them, Deb, is a twelve-year
survivor who has had *seven* recurrences, and who knows a thing or two about making
plans (>ie you make them), living in the moment, resilience, and OC as a chronic,
treatable condition like diabetes or Chron's disease.
>Ok, to be crassly materialistic: makeup shopping at ULTA. Clinique concealer, Urban
                       730 / 1.901
Decay shimmery gold eyeshadow ("Dumb Luck") and blue eye pencil ("Chaos"). I loved
the young salesperson, who looked to be about eighteen, sporting a glittery palette of
eye shadow that would have given Bowie a run for his money. In fact, I really hope this
fellow has discovered Bowie. Instead of coordinating my dress with makeup in the same
palette, he encouraged me to 'go bold or go home,' with contrasting and/or unexpected
colors. So the peach tones of the dress may keep company with blue eye pencil (a color I
rarely wear). We'll see how this experiment pans out.
about to do some cooking now: pesto, peach cobbler. Ben and Sammi leaving tomorrow
for the weekend but several close friends are around.
Happy Bastille Day! Joyeuse fete [circumflex accent on first 'e'] nationale!

text:
Updates: 1) Had chest CT today to make sure all the critical areas are covered. Was told
the radiologists here would likely not read the scans for a week (!); I hope Dr. Beavis'
team can read them more quickly; 2)Will be starting a new course of chemo -- every
other week -- next Wednesday with one drug I've had before (carboplatin) and one I
haven't (gemcitabine). Dr. Beavis consulted with her 'tumor board' and the consensus
was that this would be the best course for me and also the next logical step in the
sequence of treatments usually given to OC patients who are not platinum resistant. I
have purposely avoided looking for info on this combo and possible side effects for fear
I'll be upset by what I read (feel free to Google away, should you wish); I'll wait until next
Tuesday when I speak with Dr. Patel. He'll review the results of the chest CT with me
                       734 / 1.901
(hopefully there will be no significant findings, he is simply doing 'due diligence') and talk
to me about the upcoming treatment. My support network here is solid -- one friend has
already tentatively offered to take me/pick me up/visit with me/bring me a milkshake
during chemo should I wish; another has let me know she can activate the Meal Train if
needed; a third, again so kindly, said she and her husband could finish packing up my
office on campus if needed so that the new head can settle in; a fourth sent me a
gorgeous necklace that she was given when she started her own OC journey in 2015; it's
silver, and bears the cancer ribbon plus the Hebrew inscription "Chazak ve'ematz" ["be
strong and of good courage"]. I am so touched by this gesture, Rhonda, and will be
thanking you very soon! I love this idea of 'teal sisters' providing "strength from a
communal place of caring," per the lovely card accompanying the necklace; a fifth
friend, in Boston, sent a kind note to let me know I was in her thoughts. I am so
incredibly buoyed by all these gestures of love, caring and support.
I have no idea how the new drugs will affect me, but I'll soon find out. I simply hope that
they are not too debilitating. I'll be ready.
 
Meanwhile, lifted up by my new 'teal sister' (and college classmate) Brenda's mantra of
"first the scans, then the plans," I am heading this Thursday to N. Conway, NH, to the
wedding of a close friend  here. Five of us will make the drive together, in a minivan
rented for the occasion, including two PSU friends (a couple, one of whom is a
physician!), the bride's mother and one of the bride's sons, who coincidentally took two
classes with me. I'll have a free day to lounge by the pool, take a walk in town,  etc.
before the wedding on Saturday. I have a killer dress, ordered from Paris (but a bit too
tight; hope I can squeeze myself into it) and found some pretty hair clips in poppy and
coral organza that match some of the shades in the dress, described by  friend as
"Gauguinesque." Probably some fairly understated pearl earrings and bracelet plus gold
sandals.
And in "first the scans, then the plans" Part II, I booked a week at a beach front hotel in
Amagansett in mid-August for myself, Ben, and hopefully Sammi for a long weekend.
We'll have a small kitchen in which to cook up produce and seafood from the farmers
market. It is not lost on me that -- and not to gloat, but... -- while my colleagues are
preparing syllabi I'll be on the beach w/a good novel, toes in the ocean after savoring a
lobster roll for lunch. I look forward to a chill, fun week. I just hope the new chemo
cocktail doesn't knock me out.
Other happy moments of the past/next few days: a)Sunday morning coffee w/my friend
Helen on the shady porch of Café Lemont -- so relaxing and so much fun to hang out; b)a
visit from my friend and soon to be bride Maria; c)a lovely walk/talk this morning at the
Military Museum with my friend Jackie (another "IIIC" who understands *exactly* what I
                       735 / 1.901
am going through and views it as I do as an anticipated setback, which will be
overcome); d)Ben's return from MA, which inspired some culinary creativity on my part
(zucchini stuffed w/ground beef, rice, pine nuts, parsley, craisins, nutmeg and allspice;
baked peaches with crème fraîche); e)tomorrow's visit from my dear friend from grad
school, Isabelle, and her equally dear husband, Rob. Rob's family has a home in PA so Isa
and Rob will drive down from there for dinner, stay over, and then depart on Wednesday.
Giggling is guaranteed!; f)a number of other texts, emails, FB messages and not so
random acts of kindness; g)four essays I am reading by Oliver Sacks, whose writing I
love, grouped together under the title _Gratitude._ He wrote them in the final months of
his life. Poignant and clear-sighted.
I'm a lucky woman.
P.S. A few people have mentioned to me that they no longer receive notifications from
CB when I have posted. I apologize for this and unfortunately cannot proffer an
explanation. Perhaps check w/CB? Reregister on the site?
P.P.S. A number of people have complimented me on my blog, its writing etc. (merci).
W/out going into too much detail here, my creative energy right now is strongly tending
towards trying to create a performance piece from it (currently 200 entries and going
strong - "an incredible archive," per Ben), which would incorporate music (I have a local
musician in mind to sing the title song -- "The Narrow Bridge" -- as well as a few other
pieces such as Debbie Friedman's "Mi Shebeirach"). I was a theatre person in college but
do not have directorial experience. I am wondering whether I could sustain interest if this
were a one-woman show (ie is my story that compelling?) or whether I should try to
include other survivors (of whom I know many). But I also have to think about my
wherewithal in terms of energy, which would argue for a more modest scope. I see this
as a community-based project (to take place at Webster's bookstore? Elsewhere?) and as
a fundraiser for cancer causes and/or Caring Bridge. Its raison d'être? Awareness,
visibility, connection around issues of mortality, pain, care, gratitude, friendship and
other recurring themes in my blog. I welcome any and all ideas (seriously), including
dismissal of my concept as balderdash, self-indulgent drivel. Seriously.
P.P.P.S - Title of this entry.  Dr. Anna Beavis (aka the Dragonslayer) dixit: "Hang in
there!"

text:
744 / 1.901
                       745 / 1.901
Maria and Greg got married! Under a brilliant blue July sky framed by pine trees and the
White Mountains of New Hampshire, and with Stonehurst, summer residence of the
robber baron-ish Bigelow family, serving as a backdrop. The sunlight, crisp air, bright
color palette, and classical music drifting through the ceremony all seemed especially
vivid to me. The couple's parents and adult children beamed, the bride's younger brother
made a heartfelt toast, a lovely luncheon was served, there was dancing. My convivial
table mates included a (formerly PSU) American historian and her documentary
filmmaker husband, a native NY-er like myself; a former bf of the bride; and two longtime
buddies of the groom, who hails from New Hampshire.
I managed to decompress from a mind-bogglingly long (10+ hour) drive to New
Hampshire (spent in the good company of Maria's mother, son [a former student of mine,
coincidentally] and two State College friends, one the officiant at the wedding) with a
relaxing day discovering the cute town of N. Conway, NH, easing into a mani-pedi, book
buying (_All the Light We Cannot See_), treating myself to a nice dinner at a farm to
table place, and being massaged by the jets in the hotel jacuzzi. Slept well all three
nights, although one sleep punctuated by a dream pitting the Nazis v. the Resistance. I
knew of my quasi-inevitable fate (ie death) as a Jew being tracked by the Nazis, but still
attempted to beat it by trying to glean clues from a cabbie named "Leon" (?) whose
name, I surmised, contained some sort of useful clue or code that I might need to
escape. The story's ending remained unclear.
I wore the killer dress and the pretty organza flowers in my hair to the wedding and
received the requisite (and appreciated) oohs and aahs on Facebook when I posted a few
pics. I *did* feel well that day and imbued with a certain feminine power and confidence.
Were these affirmations from folks who know my 'real' condition and are cheering me
on? From folks who may be misled into thinking that I'm 'all better?' Was this my 'last
hurrah' (hope not)? No matter, it was fun to dress up and attend a party and dance; I've
always enjoyed that.
My luncheon companion to my right (one of the groom's buddies), Bob, an interesting
guy who has lived mainly in China and traveled widely in Asia, told me that his wife
passed away just a few months ago: colorectal cancer that metastasized to the liver and
eventually the brain: "It was simply awful to see this brilliant, vibrant woman completely
disintegrate." Gulp. I tapped on my port and shared that I too was surviving with
advanced metastatic cancer and perhaps had some inkling of the shock and grief he was
experiencing. That was a 'narrow bridge' moment for me. It made me think of those
game shows I used to watch when I would be home sick from grade school, "Let's Make a
Deal," for example. Behind door 1 there's a new car, door 2 opens to reveal a new dining
room set, and the curtain rises on door 3 to reveal ... bupkis. Behind which door does my
fate lie? Will it play out as it did for Bob and his wife (certainly plausible)? As it currently
                       746 / 1.901
is for my college classmate/'teal sister' Brenda, who's been contending with terrible
headaches and nausea that have led her dr. to order an MRI of her brain (plausible too)?
As it is for my "III C" pal Deb, seven recurrences and counting after twelve years?
(plausible, I suppose)? Or as it has for my "III C" ladies Jackie and Helen (breast cancer
but no further OC recurrences)? So....much....uncertainty.
So tomorrow begins a new course of chemo. Cisplatin + gemzar, every two weeks, six
hours each time (the actual drugs will only drip into me for 1.5 hours, the other 4.5 hours
I'll be infused with other fluids). It's unclear for how long I'll receive this treatment; it will
depend on how it affects me. The list of possible side effects -- tinnitis/hearing loss, rash,
nausea/vomiting, neuropathy in fingers, decrease in red and white blood cells and
platelets - made my eyes glaze over. I hope my body will be strong. More than anything,
though, I hope that the drugs will beat back the cancer. Good that Dr. Patel did 'due
diligence' by ordering a CT scan of my chest, because there are indeed some small
nodules there now, along with an enlarged lymph node near my trachea (I forgot to ask
whether this means that tracheal cancer might be in my future).
I woke up one day recently scared. Is cancer trying to make quick work of me? So I go
back to the mantras: one day at a time; the important thing is not to give in to fear; be
strong and of good courage. Dr. Patel assured me that he'd be right there with me each
step of the way, and will tweak the amount of drugs I receive if need be. Obviously the
spreading isn't good news but hopefully it can be arrested. I feel grateful to be able to be
treated here in Sate College where I am comfortable, and very well supported by friends
and by my medical team (Dr. Beavis is consulting with Dr. Patel throughout). I'll have my
blood tested and my pelvis/abdomen/chest scanned regularly. Thank you  in advance --
all of you -- for directing healing energy my way. A doctor friend who was part of our
'caravan' on the ride to NH confirmed for me that a 'positive attitude' can really make a
difference physiologically. And most of the time I can count on that (my blood pressure
was a bit high today but that's probably b/c I am anxious).
A  visit from my dear friends Isabelle and Rob was a huge blessing last week!
Reminiscing about all the fun and silliness of our grad school days, catching up on
whatever is important in our lives (we each have one 25-30 yo son), and massive
giggling over both dinner on my little patio  and then breakfast the next morning at a
cute local breakfast place felt like balm to my spirit! Grateful for these solid,
longstanding, rich friendships.
Will try to report on tomorrow's chemo provided I have the fortitude to do so.

text:
757 / 1.901
I got through my first chemo ok yesterday. Six hours: 1.5 for the two chemo drugs (1 +
.5); 4.5 for fluids, including electrolytes, a diuretic to make sure the meds were working
themselves through my kidneys (and which had me going to the bathroom every ten
minutes, tethered to my infusion pole); a bit of time for 'miscellany' (eg flushing out my
port, accessing/deaccessing). I am in a new chemo room that opened in January, so
much more comfortable and pleasant than the dingy one I started off in. This one is
larger, outfitted with windows (!!), ample bays for each patient, etc. The nurses are
wonderful, and I was lucky to have assigned to me yesterday my favorite, Tracey, a
divorced mom of two sons a bit younger than me who is skillful, and compassionate. I
enjoy chatting with her. No raging Trumpers in the chemo room (an unpleasant memory
from my pre-election course of chemo) but an equally obtrusive man whose phone
conversation reverberated throughout the room, as did his equally loud snoring
afterwards! My iPad had no charge, unfortunately, so I dozed a bit, sent messages to
friends, and had a few snacks (protein bars, Goldfish and water bottles à volonté in the
chemo room, plus my yogurt, peach, banana bread and Lacroix sparkling water brought
from home).
My reliable neighbor, Janis, drove me to Geisinger (about 10 mn from my home), while
my sister "III C" Jackie picked me up. We made the now ritual stop afterwards at Meyer's
Dairy for milkshakes (my treat to her this time). I came home to find a large freezer bag
by my front door; Michael had kindly brought me, as I requested, a large container of
                       758 / 1.901
Panera tomato soup, a comforting post-chemo meal. I crashed on the couch and woke up
a few hours later, feeling somewhat refreshed. Didn't move much all evening; the
Olympics made for good company.
Didn't sleep great. Awoke every hour or two, to make sure I was ok I suppose and in
anticipation of side effects. Felt a bit itchy at one point and was focused on keeping well-
hydrated. So I feel tired today but overall not too roughed up. We'll see what the next
days, weeks, months bring. As long as those cancer cells get zapped and my body can
handle the treatment without significant diminishing of quality of life (quite ok on that
score for now; SO grateful I can receive my treatment here rather than at Hopkins, but I
am apprehensive about any return trip to the hospital here, which in many ways I find
sub-par).
As always, I'm *immensely grateful* for all the expressions of caring and concern from
family and friends directed towards me over the last few days: texts and calls, responses
on my CB page, gifts (thank you, Paula!), chicken soup (merci, Monique!), offers to
grocery shop and run other errands for me, a promise of homemade borscht (Michael
and Sue) and carrot cake (a local friend, Scott) later today. Full disclosure: being a 'taker'
is not an unfamiliar role for me, and can actually feel quite good to me, yet at the same
time I often feel like I'm 'extorting' the kindness sent my way. Likely more to say about
that at some point, but I also hope I can repay (or pay forward) the love and care that
continue to envelope me like a warm blanket.
A few days ago my therapist and I were discussing items that I plan to carry with me in
my metaphorical 'knapsack' as I journey forward. I am *definitely and without any doubt*
taking all of you, perhaps first and foremost. I will likely *not* be taking the chorus of
Furies dominating some of the OC survivors Facebook pages I subscribe to; there is too
much conflicting information/misinformation there, too much catastrophizing (or perhaps
I'm just in denial about the inevitability of this?), with the terms "hospice," "angel gained
her wings," "teal angel," etc. jumping out at me each time I sign on. But I *will* be taking

My 'back to school' muscles have retained their memory, leaving me disoriented and
confused as we round the bend into syllabi prep season. To wit: two vivid dreams on two
consecutive nights: 1) I've completely lost control of my class; students are walking in
and out of the classroom cavalierly and I can't stop them. The scene is spinning out of
control in other ways too (a persistent sound of sand or gravel crunching in the
background?). A former college classmate, Paul Tavrow, is calling me out for the disarray
but the chaos persists; 2) I'm at a conference and haven't written my paper. Somehow
I've become isolated from the conference regulars, the ones I usually hang out with, and
am with stuck with two older men who look like scholars from a previous generation (one
has a goatee). One of them uses the word "Soviet" in relation to his research (indicating
how antiquated it is, as in "Soviet-era"). The three of us are traversing an uneven
landscape dotted with brown turds (!) [my thought here is that this may relate to the arid
soil in the community garden plot that I saw my former student/friend Yvonne
overturning in a video online yesterday].
I've long had these types of anxiety dreams as the spectre of the academic year's
beginning looms, but these had a nightmarish quality. Feeling 'adrift' and 'in transition'
for sure these days, the shakiness (walking on an uneven surface?) augmented by all the
other 'uncertainties' in my life right now. 'Getting a grip' seems fraught; perhaps
gentleness and self-compassion are the key.
On this chemo day +4, I'm at a strong "B+" -- feeling slightly tired and even more
slightly nauseous (did not even take an anti-nausea med today). Trying hard to be a
good patient>ample rest, ample hydration, healthy eating (need to start tossing some
exercise into the mix). Took a restorative multi-hour backroads drive yesterday: the corn
*is* (nearly) as high as an elephant's eye; the slant of light and mellow warmth hint ever
so slightly at back to school; Elk, Penn's and Spring Creeks glint and gurgle in the sun;
bales of hay dot the wide expanses of farmland. My country jaunt purchases included a
gold metal plate for change (looks vaguely Arabic in design) from my trusty antiques
store on Rte 45; a few ears of corn from a roadside stand; new potatoes from "Mamy's
Donut Shop" in Smulton; a luscious tomato from Yoder's farmstand near Aaronsburg, and
a dozen brown eggs from an Amish farm in Madisonburg ($1.75!).
Thank you, Jackie and Clare, for stopping by and to others of you for checking in. This
season is beautiful in Happy Valley - come visit!
