text:
...and some dreams seem to convey the depth of my terror. Taking a short pre-lunch
break to write this one down so I don't forget it (although I'd like to):
In a movie theatre or some sort of auditorium to watch a film, performance etc. I believe
my mother is near (next to?) me. Suddenly conscious of a man entering the back of the
auditorium and sense that something ominous will happen. Most everyone seems to
have the good sense to crouch down between/below the seats; I do the same and push
my mother down too. An eerie stillness; we are obviously sitting ducks with no visible
means of escape. The guy has a gun. He ambles around the auditorium, not saying
anything, takes aim, then puts the gun down and walks away from it. We/I have literally
'dodged a bullet.' Huge relief yet still immense apprehension. I am frozen in terror. He
repeats this a second time: walks back to the gun, picks it up, takes aim, then puts it
down. I've dodged a bullet a second time. I am walking "through the valley of the
shadow of death." And yes, this happens a third time [= third course of chemo?], but I
sense he's getting closer. I can simply *feel it in my bones.* This time --in real time (not
in the dream) -- I literally bolt out of my bed to avoid getting shot and killed. Then I
realize it's a dream and go back to bed (about 4 a.m?).
These are the terrors that I try hard to keep at bay during the day as I go about my
business and that flood my dream sleep. Horribly frightening.
I think I'll go get a slice of pizza for lunch and then see if I can work on an article.
Onwards.

George Michael - Faith (Official Video) - YouTube
 
Can't get George Michael, with his syncopated riff on having the faith in himself to hold
off an alluring yet dangerous lover, out of my head (by the way, I never realized that the
opening bars of organ music from "Faith" are actually lifted from "I Don't Want Your
Freedom!").
 
I guess I gotta have fa-f-fa-f-fa-f-faith when seeing my labwork results dotted with "H"
(High) and "L" (Low) and when confirming that my CA 125 number had jumped over 20
points, from 31 to 52.6 (above 38 is considered outside normal range and my normal
usually falls between 11 and 13). I gotta have faith, as both Dr. Beavis' and Dr. Patel's
nurses or PAs told me, that it often takes several rounds of chemo to see a drop in the
CA125 number; moreover, it's likely that the jump up occurred during the several week
interval between my recurrence being diagnosed and the beginning of treatment, ie a
period when I was completely off chemo.
 
As for the blood work, I had been told that this chemo combo can be harsh on red blood
cells, white blood cells, platelets, kidneys, and liver (is anything else left?..... the heart, I
suppose). So I wasn't completely surprised by the results, ditto for the CA number, but of
course instinctively I wanted to see the numbers trend in the opposite direction. And I
surmised that my cells were not being sufficiently oxygenated when I felt myself
somewhat winded on exertion several times last week. My kidneys are apparently fine
(yay kidneys!), which means I've been diligently hydrating. One of my liver function
markers is high (or is that low?). The red blood cell counts are out of whack, ditto the
white blood cell and platelet counts. Counterintuitively, though, Dr. Patel's PA says I am
                       771 / 1.901
doing well ("I've seen worse">HA!) and I'm certainly not in the 'critical' range at which
point treatment might need to be reassessed or a transfusion ordered. My blood will be
checked again before my second round next W, to see if anything has changed. In
theory, within two weeks the cells are supposed to rebound. Because of the low counts,
I'm now prone to bacterial infections, so must avoid gardening (I told the PA that the
most 'gardening' I do is to stick a plant into a pot and water it), pumping gas (rarely do it
myself), poor 'hand hygiene' (highly unlikely; I'm a compulsive hand washer), large
crowds, and other scenarios in which I might be exposed to bacteria.
 
At what point might the blood cell counts drop into truly troublesome range? What
happens then?  After how many rounds might I expect to see the CA125 number trend in
the opposite direction? After how many rounds is it determined that the treatment might
not, in fact, be working? And the cancer continues to grow and spread in the meantime?
So...much..uncertainty. 
 
But I gotta have faith...
 
I am feeling ok. I have energy to work at my desk, write emails, enjoy at least one social
outing a day, run errands, cook etc. Lifting heavy grocery bags is difficult for me, and not
advisable. Driving is no problem, enjoyable. At some point during the day I find myself
lying on the couch for a bit, but not necessarily napping. I try to sleep as much as I need
but struggle with insomnia some nights (even w/an over the counter sleep aid). Everyone
is telling I look great (WHO KNEW? Cancer is really hilarious sometimes). All kidding
aside, at times I do feel that I look as "radiant" as a friend recently claimed I do. I am
viewing life in technicolor with no filter, communicating soul to soul.  Is this a privilege
afforded those staring down their own mortality?

And I don't need another heart (To have and hold)

Loading up my social calendar has been a good antidote to getting up close and personal

A shortish update: Round #2 of chemo went smoothly yesterday. While my red and
white blood cell and platelet counts are still wonky (to be expected with the harsh drugs
pumped into my bloodstream), they've avoided falling into critical range, thereby
forestalling any need to hold off on treatment or consider a transfusion. On the better
news front, my liver numbers looked significantly healthier yesterday (they are
'normalizing') and my kidney function is good (one of the few realms I have control over
via hydration, so bring on those fluids!).
What I've been terming 'uncertainty' might better be labeled 'navigating.' This emerged
as the mot du jour yesterday. Dr. Patel needs to *navigate* between safe and effective
treatment. Because of the concerns re my red and white blood cells (and platelets), I
must have a low(er) dose of the treatment, but not so low as to be ineffective. It's a
numbers game. If the blood cell counts improve, perhaps he can consider a higher dose.
A higher dose at this point might entail the risk of severe damage to my white blood
cells>bone marrow, which in the worst case scenario could necessitate a bone marrow
transplant. And we don't want that. So for now we are navigating the high seas of the
chemo ocean, in the hopes that we'll start to see some improvement in the cancer
marker later this month (unlike the disappointing twenty point rise we saw this time, also
not unusual).
I don't feel too badly today. I slept pretty well but am tired. Only mild nausea. It is
sweltering today (I can feel the heat seeping through my study window as I type), so for
the most part I'll stay inside and rest, but I've already succeeded in writing a few emails.
I wrote to both Drs. Patel and Beavis to see when I can get in line for the booster shot to
be offered (so I read in the _NYTimes?_) to immunosuppressed and other categories of
vulnerable people.
My chemo day was long, 9:30-5:00, including labwork, a meeting with Dr. Patel's PA to
go over the results, and a brief meeting w/Dr. Patel, who explained why he can't raise
my dose right now. The hours somehow passed quickly enough, though. Had great plans
to read, but mainly texted with friends and even dozed for a while. The nurses, as
always, were kind, friendly and attentive. The final two hours I receive a diuretic that has
me going to the bathroom every twenty minutes - not fun. My bighearted neighbor Janis
drove me to Scenery Park in the morning and my wonderful friend (and OC survivor)
Jackie picked me up and took me to Meyers Dairy for the ritual milkshake (I opted for a
rootbeer float w/Chocolate Almond ice cream - so refreshing). My appetite is ridiculously
healthy and I fear that soon I will have regained all the weight I've lost in the past two
years -- almost 30 pounds. I was definitely too scrawny post-first surgery and can't say I
look overweight now (by any means), but I was hoping to come in at at least ten pounds
under my pre-chemo weight. Oh well. It's 'insurance,' I guess, for what may lie ahead,
and the docs seem to think I'm at the right weight (apologies for this utterly vain
                       779 / 1.901
digression).
A piece of good news: I have the 'all clear' to head to the beach next week for vacay! I'll
spend the week at an oceanfront hotel in Amagansett, LI (Ben will be w/me and then
Sammi for the weekend). Weather looks perfect. Anticipating reading a novel (or more)
in a beach chair w/my toes dangling in the ocean, poolside relaxation, food
shopping/cooking (lobster? ceviche? scallops/shrimp and pasta? Roadside clam shacks?),
time w/a dear high school friend, a bit of local tourism. Aim to keep it very chill. I'll drive
to NJ this coming Monday and meet Ben at the NJ Transit station, from where he'll take
over the driving. Return scheduled for the 24th in time for my labs, with chemo the next
day. I can't wait for a week to clear my mind, body and spirit with loved ones.
Thank you, Katerina, for the wonderful catchup at Duffy's once we were booted from the
Pump Station, and to Susan W for a great chat at Panera. Wonderful to see you,
Bénédicte, as well, even though we had to focus on work! Thank you to everyone for the
texts, emails, cards (Melissa, Heather - thank you!), comments on CB, and innumerable
acts of caring. Please forgive me if I've left anyone out. Chemo brain.
Apologies if this post is not completely 'à la hauteur.' I may have a bit of brain fog from
chemo. Time for a shower, two quick errands, and then to the chemo den/sun room with
a book!

Chemo tomorrow. Bloodwork earlier today. I see some of the results have come in, and
I'll receive the CA 125 result tomorrow. I don't want to look yet (too anxious), but I'll do
so (I think) before chemo. I'm worried about the possibility that my CA 125 may have
risen again. I'm concerned that there is a lymph node with cancer on it lying against my
stomach. Perhaps it might be removed? Must ask. Am feeling generally well overall. I get
winded on exertion (that's the chemo targeting my red and white blood cells). Cancer is
with me 24/7 though, for sure, and dread is never too far from the surface. But I keep on
keepin' on.
Vacation in Amagansett helped.
This Pisces loves water and the elements were healing. Sun, wind, surf, sand, clouds. I
did need to cover b/c of chemo-related sun sensitivity. The first day on the beach, I
dozed somewhat troubledly, as if my mind needed to rid itself of some bile (there was
also a strange dream that first night, which I'll relay later). The following days, though, I
felt much more in harmony with my surroundings, shed some of my anxiety, and was
able to enjoy one of my favorite activities: getting lost in a good novel at the beach (in
this case, the wonderful _All the Light We Cannot See,_ by Th. Doerr). Other activities
(beyond the luxury of quality time with Ben and Sammi): a morning yoga class on the
beach, which I dedicated (per the teacher's suggestion) to my pursuit of wellness. Was
unable to do bridge and a few other poses because my surgeries wreaked havoc on my
abdominal muscles, and I did get a bit winded (made sure to be gentle w/myself and not
give myself a hard time about my underwhelming yoga 'performance') but did feel sore
the next day, which I was glad for; a few nice meals out w/Ben (super fresh, delicious
sashimi at the Westlake Fish House in Montauk; excellent Mexican [roast LI duck in
pomegranate/apricot sauce] at Coche + killer Mezcal drinks -- Ben offered me a taste) +
an equally yummy meal  we cooked once Sammi arrived (linguine in pesto w/fresh
scallops bought at Stuart's, a longstanding fish+++ store in E. Hampton); E. Hampton
farmers market (hideously overpriced and no better than our local ones); a quick coffee
and catch up with a dear grade school friend of 50-ish (??) years, Eva, who lives in Sag
Harbor year-round. We only had time to scratch the surface but it was so heartwarming
to reconnect. Her stepson is a first-year student at Penn State, so hopefully we'll be able
to visit again in State College when she's next there. We have such a long history and so
many shared memories -- plus an 'older and wiser' perspective on some of the path
we've travelled too.
We abbreviated our stay by 1.5 days to avoid the approaching hurricane, but
nevertheless had a hellacious drive back to NY Saturday night -- pounding rain, godawful
traffic. Foodies that the three of us are, though, we nevertheless made a 20 minute+
detour to enjoy pizza at a 'real deal' LI pizza parlor, Umberto's in Sayville, which Ben and
Sammi had discovered on a previous trip to the Island. Amazingly good.

I spent two nights in the city at my mother's once we got off the Island. Ben was kind

The dream: I'm going to a new therapist, perhaps one that my current therapist has
recommended. It will be a therapy group. A youngish guy (blond hair, wire rimmed
glasses, kind of 'crunchy granola' looking) tells me about it -- he may even be a member,
but he quickly drops out of the dream. The therapist (and group leader) is a  fairly stylish
youngish woman with dark hair; she seems a bit harried getting ready for the group but
warmly shakes my hand. Once in the room with the other members, she puts her cheek
against mine as a kind of welcome. When I either tell her or indicate otherwise that I
don't find that gesture appropriate in a group therapy setting, she kind of snorts and
says: "Well, you want to have your cake and eat it too!" The group members are
numerous and all women. On first glance I realize that I know many of them. One is a
local acquaintance/friend, Jean N., who greets me very warmly in front of everyone
(thereby revealing that she knows me). Another women, Lynn S., is a former staff
assistant in the Dean's office who (in reality) passed away two years ago at age 60 - I
don't know how. Another woman [in the dream, not in reality] is someone I know from
Holocaust teaching/research circles. Because there are so many women in the group,
this last woman is sitting at a desk in a secondary ring of chairs/desks around the first
one. This clues me into the fact that the set up bears some resemblance to a

                       784 / 1.901
me now that I've retired, replacing - or overlapping - my school/teaching networks. The

The fall semester started yesterday. It feels strange not to be teaching. I miss the energy
of the first day of classes, the adrenaline rush. I miss interacting with students (ie
undergraduates as I am still working with several graduate students). I don't miss the
admin stuff though, to be honest, especially in this challenging environment. A fear:
becoming irrelevant, marginal, de trop, lacking opportunities to be helpful.
The holidays are almost here.  I'll celebrate my *third* new year since my diagnosis.  My

text:
A brief update as I'm wiped out from yesterday's chemo session. Everything went
smoothly but it's a long day -- 9:30 a.m.-5 p.m.! -- requiring much physical/mental
wherewithal. I always bring lots of reading, projects etc. but usually just wind up dozing,
writing to friends etc. It seems to be hard for me to concentrate on much else, and of
course I'm conscious of the presence of other patients too, although curtains provide
some privacy. A favorite nurse, Brianne, kept me covered in warm blankets, well-stocked
with water and snacks, and generally very well cared for. My kind neighbor, Janis, woke
up earlier than she usually does to drive me to Scenery Park and my steadfast friend,
Jackie, picked me up and treated me to -- wait for it! -- a milkshake at Meyer's Dairy (a
chocolate marshmallow malted milkshake, to be precise).
The chemo continues to batter my red and white blood cells; my hemoglobin production
is even lower than two weeks ago. And that makes me tired. On the (much) better news
front, though, my CA125 level dropped from the higher than considered normal 51
earlier this month to 29 U/ml two days ago! This is a significant drop, which suggests the
treatment is working (I say 'suggests' because this marker is not a hard and faster
indicator -- another uncertainty -- although for me it's been a pretty reliable one). So I'm
                       789 / 1.901
back into a range considered normal (<38 U/ml), although my normal is more like 11-13.
Hopefully next month I will see the indicator drop even further. I've mentioned before the
stress of feeling like I'm living/dying by a number, the feeling of 'retraumatization' every
time I see an increase and, conversely, the tears of relief and gratitude I cry (my body
literally shakes) every time I see a decrease.
Current plan: one more round of chemo (under current regimen) in two weeks. Then
scan (abdomen/pelvis/lungs). Then (re)assessment, with my oncs, of where things stand
and what future treatment may entail. At that point, I also want to get a 'bigger picture'
sense of what my long(er) term treatment may be going forward. Dr. Beavis spoke of
several 'back pocket' options. I will keep my eyes on emerging clinical trials. Perhaps
another parp inhibitor is in store, perhaps further rounds of the current regimen if it
continues to be effective. 
Blood pressure good, platelet production seems to have increased since last time - also
good. V. tired today, as mentioned, but hope to begin rebounding a bit tomorrow. I made
it to the farmers market and to my favorite drive through café for an iced latte, but
envision an afternoon at least partly on the couch in my 'chemo den'/sunroom, beating
the heat, tucking into _The Handmaid's Tale_ (which somehow I have never read).
As expected, I feel 'unmoored' not being on campus, in the classroom, in my office, with
my faculty and staff colleagues, and students -- some of my 'happy places.' I knew that
low-grade depression was going to hit me as I experienced this loss (props to Lexapro).
I'm still working through it as I continue to transition to a schedule (even if it's a non-
schedule) that makes sense for me and motivates me. On the other hand, I am
categorically certain that I'd be unable to handle the rigors of my
teaching/administering/researching schedule right now, and am grateful to be able to
avail myself of the resources necessary for me to focus primarily on wellness.
"God grant me the serenity To accept the things I cannot change; Courage to change the
things I can; And wisdom to know the difference. Living one day at a time; Enjoying one
moment at a time." Reinhold Niebuhr
Much gratitude to the friends/family who checked in with me yesterday,
before/during/after chemo, via text, email, grocery shopping, rides etc. The uplift is very
beneficial to me on a day when I need all the strength and courage I can muster. Thank
you: Ben, Mom, Ethan, Eve, Maria, Jackie, Janis, Monique, Scott, Helen, Clare, Michael
[*please* forgive me if I haven't listed you here; admittedly, I was experiencing some
'brain fog' yesterday. If I've left anyone out, it is inadvertent and I'm sure I'll remember
later. I know that others were thinking of me too, and I appreciate that]. Thank you,
Katerina, for providing some fascinating and plausible insight into the dream I recounted
in my previous post.

Be well, everyone.

September 18, 2020 - Happy birthday to the world
Journal Entry by Willa Silverman — September 18, 2020
This is the second New Year I've been able to welcome in since my "alive day" last May. 
So -- and because I'm a bit rushed right now getting ready for the holiday -- I will, for the
first time, post a 'reprint' from last 29 September. So much has changed since then.
COVID has upended our lives - irrevocably? My mother and I have enjoyed many a Rosh
Hashanah here together: she comes up to State College, we cook up a storm, go to
services followed by a nice lunch, then tashlich, marked by a pleasant stroll in Walnut
Creek Park with other congregants. This year I'm solo -- I'm sad to be without my family,
but I'm ok. And traditions must continue! Last year, as I recall, I felt very worn out (I was
                       792 / 1.901
undergoing my first course of chemo) but still managed to whip up a brisket with
pomegranate sauce. This year I'm feeling stronger -- undergoing "second line" treatment
for a recurrence, but I seem to be responding quite well. No hair loss, better energy,
working full time. I had chemo yesterday but still had ample energy to make chicken
soup, honey cakes and a plum compote w/vanilla and cardamon. For the rest of the meal
I splurged and ordered a big boxload of goodies from Zabar's -- matzah balls, chopped
liver, herring in cream sauce, noodle pudding, gefilte fish and a round challah (a lovely
fellow congregant also brought me a round challah today - so kind of her).  I think I'll
dress cute, putting on a new skirt I ordered from Anne-Elisabeth in Paris, my favorite
shop for clothes.  At 8 I'll Zoom into services w/my congregation; ditto for tomorrow
morning. And if I have the energy (I often go into a post-chemo crash after two days), I'll
perform tashlich beside one of our pretty local streams.  I hope I can make it.
I am fine. And I received the good news this morning that my CA125 level has dropped
two more points, to 17 from 19 - still trending in a good direction. I think I'll have a glass
of wine to celebrate the birthday of the world. Let's hope for a better 5781 than the year
before. We need it.
Blessings to all.
Last year's post:
Today is the birthday of the world, Jewish tradition teaches, a time of renewal and hope
for the year ahead. We've fully entered the month of elul, which coincides with early
autumn, and the "Days of Awe:" Rosh Hashanah, on which our fate for the new year is
written, and Yom Kippur, on which it is is sealed. Our lives are depicted as being in the
balance during these days before the 'gates close:' "who shall live to a ripe old age and
who shall lie dying on a bed of pain?" It's an existential state; we're truly 'on the narrow
bridge.' We beat our chests as we catalog the sins that we've been guilty of the past
year. Yet we are told that teshuvah (repentence or return), tefillah (prayer) and tzedakah
(charity) can temper the harshness of God's decree.
Having had to confront my own mortality over the past few months, the spiritual side of
my journey has come into fuller relief, including during the holidays. I'll welcome the
opportunity at dinner tonight, while blessing a round challah, symbol of the cycle of life,
and later at services, to tap into feelings of hopefulness, renewal, and immanence. To
Emily Dickinson, hope is "the thing with feathers-/That perches in the soul-" that can be
heard in "the chillest land-/And on the strangest Sea-" I've indeed felt glimmers of hope
in the 'chillest land' and 'strangest Sea' where I've found myself struggling over the past
few months. As for my fate, it surely lies somewhere at the intersection of the designs of
some nasty, aggressive, microscopic cancer cells, the skills of my medical team, and my
own fighting spirit. 
                       793 / 1.901
I am spiritual, yet agnostic. I apologize if this offends any believers who may be reading
this. But I do firmly believe in the manifestation of 'godly' qualities in people, animals,
and nature, whether it be loving kindness, graciousness, mercifulness, or compassion. I
have seen these attributes displayed time and time again since my diagnosis, whether
through friends coming to spend time with me, text or call me, send me thoughtful gifts,
volunteer to do errands for me, cook for me, drive me to Baltimore, or just 'hold space'
for me. It is quite wondrous. 
It is a wonderful holiday this year because my mother and Ben are here. My mother and I
have been cooking up a storm; I'm not quite sure how I managed to pull it off as at the
beginning of the week I was completely wiped out from chemo, but I was searing brisket
and frying onions in pomegranate molasses early this morning. I was hoping that Ben
might take some interest in the holiday cooking (he certainly does in the eating), as I'm
not sure who will continue the culinary traditions after my mother and me.

text:
794 / 1.901
                       795 / 1.901
I wasn't able to receive chemo yesterday. Both my hemoglobin and platelets had again
decreased in volume/number, not uncommon with this treatment. The  last round of
chemo, two weeks ago, really wiped me out and it took me a full week to recover (I spent
an *entire day* curled up on the couch in my nightgown, devoid of energy and in a
strange mental state as Hurricane Ida wreaked collateral damage outside in the form of
a monsoon-like rain all day). The second week I felt better but still winded on exertion,
even fairly minimal exertion. My heart has to pump faster/harder to ensure adequate
blood flow, and hence sufficient oxygen flow throughout my body. Thankfully, I have a
healthy heart as excess pressure on it can lead to no good, just as a steep decline in
platelets, in the event of a cut or infection, can lead to no good. As I had mentally
prepared myself for chemo, arriving at Dr. Patel's office bright and early w/all my 'gear'
(lunch, novel, masks, cozy PSU hoodie), steeled for an eight-hour day in the infusion
room, I felt frustrated when Dr. Patel's PA told me that the doctor advised waiting
another week to play it safe. I was likely somewhat pissy with Mary Beth (despite my
Rosh Hashanah resolution to be more patient), attempting to extort 'guarantees' from
her that waiting another week would not give those sneaky cancer cells license to swarm
back in. I seemed unable to channel the frustration in a less childish way... :( So next
week it is, likely on Yom Kippur..... which I don't feel great about, although the dramatic
potential of offering prayers of supplication to be sealed in the Book of Life for another
year at the same time as life-preserving/destroying poison is being shot through my
veins has not been lost on me...
 
The holiday, though, was lovely. After spending last year's holiday on my own and
attending services virtually, this year, per tradition, my mother was able to make the trip
from NY on the Megabus, bearing a beautiful round challah (=plenitude, the 'circle' of
the year that is ending) from Breads Bakery. So grateful she was able to spend the
holiday here! We had a lovely time together. Per tradition as well, I spent about four
days cooking , the last two assisted by my mother. My meal featured traditional dishes
with a twist: chicken liver pâté (shallots, Port, butter, heavy cream), semi-sour pickles,
chicken soup w/matzah balls (the latter containing ginger, nutmeg, paprika, fresh
parsley, onions and schmaltz), brisket in pomegranate sauce, noodle kugel w/apples and
raisins, tzimmes, green beans, honey cake w/stone fruit compote (peaches and plums,
lemon peel) for dessert, an excellent red (Châteauneuf-du-Pape). I love table décor and
enjoy setting an eye-catching table.  I invited my neighbors (and fellow congregants),
Ron and Carol Hodes. While we had never socialized in this way, we had a convivial
dinner, the homey food and good wine loosening our tongues and spirits. I am still eating
leftovers.
It is all partly a hommage to my E. European born grandmother Bessie and great-
grandmother (bubbie) Bella, who also spent days in the kitchen so that we could be
ushered into the overheated kitchen on holidays with indescribably delicious scents (I'm
                       796 / 1.901
remembering 'sweet' and 'schmaltz' -- chicken fat, which was their stealth ingredient).
Every dish had been cooking, it seemed, for hours if not days -- the chicken soup was a
deep yellow (and yes, redolent with schmaltz) while the tin foil that had covered 
roasting pans was now coated with a layer of dark caramelized something. My
grandmother lived in a five floor brownstone on E. 94th st. (between Fifth and Madison)
that featured a *dumbwaiter* for hoisting food from the kitchen to the large dining room
above, whose sideboard groaned with delicious desserts (my favorites were chocolate
covered orange peels and a gâteau St. Honoré with cream puffs) from William Greenberg
bakery or Madison Avenue - oh, and a homemade teiglach, small hard dough balls bound
together with honey in a pyramid, and studded with dried fruits and nuts. Aside from the
traditional Ashkenazi holiday dishes, my grandmother's table also boasted a roast beef
and ...spaghetti and meat balls.
This year Ben and a few friends ordered RH dinner from a Montreal-style place in
Brooklyn, Mile End (Ben and I actually went on a Jewish foods walking tour of this
neighborhood), making me optimistic that he will carry on the traditions in some way.
I've begun writing down all the recipes for him in a lovely blank leather-bound book
gifted me by my grad students. My recipe for "Mom's Chicken Soup" is five pages,
including all my tips!
It was heartening, on Monday evening and Tuesday, to return to the synagogue
sanctuary for the first time in at least two (?) years and to greet friends/congregants.
While - to be candid - most of the prayers do not resonate with me, the meaning of the
holiday -- hope to be 'renewed' for another year and  forgiven for 'sins' against God and
other people (I was focusing on impatience, lack of compassion at times, and lack of
sufficient care towards my body) -- is not inconsequential for me.
The following always stick with me, though, and have become mantras:
{Something like}: "May you walk with good companions." As I've stated before, I am
very blessed to "walk with good companions" and I wish the same for everyone I know
and care about.
Also: [something like] "With hope in our hearts and eternity in our souls." 
I have read a lot about this verse (from Ecclesiastes but must also exist in the Torah in
some form too) and about various translations of the word 'olam' (as darkness but also
eternity), but I can only offer what it means to me at this point in time: not a hope for
eternal life (which, if it means a hope for an afterlife, I do not believe in) but simply some
sense of transcendence -- that there is some dimension to life that is not immediately
visible or perceptible to us, but that is *there.* This is the part that I am hopeful endures,
including in memory. I'm probably not explaining this well, but out of the entire service it
is the verse that makes me feel calm and at peace.
                       797 / 1.901
I also read a poem that resonated with me before dinner on erev RH. While I'm a bit
embarrassed to admit that it's by a seeming self-help guru (with a Jewish slant), Dawna
Markova, it seems nevertheless to describe my current path:
I will not die an unlived life,
I will not live in fear
Of falling or catching fire.
 
I choose to inhabit my days
To allow my living to open me,
To make me less afraid,
more accessible,
To loosen my heart
Until it becomes a wing,
A torch, a promise.
 
I choose to risk my significance: to live
So that which came to me as seed
Goes to the next as blossom
And that which came to me as blossom
Goes on as fruit.
***
Rhonda stopped treatment three months ago and her cancer has progressed, making
her day to day activities more difficult. Rhonda is a 'teal sister' whom I've never met
except virtually, but who is also treated for ovarian cancer at Hopkins. Rhonda is the
                       798 / 1.901
fellow survivor who gifted me the beautiful pendant I am wearing right now, with the
cancer ribbon and the Hebrew for "be strong and of good courage" inscribed on it; I told
her I will 'pay it forward' when/if the time comes by gifting the pendant to another
survivor. Rhonda is moving forward without fear of the unknown; palliative and hospice
care can be instrumental shorter- or longer-term methods for facilitating a beautiful end
of life and a 'good death.' Rhonda inspires me to keep eternity in my soul [and heart and
mind].
***
I have been binging documentaries (my favorite film genre) about highly creative,
complex, and often dark people (who happen to all be men, in this section of my binge). I
am enthralled by what motivates them, their creative process, their lives, their struggles.
Hence: _Roadrunner_ (excellent doc about Anthony Bourdain); Scorsese's two-part doc,
_George Harrison: Living in the Material World_ (the 'quiet Beatle' has always been my
favorite - a brilliant, deeply spiritual musician); _Bitchin:' The Sound and Fury of Rick
James_ (I danced my ass off to his music in college, but didn't realize how rich his legacy
was -- from the ghetto in Buffalo to the Toronto music scene in the 1960s with Neil
Young, to anti-war protestor and 'draft dodger' during the Vietnam War, to Motown to a
sad demise; _Street Songs_ is a brilliant album); _The Bee Gees: How Can you Mend a
Broken Heart_ (HBO) - say what you will, the Gibb brothers were/are (Barry) major
talents (and I'll readily admit that _Saturday Night Fever_ is a prime 'soundtrack of your
life' album for me).
Also trying to catch up on classics that I never got around to reading, currently _The
Handmaid's Tale." Very OMG in the current context but Margaret Atwood not my favorite
contemporary author. looking forward to the new Colson Whitehead, coming out soon.
 
.הֶּזַה ןַמְּזַל ּונָעיִּגִהְו ּונָמְּיִקְו ּונָיֱחֶהֶׁש ,םָלֹועָה ְךֶלֶמ ,ּוניֵהֹלֱא ָיְי ,הָּתַא ְךּורָּב
TRANSLITERATION

v'higiyanu laz'man hazeh.
TRANSLATION
Blessed are You, Adonai our God, Sovereign of all, who has kept us alive, sustained
us, and brought us to this season.
WHO HAS KEPT US ALIVE, SUSTAINED US, AND BROUGHT US TO THIS SEASON.
 
p.s. Tzedakah (>ethical obligation to be charitable) this RH>Central PA Food Bank; State

text:
A health update first: as you may know from recent posts, I was unable to receive my
treatment last week because my hemoglobin and white blood cell/platelet counts were
too low. I was disappointed and probably did not handle that feeling as well as I could
have but I got with the program relatively quickly. After all, delays in chemo are not
uncommon given the havoc the toxins can wreak on one's system. 
Fortunately, the week's wait was helpful. Although I had to get up early to have my blood
tested before heading off to Yom Kippur morning services -- no fasting for me this year --
the results were, on the whole, encouraging. Both my hemoglobin and platelet counts
had improved, and my magnesium count - another source of some concern - had also
shown improvement. I was too nervous to look at my CA125 number until the following
day, after a wretched, anxious sleep and right before leaving earlier than I'm used to for
chemo (thank you to my stalwart, kind neighbor Janis for driving me there), but that too
is trending in a better direction, decreasing from about 29 last time to about 22 this
time, after a 51 to 29 decrease between the previous two treatments! All of this made
me feel encouraged, to say the least, and Dr. Patel's PA (to whom I apologized for being
snippy the previous week -- this was the Day of Atonement after all) ok'd me for
treatment. 
Somehow treatment day -- 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. -- passes. I slept a bit. Texted friends. Ate
lunch (delicious yogurt my friend David made for me, which I mixed with local honey,
slivered almonds and golden raisins). My very kind, highly efficient nurse, Brianne, talked
about her growing up in a heavily Jewish area in New Jersey, so she knows from chicken
matzah ball soup, bagels and lox, and the high holidays -- a refreshing change in a
community where the HHs usually go completely under the radar. I promised to give her
a copy of my soup/matzah ball recipe, the one I wrote out for Ben with all my tips. My
dear friend Maria picked me up, bearing the turkey chili I had asked her to pick up for me
from Wegman's, and knew to whisk me right to Meyer's dairy for the now customary post-
chemo ice cream treat (Otto's root beer float w/coconut chip ice cream for me, a quart of
ice cream for her to take home). We sat at a picnic table in the sun, catching up and
gabbing, before Maria's ice cream showed some signs of melting. When I got home I was
so tired I crashed on the cozy couch in my sun room/'chemo den,' then spent a relaxing
evening resting and watching t.v.
Today I didn't get out of bed until close to 11, rallied for breakfast, then had to lie down
again. Somehow by 2 p.m. I rallied again, showered, then took a long drive (as I'm wont
to do...) along country backroads, discovering some new ones that will keep me sourced
with delicious brown eggs and freshly made apple cider (unpasteurized, hope that's ok
                       815 / 1.901
for my fragile immune system but it looked so tasty... maybe if I boil it and drink it hot
spiced). Stopped at 'my' antiques store, The Beaten Path; if anything can rouse me, it's
antiquing! Bought a cute blingy baroque-ish trinket holder for $3; a set of five Art Deco
apéritif glasses (great design); and - wait for it - ten brass (?) napkin holders in the shape
of turkeys! These will complement my burgeoning collection of 'Thanksgiviana' - all
bought at antiques stores: vintage Thanksgiving postcards, a cool 1950s set of nesting
(like Russian dolls) turkeys, etc. Now just need to figure out the Thanksgiving plans for
this year...
I hope to feel well enough to have dinner at friends' house tomorrow night to celebrate a
book publication but will see how I feel tomorrow when I wake up. Don't want to overdo
it.
In two weeks I will have a scan (pelvis/abdomen/chest) -- by which point I will be in full-
throttle 'scanxiety' over what it might reveal (or not???) - followed by an appointment
with Dr. Patel the following week to consult about the treatment plan (presumably,
hopefully in consultation w/Dr. Beavis; I will, in fact, insist on it). At this point, I will want
to ask questions about the longer term: how much treatment can my body safely
absorb? At what point will we exhaust treatment options? It is possible -- as a next
appointment was already scheduled for three weeks from now-- that since my current
treatment is working effectively, I will continue with it for a while, or until it is not longer
working.  I need to discuss options, plans. So.much.uncertainty.
Happy, though, to have a three-week break from chemo.
Yom Kippur came and went this past week (Wednesday evening and Thursday). My kind
neighbors and fellow congregants, Carol and Ron, reciprocated my erev Rosh Hasahanah
invite by having me over for erev Yom Kippur dinner - more chicken soup and brisket
was consumed! During services, again, I let my mind wander, making a mental checklist
of 'sins' or infractions I may have committed (more than a few, according to the lists we
recited) and thinking about how I could do better. I could not help but feel a big "UGH"
around one of the holiday's central questions: who will be sealed for another year of life,
who shall not, and by what means might literal or figurative 'death' occur (not just "who
by fire" but also "who will wander...who will suffer"). This brought to mind the Leonard
Cohen song, "Who by Fire:"
And who by fire, who by water,
who in the sunshine, who in the night time,
who by high ordeal, who by common trial,
who in your merry merry month of may,
who by very slow decay,
and who shall I say is calling?
And who in her lonely slip, who by barbiturate,
                       816 / 1.901
who in these realms of love, who by something blunt,
and who by avalanche, who by powder,
who for his greed, who for his hunger,
and who shall I say is calling?
And who by brave assent, who by accident,
who in solitude, who in this mirror,
who by his lady's command, who by his own hand,
who in mortal chains, who in power,
and who shall I say is calling?
As I think I've written before -- and I sincerely hope not to offend the religious convictions
of those more strictly observant than I am -- I don't believe that my fate is "in God's
hands" but will depend, rather, on the wiles of sneaky cancer cells and the ability of my
medical team to beat them back for as long as possible. My "positive attitude" will not
change anything physiologically, as far as I know, but will help me navigate this difficult
journey in terms of my emotions, mental state etc. (w/a shout out to Lexapro and my
therapist). In this regard, the loving support of my family and friends -- especially those
of you dear ones who have been "ride or die" since the very beginning -- wingpeople
extraordinaires -- has been a constant uplifting balm. I am so grateful.
So I found myself sitting in the sanctuary, drawn to certain passages, sound bites and
prayers (Psalm 27 is one that calms me), thinking about the essence of the holiday being
about love on some level, and simply hoping (wishing? praying?) to be here again next
year. I so very much want to be.
I livestreamed the Neilah service on Thursday at 7 p.m. - the climax of the holiday when
"the doors of the ark are closing" and we are sending up the final supplications for the
year ahead, only to be awoken to the urgent matter at hand, ie living, by the blasts of
the shofar. I was really connecting with the service when.... it suddenly cut off (I don't
believe it was a connectivity issue), which was frustrating but oh well. I treated myself to
a Trader Joe's bagel with smoked salmon, an adequate reminder of the delectable spread
we used to have at our synagogue's post-Yom Kippur 'break the fast' (cancelled this year
out of COVID precautions).
Thank you to everyone who texted, sent cards, emailed etc. before/during/after
yesterday's chemo. It makes me feel surrounded by love and caring!
 
 
 
                       817 / 1.901

text:
818 / 1.901
                       819 / 1.901
I will appreciate any and all good thoughts, healing energy etc. you care to send my way
tomorrow when my abdomen, pelvis and chest are scanned beginning at 9 a.m. I
imagine that the scan will be with contrast, which means no breakfast and drinking a lot
of yucky stuff before the scan. It takes a few days for the radiologists here to produce a
report on the scan, and I'll have a disc made so I can send it to Dr. Beavis as well for the
Hopkins' radiologists to read. My inclination is not to look at the report myself before I
can discuss it with the doctors. I can't always parse the technical language, which results
in confusion and anxiety for me, and don't need any excuse to *avoid* knowing the
results for as long as possible. Ignorance = bliss?
The scanning experience tends to be retraumatizing for me. I can picture the alarmed
expressions on the doctors' faces when my (plentiful) cancer first showed up on a scan in
the ER in March or April 2019, and then again a few months ago, also in the ER. I am
anxious about the discrepancy between my still well-put together exterior (everyone
seems to think I look good and I do take some comfort from that fact) and the cellular
havoc that may be occurring underneath/inside it. I hope the cancer hasn't metastasized
further, endangering other organs; well, I'll find out soon enough. I feel a little bit
bloated, but perhaps that's from the butter pecan ice cream cone I indulged in today!
A very wise, compassionate and kind friend helped me get out of a funk last week. I had
sort of worried myself into a corner, trying to figure out if I should devote my energies to
preparing to die (eg downsizing, fine-tuning my will, general putting my affairs in order
etc.) or continuing to live (eg working on the article that's currently engrossing me;
sticking to my current routines etc.); the latter option is of course what my oncologists
have been promoting all along. My friend pointed out that, in some sense, this is the
existential dilemma we all face (ie how to confront the fact that we are mortal and how
to live meaningfully with this fact in mind) but that this dilemma may well seem more
salient in my case because of a potentially (likely?) shorter lifespan. I noted (and she did
too) that I often set up false dichotomies for myself, falling prey to 'either/or' thinking
rather than what she called 'and/and' thinking: giving away about six large boxes of
Ben's baby clothes and toys the other day, for example, does serve the 'downsizing' goal
but also helps create a less cluttered, less encumbered environment for myself that is a
healthier space in which for me to thrive/focus on living. I'm not sure this makes sense. It
may seem very obvious. In any event, I am grateful to my friend for helping me get
'unstuck' (during an always fun jaunt to an antiques store) and also helping me figure
out how I want to focus my energies: quality time with loved ones and some research
projects are two pleasurable/meaningful activities that come to mind immediately.
Although I definitely hope to get to Paris sooner rather than later, I am not particularly
invested in changing my routines dramatically at this point or in completing any sort of
'bucket list.' A day that is wonderfully 'normal' in its routines can seem like a gift these
days. We'll see if that changes over the next stretch, post-scan and discussions with my
                       820 / 1.901
oncologists.
Meanwhile, life continues. The weather has been glorious. Today a dear friend and I
enjoyed lunch outdoors at the arboretum (a bit comically, our peaceful moment was
interrupted by earsplitting construction noise, perhaps in view of a new parking
garage?). There has also been a pleasant visit (also outdoors in the sun) from another
wise friend, an outing to see Los Lobos in concert at the State Theatre (yay to evening
entertainment resuming!), another lunch outdoors at Café Lemont, a friend's birthday
party, and a dinner party with friends (likely a prelude to another antiquing trip this
Saturday), a long drive in the country, and much work on an article. I am so grateful to
know that I will get to see the fall foliage this year; this "season of mists and mellow
fruitfulness" is my favorite.
A p.s. for State College peeps: if anyone reading this works with a housecleaner they
might 'lend' me for occasional or regular visits please let me know. I let go my longtime
housecleaner (whom I was close to) because she wouldn't get vaccinated, and I'm afraid
that ship has sailed now. I started to work with someone else who was very good, but
she found a permanent job of a different type. I am last on a very long waiting list with a
cleaning service. Unfortunately, I don't have the physical wherewithal to do deep
cleaning right now and I really need some help. So please share any bright ideas you
may have!

text:
826 / 1.901
                       827 / 1.901
I greatly appreciate all the shows of concern while I await the results of my scan.
Unfortunately but not unexpectedly really, my scan revealed progression of my cancer. I
received that news from Dr. Beavis via email as I was driving (fortunately, to my
therapist's) and my heart started racing, although the phrase "many options" reversed
that thumping a bit. Tumors in my pelvic/abdominal area have increased in size (by mm)
and several lymph nodes in the abdomen and chest area (and maybe shoulder?) have
enlarged. In better news, there is no visible cancer in my lungs nor in my liver. Dr.
Beavis, with whom I videoconferenced for about an hour yesterday, explained, very
clearly, how and why my CA125 number could have decreased while my cancer
progressed (it has to do with the inability of a protein on the surface of cells to 'express'
itself as the cells undergo mutations -- at least that's what I understood given  my limited
amount of scientific literacy). It is also possible to look well (as I believe I do) while
cancer cells wreak havoc below the surface.  I've got to imagine, though, that a 'put
together' appearance is helpful on some level, as it tends to make me feel more
'collected.'
In her words, my cancer is "not going away" -- something I also understood intuitively
but understand in a more visceral way now. At the same time, I think she said something
about my having "many years." However, I also 'did the math,' with the knowledge that
successive treatments are successful for progressively shorter and shorter amounts of
time -- and the number of treatment options is limited (although many trials are ongoing,
including one involving immunotherapy that may be starting soon). On the other hand,
Dr. Beavis mentioned a current patient who is doing very well on Taxol after a *year.*
Further, she added, ovarian cancer is notoriously "unpredictable."
So...much...uncertainty.
Dr. Beavis (who had conferred with Dr. Patel) presented me with three treatment
options: 1)weekly Taxol (this is one of the drugs with which  I was treated initially),
administered here. Average effectiveness rate in maintaining cancer at current level or
shrinking it: 30-35%. I am now 'platinum resistant' so drugs like cisplatin will no longer
work for me.
2)Taxol (infusion) + Fostamatinib (a type of inhibitor in pill form), administered as part of
a clinical trial conducted by Hopkins. What I gathered is that this would involve weekly
trips to Hopkins for the first month or so; after that, Dr. Patel could administer the Taxol
here while I would be supplied with the pills to take. As this is a clinical trial, there is no
data on effectiveness; it would be a leap of faith. The treatment would not make me any
*worse* off than treatment 1, and might yield a better result. The complicating issue
relates to logistics, travel to/from Baltimore, especially when fatigued etc.
3)Taxol + Avastin (potential success rate in containing or reducing cancer = 50%). There
                       828 / 1.901
is a low (4-5%) risk of a very bad side effect with Avastin: an unfixable bowel perforation.
If that happens, per Dr. Beavis, it can be "life threatening." She has seen such a case
before and it was basically "game over." I think we've all decided that this option should
be 'back pocketed' until the number of acceptable treatment options becomes slimmer.
I had a productive meeting with Dr. Patel this morning as well. He went over the scan
results, examined me, and discussed the options. By the time I saw him, I had already
determined that I was leaning towards the trial. I can make the logistics work (one option
would be to base myself in NY during the period of weekly commutes to Baltimore).
Given this, I want to go for the potentially more hopeful option. Tomorrow I will speak by
phone with a Hopkins nurse associated with the trial who will answer all my questions.
My main concern is that the trial might end before I have to a chance to (potentially)
benefit from it (although no one has said for sure that this might be the case); it's been
running for two years already and once a certain number of patients (subjects?) are
enrolled, the trial may end. However, I was sent the consent form today and Dr. Beavis
presented this trial as a viable option, so I'm crossing my fingers that it will be. She left
the choice between options 1) and 2) up to me. Dr. Patel recommends the trial.
On Taxol, I will lose my hair again (time for a new wig and more cute hats/caps), my
neuropathy will probably worsen (perhaps my fingers will be affected, which would be a
drag), and I'll be fatigued (the fatigue the first time around was acute, but maybe it
won't be as bad this time).
Please disabuse yourselves of the idea that my cancer may go into permanent remission
or even 'be cured.' It won't (how long does Willa have left -- a new parlor game?).
Ovarian cancer in Dr. Beavis' words is "insidious." Did you know that cancer cells can
generate new blood vessels to feed off?? I didn't. If that isn't insidious I don't know what
is.
Please don't feel sorry for me, as I don't feel sorry for myself. Well, maybe on occasion I
have moments of nearly unbearable FOMO. But they are matched by swells of immense
gratitude, and a weird yet fleeting *liberating* feeling after speaking with Dr. Beavis and
realizing that I'll have time to organize and orchestrate this next chapter, in all respects.
And I look forward to more fun, creativity, time with loved ones, giggles. At least that's
how I'm feeling today. 
I do feel a need to create a safe, calm, protective bubble around myself. This is why I
may undertake some 'triaging' of thoughts, sights, acquaintances etc. that are inimical in
relation to this goal.
I am incredibly grateful for my medical team. And for my State College support team,
and wonderful friends and family near and far. I told Dr. Beavis that I always feel better
after speaking with her. She, in turn, told me that she always feels better after speaking
                       829 / 1.901
with *me.* Amazing!
This post may be rather disjointed, reflecting my state right now. My mind has been
racing and it's hard to turn it off. I have a lot to figure out. Was hoping to spend the
weekend at my brother and family's country home in the Catskills but will now take a
rain check (perhaps literally as a rainy weekend is in store, which may thwart my fall
foliage oohing and aahing ambitions) for a hopefully not far removed weekend. 
So I'm on the 'narrow bridge' again. And the most important thing, per Rabbi Nachman of
Breslau, is *not to give in to one's despair.*

text:
Here's as much of an update as I can muster (or muddle through) at present:
1)I've decided to opt for the clinical trial at Hopkins, which is the most *potentially*
promising option, although it's also entirely possible that I'll see no benefits from the
treatment. I'm banking on 30-35% odds, from what I've been told.
2)*If* Aetna authorizes my claim, next Thursday I will be at Hopkins for a)blood work (I
think?); b)a physical with Dr. Beavis; c)and an EKG (?). This physical screening is a
prelude to treatment starting the following week. While the nurse working with patients
enrolled in the trial conveyed to me that my claim was 'pending,' when I called Aetna
(think phone trees, recordings, long stretches of Muzak etc.), I was told that they had no
record of a claim being filed on my behalf. It turns out that Dr. Beavis needs/needed to
submit her signed notes on my case to Aetna. I very much hope she did so today. That
will leave a mere few days for Aetna to review my claim. If I don't receive authorization
by Wednesday, everything will have to be pushed back a week, meaning I will have gone
without treatment for seven weeks, a stressful prospect (and I have a feeling those
sneaky cancer cells draw some hidden power from my stress). I have no reason at this
point to think Aetna will not authorize my claim (the part not covered by Hopkins in the
context of a clinical trial). I just hope it happens soon.
3)*If* Aetna authorizes my claim, I will start treatment the following week, the 27th/28th.
On the 27th I will have a needle biopsy of one of my tumors, as I agreed to participate in
                       832 / 1.901
a second study in which tumors are being studied to assess which treatments are most
or least effective for specific tumors. Someone must be with me to accompany me after
the biopsy. On the 28th I will have treatment. I have no idea what I'll feel like afterwards,
what side effects may hit me etc. One uncertainty among many.
4)I spent about an hour on the phone with a lovely sounding nurse, Justin, who will be my
'nurse coordinator' for the duration of the trial. He (re)convinced me that the nurses at
Hopkins are gems. I spent another hour on the phone with another nurse who set up my
biopsy, did some intake, and answered my questions. And I spent more time on the
phone with the housing coordinator at Hopkins, who provided info about longer-term
housing options. Joanne's affect was nurturing and caring (but also no-nonsense) and we
'hit it off' as well as one can with a stranger during a short phone call. We had both
received the COVID booster the day before and were suffering through flu-like symptoms
(awful in my case, but that's another story). She made me *promise* her that I would
have a caregiver with me during each of my trips to Hopkins. She also said I sounded
stressed (on point there) and made me promise her that I'd lie on the couch and relax
with a cup of tea once i got off the phone with her.
5)PA, MD or NY? Logistics, logistics. I'm still muddling through where to base myself
during the month when I'll be making weekly trips to Hopkins (after that it will be
monthly trips). Per one of my personal mantras: "Everything in life is a tradeoff," in this
case  between comfort and convenience. I've more or less ruled out State College,
except for the next two weeks, because it's a four-hour drive from Baltimore, the
weather may start to turn rough next month (especially through those last miles of
mountain passes), and I can't predict how I'll feel/if I'll feel up to driving after treatment.
While Baltimore makes a lot of sense in terms of convenience (and a few people whose
opinions I trust are lobbying for that option), I'm leaning towards NY and my network of
beloved family and friends there. I have an image of myself alone in a hotel room in
Baltimore, should I spend the month there, sort of withering emotionally because cut off
from 'my people.' I really don't do well in that type of situation (although a few kindly
souls might decide to come visit me). In any event, every week I will need most likely
need to spend one night in Baltimore because of the way the appointments will be set
up. If it happens in any given week that I simply feel too tired to return to NY, I can
always stay overnight at my trusted Residence Inn John Hopkins Medical Center, where I
have stayed many times. Hopkins has some longer-term housing options for people
receiving ongoing care at Hopkins, but there are some restrictions that I may not meet.
Also, I had wanted to be in NY in Nov. for a few compelling reasons: my friend Mitchel's
visit from France; my friend Laurent's photography show opening; two exhibits at the
Jewish Museum, seeing other friends and family members. I have no idea how energetic
-- or not -- I'll feel, but ideally I'd like to try to be available for these occasions. On the
other hand, I am hoping to attend a family bar-mitzvah in Baltimore on Nov. 18th..
                       833 / 1.901
Isn't this simply thrilling?!? I'd much rather be sitting poolside on an an island drinking a
cocktail, enjoying a café crême in Paris (or doing just about anything else) but here we
are... and I will feel *very* grateful for the insurance hurdle to be cleared and for
treatment at Hopkins to start.
So here's my pitch: *if* I am indeed based in NY and in weekly treatment at Hopkins in
November, would any of my NY pals or fam be up to making a trip (likely involving an
overnight, *maybe* even two but more likely one -- a Th/Fr, a W/Th, or a W/Th/Fr) with
me? Given that I'll be receiving Taxol (aka the Red Devil) and also given the lovely side
effects I might expect (diarrhea, neuropathy, etc.), I am somewhat wary of making the
trip alone. I am happy to cover all expenses and hopefully there'd be some giggles along
the way. I was very touched today when my ex-brother-in-law (w/whom I had lunch
during his visit with Michael) offered to accompany me to B'more if it meshes with his
schedule (Thursday is apparently a good day for him). I know that many of you might like
to, but have other commitments and of course I understand that (so no need to respond
in that case). I'd be most interested in hearing, instead, from those of you for whom this
might actually be feasible. I know I can count on my mother one week (thank you,
Mom!).
Meanwhile, I am doing ok moodwise, keeping busy, enjoying time with friends, taking
drives, working on an article I feel good about (plus a book review + a book manuscript
evaluation). That's the best medicine for me. Bought a blingy green ring at an antiques
store. Enjoyed a Latin Festival downtown with my friend Clare, Went to an outstanding
concert with my friend Jackie by a choral group I adore, Voces8. Please listen to
"Timshel" below and understand why I appreciate this song of comfort. Thank you, John,
for the very last rhubarb of the season (in October!!), Michael for the carrots, Bénédicte
for the sweets and the magnificent vintage Whitman's chocolate tin adorned with
Mucha's Sarah Bernhardt, Heather B. for your handwritten notes, Jeff for the catch-up
call,  Julie for the long overdue catch-up Zoom, Scott for the yummy chili, and many
others for texts, emails and calls of concern. "In spite of everything, I still believe that
people are really good at heart."
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jbMFhW-y1Ew

text:
Greetings from Baltimore.
My 'teal sister' Rhonda Gold, whom I never met but knew only through social media as
an OC survivor treated at Hopkins, died a day or two ago, in her late sixties, after a six or
seven year bout with OC. I've been wearing the pendant Rhonda sent me bearing the
cancer bow, two teal colored stones, and the words "Chazak ve'ematz" ("Be strong and
of good courage"), from the Book of Joshua. Someone had given it to her one Rosh
Hashanah and she entrusted it to me, as I hope to entrust it, eventually, to another OC
survivor. I wish I had met her. She seemed like an extraordinary, vibrant woman, like me
most 'afilliative' (to use a word my therapist sometimes uses to describe me). On her
                       836 / 1.901
Facebook page today, a quote from the 13th-century Persian poet Rumi: "Goodbyes are
only for those who love with their eyes. Because for those who love with heart and soul
there is no such thing as separation."
I'm in Baltimore for a few physical screening appointments prior to my first treatment
next week (I hope) as part of a clinical trial at Hopkins. This being said, Hopkins appears
to have been very late submitting the precertification request to my insurance company
so it hasn't been approved yet (frankly, I don't even know if it's even been submitted).
Aetna needs to clear everything by next Wednesday, when I have a biopsy (I agreed to
enroll in a second study that involves studying tumor samples). Aggravation.
Let me apologize off the bat to those whom I might have 'left hanging' as I try to work
out complicated logistics for the next month, when I'll be travelling to Baltimore once a
week for treatment, most likely from New York. My focus has been on getting the first
one or two weeks set up (a complicated endeavor in itself) but I promise to be in touch
asap with those most generous family members and friends who have offered rides,
accompaniment to Baltimore, housing, and meals/errands/miscellaneous. Much as I
treasure my independence, I unfortunately can't make the next month (or more) work
without help, so I am extremely grateful for the generous responses. Thank you.
I also owe some emails and will try to get back to everyone asap!
Plans, plans, plans. Plans will keep me busy this next month. And busy-ness is a bulwark
against anxiety, depression, and worry. Dr. Beavis said: "I can't give you a cure, but I can
give you a plan." So I grasp at plans and their myriad components, hopefully. "These
fragments I have shored against my ruins."
I am feeling ok, with some slight discomfort in my abdomen/pelvic area and back. I am
very eager to begin treatment before my cancer has any more time to grow/spread, and
equally eager to assess whether treatment is working as soon after that as possible. If
it's not, we're on to the next plan. That *might* be a clinical trial at Memorial Sloan-
Kettering, if they can offer me a potentially (more) effective treatment or trial. Since I
will spend most of November in NY, Dr. Beavis suggested I schedule a consult there,
which I find a great idea. She has already sent a gyn onc surgeon she deems 'terrific' my
information and I hope to contact her asap. I'll see Dr. Beavis tomorrow and she can
advise.
I had such a pleasant drive down here. It's really not arduous at all: perhaps 3.5 hours
driving time. A gorgeous fall day with the foliage colors becoming deeper, more vibrant
and varied the further south I drove. I stopped for lunch at Alvaro's (alvarobread.com), a
'real deal' Italian bakery that has long been my midway point/pit stop between State
College and Baltimore/DC. It's a small place on a corner in the historical downtown area
of Harrisburg (which I think they call 'Uptown?'), casual, full of state government
                       837 / 1.901
employees and locals who appear to be regular customers. A few tables with umbrellas
outside. The 'nonna' holds down the fort in the kitchen, producing the mouth-watering
daily specials; I dug into delicious soft meatballs in sauce with a side of homemade bread
that I dipped in the sauce, then bought stuffed shells and sausage to take with me for
dinner tonight, along with a hefty portion of pastries (a cannoli, an eclair, a mini
sfogliatelle and a few cookies). It is always shocking to see the housing inequities in
Harrisburg (and of course Baltimore, much of it right near the JH Medical Center), block
upon block of dilapidated houses along with lovely renovated Victorians and a glistening
Susquehanna waterfront.
I'm back at my 'home away from home' here in Baltimore: the Marriott Residence Inn
Johns Hopkins Medical Center, where I've stayed many times. Many JHMC patients stay
here and the staff is kindly, the rooms ultra-clean and quiet, the free breakfast copious.
The top floor restaurant with the great view (my friend Sandy, mom, Ethan and Ben will
remember it) apparently did not survive the pandemic, but I ordered a small salad from
the bar downstairs. While I'd prefer not to remember some of my previous post-surgery
or post-procedure visits here, tonight I am feeling strong physically and mentally, ready
to move forward. I continue to be blessed to "walk with good companions."
If all goes as planned, I'll drive back to State College tomorrow and can't wait to hug Ben
and Sammi, who will be arriving for the weekend on Friday. I'll return here next Tuesday
for my biopsy Wednesday morning and treatment and other appointments on Thursday.
As promised, I will be in touch asap (certainly once I return to SC) with the kind
friends/family members who have offered me rides to/from Baltimore as well as help 'on
the ground' (I must have a 'caregiver' with me for the biopsy and likely for treatment as
well). Then back to SC for  a few days before driving to New York with my friend Deb, to
stay until.... Thanksgiving? That's the tentative plan, although it's always possible I may
only go so far with the trial if it doesn't prove effective. If I have adverse side effects,
moreover, it is also possible, that we might stop the trial for a week or two and then
restart. So...much...uncertainty. But in the meantime....plans!
Go figure that just as my cancer progresses my social/friend life in SC starts to get
interesting, maybe more interesting than it's been in years as I always felt that my 'real'
friends were elsewhere -- in NY, or Paris, or Boston etc. But the past months and, I
suppose, 2.5 years have brought some wonderful people into my PA life and have helped
solidify existing friendships. Wonder if that's coincidence -- or not (I think not). A jaunt to
Duncansville PA along gorgeous backroads with my 'antiquing posse' was lots of fun last
weekend, as was a visit from and great convo w/Mark, a State College friend who moved
to Cali, as was Thai take-out lunch in a cute park in Lemont w/my friend Maria, as was
dinner with three smart, stylish, kind women friends, Kathryn, Cheryl and Sandy (a Paris
trip was discussed....), as was a long catch-up visit with my friend/colleague Benedicte
(don't have my 'accent-friendly' keyboard with me), who brought me a vintage Witman's
candy box adorned with a Mucha image of Sarah Bernhardt -- which B. had loaded up
                       838 / 1.901
with all sorts of sweet treats (VIchy pastilles and such) from France. Looking forward to
(her) bday lunch w/my friend Helen on Monday. And did I mention lunch outdoors at the
Ale House, in the mellow sunshine, w/ex-bro in law Bruce?
I'm a lucky girl. :)

text:
846 / 1.901
                       847 / 1.901
Just a quick update: I am back in Baltimore to begin treatment this week, if all goes as
planned. My main hopes for the coming weeks are that a)the treatment is effective in
stabilizing or reversing my cancer growth (this will likely only be ascertained in eight
weeks, when I have a scan, provided I do well in the trial>see b] and c]); b)the side
effects of the treatment are not too harsh, debilitating, and potentially irreversible (I'll be
monitored very closely here); and c)related to b]: I can withstand the side effects without
undue delays in my treatment.
I think I'm 'just' anxious. I've never participated in a clinical trial, never had chemo
administered at Hopkins, never done this weekly commuting thing, never had my
treatment become *such* a full-time job, never met any of the staff associated with the
trial etc. The presence, physical or virtual, of 'good companions' (angels?) helps
immensely.
My friend Sandy and I gabbed for 3.5 hours in the car to Baltimore, so the trip went very
quickly. We reminisced about two previous times she drove me to Baltimore, including
our getting lost trying to find a lunch spot in/near Harrisburg and winding up at a very
strange sandwich shop ("Sandwich Man") on the outskirts of the capital that was pretty
much a dump but that had very attractive, Maxfield Parrish-type prints on the wall in
beautiful frames -- a weird contrast!
I loaded up a Zabar's freezer bag with food this morning to tide me over for my three
nights here. As I mentioned in a previous blog, the hotel restaurant closed as did my
other go-to place around the corner, Atwater's. The neighborhood's sketchy and I don't
feel like going farther afield, although I've discovered a few good restaurants during my
previous trips.  I can't eat anything past 5:45 tomorrow morning in preparation for my
biopsy, to which my college friend David will escort me, picking me up after the
procedure (he's also 'on duty' on Thursday). Despite (because of?) the circumstances, I
am looking forward to seeing him! He nicely came to visit me in the hospital after my big
debulking surgery in May 2019. 
Nurse Justin left me a voicemail this afternoon to let me know that Aetna has approved
coverage of my treatment at Hopkins - phew.
I'm comfortable in my 'home away from home,' the Marriott Residence Inn Johns Hopkins
Medical Center. The staff is especially kindly as many of their guests are Hopkins
patients. Although there always seem to be a few things awry (today: no tv remote, no
makeup remover wipes, no antiseptic wipes), the rooms are clean and quiet, and I'm
comfortable here.
It was wonderful to see Ben and Sammi this past weekend, albeit somewhat briefly (I'll
                       848 / 1.901
see them soon in NY). Michael grilled hamburgers and hot dogs for us on Saturday night,
an annual tradition. The kids came for brunch on Sunday and helped me with a few
things. They went to the football game on Saturday; there were multiple overtimes and
apparently PSU played miserably. I listened to a few mn of the game on the radio, while
driving around the countryside looking for fresh apple cider and maple syrup (both of
which I found).
Thanks to the 'angels' who sent me texts this a.m. w/well wishes. I appreciated the
sendoff. 
I'll end with a video of Dr. Beavis, whom I write so much about. She lived in England until
she was twelve, and has retained a slight British accent. I won't see her this trip but will
be examined by the oncologist running the clinical trial, Dr. Stephanie Gaillard (I believe
she is French, or of French heritage! We'll soon find out).
Dr. Anna Beavis | Gynecologic Oncologist - YouTube

text:
851 / 1.901
                       852 / 1.901
Today felt a bit 'unproductive' as the biopsy I was scheduled to have as part of a second
clinical trial did not go forward as planned. The nodule that was to be biopsied,
pinpointed on both a sonogram and then another type of scan to get a better view, was
too small to be useful (of course, I was not unhappy to learn about its small size!). There
are other nodules/tumors in my abdominal/pelvic area, but their location was too
problematic to be of use: one is right near my bowel (which makes me anxious), another
near 'surgical clips' placed during one of my surgeries. While I appreciated the prospect
of helping other women, even myself, by contributing cancerous tissue to this clinical
trial (to be injected into mice along with different types of anti-cancer medications), I
was also extremely relieved that the interventional radiologists were not about to take
any chances trying to perform a needle or core biopsy on me. As the no-nonsense, fifty-
something woman radiologist reminded me, in an appealing accent of some sort
(Iranian?): "First do no harm. That is our guiding principle." She explained that
proceeding would not be "productive," as the team would not be able to obtain the
needed sample; this does happen sometimes. Thank you, Hopkins radiologists, for not
risking my health by jabbing at a cm or so large nodule or risking a biopsy near a
sensitive organ. And this type of wise, skilled care is why I make seven hour round trips
to be treated by the world-class physicians at JHMC!
In the context of my visit, it's more important to me, though, that my actual treatment,
scheduled for tomorrow, go well: four appointments beginning at 7:45 (!). I feel
somewhat anxious. Fingers crossed.
The day was salvaged by spending time with my college friend David, who nicely came
and met me at the Residence Inn, waited (briefly, it turned out) while I was prepped for
the biopsy, and then walked me back to the hotel after we had coffee (and, for me, the
first meal of the day as I was off food and drink as of 5:45 this morning). We had such a
nice conversation that ranged over his interesting family history (a great-grandfather
who was an artist of note in Spain, whose fortunes were buffeted by both the Spanish-
American War and the Spanish Civil War, which led him to time in Paris), Harvard
reminiscences, retirement plans, work, family, COVID, Baltimore and more. We have
known each other since we were eighteen! I found his presence comforting; a clinical
psychologist by training, he's a kind, empathic, and steady person. He may meet me
again tomorrow if I feel I need a shoulder to lean on returning to my hotel after a day of
treatment -- I may, though, be able to get an Uber or even walk if I feel up to it. I have no
idea how I'll feel, but fatigued is a safe bet.
I rested for a while when I returned to the hotel around 2 p.m. and then Ubered to a
great Italian bakery (you may have picked up that I have a strange obsession with old
school Italian pastry shops), Vaccaro's, in Baltimore's Little Italy. I enjoyed a delicious
cappuccino and bought a few cookies. I'll try to get to bed early to rise by 6:30 or so
                       853 / 1.901
tomorrow.
