And so, while my world has been somewhat upended and my life expectancy potentially
cut short, I am feeling preternaturally calm and content. Strange, eh?  I hardly slept, but
my body was still and relaxed. I planned out a modest bday party for myself and pretty
much wrote this blog in my head. On to a few bills (there are many....). Must get off my
social media devices at night. Ben ordered a new reading lamp for me and I plan to
replace those wasteful bedtime hours with more reading every night -- Whitehead,
Shteyngart....
Be well, everyone.
label: neutral

text:
Things are moving forward. All in all, it's been a pretty good week. Here are some
updates:
Monday (2/7): Ben and I had a bit of an emotional parting. I started to get anxious about
                    
how I would fare on my own, as did he, despite his herculean efforts to set everything up
expertly for me (meds, appointments etc.). He and Sammi took incredible care of me for
a week (I was so happy to send them heart-shaped boxes of Jacques Torres truffles as a
modest thank you). We worked through our tears and anxieties and got to a better place
before Michael came to pick Ben up for lunch and then take him to the Megabus.
It turns out I've been fine. Shortly after Ben left, I worked with my therapist (online) and
part of what I got out of it was a revised attitude towards my sleeping, realizing that I do
not, in fact, need to be awake through the night to maximize my time (terribly
counterproductive as I'm usually tired the next day). Yet, the thoughts keep coming as I
drift in and out of galaxies. My friend Maria came by later to deliver unsweetened
cranberry juice for a minor UTI that, thankfully, now seems to be resolved with a few
days of antibiotics. And there was a lot of couch resting and snoozing.
Tuesday (2/8): A locksmith came in the morning to rekey my doors, which I felt
necessary. Later, the LpN came by, just to take vitals. From 4-6 a very nice woman
named Abbye was here; she's a local woman who does errands, tasks around the house,
things I might be too tired to do right now. She washed my dishes, made my bed, ran a
bunch of errands for me (dry cleaners, framing shop, Ulta). She's sort of the 'missing link'
in terms of my care right now, and is extremely helpful. Lots of couch resting and
snoozing.
Wednesday (2/9): My house was thoroughly cleaned by my two house cleaners and is
getting back to being a very calm, hospitable environment. That took a few hours. In the
afternoon, someone from PT came and we did some exercises. I am doing very well on
that front, don't even use a walker, use a cane sometimes when I go out. I lack some
strength but am working on it (sorta). I am also throwing out/purging/paring as much as I
can from my house; it's time. Ben and I threw away three massive boxes of my class
notes and I've finally gotten the top of my desk all clear. This will continue; it's crucial to
my sanity. Lots of resting and snoozing in my sunroom, so peaceful.
One day (I forget which), Isabelle and Vinni, my dear grad school friends, sent me four
*pints* of the most delicious ice cream packed in dry ice, from a place in Maine called
Rococo (self-indulgent ice cream as its name suggests). Maine Whoopie Pie, Cardamom
Chai, Pear Caramelized Ginger (my favorite) and Goat Cheese Blueberry Chambord are
all heavenly! So sweet and thoughtful of them; they were encouraging me to eat ice
cream for breakfast, too!
Thursday (2/10): OT came for a visit. Two takeaways were a)to buy a foam mat for my
bathroom that depresses with my footprints and does not move around when I exit the
shower (which I'm able to do) and b)keep bowls and dishes I need at a handy reach
(currently not the case). Later that afternoon, Abbye came over for about two hours and
did more errands and tasks for me (changing the water in my flowers, the vases are
                    
heavy etc.). Lots of resting in my sunroom. Ben and I had cooked all my meals for the
week (a pot roast with udon noodles, corn, broccoli and Thai-ish bbq sauce; butternut
squash; butternut squash soup etc.) so I was set on that front. Taking many meds
throughout the day, including the last of the Oxycodone for pain and a tapering down
steroid, Decadron.
Thursday (I think) my friend Deb Guerrero brought me lots of goodies from my
hometown! These included 'viennoiseries' from a bakery across from her place in
Chelsea; a Breads Bakery babka (the grail...); two Breads Bakery loaf cakes (to be shared
on my birthday) *and* a lasagna from her husband Tony, who is a great cook (I had it
last night; very tasty indeed). Deb and I drove to NY together not too long ago and we
have kids around the same age. I hope we'll be able to do that again sometime; we had
fun.
To be continued now  - this link is acting up....
label: fear

text:
Friday (2/11): two-hour consult with radiation oncology at MNMC (the hospital), with a
nice nurse and then the very young radiation oncologist, Dr. Veejay Patel (no relation). I
did not come away entirely happy, and tomorrow and Monday I need to get to emails,
likely with Dr. Bettegowda at Hopkins, Dr. Beavis and perhaps Dr. (Nilesh) Patel.
Everything with the nurse was fine: we reviewed my meds, went over the procedure for
radiation. This coming Monday I'll have a CT scan at the hospital; then it will take about
7-10 days for the oncologist and physicist (!) to read and study the images, make a
model (I think) and work out the details of my plan (schedule, duration, targeted
locations etc.). The nurse showed me a positively medieval, Monty-Pythonesque looking
mesh helmet that I have to wear and that then gets bolted into another surface during
radiation. The better news is that the radiation treatments are fairly short, nothing like
the 30 mn or so I needed to hold still during MRIs. These treatments, it seems, are more
like a few minutes. Potential side effects; hair loss (done deal already), nausea and
vomiting, fatigue; skin rashes, burns; etc. Nothing I haven't contended with before (other
than the skin issues).
What annoyed me is lack of consultation/coordination among my doctors, specifically
between Dr. V. Patel and the others. He told me what he wanted to do for me and what
he planned to do but I made him assure me that he would talk to Dr. Bettegowda first.
Frankly, I thought that a different set of mets needed to be radiated than the ones he
proposed but I could be wrong; obviously, we all need to be on the same page about
this. And I am hoping he has read my file very carefully (at one point, he alluded to it
being very 'thick' but I am worried that he hasn't read it carefully). *He* asked *me* if I
was supposed to get full brain radiation -- dear God... Also, they do not use gamma knife
technology at MNMC, which I know to be quite cutting edge (pun intended?). Part of me
wants to bag MNMC and be treated at Hopkins, but there is a real advantage in my
receiving treatment here, not having to make 7 hour round trips to Baltimore; being able
to be in my home, near my friends, in my comfort zone. Dr. Bettegowda was fine with
me being treated here in State College -- as long as the treatment is good (of course
they do this all the time at MNMC but I am anxious).
[In all honesty, what Dr. V. Patel described as treatment did not sound that bad: 3-5
treatments (but there again I thought that contradicted what I had been told], a good
prognosis (but how does that jive with my life expectancy?). Maybe I'm so used to
arduous treatments that I'm surprised this seems so 'lite.' I'm confused and need more
info, which I'll get. :(
So voilà. I am letting things 'sit' as nothing happens over the weekend, Dr. V. Patel said
he'd be in touch with Dr. Bettegowda and I currently feel ok (sleep still a bit wonky, but
improving) Tomorrow I'll start crafting emails. Dr. Beavis can always 'quarterback' for me
even if she's not a neurologist. I worked a lot of this plan out with my trusted  and kind
                    
friend Jackie, who was kind enough to drive me to both appointments yesterday, with a
cappuccino stop in between. Needless to say, I needed this help! 
A bit unnerving. I came home and rested for a while. Then it was time to go to Gray's
Woods to have my sutures removed by Dr. Damaske's nurse practitioner. This proceeded
smoothly and I'm glad to no longer have stitches (you can see my 'before' picture above
- not for the faint of heart....). After the suture removal, I climbed into bed at home and
took a nap.
****
Maria is coming over in a while and we'll take a short jaunt into the country on this pretty
day. Thanks too to Monique for the treats and to my friends Cheryl and Sandy (and Jon
and Ron) for the opportunity to have a delicious Valentine's Day meal from the
Hummingbird Room tonight. I wish I could join you but need to be 'under wraps' at home
for just a few weeks more while I recover. And Mary, thank you for the MBB gift card! I
am dreaming of fresh fish from Maine, which I will make with za'atar and preserved
lemons (easy enough). And to everyone else for texts, emails, well wishes. I hope not to
have forgotten anyone. I am so grateful.
I guess I'm progressing further into one of my nine lives (I actually don't think I've had
that many), this one as a cancer patient. Although I hate any thought of myself as an
'invalid' ("in-valid??"), I do need to be a bit dependent right now.  And this new stage as
a cancer patient is simply...different than the previous ones. It's becoming somewhat
easier for me to sit with the dichotomies and contradictions, the 'double lives' (doubles
vies>W of the Perec novel's title).
label: fear

text:
Because there was some concern about the confusion surrounding my radiation
treatment options, including seeming lack of coordination among members of my
medical team, here's a brief update:
Drs. V. Patel and Bettegowda spoke by phone and I feel much better about things now.
At this point, I am leaning about 98% towards 3-5 stereotactic radiation treatments here
in State College, mainly or exclusively directed at my cerebellum. The confusion over
what to radiate stems from the fact that there is another tiny spot that *may or may not
be cancer* in my brain as opposed to what Dr. Patel called an 'artefact;' they will know
more once they study CT imaging I had done this morning at the hospital. Regarding
gamma/cyberknife: according to Dr. Patel, there is *no data* indicating that
gamma/cyberknife is a *better* technology; whether or not to have it available is an
institutional choice. The technique he will use will accomplish the same thing, and he is
hopeful that my cancer will not recur there (but one never knows, I suppose...). And then
it will be back to chemo to treat my ovarian cancer: whee!! Dr. Bettegowda is completely
on the same page as Dr. Patel. So that's the plan. Full-brain radiation is not in the
picture; it will be very directed. I had written to Dr. Beavis asking her to 'quarterback' for
me, then walked that back a bit after my time at the hospital this morning. She's aware
of the situation, though, and may insert herself into the conversation somehow. My last
email will likely be to Dr. Bettegowda (to whom I've already written a thank you note),
just to make sure Dr. Patel's reporting was completely accurate. Each of these
communications does take something out of me as I try to recuperate. Each is stressful
but as mentioned I feel considerably relieved now.
This morning I was at the hospital for a few hours for CT imaging and to have my
'helmet' made in preparation for radiation. Initially, it felt like a lovely spa experience (or
at least I imagined it so), with the warm plastic goop pressed into my face but then it
became less fun. Please see the pics of the personalized Darth Vader helmet I'll be
wearing during radiation, bolted into a table. Oy!
 
 
Photos
label: joy

text:
Many thanks to all for your expressions of care and concern. Herewith, a few updates on
the week:
Tuesday (2/15) - My friend Martina was kind enough to take me to my routine
mammogram appointment at Gray's Woods in the morning. Happy to report that that
exam was normal, thankfully. Another cancer would have been a kick in the head (no
wait, I already had that one...). Martina drove me to get a coffee after that and to CVS to
pick up a prescription. And we stopped by the liquor store so I could pick up a few items
to share on my birthday (I am abstaining from alcohol these days; if my doctors ok it, I
might have a small glass of something on my bday). Abbye came by in the afternoon
and ran some errands for me, which is a tremendous help. Frame shop to digitize old
family photos etc....
Wednesday (2/16) - Physical therapy came in the morning and we did some exercises. I
know I should be grateful for weekly visits (which are almost over) from PT, OT and LpN,
but to be honest sometimes I find them disruptive (the therapists often call you on the
day, wanting to come over shortly after that) and tedious, and I'm not too keen on the
therapists themselves.
In the afternoon, my friend Jessica drove me to Spectacles, in part to deal with a new
                    
problem as I try valiantly to address various health kinks: I have an *ulcer* (!) on/in my
eye, which explains why my eye has felt very irritated and scratched recently. Dr.
Damaske's PA had given me antibiotic drops for this but they did not help as this *open
sore* on my eye needs to be treated like a virus (even though it's an infection). I now
have new drops that are helping but my eye is not yet fully better. I have already
returned to the optometrist once for her to check the eye and will return again on
Monday. My eye is healing, but has not yet healed completely. It's truly annoying and
uncomfortable, although I'm not letting it hinder me too much. I may also check in with
the ophthalmologist next week. Once the eye is healed, I'll proceed with getting my new
prescription tweaked and filled, new frames etc. I hadn't seen the optician (Joseph, the
optometrist Julie's husband) in a while. He's French (and Jewish, half-Ashkenazi half-
Sephardic as I recall, last name Haloua) and we always enjoyed chatting in French (this
week was no exception). After I filled him in on my cancer, he shared that he has
epilepsy -- grand mal seizures - and we agreed that serious illness can lead to
unexpected perspectives on just about everything.
Thursday (2/17): Stephanie, the occupational therapist, came by for a short while. She
gave me some "Thera-Putty" akin to Silly Putty, which keeps my hands and fingers
supple. This is actually helpful as my hands had been cramping up while doing mundane
chores like writing cards, putting on a necklace etc.
Friday (2/18): It turned out to be a somewhat hectic day, by my current standards. I
spent about two hours or so in the morning making soup (and standing the whole time),
which I hadn't yet done since my surgery, and which did tire me out a bit, but not
excessively. But now I have a good week's worth of meals or supplements, so it was a
worthwhile and enjoyable activity. I made harira, a North African/Middle Eastern
vegetarian soup/stew that I'd made once before and that's very tasty and nutritious:
onions, celery, carrots, crushed tomatoes, chicken broth, turmeric, cumin, salt, pepper,
harissa spice (and paste), coriander, parsley, chick peas, lentils. I usually add more
harissa paste and maybe a dollop of sour cream when I'm eating it and might serve with
a piece of crusty sourdough bread from the Bellefonte Bread Baker. Yum.
Brian the physical therapist called and of course wanted to come over immediately. I
forestalled him a bit before he came by, led me in some exercises, and then pretty much
signed me out in terms of further treatment with him. My optometrist called and wanted
to look at my eye a few hours after that, so I set that up including ride etc. (thank you,
Jackie!). Abbye came by at 3:00, took my laptop to have a new battery installed (an
important errand I haven't been able to get to) and to pick up four delicious fresh fish
fillets from Maine Bay and Berry for me (thank you, Mary, for the gift certificate). For
dinner, I baked a salmon fillet with za'atar and preserved lemon + asparagus + a
delicious potato pancake my friend Helen had picked up at a deli in CT when she was on
a business trip (thank you, Helen, and for the half-sours and the cappuccino at my
doorstep!). Abbye also washed some of the remaining soup making dishes, pots etc. and
                    
made my bed. She's the essential 'missing link' in my care, at least for the next few
weeks as I continue to gather strength.
I also talked to my friend Clare and we planned a little outing for later today, to a
consignment store we both enjoy called "Arcadian." Looks a bit gray and wintry out
there, but I am glad to be here!!!
Last night I continued the Sidney Poitier films series I'm curating for myself; I really don't
know why I hadn't seen more of his films aside from "To Sir, with Love" (which I had seen
several times). I fully understand now why he was so lauded at his death (and before);
what an amazing actor. I was engrossed in all of these and can recommend (*****) them
all: Lilies of the Field, A Patch of Blue, A Raisin in the Sun, To Sir, with Love, and In in the
Heat of the Night. Anything else I should watch?
Overall, I feel pretty well. I still need a lot of rest; my body gets tired, but I am sleeping
better (although often in several 'chunks'). I am grateful for the reprieve as the doctors
continue to study my brain imaging and work out my radiation plan. I expect radiation
will begin late this week or the beginning of the following. Once my radiation oncologist
clears me, moreover, I need to get back to chemo, likely weekly Taxol (as before the
brain episode) for the time being. I am actually more concerned/nervous about the
chemo than the radiation, but I'm putting it out of my mind for now. Basically, as my
chemo treatment options become fewer, it is likely that they'll become slightly riskier.
More on that -- but not now. The sun just came out! And I'm off to shower, to have a bowl
of harira, and to the consignment store.
Very grateful thanks for all the generous 'acts of affirmation' this week (Paula for the
divine-smelling rose spa treatments; Melissa for the lovely card; Zia for the call and
email>I'll get back to you, especially after Ethan just ran into you on the UWS!; Heather
for the VDay card; Gay for the card; Mar for the tasty turkey chili). Please excuse me if I
neglected to mention you personally here. Thank you to others for reading my blog,
emails and texts etc. It helps me!!
label: anger

text:
Please direct some good thoughts my way tomorrow (Wednesday) around 10 a.m. when
I begin a new phase of my cancer journey: radiation. I will have five treatments: this
Wednesday and Friday, next Monday and Wednesday and perhaps Monday 7 March (I
need to reschedule, as I asked for a 'reprieve' on my birthday). Each appointment is
short; the first one will consist of a 'dry run' (rehearsal?), followed by radiation (30
minutes total?), the remaining four will take even less time (perhaps 15 minutes). I have
no idea how fatigued I'll be, if I'll have other side effects etc. I am eager for radiation to
get underway. Yesterday, I felt a bit of the type of discomfort I was feeling from swelling
in my head (yet nowhere near the head-splitting pain this became), but perhaps this is
just phantom pain. My dear friend Jackie will take me tomorrow and next Monday, while
kind neighbors the Matthiesens will transport me on Friday. I have another appointment
too on Friday, with my PCP, which I need to arrange a ride to/from. When I return
tomorrow, my home will be in the process of being cleaned (including my perennially
messy study, a huge victory as I've been purging lots of stuff). A very clean home will
help a lot psychologically.
My radiation oncologist, Dr. Patel, continues not to inspire the utmost confidence. I
believe this is due to his 'youth' and relative inexperience. When I spoke to him on the
phone the other day, he led me to believe that what needs to be radiated in my
cerebellum is still sizeable ("not exactly huge, but not exactly small," was how he put it,
most inexactly). Imho, the early 40s of Drs. Beavis and Bettegowda (as far as I can tell) is
the sweet spot in terms of age. Dr. Patel the Younger also equivocated on when I should
restart chemo (I could hear hesitation in his voice), despite Dr. Beavis deferring to him
for this decision. He merely told me, hesitatingly, that he had a few patients undergoing
chemo at the same time as radiation. Then Dr. Patel the Elder's scheduler called me to
arrange my chemo; it turns out that Drs. Beavis and Patel the Elder had already
                    
conferred and decided I should resume weekly Taxol as soon as radiation was finished. I
opted for a slightly later appointment than I could have gotten, on March 16th, a)so I
could meet with Dr. Patel instead of his PA (who I also don't trust) prior to chemo and
b)so I can recoup more energy post-radiation. I hope I can delay these extra few days
without negative repercussions. Despite hiccups, things seem to be falling into place for
the next phase.
In better news, the ulcer on my eye appears to be healed but I need to use the drops for
another week. And today I'm generally feeling ok, having slept well in 'only' two chunks.
AND I believe Dr. Bettegowda is clearing me to begin driving on Feb. 26th! I have to
confirm this. I think I'm ready for it, although I won't undertake anything ambitious, just
some short drives to appointments, around town etc.
My former colleague and buddy Jim Davis sent me the most delicious toffee (the
crunchy, buttery, non-gooey kind) from a place in Palm Springs that is known for it,
Brandini. And my friend Scott gifted me a big slab of homemade carrot cake. I think a
conspiracy may be afoot to fatten me, but I'm trying to eat as healthily as possible of my
own accord, and look forward to a bowl of butternut squash soup for lunch.
label: neutral

text:
A brief update: everything seems to have gone smoothly this morning during my first
radiation treatment. I was a bit anxious and slept so-so (perhaps 6-7 hours, in two
installments, with some time for thinking in between). My very responsible friend Jackie
drove me and we wound up talking about the puzzles/word games we do to keep our
minds sharp (I'm a NYTimes Spelling Bee and daily puzzle stalwart, and am dipping my
toes into Wordle, but it involves strategy, which I'm terrible at; a plus for the NYTimes
puzzles, I have a large vocabulary); stuffed animals; and my pre-radiation anxiety. 
The treatment itself was fairly short: 30 minutes all told? The sweat-inducing part was
literally being tightly *bolted* onto a table via the futuristic helmet made for me and
being told that I must lie very still for fear of the radiation being misdirected. Two
technicians conducted the procedure, yet Dr. Patel and The Physicist (an individual I
know only as The Physicist; being fairly scientifically illiterate, unfortunately, I don't know
what she or he does, but I'm curious to find out!) were seated behind a barrier,
supervising (or assisting?). I was told to relax and think pleasant thoughts. I kept my
eyes closed and held as still as possible. Some 'good' easy listening music helped: James
Taylor's "Carolina in my mind" (one of my favorite songs), a nice Simon and Garfunkel,
Heart's "These Dreams." Perhaps coordinated with all the prayers and well wishes
headed my way at 10 a.m., Queen also came on: "We are the champions, my friend/And
we'll keep on fighting 'til the end!"
I was most concerned about which side effects I'd feel afterwards. So far I'm doing ok,
rather worn out but unable to sleep so I'm writing. Very low-grade headache, but not
bad. So far, no nausea, vomiting, or visible rashes. We'll see. Next treatment Friday
morning. My kind neighbors Pat and Denis Matthiesen are taking me. They seem
undeterred by the "wintry mix" forecasted. My friend Clare will drive me to PCP
appointment that afternoon, weather permitting. Then Jackie will accompany me again
on Monday. Helen and I have a little outing planned for Sunday, in Bellefonte, which I
look forward to.
After treatment today, Jacke drove to Lemont so that we could get coffee at Café
                    
Lemont, a latte for her, a cappuccino with a shot of almond syrup for me, reminiscent of
the steamed whole milk with syrup I drank every evening during my last trimester of
pregnancy, and which contributed to my packing on 70 pounds (I lost most of it, and Ben
was worth every kilo!). Café Lemont's coffee is the best in town, imo.
I'm picking up from a few comments that maybe I'm being too hard on Dr. Patel the
Younger. I will give him the benefit of the doubt; I need to trust him. But I also need to
advocate for myself. Contradictory aims. I am eager to speak with him again.
label: fear

text:
Radiation appeared to go smoothly yesterday. The only blip came in the form of a  phone
call in the morning asking if I wanted to shift my appointment to the afternoon, due to
inclement weather that shut our town and campus down for the day. So I moved my
                    
morning appointment to 3:15, forcing me to also shift my afternoon PCP appointment to
another day, as yet unidentified (my PCP does not have openings before July! I'm
working on this with scheduling). In any case, treatment was more crucial than the
relatively routine follow-up appointment with Dr. Damaske (for whom I do have
questions, though, including about when I might have a shingles vaccine).
My helmet-like contraption is bolted so tightly into the table that I was afraid my teeth
would pop out, so firmly are they held in place by a mouth guard! I asked the technicians
(two very nice women) to let me know when 15-10-5 minutes remained; this is helpful.
Otherwise, I close my eyes and listen to "hits from the 60s, 70s and 80s" -- yesterday,
Jim Croce, "Bad, Bad Leroy Brown," Marvin Gaye, "What's Goin' On?," Fleetwood Mac,
"Go your own way," the Eagles. I calculate that each song lasts about three minutes; that
means five songs or more per treatment, each lasting 15-30 minutes. During that time,
eyes shut, I hear whirring and buzzing when the radiation is actually directed at my
cerebellum, feel the table rock slightly to secure me into position, smell a singing,
burning odor at one point (unpleasant), and lie still throughout, crick in my neck be
damned. Dr. Patel and "The Physicist" (whose name, I recently learned, is Neil) sit in a
control room behind a window, overseeing the treatment (the radiation machine is
actually programmed to deliver the radiation on its own, according to my individualized
radiation plan).
No more than 30 minutes and not bad. When I told the technicians that my side effects
so far were minimal, they found that unsurprising as only a small area is being radiated
(as opposed to, say, an entire abdomen). This contradicts somewhat Dr. Patel the
Younger's assessment of my tumor as "not exactly big but not exactly small" so I'm
getting to treatment a bit early on Monday to talk to him about how treatment is going.
My neighbor, Denis Matthiesen, drove me to treatment. Nice man, nice neighbor in his
70s (?), who lives with his wife, Pat (second marriage for each), across the road from me.
From Queens (and has the accent to prove it!), devout practicing Catholic, Democratic
voter (father a lieutenant in the fire department who died of cancer resulting from
fighting fires). Flirtatious to the point of making me a bit uncomfortable at times, but
nothing untoward so far other than a friendly pat on the shoulder (and I know how to
deflect). Monday I'll be with my stalwart pal, Jackie, and Wednesday with another
stalwart pal, Maria. Denis drove me to get a cappuccino after treatment, warming
comfort in a cup.
I slept miserably last night, but I'm ok. I had taken my steroid later in the day because of
the later appointment, and that can cause insomnia, plus I had ingested caffeine 4-5
p.m. Mistakes. I do know how to shut my brain off at night and focus on my music
(Tibetan bowls, chanting, thunder storms, waves) but somehow my brain was stubborn.
So I was galaxy-hopping again.
                    
At first I was shaken by events in Ukraine, grief-stricken for the civilians, impressed by
the courageous resistance of the Ukrainians, fearful that this is yet another 'canary in the
coal mine' harbinger of the blows against (end of??) democracy, thinking of the late
1930s (Munich, Anschluss) (even earlier, centuries earlier) and the power of autocrats,
but in a vastly different, globalized and interconnected world. Somehow, these anxieties
merged with my own interest in genealogy -- we come from that part of the world
(Belarus, Lithuania, about whose history I am realizing I need to know more) -- and I
wondered if Ben would like a narrative account of our family's history. So I pretty much
wrote part of it in my head, relying on some of the documents I have uncovered on
genealogy sites. Of course, the further back you go with Jewish genealogy, the harder it
becomes to trace, similar to the genealogy of former slaves. Scratch the surface and you
come up against the Holocaust, with at least one of my great-grandmother's sisters
deported to a camp in Russia. I'll do more digging.
Then I was was micro-managing a gathering I'm having on my birthday (the 4th),
'making my lists and checking them twice,' ensuring that we'll be well provisioned.
Next I was back to the idea of turning my Caring Bridge journal into a performance piece,
towards which I'm leaning more heavily recently, especially since my therapist and I
discussed how it might be of help to some others, as they have told me my journal is.
This idea is particularly appealing, relieving some of the focus on me and the
particularities of my journey. I also have a partial play list in mind to accompany the
piece, and a wonderful local musician on board to sing/play guitar. I'm in the process of
cutting and pasting the journal into something resembling a book (several hundred
pages so far), and then I'll be moving on to editing, cleaning up, and seeing what I can
do with this behemoth (performance would be both live at my house and live streamed
and other voices would add to mine in the form of the hundreds of comments people
have left, of which I'd choose a modest selection).
Finally, I was revisiting the fun photo shoot my friend, the photographer Stéphane Cojot-
Goldberg, and I joined forces for in Paris in 2019 when I needed some professional shots.
I'd like to do this again with Stéphane on my next Paris trip, with some different locales
featured (the Pont des Arts w/the Institut in the background would be nice, and maybe
l'As du Falafel in the rue des Rosiers could be fun along with other sites in the Marais)
and as long as Stéphane is feeling well enough from his recurrence of and treatment for
leukemia. I'm envisioning some bald shots, different wigs, different outfits. That was
about 3:30 a.m. I think I finally drifted to sleep around 4 a.m. and awoke at 8:00 a.m. My
'carer' Abbye brought me a delicious cappuccino so I'm doing alright, just feel like I have
some cotton balls stuffed inside my head. Luckily, I can rest today and am eyeing my
couch already. Reading's in store, and some house straightening, work on my journal,
maybe some Vever work (to which I returned this week!). Maybe a nap. I look forward to
lunch with my dear friend Helen tomorrow in Bellefonte (Bonfatto's), followed by a stop
at a newish market that sells local products, including local pickles (an obsession of the
                    
past two years) with a lot of spice and snap!
Be well, everyone. Happy 18th birthday to my dear nephew, Isaac. Sorry I can't be in the
city for the festivities as I continue to gather my strength. Hope Ben and Sammi continue
to have fun skiing in Stowe, Vermont, in preparation for their Colorado ski trip.
label: fear

text:
Radiation went smoothly yesterday. Happy to report minimal side effects, beyond some
fatigue. Took about 20 minutes. I had requested to speak to Dr. Patel the Younger before
my treatment. I'm feeling better about him now, just as I warmed up to Dr. Patel the
Elder after a rocky start. Veejay Patel confirmed that treatment was going well, that the
tumor had shrunk considerably (from about a 5 cm size...), that it was fine for me to
have a drink on my birthday, that it was fine for me to restart weekly chemo with Taxol
on 3/16, that the likelihood of my having a stroke or other major neuro event was low as
those affect a different part of the brain (the cerebrum) than the one we are treating etc.
Since then I've thought of additional questions that I will ask him at visit #5. I'm just glad
that radiation is going smoothly and that I feel generally well.
Jackie was kind enough to provide a ride and we had a good chat. After treatment, I
headed to my former Dean's house to drop off some homemade butternut squash bisque
for her (she's a cancer survivor as well). Then we headed to Pump Station for my ritual
post-treatment cappuccino, and ended up in Jackie's car in my driveway having a good
talk about some challenges arising from a situation involving Jackie's sister and her
family in Germany. When I returned home around noon, I lay on the couch for a while
and finished my book (_Sag Harbor,_ an early Colson Whitehead novel; he writes
captivatingly, in this case in a teenage, middle-class Black boy's vernacular, but the
novel has no plot; it ambles along, like the boys' summer at the beach in Long Island,
and that gets tedious after a while. I'm not sure I'd recommend the novel but I wouldn't
dissuade you from reading it either. May move on to Gary Shteyngart next).
I had bad insomnia again last night! That was unexpected. The previous night I had slept
well. I likely made the mistake of (re)watching, shortly before bed, a documentary called
_End Game,_ focusing in part on terminal patients and the kinds of decisions they face
(this was *after* watching the very worrisome news reports from Ukraine). Some of
these patients are being cared for at the Zen Hospice Project in San Francisco, founded
                    
by the man who's become my guru for all things End of Life, the physician and palliative
care/hospice care authority, B.J. Miller. As always, B.J. had some compelling things to say
about death (that it fosters "love, connection" and something else I can't remember; and
"from what I've seen, what happens after we die ain't all that bad"). He encourages
honoring each patient who dies at Zen Hospice Project by covering their shroud or coffin
with flowers, thereby marrying moments of grief with simplicity and beauty. This gave
me a lot of ideas, much to think about. Plus B.J. is hot, a truly beautiful man in his fifties,
who lost parts of three limbs in a college accident in which he was electrocuted at 19
while goofing off on top of a train car at Princeton U. I need to soon rewatch his popular
TED Talk, "What Really Matters at the End of Life," read some of his writings, and
perhaps find out more about another service he founded, Mettle Health.
B.J. Miller encourages "cultivating a relationship with death." But this is such a challenge
when one is enamored of life, as I am. Part of my problem is that once the issue of
lifespan was presented to me, I started to become very anxious. Dr. Beavis, whom I trust
completely, said it could be as short as six months (!!) while Dr. Frader, the head of
KGOS (Kelly Gynecologic Oncology Service at Hopkins) told me she had a patient with
my profile (OC then brain mets) who lived for ten years. Dr. (Nilesh) Patel, in my last
convo with him, refuses to pronounces on lifespan, deeming each case highly
individualized. Having gotten over the initial shock about these varied predictions, I need
to query Dr. Beavis further about how she thinks this will all go down: we run out of
treatment options? I develop some sort of complication? I run out of steam? I simply
conform to the overall odds of 50% of OC patients making it five years? How can I
possibly be feeling so good and full of life now and have six months to live? (Dr. Beavis
did say that her prediction tended towards the 'two years' side of the equation and of
course there are 'outliers'). Well, I guess at this point I always come back to the idea of
embracing every day, hour, moment, second and trying to live 'in the moment.' Another
challenge, especially for someone like me, drawn as strongly towards past (nostalgia,
memory) and future (plans, dreams, hopes) as to the present.
Just to put it out there: I do understand that, for all of us, "none of our tomorrows is
guaranteed" but let us concede  that this is a more pressing, germane, and 'real' issue
for advanced cancer patients such as myself.
I also want to get a better sense of why I saw a palliative care doc at Hopkins, which at
first I confused with a hospice doc (it is not!). From what I understood, palliative care
coordinates all the different strands of a patient's care (not just medical but also
spiritual, emotional etc.). From B.J's documentary, though, it seemed as if palliative care
was a sort of transitional step, anticipating (even at a far remove) end of life care in
some way. That idea jolted me a bit. I'm either in denial or not understanding something
correctly.
A college classmate, Nancy Audesse, died a few days ago, of throat cancer. I didn't know
                    
her in college, but she seemed an exceptionally brave, clear-sighted soul. When about
fifteen of us classmates gathered at Lisa Peters Driver's funeral a few years ago, Nancy
paid for dinner for all of us, somehow wanting to honor the beauty of that moment and
the warm connections we all formed and furthered in the wake of Lisa's death. At that
dinner, wheelchair-bound Nancy -- recovering from a massive stroke and several bouts
of cancer -- was cared for lovingly by David, another college classmate whom she had
not known prior but with whom she was cultivating a budding romance! Both Nancy and
David had lost long-time partners w/whom they had had loving relationships. They
married shortly afterwards and enjoyed several years of marriage, despite (or because
of?) Nancy's illness. A beautiful love story.
That close-by 'whoosh' of death always unnerves me some -- "it tolls for thee" -- although
I'm feeling well overall (despite insomnia) and very much looking forward to my bday on
Friday. In my sleepless state last night, I was fretting about the effect of pressure in air
planes on my brain (yes, I have the travel bug again) and what I would need to tell TSA
about the titanium bolt in my head while going through pre-check.
But today the sun is shining. I've just received a box of luscious pears from Harry and
David (don't know who they are from yet, but thank you!), an eye-catching beaded
dragonfly purse from Jane, with a box of 'schmear' (nova, bagels and lox) to come - what
a treat!; and an iconic Jo Malone shopping bag from my mother, undoubtedly containing
the very divine-smelling gift I was going to offer myself (or something similar)! Will wait
until Friday for the big reveal. My mother has never gotten my tastes wrong, in 63 years!
So much love. I'm a lucky girl. Be well, everyone.
label: joy

text:
A brief note to say that radiation went well yesterday; last treatment will be on Monday! I
have had practically no ill effects except fatigue. I slept well the night before, Maria
                    
picked me up and we were able to gab a bit, treatment took 20 minutes, and then we
were on to Café Lemont to pick up the cappuccinos. I rested for about an hour when I got
home, ate lunch (harira soup/stew; very nourishing) and then was able to work at my
desk for the rest of the day. I look forward to asking more questions and receiving an
update on Monday. Then back to weekly chemo on the 16th - ugh. Dr. Beavis and I have
exchanged emails and will talk by phone or videoconference sometime soon about the
plan going forward. I'll see Dr. Patel (Nilesh) on the 16th, before treatment. I feel well
overall. After a nurse comes to check my incision, my nice neighbor Janis will drive me to
Café Lemont to get a coffee (which I'll be able to do myself as of next Wednesday!).
Like everyone, I'm distraught about events in Ukraine. How can so much love, caring,
concern and respect, such as I've been shown, coexist with such misery, wanton
disregard for civilian life, disrespect for the rights of sovereign states, murderous, power-
greedy intents and autocratic desires (bolstered by nuclear power)? And the bravery of
the Ukranian people, and the many Russians against the war, and others, throughout it
all... I know that comparing my situation as a cancer patient and the complexities of
politics, geopolitics, history etc. is sort of ridiculous and I'm a hopeless Polyanna, but
still... So worrisome. People, our young people, must understand the history (yet also the
novelty of this situation in a globalized context). I awoke about 6:30 today and found
myself scrolling through videos of human suffering, Ukrainians walking miles to reach
border safety, families sleeping in subway stations, children receiving chemo in a kids'
hospital in Kyiv... Regular people, like you and me. What will happen? It won't be good.
How can we help? I've given to International Red Cross and José Andres' World Central
Kitchen (nominate that man for a Nobel Peace Prize, immediately). But what else, when
our own government (rightly, for now, in my view - that nuclear trigger, again) won't put
boots on the ground but is doing everything it can (I think?) through NATO. CaringBridge
is not the forum for this discussion (yet again, maybe it is: health and *caring*), I know,
but please pray that the situation resolves peacefully. It's so upsetting, yet of course this
awful disregard for human rights is not unique to Ukraine...
label: fear

text:
This morning I had the last of my five radiation treatments, and all went smoothly. The
technicians asked me if I wanted to *keep* that hideous Monty Python mask as a
'souvenir' (?). No thank you very much, the few pictures I snapped of it will probably do
for a lifetime... They gave me a 'joke' diploma (again: lol) to confirm that I had completed
the "the prescribed course of radiation therapy" "with the highest degree of courage,
determination and good nature." Heehee. Then, I met with the nurse, PA (who kept
addressing me as "Wilma" or "Willow), and finally Dr. Patel. We once again seemed to
have some misunderstanding about the spots that were to be radiated (I'm sure he
radiated the right spot -- post-surgical radiation -- especially as he was basing much of
what he was doing on imaging -- but I may write to Dr. Bettegowda to be ultra-sure and
to assuage anxiety that I'm sure is at play here). He confirmed that all went well, that he
estimates there's a 15% chance of my brain cancer recurring, that I'll have an MRI in
three months unless I become symptomatic before that (worsening headaches, vision
troubles etc.), that there's really nothing much else for me to do as far as radiation goes.
The entire visit took about an hour. Jackie was kind enough to take me/pick me up and
as usual we managed to get in both a good conversation and a cappuccino at Café
Lemont (with thanks to the "cappuccino fairies," Kathryn and Isabelle!). I rested and read
for a while when I returned home, and was then at my desk the entire afternoon, happily.
Weekly chemo (Taxol) will start up again, here, next week. I hope to speak with Dr.
Beavis soon about the treatment plan going forward, and about whether there might be
any clinical trials for me to enroll in. The effects of not having had chemo in so long while
we dealt with the brain issue (quite a detour!) are unclear to me. Thank goodness my
last OC scan, benefitting from the clinical trial, was stable.
I'm reading a good book: _The Beauty of Dusk,_ by Frank Bruni, which recounts the
struggles of this former NYTimes restaurant critic and current op-ed columnist with
sudden near blindness brought on by a stroke. It's a book about learning to make
adjustments, to live with uncertainty, to find open doors to compensate for the closed
ones. One takeaway I like is the importance of humor in these totally eccentric,
unprecedented situations (Monty Python plastic helmet, anyone?). Bruni writes very
nicely so it's an engaging read, and I'm ripping through it. 
Very much looking forward to my mother coming to visit next week! I will be glad for the
company.
I had a lovely birthday. The whole day was punctuated by greetings from friends and
family near and far -- texts, emails, FB messages, cards and gifts, a gorgeous bouquet, a
donation to José Andres' World Central Kitchen in my name, phone calls. Each one
brought a smile to my face. I am trying to respond to each in some fashion (have
responded to all the texts). Please bear with me. I am so appreciative of the well wishes
                    
and attention and outpouring of caring!
I also spent the day 'beautifying' my home for a gathering of about 20 local friends who
have been particularly kind and helpful over the past several years, throughout my
health ordeal, and who have never shied away from getting 'down and dirty' with me
when the going got tough. Again, I felt so blessed to receive this help and kind, non-
pitying connection when *I really needed it.* So the party was meant both to thank all
these wonderful folks (only two could not attend) and to celebrate. Everyone seemed to
have a blast; I think we were all happy to enjoy some maskless socializing (we all tested
beforehand and no one fell ill) after so many Covid restrictions and self-restrictions. We
all seemed to enjoy, as well, putting on our 'party clothes' after months in yoga and
sweat pants in front of Zoom. Therefore, I put quite a bit of thought into my outfit,
ordering a new 'party dress' (on sale) from my favorite Parisian clothier (Anne-Elisabeth),
buying some new makeup (my favorite sales guy at Ulta, Josh, the one who wears drag
show makeup and is himself immersed in drag culture), helped me pick out a bright pink
Mac lipstick, shimmery pale pink nail polish from OPI (called "Princesses Rule!"), fake
eyelashes (for the first time *ever;* just felt like trying them as I'm hairless now), and an
eyebrow enhancer. I teased my newer wig so it looked quite nice and wavy. I wore the
perfume from my mom, Jo Malone's Sambac and Marigold, which is divine and which I
would have bought myself. I truly did look well and happy; as it happened, I felt well that
day and was certainly happy to be surrounded by friends all enjoying the celebration. I
prepared a 'groaning' dessert table with both savory (cheeses, pâté, sausage) and sweet
treats (cake, chocolate strawberries, homemade Tahini cookies, lemon cake from Breads
Bakery in NY, candy, fruit salad w/homemade whipped cream etc.), wines, liqueurs etc.
Cake, from a fairly new local baker (The Cakeshop by Tati) was extraordinary, and lots of
people photographed it before I cut it. I was glad for the opportunity for folks to meet
those they didn't know. Helen and Greg, off to Paris the next day, came over a bit early
to help me set up while the amazing Maria (with some help from her Greg) cleaned up
for me as I was starting to flag.
Everyone told me how good I looked. I wish that correlated with prognosis. While near
death *does* look, well, near death, per Dr. Beavis, I know that my outward appearance
is to some extent misleading. Even Dr. Beavis once said: "It's surprising, you could cross
the path of someone very ill w/cancer in the grocery store and have no idea anything
was wrong." I do want readers to hold onto this lest I be accused of 'false advertising' in
any way. Clearly the OC/brain cancer double whammy is not an ideal scenario. *But* I
was happy to dress up in my party dress + new makeup (w/great pink faux pearl
dangling cocktail earrings to match!) and revel in the celebration. Every day a blessing.
And I made it to 63!
Photos
label: neutral

text:
Now that radiation is finished it's back to chemo for the ovarian cancer, after a hiatus of
well over a month as the brain issue was resolved. Instead of viewing the resumption of
chemo as 'regression,' I consider it simply the next phase in treatment of a chronic
condition. Thursday I had blood drawn; there were no red flags to delay the start of
chemo. My bloodwork looked fine. I also met with Dr. Patel on Thursday. I was happy to
see him. After a rocky start a few years ago, when I found him rather brusque and
'unrelatable,' we have developed a warm relationship as we've gotten to know each
other better. He showed me MRI scans of my brain where I saw, for the first time, the
large tumor that was constricting the left side of my cerebellum - yikes. He said he
thought I was doing well for my situation, meaning that I'm mobile, driving, have
recovered well from the brain operation etc. Dr. Patel (still) refuses to pronounce on life
span, refrains from quantifying. He said that it will depend entirely on a) whether the
cancer has progressed to other organs or has simply progressed in the abdomen and b)
the ability of the chemo medication (Taxol) to control the cancer. While this initially
made me feel better than Dr. Beavis' prognosis, I was also starting to realize that the
cancer had to progress from my abdomen to my brain *somehow.* Bloodstream? Lymph
nodes? Will this happen again? This thought, coupled with Dr. Beavis' early statement
about my cancer being particularly aggressive, in fact made me worry more. Dr. Patel
                    
always advises me not to fetishize the CA125 number ("It's just a number"). At the same
time, I know he is committed to helping me, agreeing heartily when I said: "If you
continue to treat me, I'll continue to fight" -- or something like that. When I brought up
travel -- Paris is on my mind big time -- he encouraged me to go sooner rather than later,
for example, before my next scans for him (in two months) and, of the brain, for
radiation oncology (three months). This is what I had been thinking too, I would simply
need to think through some contingency plans if I start to feel unwell there (I have
enough Parisian friends to be able to garner a wealth of doctors' recommendations). I
was grateful that Dr. Patel had also called me a few weeks ago simply to check in, and
that I saw two of my favorite nurses when I was at his office, both of whom were very
kind, knew about my neurosurgery, and had lots of encouraging words for me.
The next morning my neighbor Janis drove me to chemo. I'll be having weekly Taxol
infusions (or rather three weeks on, one week off) for one hour, preceded (or
accompanied by) infusions of saline solution, Decadron (a steroid), anti-nausea medicine
and Benadryl (which usually knocks me out immediately). I was taking Taxol during the
clinical trial along with another drug, Fostamatinib (the combination of the two was the
'trial' aspect). As mentioned, my having had brain surgery now makes me ineligible for
most trials. Two of my favorite nurses, Tracey and Brynn, administered my infusion, and
were super kind to me. We enjoyed catching one another up on our lives and I showed
them some of the pictures of my fabulous birthday cake! Jackie picked me up and drove
me home w/a detour to Café Lemont to pick up a cappuccino. I rested for most of the
afternoon, reading a Gary Shteyngart novel that Michael had recommended to me, _Our
Country Friends_ (excellent, love his gift for wit and satire! Another novel that makes me
laugh out loud).
Surprisingly, I didn't sleep well, waking at around 4:30 this morning and sleeping just a
bit after that. I was tired, but also at times worried about my health, thinking about
things I had to do, etc. Hopefully I'll sleep better tonight. I'm very much looking forward
to my mother visiting for a part of this coming week. I'll have chemo again next Friday,
plus a visit with my PCP, Dr. Damaske. Will also televisit with Dr. Beavis this Wednesday
and will be eager to speak with her.
Overall, though, feeling ok. Sure glad I don't have to deal with the host of stomach woes
of the first half-year leading to my second, Jan. 2020 surgery (fistula repair): stomach
drainage bags, ultra-strong antibiotics, multiple stomach blockages, several failed
stomach plug procedures, many trips to Hopkins. All is well on that front!
One day at a time.
Be well, everyone.
label: neutral

text:
I see I haven't provided any updates in a while, partly as I was hosting my mother for the
better part of last week. Since then, I've had one chemo infusion -- Taxol -- which was
surprisingly 'untaxing.' My blood counts looked stable aside from a slightly elevated
bilirubin count. My friend Jackie picked me up from chemo and we returned to my house
for a Friday pre-dinner snack along with my friend Martina, bearing adorable plants that
flowered from seeds from a bag of lemons I had in the fridge. The get-together was also
the pretext for Jackie and Martina to meet my mother (in Martina's case, to meet her for
a second time as they had met at an MLA convention a long time ago). Earlier in the
week, my friend Helen also came over to visit with me and my mom; we had all enjoyed
a lovely lunch outdoors at the Ale House last summer, along with my friends Kathryn
(w/whom I enjoyed another *indoors* Ale House lunch this last week) and John. In any
event, the chemo did not tire me out excessively, and I was able to take a long drive
Saturday after I had put my mother on the Megabus back to the city.
I also had a post-op visit with my PCP, Dr. Damaske, and a video visit with Dr. Beavis and
nurse Justin Mahonsky, who had worked with me when I was participating in the clinical
trial. Our hour-long meeting was very useful, as always, and I suppose a bit sobering.
Both told me I looked "amazing" (I'll cling to every shred of my vanity for as long as I
can!). After my two scans (brain and pelvis/abdomen/chest) in about two months, Dr.
Beavis would like to add Avastin to my chemo cocktail, as it has been shown to make
Taxol work better. As you may recall, a potential side effect of Avastin is bowel
perforation, which I *may* be even more susceptible to as in March 2020 (just as COVID
hit) I had a long operation to repair a fistula between my bowel and abdomen. However,
as the number of viable treatment options 'dwindles' (my word, which Dr. Beavis found
apt), the risk/reward calculus must be reassessed with that in mind. Since I asked Dr.
Beavis, in this same conversation, how my 'demise' would likely 'go down,' she told me
that it would entail running out of viable treatment options. At that point, a likely (but not
definite) way death would occur would be loss of appetite (how ironic!) as tumors begin
to colonize the bowel, causing obstruction. Her recent suggestion of a potential lifespan
of "six months to two years" (while of course with the added caveat that these are
averages, there are outliers, each case can be different etc.) made me tell her and Justin
that I was "mad" about this (why wouldn't I be? It sucks!). But then I felt guilty towards
Dr. Beavis, whom I feared might think I was mad at her, so I wrote her a note to clarify.
She understood completely - she must get this all the time from patients.
Indeed, fear and anger are fairly new components of my emotional vocabulary right now,
despite my efforts to allay them and my firm intent to maintain a posture of gratitude
and happiness (I told my therapist today that I felt "it would be a crime" for me not to
remain positive, although she thought the word 'crime' was a bit strong...). On my
brother's recommendation, I just bought Fear: Essential Wisdom for Getting through the
Storm by Thich Nhat Hanh, and look forward to reading it now that I'm between two
                    
Shteyngarts. I also want to read Between Two Kingdoms: A Memoir of a Life
Interrupted by Suleika Jaouad, a bestselling NYTimes author who wrote "The Isolation
Journals" for the Times when she was a 22-year-old leukemia survivor (her cancer has
just recurred at age 33). I'm interested in what she has to write about creativity and the
special (sacred?) nature of these 'life interruptions.' In the meantime, rereading my blog
(actually editing it into user-friendly shape), time with friends and family, buds on trees,
cooking and more are proving therapeutic and keeping me 'positive' (I really don't know
what the appropriate word is here...).
I have a big, complicated decision to make about whether or not I'll go to Paris during an
off week for chemo. I won't write too much about it here because it's a fraught decision
that I'm still contemplating and that seems to have taken on existential dimensions for
me (while I still have a niggling feeling of 'first-world problems' with so much crisis
occurring in the world). I change my mind every day. My doctors are presenting this to
me as a 'bucket list' item, for which I have a very small window of opportunity. I'm very
tempted to flip this script and hold out for a wider window, simply out of cockiness. After
all, both Dr. Patel and Dr. Damaske refuse to pronounce on lifespan, stressing that each
case is individualized and really depends on how effective the medication is. Reward v.
risk: spending time with beloved friends, returning to meaningful places (a bench in the
gardens of the Palais-Royal; the marché d'Aligre; my old apartments beginning in Passy),
touching base with work contacts, eating favorite foods in favorite places. For now, I'd
like to eschew the idea of a 'victory lap' or, rather, 'valedictory,' much as I'd like to
sidestep the 'bucket list' idea. Risks: coming COVID surge in Europe (??), falling ill
w/cancer or COVID in Paris (potentially disastrous on many levels), neurosurgeon's
suggestion that the jet flight could make me 'slightly uncomfortable' but would not cause
damage to the work he did (!), uncertainty about whether I could have the experience I
wanted rather than something else, perhaps tinged with a bit of worry; potential
necessity of making the trip myself (which normally would not be a problem but that
leaves me a bit anxious right now); unease of certain family members. I need to gather
some additional information (have queried Dr. Bettegowda about just how uncomfortable
my head might be from the flight; need to follow up with my friends who still *might*
want to make the trip, as we had planned from the start). I believe there's no right or
wrong decision here; whatever I decide, I will create the optimal conditions around it.
Btw, Drs. Patel and Damaske are strongly in favor of my Paris idea; Dr. Beavis sounded
more cautious but would support the idea as well. She doesn't want me to wind up in the
hospital in Paris.
My mother and I had a lovely time taking drives to neighboring towns, lunching,
shopping, feeding the ducks in Talleyrand Park, talking, watching _West Side Story_ (an
American masterpiece; mediocre movie) etc. It was nice to have her company. I'll attach
a few pics.
                    
I'm very much looking forward to lunch with the "III Cs" this week and to spending time
with other survivors, at different points in our treatment, survivorship etc. I'm less
looking forward to having an X-ray (likely on Thursday) of my left hip, which has felt a bit
sore recently (but which I'm hoping 'just' has a touch of arthritis). When I mentioned it to
Drs. Beavis and Damaske, I had in mind that my dear grade school friend Debbie's
cancer had spread at one point into her hip, nearly incapacitating her (not my case in the
least). Much as it's a bit scary, I felt I needed to 'come clean' about this and not delay
further. Fingers crossed. I also had my fourth COVID shot today, a bit of extra protection
for us immunocompromised folk. Hoping not to experience flu-like effects from it. So far
so good.
Since I'll be tethered to my chemo pole once a week (three weeks on, one week off),
please come visit me this spring or summer, provided I feel ok. Am I being pathetic and
needy here or simply stating my needs and desires explicitly? Or invite me to come visit
you or meet you halfway, if it's not too far. Local friends: I will continue to reach out too,
of course. We have: breweries, farmers markets, farm to table restaurants, a network of
creeks, hiking trails, state parks, Creamery ice cream, a local music scene, a beautiful
arboretum, roadside fruit and vegetable stands, Amish farms and hamlets, antiques
stores and, chez moi, a private bedroom and bathroom upstairs ("Ben's lair" when he's
here), comfy condo, summer kitchen. My grad school besties are coming out in late April,
after I return from the city (where I'll get to cheer Ben on in the first Brooklyn half-
marathon). But consider a country getaway!
Photos
label: neutral

text:
Since last week my abdomen has begun to make itself known, with significant discomfort
in my stomach and other points in my abdominal area. New cancer? Scar tissue?
Blockage? Dr. Patel ordered a CT scan for tomorrow afternoon, never pleasant (long
procedure, four hour fast, drink that tastes like greasy melted chalk) but necessary to
find out what's going on. Luckily, there was a cancellation tomorrow afternoon at Gray's
Woods; otherwise I would have needed to wait until mid-April for the scan. Never a dull
moment. Of course, this makes me very anxious. I received the result of the hip x-ray
but as a non-medical professional am having trouble parsing it. The bottom line seems to
be that an MRI or CT-scan is needed for further clarification. And some of the discomfort
there may simply be due to cartilage loss and not necessarily new cancer, as I
suspected.
My sleep last night was fairly atrocious. I awoke every hour or two with horrible leg
cramps, most likely due to dehydration because of diarrhea (tmi?). A combination of leg
massages, heating pads, numerous glasses of water etc. finally relieved me of the
cramps but I feel slightly zombie-like today. Oh well. The night before I slept well. I
rested a bit and got myself a cappuccino and felt better.
I am trying to get on top of my anxiety. Sometimes it's hard. I'm reading _Fear: Essential
Wisdom for Getting through the Storm,_ by Thich Nhat Hanh but it's not helping! Phrases
like "there is no death, only continuation" really don't resonate with me. I do believe that
each individual lives on after death, indirectly, in the fruits of the actions they performed
on earth, in their accomplishments, in their progeny etc. but this is in no way comparable
to having the physical person around. It is a memory-based connection, at least that's
how I'm conceiving of it now. Mindful breathing, mindfulness, grounding oneself in the
present moment etc., which this Buddhist Zen master recommends, are all useful
practices. But I'm simply not finding his book that useful, so maybe I'll return to B.J.
Miller's Ted Talk about "what really matters at the end of life." Maybe I'm just not cut out
to be a Buddhist or even a JewBu. I could use  more Zen in my life, but my at times
paralyzing anxiety needs to make way for it.
Therefore, no decision about a Paris trip yet until I get a handle on what may or may not
be going on with me physically.
No other major developments to report from last week. My Taxol infusion, once again,
did not knock me out last Friday - something to be thankful for at least. I have a week off
from chemo this week as my white blood cells replenish. Was at the dentist for cleaning
and for Steve to look at some bonding work that needs repair. Otherwise, always a high
point was lunch with the "III Cs," four other survivors whose company feels safe and
uplifting. Deb, a twelve(?)-year survivor who has been in treatment nearly continuously
and has outlived all predictions, is an inspiration. Felt equally gratified attending the
                    
Alumni Association awards dinner at the Penn Stater Saturday night with Morgane, a
graduate student whose dissertation I direct, and her husband, Aaron. Morgane is one of
thirteen recipients university- wide of the Alumni Association Dissertation Award, which
recognizes the quality of her research. She's an exceptional student and lovely person
and I'm happy to have any small role to play in her success. Sunday morning Maria and I
drove out to Elk Creek Café, a cool farm to table restaurant/brewery out in Amish country
and, with the church-going buggies rolling by, we enjoyed brunch with Mar and Jessica,
two other friends we hadn't seen in a while (Mar's painting are on exhibit at the café).
Our former long-time dean (27 years?), Susan Welch, died last night of liver cancer.
When I was a rank and file faculty member and department head, Susan was always 'the
dean,' a slightly formidable figure. She worked indefatigably to raise the profile of the
College of the Liberal Arts at Penn State, and succeeded. She was a prominent political
scientist who recently began working on the Holocaust. Her legacy is remarkable.
Sunday a building will be dedicated in her honor (sadly, she will not have made it to the
inauguration ceremony). Through our shared cancer journeys, though, we became closer
the past few years -- lunches out, email, soup deliveries, sharing details of our
treatment. We bonded. I saw her a few weeks ago when I brought her some butternut
squash soup. She looked quite frail but was headed to the office to work! And there goes
that 'whoosh' of cancer close by, again. I hope she had a peaceful death, the death she
wanted.
Also had a long overdue zoom catch-up with my dear first cousin, Julie Eagle-Cardo, the
one I was thrown into the crib with when we were both a few weeks old. We've been
thick as thieves our entire lives, from commuting between the city and Fairfield County,
CT, when we were teens to enjoy adventuresome weekends, to travelling together in
Europe, to experiencing milestones at the same time, to having sons, to producing
reams of correspondence and emails over the years. I never had a biological sister but
Julie comes close. May you be so lucky as to have such a close relative/'forever friend'
too.
Finally, several people have inquired about the Stride and Thrive event for which I
organized a team the past two years to help raise funds for KEGOS (Hopkins' Kelly
Gynecologic Oncology Service). Our great team, both in State College and elsewhere (in
the States and abroad), ran/walked on clear June days while sporting our #willapower
shirts. I just got off the phone with one of this year's organizers, who seemed to want
feedback from me as my fundraising efforts have been so successful the past two years.
Long story short: they are not opting for the run/walk format as they have the past two
years (which itself had replaced a 'cast of thousands' event in Baltimore, which Covid put
an end to). Instead, they will be hosting a garden party in Maryland on June 26th. A
month before that, though, they will organize a run/walk, similar to the Stride and Thrive
of years past. To be honest, they seem a bit disorganized and behind schedule. But there
*will* be an opportunity for fundraising once they work out some blips in their website.
                    
All this to say that I hope to raise funds for KEGOS once again this year, and will share
details, but must wait for Hopkins to get its act together first!
label: fear

text:
As for the title word of this blog post, I just like it. It also contains the word 'gris,' which is
how I was feeling a few days this week. And I love that blue-green patina formed by
oxidation. Confused yet?
I spent so much time at Gray's Woods this past week that it was really starting to
depress me -- until I remembered that the place is full of medical professionals whose job
it is to *help* patients and hopefully make them feel better. I also feel innately
compassionate towards people with serious health challenges. My house cleaner, Missy,
told me yesterday that she has a brain tumor (benign yet growing) and other health
issues, and that her fiancé has cancer. Her parents were both alcoholics. She is rural and
poor -- like many who live just beyond State College -- and works hard to make it. I wish
her a happy day today, fishing with her granddaughter.
I had separate appointments at Gray's Woods for the first shingles vaccine (which I
wanted to make sure to get), a urine analysis (yep, I have *another* UTI, which hopefully
the antibiotics will take care of; must keep ultra-hydrated at all times), and a CT-scan (oh
yes, I think I was there a fourth time, to pick up a disk with CT-scan imaging on it,
because they were unable to burn a disk while I was there. This is really pretty lame,
considering that, over the past few years, Geisinger has *never been able* to forward
imaging directly to Hopkins; I always have to pick up a disk and then upload the imaging
myself).
Anyhoo...
The CT-scan did not reveal a stomach blockage! I am so relieved. I went on a liquid diet
for a few days and that seemed to help. It's hard for me to parse the results of the
radiologist's report but Dr. Patel called me briefly to discuss (I'm not convinced he looked
at the actual imaging, which I want him to, and which I'll discuss with him this Friday
when I see him). Besides the results pertaining to the bowel, the scan revealed some
decrease in size in certain cancerous masses and lymph nodes and some increase in
other lymph nodes (which is what chemo is for...). I don't know, though, whether the net
result is an increase or a decrease in cancerous mass and exactly where these nodes are
situated (they had names I did not recognize; I suppose I could look them up but I'd
prefer to let Dr. Patel or Dr. Beavis, who has been away and will return this week,
explain). Dr. Patel said that the most enlarged lymph node was in my abdomen but that
it "shouldn't bother me a lot." I also still don't understand why I have marked discomfort
at the bottom tip of my right rib cage (the CT-scan revealed nothing of concern in my
liver). More points to bring up with the doctors this week.
So...onward we go, with what sometimes seems like a ticking time bomb inside me. Not
easy.
                    
All the medical 'stuff' was at the root of a dark hole I was plunged into, and couldn't get
out of, for about two-three days this past week. I was afraid that being mired in my
health issues was going to wipe out the memory of how much *fun* I certainly used to
be, and like to think I still am! I was feeling super-stuck and therefore doing nothing,
feeling paralyzed, when I still get on my case for every moment 'wasted.' 'My incredible
shrinking' world depressed me. And so did not feeling well, of course.
What helped lift me out of my gloom was the support of friends! May sound corny to say,
but true. "Be of good cheer," writes Whitman in _Song of Myself._ "We will not desert
you." A few texts reminded me that I am not alone.While opening gifts that arrived
simultaneously from two wonderful friends and reading the note from one, I *literally*
felt my spirits lift and I could hear myself saying "Awwww!" and smiling (I do want to
clarify here - not that it's necessary -- that I am not "holding out" for gifts, nor do I
consider them *at all* a more tangible display of friendship. I am certainly not that kind
of materialist, either! Gifts are lovely [thank you for the tea, Martina!] But a kind word,
visit, call -- or simply taking the time to read what I've posted -- is really a mood-lifter).
In any event, my dear old friend and colleague, Jim, sent me _The Book of Joy,_
conversations between the Dalai Lama and Desmond Tutu. I can't wait to read this book,
as Thich, no matter how noble a man he was (and I'm sure he was), is simply not doing it
for me. And my college friend Wilson, w/whom I've reconnected, sent me blueberry
preserves and pear compote that he canned himself from fruit on his farm. He sent me
the kindest note, too. Wilson, thank you so much for lifting my spirits and I will write you
soon! Thinking of the right words to you in response...
I'm feeling generally ok. It looked like the sun was out this morning so I got myself out of
bed, got a cappuccino at Café Lemont and then drove to Tati's cakeshop, the one that
produced my stupendous birthday cake, for some muffins. Will take another drive this
afternoon to view early spring in the country; it will be calming. Dinner tomorrow night
with my friend Maria, and thank you, Monique, for coming to dinner at my place after my
tiring CT-scan experience.
I did enjoy a lovely dinner at the Tavern with Dallas, a former undergraduate student
who I taught *thirty* years ago! We lost touch for a while but have since reconnected as
friends. We talked about Henri Vever (whose 1898 diary he read, and I signed with a
dedication to Dallas) and many other things French, essential oils, life, work and much
else. Dallas is returning to French after varied and interesting first (and second) careers,
substituting and perhaps eventually teaching in a private school in his home of Reading,
PA. He was kind enough to share that he remembered I always dressed up for class (at
least in the early days!), in my cute Parisian skirts and heels and jewelry, and that it was
always fun to see what I'd turn up to class wearing. Love this memory! Dallas (who must
love good smelly stuff like me), also gifted me a lovely lilac candle from Etsy with a
                    
heady odor; that smell will always remind me of the end of the semester, when the lilacs,
as if on cue, bloom on the path besides "Deans' Walk," a row of office in Sparks Building).
There is a line from the prayerbook we use for shabbat services that came to mind: "We
are loved by everlasting love. We are [?] by arms we cannot see."
Ben - who turns 27 on Monday! - will be coming 'home' in about two weeks, around
Passover. Then, if all goes well, I'll head to NY later this month to watch him run in the
first Brooklyn Marathon. He graduates next month from NYU with an M.S. in Data Science
and is narrowing in on some worthy job possibilities. He and a friend are off to a
butchering class in Brooklyn today, a present from their girlfriends - I asked for pictures
of these two bros sipping a beer after butchering an animal -- so Brooklyn.
I wanted to remember a strange dream I had: Michael (my ex-husband) said he was
about to join a (the?) squash team. People in his household were also about to embark
on a sale of Girl Scout cookies. I inquired about purchasing thin mints, my favorites. In
the next scene,  I was dancing with Jason Momoa (not unpleasant!); he was behind me
and we were kind of loping/dancing along and having a conversation at the same time.
He expressed a wish to be invited to my house (but I think it was my mother's house?)
for a stay. I alluded to the previous guest, who had had drug issues (somehow conflated
in my dream with my ex-boyfriend Gregory). End of dream. Wonder if the final part might
echo the death of Taylor Hawkins, a musician I long found charismatic and talented; I
had listened to many interviews with Taylor and Dave Grohl, although I really didn't
know the Foo Fighters' music very well. What a pity.
label: surprise

text:
Dear friends,
For the third year in a row, I am privileged to be raising funds for KEGOS (the Kelly
Gynecologic Oncology Center) at Johns Hopkins, and its programs. I would be honored if
you would consider making a donation in any amount, to help women like myself (and
including myself!) thrive while confronted with often insidious diseases. The website for
donations is: ttps://runsignup.com/Race/127044/Donate/Qq4CULKMK4y6KGMx
The website has changed a bit since last year. If you are able to make a donation to my
team (#willapower) as opposed to a donation to my individual fundraising account (there
may be a button on the page for this purpose), please do. All donations go directly to
Johns Hopkins.
If you have any questions/problems, please ask!
The format for the culminating event has changed a bit. This year a garden party for
survivors is planned at an estate in Maryland, on June 26th. I *believe* that one month
before that, on May 26th, there will be a 'fitness challenge' similar to the 1k walk/5 mile
run some of us have participated in the past few years in locations as far flung as State
College, New York, Philly, Baltimore, Michigan, California, Massachusetts, and Japan! I
will let you know as plans for this event develop and, as/if they do, look forward to
(re)assembling team #willapower for the occasion!
Thank you.
label: neutral

text:
First, I wanted to thank the following friends and family members for donating
generously to the Stride and Thrive/Reunite and Reignite Fundraiser for KEGOS: Phil,
Clare, Susan Wolfert (whom I don't believe I know), Kathryn, Denise, Helen, June (my
cousin), Julie (my cousin), Sharon (aka mom), Jane G. We are nearing 20% of our
fundraising goal. The link to the donations page is in the entry just before this one.
Thank you in advance for helping women like myself combat ovarian, uterine and other
'below the belt' cancers.
I've appreciated the blessing of a relatively 'normal' (all things considered etc.) week,
meaning no unexpected medical visits, subsiding abdominal pain, a suspected UTI that
turned out not to be one, decent energy level etc. This meant that I was able to fully
enjoy great convo and brunch with Martina at the Naked Egg Cafe (a cute local place);
drinks with Katerina at Gigi's (a mocktail for me), and dinner at the Ale House (packed to
the gills; this town always confounds me that way) with Lisa S. Taxol continues to treat
me fairly kindly; I did crash for almost two hours after returning from my infusion around
noon yesterday (but I attribute that in part to the early start time of my appointment
with Dr. Patel), A day after chemo, though, I feel relatively chipper, have a pot of chicken
soup simmering and may head out in search of horseradish (the Amish make a
                    
particularly pungent variety).
Per my appointment with Dr. Patel, things *seem* status quo; when I asked him whether
there had been a net increase or decrease in the amount of cancer in my body, he said it
was hard to tell. Because cancer cells mutate so efficiently, with the goal of 'outsmarting'
the chemo drugs, the Taxol may prove more effective against certain types of cancer
cells than against others. Also, he explained that different groups of cells have different
blood supplies -- at least that's what I understood. So treating these stealthy cells is
complicated indeed. He attributed the discomfort at the bottom tip of my right ribs to an
irritation of some sort, but I'm hoping that the Hopkins' radiologists will also offer their
analysis of the imaging. For now, then (and 'now' may mean a shorter or longer window,
as I've become used to planning for small increments of time), my situation seems
relatively stable (and I feel obliged to add that 'relatively' there!).
I'm looking forward to digging into _Between Two Kingdoms_ by Suleika Jouad (Jon
Batiste's wife), a compilation of the pieces she wrote for the _NYTimes_ as "Life,
Interrupted" when she was a twenty-two year old diagnosed with leukemia and then
recovering from it (sadly and unusually, her leukemia has recently recurred ten years
later). The book has been well reviewed and I'm interested to learn more about her
perspective and absorb any wisdom I can from it). Will start _The Book of Joy_ after that,
or maybe at the same time.
I've been wondering what people mean when they say they are 'inspired' by me. It
