seems to me that if you want to live, you make that your goal and pursue it tenaciously.
Undergoing treatment for cancer is a *project.* Not everyone undertakes it tenaciously,
but wouldn't most people? If at some point I decide to refuse further treatment, will I still
'inspire' you? What about me inspires you? Do my actions inspire you to act or live
differently, to adjust your perspective or your values? I've actually received some pretty
interesting and often surprising answers to this question (my cousin Julie offered one,
having to do with my writing I believe, but I can't remember the particulars). I do
understand that for the seven or so 'thrivers' (a word I sometimes prefer to 'survivors')
reading my blog, including a few dealing with serious chronic illness and several in
treatment for cancer now or in the past, it is possible to empathize and draw strength
from the words of another person confronting a more or less analogous situation. But I'm
never sure what it might mean for others. Is it something people say -- reflecting a
tendency to heroize suffering -- or something that truly helps them on their journey?
I'm also confused by people who demur about discussing their problems with you
because they feel you 'have it much worse.' I don't understand what kinds of feelings
generate a statement like that. Some sort of guilt, I guess, but why? Everyone's frame of
reference is different. If it's a problem for you, it's a problem. There are people worse off
than me; if they were my friends, I wouldn't let that deter me from sharing my troubles
with them. If you sincerely feel guilty about talking about your problems because you're
                    
afraid I might find them trivial, I will let you know that. I will also let you know if I need to
talk about what's going on with me in terms of my health issues (I will likely calibrate the
amount/type of information I share depending on my interlocutor). But I don't need to
talk about them all the time; it becomes boring after a while and I'm still more than
capable of friendships based on exchange (I thrive on them, actually). As most of you
know, I also abhor any kind of statement even slightly tinged with pity, which doesn't
mean ignoring that I have a serious illness that is simply a *fact* of my life right now.
Anyhoo...
I am so excited about Ben coming 'home' on W for a visit over the holiday. I hope we'll
have a meaningful seder and a good meal (there must be matzah ball soup! and brisket!
and lotsa matzah! and tzimmes!). Whatever 'narrow place of bondage' (mizraim) --as
Egypt was for the Israelites -- you find yourself in, whether physical, emotional, spiritual,
psychological -- I wish you a way out of it. I have found several prayers for Ukraine that I
will incorporate. While I hope at times to be released from the 'bondage' of serious
illness, I know for sure that opportunities for joy in life abound and are present for me.
label: joy

text:
Dear friends and family,
I won't write a full update for a few days, after chemo Friday (although thankfully nothing
remarkable to report) and Ben's arrival later today, but I did want to gratefully
acknowledge your generous donations to the Stride and Thrive: Reunite and Reignite
fundraiser, for which I'm so appreciative. There was a bit of a glitch with the new

enough to donate so far. Math is my downfall, but I think we are now at 37.2% of our

or third entry before this one.
A loud shout-out of gratitude to: Sharon (aka mom), Julie (cousin), June (cousin), Marian,
Margaret, Eva, Isabelle, Theresa, David M., Jill and Fred, Christopher, Bettina, Phil, Clare,
Susan, Kathryn, Helen, Denise and Mike, Jane -- and myself. If I have omitted any names,
please let me know! As mentioned, the website is a bit 'wonky' and I needed to

More soon, enjoy the beautiful sunshine today if you it's gracing you,
XOWilla
label: joy

text:
Thank you so much, Scott, for your generous donation to team #willapower! Scott's
donation brings us to 39% of our fundraising goal. I'd be very grateful for your
contribution, so would other women battling below the belt cancers, and so would the
staff of KEGOS, the Kelly Gynecological Oncology Service at Johns Hopkins, an
extraordinary institution. Please let me know if you need direction to the donation page.
It's a busy time -- which I hope is a good thing as opposed to a depleting one -- but
wanted to share the news that I *have* decided to go to Paris for a week, May 4-12. One
deciding factor was the wonderful offer by a very dear high school friend, Jill Morey
Gaines, to accompany me on the trip! Jill has proved an exceptional, highly supportive
friend throughout my illness, driving out here from Princeton, NJ (where one of her three
daughters lives) a year or two ago to lift my spirits, help me out around the house and
town, and drive me to Hopkins if necessary (it turned out not to be, at the last minute).
But then again, Jill is the friend who, after my parents got divorced many years ago
(when we were in high school), invited me to spend the weekend in Atlantic City in an
apartment owned by the family of another friend, Debbie (of blessed memory). They
were the only two friends who reached out to me in such a direct, kind way, and that
seaside weekend with my two friends was a balm for me, as I recall. Jill went to a French
school before joining us at Nightingale for high school, speaks French, has been to Paris,
and understands the adjustments I may need to make on this trip (ie sadly, likely no
more 15 km strolls around Paris and perhaps a mid-afternoon nap on some days when
my stamina is low). She said she'd be content to sit in a café together for several hours
and people watch (as would I) and knows that there are a few friends I may need to
                    
spend a bit of time with solo. I can't think of a better travel companion, in fact. She's a
lot of fun! And we're totally on the same page when it comes to shopping, eating out,
some light museum going etc. Merci, Jill :). Jill will fly from her home near LA at the
beginning of May, spend a night or more at her apartment in NYC, then meet me at
Newark for our flight (let's just say we're both pampering ourselves throughout the trip).
We'll return on the same flight on the 12th, then I'll catch a connecting flight from
Newark to State College, just in time for chemo the next day...
A particularly luminous spring day in State College also, somehow, made me yearn for
the luminosity and visual gorgeousness of Paris in the spring. One *can* feel a deep
emotional connection to a place, and I want to be there, sitting on a bench in the Palais-
Royal, strolling the rue des Francs-Bourgeois, spending a lazy afternoon in the Tuileries
or Jardin du Luxembourg chatting with a friend, eating a baguette sandwich in the place
des Vosges, people watching over a café crème on the _terrasse_  of a café.
Jill and I are staying at Hôtel Le Mareuil in the 11e, a nice-looking boutique hotel Jill's
travel agent identified for us. I had wanted to stay right in the Marais, but the hotel I like
there (Grand Malher) is fully booked. We won't be far, though, from the 'haut Marais,'
République, the trendy Oberkampf neighborhood, even the Canal Saint-Martin, and the
marché Richard-Lenoir, so we're well-situated. 
I've started making some plans with friends (Jill and I will have a reunion with one of our
32 high school classmates, ie 'sisters,' Christina, and her delightful husband, Vincent). If I
haven't contacted you yet, Paris friends, I will do so within the next day or two! 
Restaurant recs welcome, btw. I do have my favorites, of course, but it will have been
*three* years since my last visit, and the dining scene can morph rapidly.
I understand that my plans could still be upended. There is so much uncertainty
surrounding my illness. Between now and May 4th, I could still experience a stomach
blockage, headaches, or other worrisome cancer-related symptoms. And then there's
COVID. I've asked a few friends to supply doctors' names/numbers there in case of
emergency. I will take all the precautions. Hopefully, I'll have the will(a)power to make
some necessary modifications to diet, alcohol intake etc. while in Paris -- many
temptations there, of course, as I search for the ultimate _tarte au citron_ (and have a
good idea of where to find it), and I again need to chart a middle ground between
indulgence and the real care with which I must treat my body. Oy!
I am feeling generally ok these days -- something like a modified 'honeymoon period' as
I've experienced with OC before -- chemo went smoothly yesterday -- and just need to
stay well during a busy upcoming stretch -- always need to find that balance between
taking advantage of the well-feeling periods and not overdoing it. Ben is here for a few
days and we enjoyed a lovely seder last night with all sorts of yummy food that I cooked
                    
over a two-week period (I'll perhaps write another entry about that). Thursday or Friday,
after chemo, we will most likely drive into the city, where I'll spend about a week. On the
agenda is hanging out with my mother (who's recovering from a fall in the street,
fortunately *not* resulting in any broken bones but still a badly sprained knee and ankle
and nasty bruises); lunch with two more wonderful high school friends, one of whom I
haven't seen in a few years outside Zoom; part of a day with Mitchel, my very dear
college friend of 45 years, who will be visiting the States from Nice; if all goes well (ie
somewhat iffy Achilles heel permitting), the first Brooklyn half-marathon, in which Ben
will be running; a little shopping for Paris. Then back to State College for the arrival of
my three grad school pals ("les filles"), Isa, Vinni and Shanny, for one night chez moi and
a second at Bedford Springs resort and spa in Bedford, PA (about a 1.5 hour drive from
here). Following our nascent tradition that began at Kripalu yoga center a few years ago,
we'll seek answers to our pressing questions from Shanny's crystal pendulum, act much
younger and sillier than our age, collapse into gales of giggles, take goofy selfies of
ourselves, have slumber parties, reminisce, and share some serious talk too. A few days
after the pals leave I head to Paris. Kooky planning? Too much? So far the efforts are
proving uplifting and not debilitating as it's all about fun, vibrancy and life as I like to live
it, taking it by the horns and riding it for all it's worth. And then there are those seeds
planted in the back of my mind by my medical team (whose members are generally
enthusiastic about my making this trip) about these weeks representing some sort of
'window of opportunity' that may or may not present itself again. Hence a
certain...franticness? Of course, I hope this episode won't end with a curtain falling on
the action, but I'm apprehensive about a potential upcoming change in chemo regimen
and some telltale scans, likely in June. Ah well, "I'll think about it tomorrow."
label: joy

text:
Many, many thanks to the most recent donors - Scott S., Josh, and Nancy - to the Kelly
Gynecological Oncology Service's annual Stride and Thrive event ("Reunite and
Reignite") to help women combatting gyn. cancers. We've reached 40.7% of our
fundraising goal. To donate, please find the relevant link listed in the posting a few
entries before this one; please let me know if you'd like help locating it.
Also: would any State College (or other?) peeps be available to drive me to Newark
airport on W 4 May to catch my 6:30 p.m. flight to Paris? On the return, I will fly from
Newark directly back to State College, but would really prefer to drive directly to Newark
on the 4th rather than getting there via NYC. The direct flight to Newark from SC will not
work out for me on the 4th. I realize this is a big ask but thought I'd try.
I haven't written in a while. There's been much activity recently. I'm trying to take
advantage of the proverbial "window of opportunity" my doctors have identified for me
to travel, see friends and family etc. This makes for a very busy time. Cancer time is so
strange. Because there is so much uncertainty surrounding my health, I am often
compelled to measure time in very short increments. Let me get through the day, the
week, two weeks. Long-range planning is tough. Cancer time also seems to unfold as it is
doing now: 'honeymoon periods' of intense activity v. periods of fallow time. I've had to
adjust to a completely different way of structuring my time (which is in part a feature of
retirement): the academic calendar, semesters, portions of semesters, school holidays
etc. used to structure my time. No longer.
Like Icarus' wings of feathers and wax, mine are flimsy, yet I still, often mistakenly,
expect that they will allow me to 'reach the sun,' to fulfill all my goals, realize my hopes
etc. It's not really a question of hubris in my case, but rather wishes, hopes, dreams, and
imaginings that things might be 'like before.' They can't, and at times I still rebel against
accepting this.  I almost passed out in a coffee shop near my mother's house yesterday,
due to a combination of feeling overheated in a small, crowded below ground coffee
shop, dehydrated, slightly nauseous, and tired from standing for about 15 minutes to
chat with a close friend I had run into in the coffee shop. Beyond this, my red blood cell
count is somewhat depressed from chemo.  This perfect storm forced me to slump down
into a chair, in a cold sweat, with my head on the table until I could get sufficient fluids
into me. The baristas called EMS! The nice EMS workers asked if I wanted to go to the
hospital, but I definitely wanted to avoid this. Instead, the friend I had run into (my
wonderful photographer friend Laurent, whom I've known for 41 years since he was my
student in Avignon and whom I seem to run into on the street every time I'm in the city)
insisted on walking me home, arm in arm, to make sure I was ok. I lay down for a while
when I got back to my mother's apartment and felt ok, but took it fairly easy for the rest
of the day.
                    
This morning I had planned to get up very early to head out to Brooklyn to see Ben run in
the Brooklyn half-marathon (the ostensible original purpose of this NY trip). But I slept
very poorly and had a bit of a stomach ache, so I gave up on that idea at about 6 a.m.
and wrote Ben to tell him. I was extremely disappointed not to be able to check out the
lively scene (20.000 runners!) and cheer Ben on, but feel I made the right decision,
especially foregoing standing amidst a huge crowd for hours.... My brother Ethan, who
had kindly agreed to meet me at Grand Army Plaza, did make it out there, snapping  a
pic of Ben as he ran past. Oh well. It's still hard to live with so much 'fomo,' and hard to
channel regret into acceptance rather than depression. Serenity is needed.
I'm feeling ok, tired, stomach a bit queasy, but ok. Every other night or so I seem to
sleep poorly and that is wretched. [p.s. For my friends I have plans to see in the city the
next two days, and then in State College, and then in Paris, I definitely want to meet up
with you - my friends are important to me - and feel well enough to do so. I just need to
not go too far afield and must get ample fresh air and water --- it's all good and I'll let
you know if that changes!]
Every day a gift, no matter what, must retain that. 
Have had some strange dreams recently. One featured my high school classmates, our
band of 32 'sisters,' several of whom I will be blessed to reunite with soon (lunch with
Eva and Zia tomorrow; trip to Paris with Jill; dinner in Paris with Jill and our classmate
Christina and her husband Vincent). In the dream I was late to an event at the
schoolhouse on 92nd street (depicted extremely realistically in the dream). I saw myself
running through the corridors and up the staircases of the school to get to the event,
some sort of ceremony in the auditorium (also appearing in exact detail!) in which my
class was participating or would be honored. Finally catching up to my class as it
processed into the auditorium in a compact group, I noticed that the classmates were all
stylishly dressed, yet I could really only see them from the back as I was following the
group. Christina (whom we'll see in Paris) was wearing a chic off the shoulder dress in a
colorful pattern. Another classmate was wearing a white suit (skirt/jacket) in a crepe-like
fabric. I looked good enough, but my outfit seemed *old-fashioned;* a maroon dress that
reached to the knees or below, hair done fairly stylishly but nothing like the others. So
there I was, *behind the times, of another era, frozen in time in some sense, hoping to
catch up, hoping not to be left back.* I don't want to leave these girlhood friends - the
dream was clear on that point.
Last night's dream: I'm in a house that belongs to me but is unfamiliar. It's luxurious:
tiling on the floor (as in an Italian villa), a long, elegant hallway with many rooms off it. I
am tasked with showing it to Christina B., one of my former undergraduate students
(who also participated in a trip I led to Paris). I was unfamiliar with the house and had
trouble finding the light switches so I could illuminate successive rooms and parts of the
house. The first room we came to off a long hallway turned out to belong to my former
                    
brother-in-law, Bruce (whose voice I may have heard 'offstage'). For some reason, today,
the Biblical verse "In my father's house there are many rooms" is stuck in my mind, but
I'm not sure why. The other 'half' of this dream (presenting a contrast, but it's vague in
my memory) had to do with hospitalization, procedures, medical equipment,
unpleasantness (and my connection to these), yet also a cake being left for me as a gift.
Paging Dr. Freud?
Ben came home for over a week, which was wonderful. We enjoyed a meaningful seder,
using a new (to us) Haggadah by Marcia Falk, which has a much more feminist, current,
'relatable' bent than our old school, ultra-patriarchal Haggadot (that instructs the 'master
of the house' to perform various  ritual actions). The Haggadah drew attention to the role
of women in the Exodus story and pondered why none of the women (except Miriam,
belatedly) are named, including Pharaoh's daughter, who raised Moses. The meal, which
I had worked on intermittently for about two weeks, was delicious, and we enjoyed
singing some traditional songs (and some less traditional ones), including "Miriam's
Song," which we had introduced to Ben when he was little (he'll always know,
consequently, that a 'timbrel' is a tabmourine!). We also talked about the "personal
mizrayim" ("narrow places") that we hope to be delivered from, and read a prayer for
Ukraine. The rest of the week Ben and I did our separate things -- he had class (online),
job interviews, homework etc. while I had plenty of tasks and work to take care of. I
introduced Ben to the movie "The Woman in Gold" so he could learn about the history of
looted art in Vienna, where he'll be headed next month to visit Sammi; we also checked
out several nights of NBA playoffs. He drove me to chemo, labs etc. and also to the city
this past Friday. I've always enjoyed the long car trips with Ben -- we listen to podcasts
("The Daily" and other NYTimes podcasts) and tunes, share lunch (the last of the matzah,
mine with avocado spread) at a picnic site off Route 80, and shoot the breeze. This is
where the best talks happen. :)
Another lesson from today: My son and my brother are here, and they will finish the race
for me.
Be well, everyone.
 
 
 
 
 
                    
 
Photos

text:
[Hi everyone, I am in Paris right now, having a great time -- and so far Covid free,
yippee! -- but wanted to send this entry of which I wrote a draft on May 3, hoping to
finish before I left for France. The moving image changes quickly and the past several
weeks have been most eventful, but I did want to at least get a short post off before I
have a chance to write more fully when I'm back. It's a gorgeous day in Paris, and I'm off
to do a bit of present shopping before meeting my friend Doris in the Marais for lunch
outdoors at La Terrasse des Archives. Then later, a drink with my friend David Drach at
the Cafe La Perle and dinner with my ride or die travel companion, Jill, at Breizh Cafe
(among the best crepes in Paris, I'm told). As of today: Life is good!). XO
I wanted to write a quick update on the eve of my departure for Paris tomorrow. It's been
over a week since I've written. I do feel well enough to undertake the trip, despite all
manner of cancer-related symptoms. As per my labs, my magnesium levels were low so
Dr. Patel ordered magnesium infusions that wound up taking about five hours yesterday
and today. Diarrhea is still a problem (and a worry, for all the reasons - I have lots of
medication with me!). The past few days, I've also been having some discomfort on the
right side of my head (my 'bad' side): my skull feels stiff, tight and somewhat
constricted, I have some tenderness behind my ear and in a few other spots. The anxiety
that consumed me on Sunday abated considerably when one of the nurses messaged Dr.
Patel on Monday; he ticked off the telltale signs of brain cancer recurrence (searing
headaches, blurry vision, balance problems), of which I have been experiencing *none.*
Today he was in the office and was able to briefly come to the infusion room to examine
my head. He thinks my symptoms are related to post-op changes (yes, even after three
months) -- perhaps the formation of scar tissue, perhaps some inflammation. If I had told
him sooner, he said, he likely would have ordered an MRI out of an abundance of
caution, and we'll probably move my brain scan up from mid- to early-June or late May.
But I only began fixating on my skull a few days ago, despite less recent (and maybe
milder?) symptoms. Meanwhile, I will travel with a veritable pharmacy of meds -
Oxycodone, a steroid, antibiotic etc. in case I become symptomatic. Energy level is
pretty good. In the moments when I stop being anxious I can hardly contain my
excitement.
I feel like such a worry-wart. But please understand that very soon after my last trip to
Paris, three years ago, I was diagnosed with ovarian cancer. I am nearly positive that I
had cancer already when in March 2019 I took eighteen students under my wing for a
transformative week of meetings with Auschwitz survivors, hidden children, historians,
visits to Holocaust memorials etc. I remember showering one morning in the hotel, my
hands running over my bloated belly, a telltale sign of ovarian cancer. I've forgiven
myself for letting a serious health issue take the back seat to a once-in-a-lifetime study
tour. But I still carry guilt and trauma with me. Hence, my anxiety.
Many thanks to my friends Nancy, Sandy and John, the most recent contributors to the
"Reunite and Reignite" initiative to help KEGOS. Please help *if possible;* I realize not
                    
everyone can, nor does everyone want to, for a range of valid reasons. I do not take this
*in any way* personally. But I will continue to be a warrior for women's cancer care.
Given the uncertainty of so much in my life right now, this is one of the ways I feel I can
have real *agency* and empower myself to help other women with 'below the belt'
cancers.
My recent trips to New York and Bedford Springs were memorable for my 'reunions' with
very dear friends from grade/high school, college and grad school. Why were these get
togethers so heart-warming? I'm not entirely sure! Whenever I'm with Eva, Zia, Mitchel,
Bryan, Vinni and Isa (et al - these were the friends I saw on this trip), I'm in a safe space.
The shared history, the road travelled, the coming of age together are all grounding. The
affection. And I rarely *laugh* as hard as I do with the old friends. [I will add that of
course it was wonderful to spend time with my mother -- we made a beeline for the pizza
place as soon as Passover was over -- Arnold, and Ben, with whom I drove to the city
from State College].
In the city I had breakfast w/Bryan, a college friend and NYC kid like myself, at my go-to
coffee shop around the corner from my mother's, Sunburst. We talked about Paris (a city
both of us love, where we've also hung out together), classmates, our aging mothers,
current life/career goals and challenges. A nice morning!
On one occasion, you reach over and casually pick up a chunk of my scone from my
plate. With other dear ones, we laugh hysterically, doubled over, nearly falling off our
seats, our body movements signaling the many other times we've laughed this hard in
the past, all the goofy adventures. Friendship. :)
The ostensible reason for my trip to the city was Ben's participation in the Brooklyn half-
marathon. Unfortunately, I didn't sleep well Saturday night and consequently felt
unsteady Sunday morning -- so I didn't make it. This depressed me, as the pre-cancer
Willa would have had more stamina, poor sleep or not. Fortunately, my brother, with
whom I had planned to meet up at Grand Army Plaza, continued on to Brooklyn and
cheered his nephew on, snapping a pic of him and even getting a low five from Ben as
he ran past. So glad that the valiant Ethan could be there. Ben finished the 13.1 mile
race along with several of his buddies, and their day continued on over beers and cheers
and brunch in Brooklyn.
 
More soon! Greetings from my happy place! :)
label: joy

text:
I don't have Covid, at least not yet. Nor am I symptomatic. I've consistently tested
negative since this past Monday, the day my dear friend and travel companion
extraordinaire, Jill, tested positive for the virus, in Paris. Jill's comment (like me, Jill
usually goes light on the swear words): "Un-fucking-believable."
I had finished a loong lunch (the way we like 'em) outdoors at the Terrasse des Archives
Monday, catching up with my wonderful grad school friend Doris and indulging in my
'one per trip' entretcôte frites, when I looked at my phone and saw a message from Jill:
"Can you please call me?" Uh-oh. We were supposed to meet up later so that I could take
her to dinner at Breizh Café, a well-known, highly recommended crêperie in the Marais.
Before that I was to meet my friend David Drach for drinks at Café La Perle nearby. I sat
on a bench in the "Place des 260 Enfants" deported from the Marais, which I've visited
many times with my students, and FaceTimed Jill. I found her propped up on a pillow
against the bright floral wallpaper of her hotel room. "Willa," she moaned, "I tested
positive." She was clearly distraught, more concerned about my catching it than having
it herself (she's that caring and mindful a person). Apparently, she had been out
shopping in the morning and had begun to feel ill (with cold symptoms) when she sat
down for lunch. She returned to the hotel, took a Covid home test, and voilà. Un-fucking-
believable. Jill is of course vaccinated and boosted. We had taken pains to be careful in
Paris, masking upon entering stores and in Ubers, in the hotel etc. But undeniably we
had removed our masks to eat breakfast as well as fixings for one dinner bought at the
marché d'Aligre in the room designated for this purpose in the hotel, and in the street. I
                    
was surprised by how few people appeared to mask in Paris, though (and perhaps it's no
better in the States, but my impression is that in New York most people are more
vigilant). When had Jill contracted COVID? From whom? Was I slated to be 'felled' next,
given how much time we had spent together the past several days? Should I prepare for
the Covid-cancer whammy?
Jill suggested I might want to change my flights and leave earlier than planned, an idea I
pretty much dismissed out of hand as I was enjoying my week and somehow feeling
'entitled' to it given the cancer-related challenges I had confronted to get to Paris. Over
the next twelve hours or so, on speaking with a few friends, and thinking through the
situation, I began to change my mind. My contracting COVID on top of cancer and being
stuck in Paris was, in fact, my worst nightmare (and Dr. Beavis' as well). Of course, I felt
terribly for Jill and didn't necessarily want to leave her to fend for herself. On the other
hand, I had confidence in Jill's sensible nature and stability (although she was driven to
tears at least once and if our situations had been reversed I'm convinced I would have
been a blubbering mess at the outset), the support arriving from her husband in Cali, her
three grown daughters, her travel agent who had helped arrange the trip for us. the kind
and helpful staff of our hotel, and, I hope, from me.
In any event, I did continue on to drinks with my friend David Drach (a dear, whose
father's film about the family's fate as French Jews during the Second World War, _Les
Violons du Bal,_ I have shown many times to my students and who has travelled to Penn
State several times to present it) and his newish boyfriend, Patrizio (hope I have that
name right). It was wonderful to see him, but I felt distracted and stressed. Then, since I
was right near Breizh Café, I dined solo there, preoccupied by our Covid worries and
unsure what to do. I walked back to the hotel (despite swollen ankles and feet, a problem
that concerned me all week, although I felt no pain from it, thankfully), stopping en route
at a pharmacy place de la République, which turned out to be open *24 hours/24,* a
relatively rarity in Paris. Outside the pharmacy a Covid testing site was set up. I
explained to the technician, a kind young woman in a hijab, that I had been exposed to
Covid and wanted to be tested (antigen test, pretty much identical to the home test).
She had me fill out a form and then pay a 20 euro fee at the register in the pharmacy.
She then explained to me that the French test involves much more 'force' than the
American one, and that I should prepare myself for that. Indeed, she jabbed the swab
deep into my nasal cavity, leaving me gasping and pained. I was most thankful, though,
for the negative result, which she implied would likely persist (I was not sure I believed
her fully on that, though, as I hadn't explained the entire chronology of the past several
days to her).
Back at the hotel, Jill and I, although in adjacent rooms, FaceTimed each other, as we
would the next day, an absurdity that made us laugh in spite of ourselves.
I slept poorly but my insomnia had the benefit of giving me time to formulate a plan to
                    
return home a day early, *provided* that I receive an official negative Covid test result,
required in order to leave France. As I had an appointment at the Maison Vever at noon, I
had to move quite quickly Tuesday morning. So first I returned to the Covid testing site
for my 'official' test and again, miraculously to me, received a negative result, which I
had actually prayed/wished for. This time I would need to get on the same long line
*twice* to pay. When I told the technician that I really preferred to pay for everything at
once (ie once for the test and then again for the official stamp and form), she was nice
enough to eliminate one of my trips to the cash register. While awaiting my test result,
nervously, I walked to the café next door and ordered a café crème and a croissant,
which I consumed while contemplating the massive statue of the French Republic in the
middle of the square. Armed with my "get of France free" (or almost....) card, I then
hurried back to my hotel a few blocks away, called United, and succeeded in booking the
same flight home a day earlier. When I was on hold w/United, I got on the Expedia
website and also changed the Newark>State College leg of my flight to a day earlier
too.  Having taken care of these 'essentials,' I felt much better, as I had found myself
sweating profusely most of the morning, when these arrangements were still in flux.
So...much...uncertainty. I had just enough time to contact my cousin Claudia and let her
know that I might have to cancel our dinner for Wednesday night (damn you, Covid) and
also let Mme Vever know that I might be a bit late for our noon rdv. I then FaceTimed Jill
(in the next room) to see how she was feeling and whether she needed anything.
Jill is still in Paris. She isn't feeling too badly and tells me that her Covid feels more like a
cold, at worst a mild flu. And every day she feels better. She spoke with Randy's doctor,
who looks hot btw (Randy showed me his photo!) and who Jill said was lovely (I had
given her Dr. Mallet's number). The doctor wrote Jill a note in French and English
enabling her to leave France next *Tuesday,* unless she tests negative before that. Jill's
travel agent helped her find a new hotel in the Marais (Jill had to change hotels as ours
was booked), and she's there now; she feels well enough to take short walks and buy
herself food, medicine and other essentials. I feel terribly for her, but she's a trooper
(and a fabulous travel companion, whom I will laud appropriately in another post!).
I am back in State College. Irony #1: the United agent who checked my passport would
not have looked at my Covid status form, which she is supposed to check, if *I had not
reminded her to do so.* In essence, I could have 'gotten through' without it (because of
this particular agent's oversight); presumably, Jill might have as well. Irony #2: after all
the precautions, tests, official forms etc. on my part, a woman sitting in the row behind
me CDG to Newark had a hacking cough and coughed, spit up saliva, and remained
unmasked during most of the seven-hour flight.
We live in strange times.
More to come.
label: surprise

text:
[I'm back in PA now, but catching up on everything, including rest, after a four back to
back trip tear whose pace some friends have described as 'insane.' No plans to go
anywhere for a while. I started this post a few days ago, in NY.]
Once again I'm writing 'out of order' as I still want to recount my previous trips (NY,
Bedford Springs, Paris). I'll get back to that. But today is a big day, as I'm in the city
(once again) to celebrate Ben's graduation with an M.S. in Data Science from NYU over
lunch for twelve in Chinatown (Ben is opting out of the actual ceremonies, both for the
entire university -- at Yankee Stadium featuring Taylor Swift as speaker -- and for the
Masters' candidates, at the Beacon Theatre uptown). The lunch -- my idea -- will bring
together the Berkman and Silverman clans: Ben's parents (ie me and Michael) and
stepmom (Sue), grandmother (Sharon) and Arnold, Ethan and family (Ronit), Michael's
brother Bruce, and three cousins (two Silverman, one Berkman, Eve, Isaac and Rachel).
Thirty-three years ago we celebrated my own graduation with a Ph.D. from NYU with a
luncheon at a now defunct Italian restaurant on University Place. I remember it as
pleasant. My dad, of blessed memory, wore his own academic regalia as I wore mine that
day; today, though, belongs to Ben, as we celebrate three generations of our affiliation
with NYU. And Michael was with us for lunch on graduation day in 1989 as he was to wish
his son well in 2022. We weren't married yet, but he helped me celebrate my
accomplishment just as I travelled with him out to Bloomington that year to celebrate his
(a loong road trip with an overnight in Columbus, Ohio). We miss Michael's parents too,
and my dad. They would be kvelling.
I am happy to be alive, to toast this happy moment with family and friends. My trip to NY
last month, overnight at the Bedford Springs resort with Vinni and Isa, and recent week
in Paris were all 'shehecheyanu' occasions, colored by my gratitude for simply having
*made it* to the day: "Blessed are You, Adonai our God, Sovereign of all, who has kept
us alive, sustained us, and brought us to this season." The four consecutive trips since
late April, taken together, have a somewhat 'breathy' quality to them. I'm tearing
through what my oncologists have described as a 'window of opportunity' before my
upcoming brain scan and pelvic/abdominal/chest CT, possible change in treatment plan,
and lots of new question marks regarding my health and prognosis, all of which are
making me anxious and, at times, depressed. These feelings are perhaps amplified a bit
by Dr. Patel's brusqueness yesterday (in my perception); he intoned somewhat
ominously, re my upcoming scans, "there will be findings," and, re my treatment, "we'll
run out of options" (neither of which are news to me, but somehow I expected a lighter
touch from him). I'm in frantic carpe diem mode ("But at my back I always hear/Time's
winged chariot hurrying near."). I'm certainly feeling 'well enough,' or perhaps I simply
powered my way through on some combination of adrenaline and #willapower. Yet I may
also be sensing in myself some undercurrent of panic, a need to keep moving at all
costs, to invoke a _perpetuum mobile,_ to dance on the edge of a volcano, to make
                    
myself a moving target, to 'run on empty,' to ward off the inevitable (?), despite Dr.
Beavis' observation that I "sounded good" in her response the note I sent  her yesterday,
accompanied by a photo of me looking peppy and radiant in Paris. Catch me if you can...
If I keep busy, if I keep surrounding myself with loved ones, I reason, I'm safe. If I stay
still for too long, cancer will find me. Perhaps 'bringing the happy' is actually having a
beneficial effect on my health (or perhaps that's just magical thinking). Who knows? Just
puzzling it all out can be exhausting. In the meantime, though, I plan to get out and
enjoy this gloriously beautiful day in the city, fortified by a yummy cappuccino, nails
manicured with Opi's "Princesses Rule" polish and decked out in a new dress from Anne-
Elisabeth (one of last week's purchases in Paris).
"Well, after all is said and done
I did all right, I had my fun
I will walk before they make me
I will walk before they make me run."
The gathering of the clans:
Our dim sum lunch for twelve in Chinatown, on a glorious spring day under brilliant blue,
cloudless skies,  was great fun. Clattering silver carts bore all manner of dumplings,
sesame balls, rice cakes and cooling coconut and tofu desserts. If I can compliment
myself on two things (and God knows I have much to reproach myself for, too, over the
course of my life), I will note my happiness over 1)my ability to, even talent for,
*federating* disparate friends and family members during uplifting events such as these
(for which I provided the impetus). Nothing makes me happier than to introduce
members of my different friend groups in the hopes that they too might become friends. 
This worked most marvelously in the case of Mitchel, my dear best friend from college,
and Randy, a dear best friend from grad school. Introduced at a party at my mom's
apartment (I think) in the early 1980s, this pair became best friends themselves, thick as
thieves, and the three of us form an unbreakable, 'ride or die' trio. Mitchel befriended a
number of my grad school friends; there are crossovers between Mitchel, Randy and my
high school friends, too. Although I'll be six feet under, literally or symbolically (haven't
decided yet), nothing would please me more (hint, hint) than the image of having all
these folks who are so important to me gathered together, with hope that their own
friendships will form or deepen, in perpetuity; 2)any small role I've played (and I believe
I've worked hard for it, as have Michael and all others involved) in ensuring the success
and continued health of such post-divorce gatherings. It was warming to see how
genuinely happy everyone seemed to be together (in some cases, after many years),
how relaxed everyone appeared, how much affection was visible (at least, that's how it
seemed to me). I personally was delighted to chat with Michael's older brother, Bruce,
who I took to lunch in State College not that long ago, and his older daughter, Rachel
(who was two at our wedding, now a lovely 31-year-old Pilates instructor living in the
                    
city). Of course, Ben's graduation with an M.S. from NYU, his new job (one of five offers)
and two-week trip to Vienna to visit Sammi (he just arrived this morning) all added up to
an eminently "the kids are alright" moment, and Ben seemed...well, like Ben (kudos,
Ben, for your history of navigating potentially fraught family situations with ease and
grace, as you are so good at doing; we love you and you can count on your family's
support). One big happy modern family! I rest easier knowing that Ben and Michael are
and have always been extremely close and that Sue is an excellent stepmother. More
than me, Michael was often the one awake at 3 a.m. to change or comfort Ben in the
middle of the night, hanging out with his baby to watch frisbee golf on t.v., the only
reasonable option at 3 a.m. on a weekday.  I know I can count on them to watch over
Ben and also, I hope, to maintain my memory and continue to impart my values and life
lessons.
We lingered outside the restaurant, snapping pictures and chatting. I love days when
time unspools in a most natural way, seemingly untethered to clocks or schedules or
'conventional' time.
Michael, Sue, Bruce, Ben and I then walked to NYU, where a sprawling, crowded street
fair for the graduates filled Washington Square Park and the surrounding streets, awash
in NYU violet splashed on regalia, signs, banners etc. We enjoyed iced coffee outside for
a while at a café on Laguardia Place, at a table dwarfed by NYU's pink-red granite Bobst
Library across the street. Memory dump:
>It is 1974 and I have my first summer job, as a book shelver at Bobst. I am fifteen. To
set it up, my father had spoken with the manager of Bobst, Mr. Flanagan, whom he knew
slightly and whose daughter and her friends had nabbed the same job as me. These kids
were all (Irish) Catholic and had thick Long Island accents; I had never met anyone like
them before. Working with us was a big bunch of 'older' (college age?) folks, so different
from me that I was taken way out of my upper-east-side girls' private school comfort
zone in a good way: a nice couple, Richie and Emily, who took me under their wing, a
good-looking guy named Doug whom I had a crush on (according to my diary from that
summer, Doug was one of several of my coworkers who piqued my attention -- and vice-
versa), a guy named Henry, just back from service in ....'nam (the war was still ongoing,
so long ago...), a beautiful, delicate-looking man from Haiti, Jean, to whom I jabbered in
my best high school French, a guy named Calderon who taught me some Spanish, a guy 
named Sidney who had his own radio show on the NYU station, and others. My family
had been watching the Watergate hearings on t.v. that summer and I remember walking
home from Bobst the day Nixon was expected to resign, extremely worried about what
would happen to the country (it was the first time in my life, but certainly not the last,
that I sensed a threat to our democracy). I remember feeling grown up that summer
sharing dinner, laughs, and perhaps an illegal beer for me with my coworkers at Factoria,
a 'fun' Italian restaurant near the Plaza (58th st.) with unlimited pasta and pitchers of
beer and sangria (a kind of Cheesecake Factory before its time?). The others invited me
                    
to continue our summer night in the city at a club, but in those days my parents still
imposed a curfew...
>It is about 1983 and Mitchel (then an NYU law student), Randy and I are studying at a
long table in a large room at the front of Bobst, overlooking Washington Square Park
(this memory is faint).
>It is summer 1985, and Vinni and I are back from a year in Paris, spending the summer
studying for our Ph.D. comps in October before heading back to Paris for another year.
We grind and cram all day, emerging only at lunchtime, a bit dazed, for a break under
the sweltering July New York sun. We try to find shade on a bench in the park for a while
(I remember buying Sabrett hot dogs for lunch from a cart on the corner), testing each
other on both random facts as well as themes we might need to be conversant with for
our exams ("History of anticlericalism in France; go!"). Then back into the air-conditioned
library for a few more hours.
>2018 (sometime in first half): A seasoned researcher and author by this point, I spend
about a week in Bobst's rare book room, reading the records of Gilded Age New Yorkers
who employed the upscale caterer Louis Sherry for their luncheons and dinners, this for
a project on 19th century Franco-American culinary exchanges. I still head out to the
benches in Washington Square Park at lunchtime and get lost in people watching.
Ben and I peeled away from Bruce, Michael and Sue and checked out the street fair, then
sat on a bench in WSP for a while (it still reeks of pot, much as I remember from my
teenage years). We then continued on to my mother's (all in all, a good 2+ mile walk for
me that day), where we hung out until Ben had to go on to a graduation party in Bklyn.
A good day. Shehecheyanu.
 
Photos
label: joy

text:
I guess I've sort of bought into the narrative spun by Drs. Beavis and Patel, of a "window
of opportunity" dutifully taken advantage of during my four successive trips, a sort of
'victory lap' or 'hail and farewell' before all-important scans and then some sort of
'descent' (Dr. Patel on the upcoming scans: "There will be findings." Dr. Beavis: "I may
want to start you on Avastin after the scans" -- Avastin, the drug with a 5% risk of bowel
perforation, perhaps a higher risk in my case because of my fistula operation, a bowel
perforation that would mean, per Dr. Beavis, "game over"). So that's why I lay awake
again last night, consumed by thoughts of my mortality: how do I arrange for a 'green
burial?' Ensure that specific pieces of jewelry are given to certain individuals? Work out
all the financials, beyond the basics of my will? I feel 'well enough,' despite being
                    
increasingly concerned by discomfort and stiffness on the right side of my skull (the
surgery side) that has bothered me for about a month. While Dr. Patel and Dr.
Bettegowda's PA, both of whom I queried about this before leaving for Paris, told me that
they thought the skull stiffness and discomfort was attributable to 'post-op changes'
(even up to four months after the fact?...) rather than cancer (I have none of the
recognizable brain cancer symptoms: headaches, double vision, balance problems), Dr.
Patel (who even briefly examined my skull before I left for Paris) now wants me to have a
brain/head MRI asap. Consequently, I've moved my MRI up to this Friday from June 13, at
the ungodly hour of 5:30...a.m.! Driving to the hospital at that hour should
be...interesting (I'll need to keep my eyes sharply focused on any deer that may cross
my path), although the sun will be out by the time I'm done, just in time for me to head
to...chemo. Oy. I don't know what's up with my head/brain/skull but I hope it doesn't get
worse (I may try to move my MRI up to even sooner). I also hope I haven't waited too
long to act, but was relying, perhaps erroneously, on what my doctors had told me
(including Dr. Patel the younger's statement that there was only a 15% of my brain
cancer recurring). I'm fairly consumed by anxiety about this, as you can likely tell.
As I shared with my friend Jackie, who picked me up from chemo on Friday (we always
get right to some quality conversation in the car), I was unhappy with Dr. Patel's
brusqueness the previous day. This is a trait I detected in him from the outset, but it
seemed to have mellowed the more I got to know him. When I asked him to what he
might attribute the stiffness in my skull, he barked "I need a test!" He sees so many
patients that he seemed to have forgotten basics about my treatment, including which
drug I'm currently receiving! And perhaps he was simply having a bad day; he expressed
frustration to me about another ovarian cancer patient he's seeing, who is refusing
treatments that would benefit her and whose husband seems completely clueless about
his wife's condition. "It's very challenging," said Dr. Patel. I can only imagine (but please
don't take your frustration out on me!). Meanwhile, Dr. Beavis is in Spain on a well-
deserved bike trip and won't be back for a while. Dr. Stephanie Wethington, who I know
a bit from Hopkins, is in charge of Dr. Beavis' patients while she's away, and my
impression is that, like the entire KEGOS team, she's extremely competent, kind and
responsive. If there's a problem, I will contact her.
Despite my fatigue, I managed to do some work today then, as I like to do, took a long,
relaxing drive in the country in search of fresh produce. This led me down the bumpy
driveways of Amish farms every time I saw a sign for "Asparagus," now abundant, as is
rhubarb (I'm thinking chilled asparagus soup tomorrow, and an omelet w/asparagus and
cheese tonight). I'm the rhubarb 'queen' so can always find a use for the fresh pink fruit.
Also bought some fresh eggs. I love these little roadside farm stands that operate on the
honor system. Take what you need and leave the $ in a cash box; the family's likely
planting or plowing the field (with teams of horses!).
Writing about my recent trips also boosts my morale, so please indulge me (or skip this
                    
section if you prefer). It's all about keeping the 'good' and 'bad' in balance. The bleak
moments make the fabulous ones even sweeter; the fabulous ones make the bleak time
easier to handle, as there's such an accumulation of stuff to be grateful for. See series of
pictures above: 1-3. Wonderful reunion lunch in the city with my high school pals Eva
and Zia. While I've seen Eva (blonde) and Zia (dark hair) separately not too long ago --
Eva in East Hampton this summer as she lives year-round in Sag Harbor, Zia via Zoom
on several occasions during the pandemic -- the three of us hadn't been together in
years. We had so much fun reminiscing and catching up over tapas at Boqueria in the
Flatiron district. Both Eva and Zia entered Nightingale in about eighth grade; perhaps I
felt some kinship with them because our families engaged in artistic/intellectual
professions unlike the Mad Men professions many of our classmates' fathers seemed to
exemplify -- the well-known art movie house, Angelika, was named after Eva's mother,
Angelika Saleh, and her father was a film producer; Zia's mother is the Indian cooking
'guru,' Madhur Jaffrey while her father (stepfather), Sanford Allen, was the first Black
violinist in the NY Philharmonic, and a prominent, highly talented one at that. Zia and I
both lived way downtown, far from the pristine Upper East Side where many of our
classmates lived; Eva and I were both Jewish. I'm sure  our classmates' reality was much
different than the way I perceived it at the time, but nevertheless I often felt marginal vis
à vis the dominant NBS culture. Eva and Zia were partners in crime, engaging with me in
all sorts of kooky mischief (much of which cannot be divulged here!); confidants (all
those sleepovers! all that laughter!); and later, cherished, trusted friends. Zia and I have
always bonded over writing, including a few tentative joint writing efforts; she's a
talented published author, and a writing teacher at the New School. I hope the pictures
convey how happy we were to spend time with one another. As Zia and I were seated
too far away from each other across the table to give one another a hug during the
photo, we held hands and lifted them in a kind of triumphant 'salute,' and then giggled
about it.
Pictures 4-5. As soon as my mother opened the door to her apartment to welcome
Mitchel, I knew I'd hear his warm, energetic, enthusiastic voice: "It's so good to see
you!!" Then I knew I'd get the biggest, tightest hug ever. My first real friend in college,
Mitchel and a female pal of his befriended me my freshman year (they were
sophomores) in a class we were taking on Proust. I was the only freshman in the class,
really way out of my league. I barely opened my mouth the entire semester. Mitchel and
his friend took me under their wing, inviting me to parties and showing me much
friendliness. When I was twenty, Mitchel and I travelled Italy north to south, a memorable
trip. We overlapped for several years at NYU, and have always visited with one another
either in NY, Paris (often with our friend Randy), or Nice (where Mitchel now lives with his
partner, Fabien). Mitchel has a gift for friendship and laughter; here we are sitting on a
bench in St. Mark's Place in the Village (we had had a lovely lunch near my mom's
apartment, and had then walked over to Veselka, where I bought a quart of their
delicious mushroom barley soup). We had just taken this selfie and were accusing one
another of looking 'feeble,' heads cocked awkwardly, odd smiles, and eyes looking
                    
askance. For some reason, we both found this vision of us as feeble hysterical and were
literally nearly falling off the bench, doubled over in laughter. The second picture of us,
on the couch in my mother's living room, contains all the love, connection, silliness, and
memories of a beautiful friendship. :)
"These fragments I have shored against my ruins."
Photos

text:
Am still catching up, and for the moment seem to be veering into diary writing as a
"preserving memories" exercise rather than a means for providing health
updates, pace Caring Bridge. But the two are in fact related, as mentioned in my last
entry. I'm in a bit of a funk, concerned about the stiffness in my skull as I await my MRI
on Friday (no earlier appointments available this week as of this morning), have written
to all my doctors (depressed that Dr. Patel the younger never responded to a message I
wrote him on *May 2* to discuss the concern about my skull), have considered then
rejected the possibility of going to the ER here (truly a place of last resort for me, unless
the situation becomes intolerable). A bunch of my friends are away for the summer or a
good part of it (while others, thankfully, are here) and I feel isolated in my worry, vox
clamantis in deserto. Nevertheless, I managed to do some work this morning, my brain
appears to be functioning in terms of cognition and memory, and I feel nowhere near as
ill as I did when my friend Martina kindly drove me to Lewistown hospital for an MRI in
January, and from there I was life-flighted to Hopkins....
It's summer, and I'd love to be travelling or out in nature, in abundant good health. Oh
well. Must hold on to the good memories from the past few weeks.
I wonder if I'm writing in my journal too much. Today, it's diverting me, calming me,
providing me with an interlocutor, lifting my mood a bit. But I don't want to bring anyone
down with this.
*Update just now: Dr. Patel the younger's office just messaged me and asked me to
come in for an appointment tomorrow at 2 p.m. in case I need a prescription from him as
a radiation oncologist. I will do this! The fact that they are not telling me to go to the ER
immediately makes me feel somewhat relieved.
I knew that among the friends or groups I wanted to spend time with these days my grad
school friends would have pride of place. There's something about the intensity of the
range of  experiences we shared from approx 1982 to 1988, in addition to all the dinner
parties, outings, travel (two years in Paris for me and Vinni, plus London, Madrid...),
laughter, adventures, life milestones, illnesses, new jobs, children (many sons!) etc.
we've experienced together, that has created an unshakeable bond among us as friends,
women, colleagues. Further, this group of (mainly) women friends has been
extraordinarily caring to me throughout my illness. I am so very grateful.
I concocted a plan to treat my 'filles' to a weekend in the country (chez moi), including
an overnight at Omni Bedford Springs Resort and Spa, a pretty ritzy resort about 1.5
hours from here, which in the late 19th c. was the site of a 'wellness retreat' for well-
heeled patrons, due to the many mineral springs in the area. I had stayed at the hotel
once, which is chock full of memorabilia and photos recalling the resort's past as a place
for 'taking the waters.' As many of my grad school friends are devotees of the c. 1900
era, I thought this would be a great choice for us, and we've always been in favor of all
                    
sorts of indulgences over the years (most recently, purchasing, when we have the
means, specific porcelain patterns, original posters from the c. 1900 era etc.). So a 'girls
spa day' seemed like an appropriate treat.
Two friends, Harriet and Shanny, were unfortunately unable to make the trip. Shanny
surely would have brought her crystal pendulum for us to interrogate, her intention-
setting cards, and her irreverent humor (she's the one who instructs us -- all of us
lifelong scholars of France, one of us French -- to yell "Fuck France" instead of "Cheese"
or even "Fromage" when our picture is taken). But Vinni, Isa and I had plenty of laughs;
in fact, we've been laughing, crying, and everything in between together for forty years.
Our invented franglais lexicon includes the terms "frapper la route" ("hit the road"), "sac
de louches" ("scumbag") and, as of our most recent visit, "sans clou" ("clueless"). For
anyone in the know, these are literal translations of French phrases and are completely
meaningless and inane, nevertheless sending us into gales of side-splitting laughter, as
do all our numerous 'in jokes.' Maybe you just had to be there...
Vinni and Isa drove to my place from Isa's in Montclair, NJ (Vinni lives near Boston and
had flown to Newark, then met up with Isa for the drive), and we spent the evening
chatting over apéro and dinner before it was time for bed. One or the other of us kept
'losing' her cell phone in my house; highly competent women, we can all nevertheless be
a bit ditzy when we're together... The next morning we breakfasted then fortified
ourselves with coffee from Café Lemont (to which these ladies had kindly offered me a
gift certificate, knowing I love this café's cappuccino, made with milk from a local dairy).
We sat outside in the sun at the café for a bit, before we decided to "frapper la route."
We enjoyed a wonderful day at Bedford Springs: lunched outdoors (weather was lovely)
and later enjoyed Prosecco on the same outdoor patio; hiked one of the many trails to
the 'limestone spring;' dined at a good Italian restaurant in the cute town of Bedford;
checked out some of the c. 1900 artefacts from the resort; toasted marshmallows and
made 'smores at the fire pit; drank champagne and were silly (think feather boas!) in our
hotel rooms.
The spa was very 'ooh la la' and smelled divine. We were given a tour of the different
baths and related relaxation spaces and then had time to enjoy them: first, an energizing
shower called "Le Déluge" (après moi le déluge?) stocked with the heavenly-smelling
(and pricey) products sold in the spa shop; then, the steam room; next, a hot whirlpool
bath; and finally, a cold bath (I was too wimpy to try that). We cycled through the series
of pools and saunas a few times; the decor, fittingly, was again 'Gilded Age' with all
manner of refreshing flavored waters and fresh fruit available throughout the spa. Before
my pedicure, I relaxed in the lounge, a large space outfitted with chaise lounges, potted
palms, small treats to eat and drink, fluffy white robes to wear. Ahh... No massage or
facial for me (unlike for Vinni and Isa) as any manipulation of my lymph nodes is not
advisable for me. But my shiny purple toes are a great look for summer!
                    
After our spa morning, we had lunch at the hotel restaurant before Vinni and Isa took off
for Newark airport and I drove home (in pouring rain).
Two years ago we had a lovely time at Kripalu Yoga Retreat in the Berkshires, this year
we blissed out at Bedford Springs. Where to next time, beautiful and brilliant ladies? It's
guaranteed to be a blast. And in the meanwhile, if any State College (or other) friends
would like to join me for a trip to Bedford Springs (en route to D.C.; easily accessible
from Baltimore and Pittsburgh), please lmk!
Photos

text:
When evil manifests itself so blatantly, I sometimes (fleetingly) think that death will be a
relief from such a cascade of atrocious news. I remember feeling this way in regard to
certain friends or relatives who have died (eg "I'm so glad X didn't live to experience
September 11th;" I'm so glad my father didn't know most of the horrors of the Trump
presidency" « Or Covid. »). I woke up crying today thinking about the massacre of
children and teachers in Texas. The last time I remember literally waking up crying was
when Trump won the presidency in 2016. And yet, of course, we must go on, and must
do what we can to protest this inhuman, evil, obscene aspect of our culture (if my health
holds, I'll definitely put my time behind our critical PA elections in Nov.). And yet, love
abounds as well, as I can attest. Choose the blessing over the curse... (Deuteronomy
30:19).
Somewhat perversely, today I snapped pics of some of our many local gun shops, on the
same road about ten miles out of this progressive university town. Outside one of them,
a sign is proudly, almost brazenly unfurled: "God, Guns, Trump." That pretty much says it
all, doesn't it? Don't tell me gun control is not a political issue. Then needed to drive way
out into the country, amidst the rolling hills and farm stands (fifteen stalks of freshly cut
                    
rhubarb for $2, anyone?), to begin to clear my mind, haunted by the niggling feeling that
in these parts 'quaint' and 'picturesque' often (but not always) translate to conservative,
right-wing (if the road signs are any indication).
Health update: I was able to get an appointment yesterday with my neuro-oncologist's
PA to address the continuing stiffness in my skull and upper neck. I was relieved that her
diagnosis pointed to inflammation rather than the "C word;" she told me that
inflammation can often occur in the skull/brain/head at any point after brain surgery and
radiation, even this far out. She prescribed steroids for me and perhaps just the relief of
having some understanding of what may be going on helped me sleep last night. I don't
feel, at this point for example, that I need to rush to the ER. Of course, more will be
determined from my MRI, scheduled for this Friday. I will then have a neck CT Friday,
June 3 (I actually requested this to address 'puffiness' in my neck, perhaps also caused
by inflammation per the PA) and an abdominal/pelvic/chest CT in mid-June. After these
important scans, a determination will be made about my treatment, eg continue with
weekly Taxol alone or add Avastin; some other option that I may not be aware of.
Knowing that I'm running out of viable treatment options, I will also do a bit more of my
own research on available clinical trials, but those options may be limited for me. In my
fantasy, the situation will be as it has been with my gums: I've been at risk for gum
surgery for years, but somehow have 'held on,' with my gum recession unchanged, for
many years, just on the precipice in relation to the maximum erosion tolerable before a
painful gum graft is prescribed.  My dentist and I have gotten a laugh out of my 'hanging
on by a thread' for years; it's quite remarkable. Wouldn't it be nice if my cancer could
'hold steady' as well? Perhaps I am an outlier. Who knows? We'll find out more soon. Dr.
Beavis has checked in with me from Spain and is definitely on top of the latest
developments, as is Dr. Patel.
I'm concerned for Brenda R., my college classmate who is surviving Stage 4 ovarian
cancer. As I've mentioned, I did not know Brenda in college (unfortunately) but was
introduced to her fairly recently by another Brenda (P.). Brenda R. and I have zoomed
and check in with one another periodically. Brenda reported a few days ago that she's
been in the hospital every month since November, sleeps a lot, and is closely watched by
her two sisters, both staying with her. Her doctors say they've never seen anyone at her
advanced stage survive so long. "Not that I'm going for any records!" Brenda quipped to
me, her text accompanied by several 'laugh' emojis. Yeah, sometimes all we can do is
laugh! You go, Brenda, warrior sister. You are in my thoughts. 
Despite yesterday's tragedy, I am grateful for this pretty day (although actually a bit
cloudy in the end), for being in touch with a number of friends, and for a pretty drive in
the country. Nice memories -- "no, no, they can't take that away from me."
I am working through emails and texts that accrued during my trips, and writing
everyone back in order, more or less. My apologies for the delays. I hope you will hear
                    
from me soon!
This was going to be a post about my Paris trip, but I'm still too overwhelmed by the
thought of children being murdered. But I do want to write about Paris too. A good
project for the holiday weekend.
 
 
*******************************************

text:
Yesterday was grueling. Despite my best efforts to package an alarm set for 3:50 a.m. to
begin my day as an 'adventure,' it wasn't fun. I was up by 4:00 a.m. after about two
hours of sleep, ate a bowl of yogurt topped with homemade strawberry rhubarb sauce
and turned my attention to the NYTimes Spelling Bee (miraculously I attained "Genius"
level at that hour; I'm a faithful Bee girl, sorry all you Wordle fans). Blessings on Ben,
who texted me around 4:30 to wish me well. Although six hours *ahead* of me with
Sammi in Budapest, he had not yet eaten breakfast, but then sent me a photo of the
yummy looking *Israeli* breakfast they were sharing near their Airbnb in the Jewish
quarter of Budapest. Go figure. Many thanks to those who sent very early morning (or
even day before) texts or emails conveying well wishes. You know who you are. I greatly
appreciated them as 4:30 a.m. is an isolating time, at least for me.
I drove to the hospital in a dark rain; as I approached, a few more cars appeared on the
road. A brain MRI is not fun; fortunately, I'm not highly claustrophobic, but the hour's
worth of jackhammering and blaring sounds swirling around my head as the images
were being captured is jarring. Luckily, I was still pretty much half asleep, yet also
fixated (once again) on my process for picking out certain of my jewelry pieces to give to
specific people. I had a few copies of the images made on discs to send to Drs. Beavis,
Patel and Bettegowda. It still astounds me that it seems so complicated for the hospital
here in State College to push the images forward to Dr. Patel the elder, also in State
College yet working for a different medical system, Geisinger Health.
I might mention that my brain MRI was scheduled for a few weeks from now at a more
reasonable hour, but I decided to move it up once what is increasingly seeming like
inflammation, manifesting itself as a 'stiffness' in my skull, began to bother me. A steroid
I'm taking for that problem appears to be helping a lot, thankfully! I'm feeling much less
tenderness on the right side of my head, and can sleep on my right side now too.
I emerged from the hospital as the sun was rising and drove home, then crashed on my
bed for about two hours, before I had to wake up again to go to chemo. My stalwart
neighbor, Janis, drove me, while my equally kind friend Jackie drove me home. By then it
was about 3 p.m.; all the cafés with decent coffee were closed, so I opted for a swing
past Meyer's dairy and a small sundae with mint chip ice cream. My eating yesterday
was as odd and untimely as my sleeping, but I just allowed myself to indulge in
whatever, whenever. Chemo and a magnesium drip proceeded smoothly; my neuropathy
was bothering me so I found I couldn't get into a comfortable position for sleeping, but
must have dozed for a bit as on awakening I felt disoriented about my whereabouts.
At some point a chemo nurse came over to my bay and let me know that the hospitals'
radiologists had read the report on my MRI and, thank goodness, everything appears to
be clear. No clear signs of new cancer nor any other significant finds. This is certainly
                    
good news, but I haven't worked up the courage to read the report myself yet and Dr.
Patel was out yesterday. I may read it this weekend or may wait to 'bundle' the scan
reports for a more 'holistic' explanation from my medical team (next scan, on my neck at
my request to check out the puffiness there, will take place next Friday; the third, on my
abdomen/pelvis/chest, to be done on June 13th). For the moment, though, it *appears*
as if I won't have to deal with a brain/ovarian cancer whammy, which doesn't mean my
cancer won't recur in my brain at some point, and which also doesn't mean that I won't
have to contend with other metastases (as I am already with regard to several lymph
nodes, colon etc.). We move forward, in the meanwhile, and enjoy these short reprieves
right now as much as possible.
After Jackie brought me home, I once again crashed on my couch, this time waking up
around 9 p.m.! I turned on the Celtics-Heat game and ordered some Indian food off Grub
Hub (my stomach feels a bit yucky today). Exciting game, unlike some of the lackluster
play I've seen in this series. I miss the days of Jordan and Magic - who wouldn't miss that
thrilling level of play? -- and of course the beloved Knicks teams of my 20s and 30s
(Ewing, Mase, Oakley etc.), but I do enjoy watching Steph Curry (who'll be waiting for the
winner of the Celtics-Heat Game 7 on Sunday) and Jayson Tatum play.
I was in bed by midnight and slept well and soundly, waking up once around 4 a.m. After
a day spent totally out of whack, my Circadian rhythms seem to be back to normal.
Stayed in bed until 10 a.m., then went to Café Lemont for an iced cappuccino, gassed up
my car, and headed out on what proved much easier to present to myself as an
adventure: a long drive to Milroy, Reedsville and Belleville in search of fresh produce.
This long drive (75 miles for the day?) involved many treks down gravel roads to tucked
away farms; slowing down for all manner of Amish carts and buggies; stopping at
numerous roadside stands; conversations with the Amish farmers (invariably surrounded
by a gaggle of sweet-faced, curious children); working out rough calculations of prices for
the foodstuffs, often picked right out of the garden (strawberries!). I bought some
delicious looking asparagus, more rhubarb, a hothouse tomato, and a big jar of
unpasteurized cream (hopefully devoid of bacteria that might harm my fragile
stomach?). I love going to farmers markets, but also very much enjoy dealing directly
with the farmers on their farms and their ethic of sustainability. No chemicals, all natural,
plots tilled by hand or larger ones by horses etc. We'll see what tastiness I'll hopefully
concoct from these products. In my heart, I'm a city girl for sure, but the mellow
countryside, network of gurgling streams, acres of green fields, silos, old barns and quiet
balance me.
Having brunch with a friend tomorrow, outdoors, then maybe some cooking and
planting. Two defenses coming up in next two weeks, so currently reading two
dissertations awaits. Onwards.
Photos
