text:
As my week in Paris was a designated part of my 'wellness therapy' consisting of a return
to my 'happy place' after three years away, I do want to leave a trace of it here. Despite
my coming very near to not making the trip for fear of contracting COVID or having my
cancer worsen there, I am of course overjoyed to have taken advantage of this 'window
of opportunity," so designated by my medical team. Mann Tracht, Un Gott Lacht: Man
Plans, God Laughs. Despite myriad precautions (near constant masking, bags of
medications crammed into my suitcase, lists of Parisian doctors' names and numbers in
                    
my purse etc.), Jill came down with COVID on our fifth day in Paris, leaving me to depart
a day early while she was required to remain in Paris an extra week until she tested
negative (in fact, I believe she received a written note from my friend Randy's physician -
whom he dubs "Dr. Love" [don't ask] - stating that she'd be asymptomatic after a week:
another 'get out of France' card). After Monday I never saw the poor woman again, but
had to resort to FaceTiming her in the room next to mine! Through it all -- sitting across
from Jill in enclosed indoor restaurants and breakfast rooms, sharing a dinner with her
shopped for at a local market -- I never tested positive for COVID. Go figure. Maybe in
this sense things did 'work out' as my contracting Covid as a cancer patient in Paris
could have yielded catastrophic results for me, but of course I felt terribly for Jill, and was
loath to leave her alone. She's all better now, back in Cali with her husband and with her
three adult daughters checking in regularly, and we've had a good laugh about our
(mis)adventure. I'm sure it brought us closer in some way. Mann Tract, un Gott Lacht: at
the airport flying home, I had to *remind* the attendant to check the results of my Covid
screening for my negative result. I'm quite sure I could have sailed through precheck
without this apparently vital control.
Speaking of Jill, she was a wonderful travel companion. And friend.  We had never
travelled together, but she had kindly visited me in PA during an earlier stage of my
cancer journey to help me out, driving here from her daughter's home in Princeton, NJ.
We've seen each other here and there over the past few years, over drinks in the city
(where she has an apartment), at the memorial service for another classmate, and have
kept in touch, but were likely not one another's very closest friend (ie we had drifted out
of one another's lives a bit). Not only is Jill a seasoned traveler, completely on top of our
logistics, helpful to me when I flagged physically during our long wait at CDG passport
control, security etc., not only was she laid back and agreeable (while always looking
ultra-stylish), happy to accompany me to favorite spots, neighborhoods, museum etc.
while also striking out on her own with complete confidence at other times (her French,
remembered from her studies at the Lycée français in NY, was completely sturdy). She is
also a wonderful and interesting and and kind and smart and fun friend (a UCLA MBA and
former Tufts undergrad, she runs her husband's law office in Calabasas). Every time we'd
sit down to dinner or at a café, I knew there'd be no lack of things to discuss, not just
about our trip but also about our families of origin (whom we both knew versions of from
our high school days) and families we've created, lives, careers, Jewish identities, travels
etc. What a blessing to reconnect with my girlhood friend in these circumstances. Jill,
thank you for offering to be my travel buddy. You deserve every iota of the lovely life
you and Fred have created for yourselves and your family. I would travel anywhere with
you!
A highlight for us may have been dinner with *another* of our high school classmates
(remember, there were only 23 of us so it's really a sisterhood), Christina, and her
                    
charming French husband, Vincent. While I've met up with Christina, who excels at
teaching and touring Paris with American students on study abroad programs, each time
I'm in Paris, Jill had not seen her in many years. We laughed when we realized we were
sitting outside at a café/bistro underneath a sign marked "Produits frais" ("Fresh
Products") and Vincent took a few whimsical pictures of me with a giant teddy bear at
the café, one of the omnipresent "Ours des Gobelins" (kind of therapy bears to help
Parisians through the pandemic), a lovely touch in often whimsical Paris (https://www.sor
tiraparis.com/news/in-paris/articles/180876-the-phenomenon-of-the-giant-teddy-bears-at-
les-gobelins-neighborhood-in-paris/lang/en).
What I loved best was a week spent appropriating the Parisian space, cutting a swath
through 'my' Paris, the one I've come to love particularly over the years, revisiting
places, tastes, smells, sensations - and people - that make me happy. The weather was
magnificent. I loved sitting in the mellow sunshine under that "certain slant of light" at
about 6 p.m., either in the beautiful courtyard of the MAHJ (Jewish Museum) or relaxing
over a drink (I couldn't overdo it, but did allow myself some wine and a Campari spritz --
along with lots of Perrier menthe, my refreshing go-to drink on hot days in Paris). I loved
sitting with Doris in small gardens tucked off to the side of the Archives nationales, which
I discovered a few years ago. I absolutely loved renewing my habit of spending Sunday
morning at the marché d'Aligre, tasting samples of fresh fruits, buying favorite foods,
visiting the covered marché Beauveau, the large outdoor market, and the flea market
(my 'scarf lady,' Martine, remembered me!), ducking into wonderful fromageries along
the rue d'Aligre, stopping for a coffee and people watching, buying a sweet pain brioché
in an excellent bakery, enjoying life.
Friends: I prioritized, in part, seeing friends as I knew that would make me happy and
wanted to catch up with and check in with my oldest pals - a high school friend, college
and grad school friends, French colleagues who have become friends. I certainly would
have liked to have seen others but was careful not to run myself ragged - and I did as
much as I thought I was able to in six days, without tiring myself too much. Aside from
dinner with Jill, Vincent and Christina, I had a lovely lunch with my dear friend Doris (one
of our group of 'filles' from grad school at NYU) at the Café des Archives in the Marais;
had a drink with my filmmaker/actor friend David Drach, with whom I've nourished a
translatlantic friendship for a good ten years, also in the Marais (and met his new
boyfriend); unfortunately, I had just learned of Jill's Covid diagnosis so was feeling upset
and distracted...; enjoyed dinner at a lovely boutique bistro, La Pharmacie (in a
renovated 19th c. pharmacy), with my colleague and friend Vincent Duclert (whom I first
met in about 1995 (?) when I showed up in a rainstorm at the Archives nationales where
he was then working, my socks drenched; Vincent procured dry socks for me somehow. I
also credit Vincent for introducing me to the chocolate shop Jadis et Gourmand in the rue
des Archives, from which he had been gifted that day a giant 'message board' composed
of tablets of milk and dark chocolate, which he shared with me, spelling out something
like "Félicitations!" -- there have been many causes for congratulations over the years in
                    
Vincent's eminent career as an historian, but in those days we were both still starting
out). Now my friendship with Vincent includes his delightful and kind American wife,
Diana, who unfortunately could not join us for dinner that evening); and spent a number
of hours over drinks and dinner at Mensae in Belleville with my 'ride or die' partners in
crime, Mitchel and Randy (my friends from college and grad school). Our 'Three
Mousquetaires' reunions since the early 1980s (and of course Mitchel and I go back
further), taking us through the Village, Paris, Nice and elsewhere, don't come about as
often as I'd like, but when they do I know we'll be in great spirits, and laughter and love
will abound. I was sorry not to have been able to meet my cousin Claudia, currently on a
prestigious assignment as an international arbitration judge in Paris, for dinner the last
night, along with Jill, but she understood that our plans had been completely upended by
Covid. I hope to see her before long, on one side or another of the Atlantic!
Things I ate: I insisted of having a few of my favorites: salmon tartare w/crispy frites; a
rare entrecôte w/more frites; a yummy croque monsieur; a delicious éclair from Stohrer
in the rue Montorgeuil made with exceptional chocolate; a sole chocolate from
chocolatier Jacques Génin; the chocolate mousse at Mensae (a study in contrasts: warm
chocolate v. a hidden scoop of vanilla cream, smooth texture v. crunchy bits, black v.
white etc.); a quartet of Eastern European lunch treats en plein air at chez Marianne, rue
des Rosiers (falafel balls, humus, baba ganoush, herring in mustard sauce); a perfectly
ripe crottin, delicious; delectably ripe, sweet strawberries; rosette de Lyon, tapenade
with figs, goose liver pâté, a mi-cuit (molten chocolate cake); an excellent crêpe
w/rhubarb at Breizh Café in the Marais. I missed out on a few faves: have to say I did not
taste an exceptional croissant (the ones in the hotel were frozen...), nor a superior
baguette sandwich, nor did I get to have my favorite pastry (tarte au citron), nor a
macaron (coffee or chocolate), did not register any truly exceptional wine and did not
have a truly 'aah' inspiring café crème doused in warm, creamy foam. But hey. I was still
in foodie heaven.
Hotel: Very nice, in the 11e (my favorite arrondissement), small boutique hotel, Hôtel Le
Mareuil. On a quiet street (rue de Malte). Closer to 'hipster' 11e (rue JP Timbaud) than to
my preferred 'bobo' 11e (rue Paul Bert, marché d'Aligre). Well-situated, a close walk to
the upper Marais (rue de Turenne, rue de Bretagne, République). Very helpful, bilingual
staff (although I was happy as a ....croissant to be jabbering away in French and
delighted to tap into that part of my cultural/linguistic identity); clean, Covid-safe (or so
we hoped?). I had a 'deluxe' room on the top floor, which of course, being Paris, was
quite small but clean and comfortable, with a view over Parisian rooftops. Breakfast was
adequate. Apparently there were some American style amenities like a gym, which I
didn't have time to check out. I do recommend.
What I bought: My shopping appetite was whet, as was Jill's, and we enjoyed introducing
one another to some of our favorite shops. Practically on arrival, I headed straight to my
favorite jewelry store, La Tonkinoise in the rue Jean-Pierre Timbaud, where Chantal
                    
Manoukian, the most creative jeweler who upcycles vintage pieces found in flea markets
into all sorts of striking bracelets, earrings, barrettes etc., remembered me very well (I
follow her on Instagram and she knows I'm always in the market for dragonfly-themed
pieces). I bought a pretty bracelet featuring a kind of Art nouveau/Deco piece in silver. I
also took Jill along to my favorite clothing store, Anne-Elisabeth. Fairly slim pickings in
the sale basement, but I did buy a nice summer dress and two shirts. Also selected a
nice smelling body lotion at Artisan Parfumeur in the rue des Francs-Bourgeois, where
the saleswoman was unnecessarily snooty, and was tempted by unique skirts in a pop-up
store in the same street. No time to go book shopping, unfortunately (although Vincent
kindly gifted me three of his recent publications), and the rest of the items I bought were
either food-related or gifts.
Other visits: Beyond visiting with friends, walking (perhaps around 3-4 miles/day for me,
not bad considering my stamina is subject to off-kilter blood counts, effects of
medication etc.), café sitting, sensual imbibing etc., I did make it, as planned, to La
Samaritaine, an iconic 1869 Parisian department store located near the Pont-Neuf (1er),
recently subject to a vast, meticulous renovation to its former glory. The multitude of
pricey sales points in the store held no interest for me, but the architectural restoration
was fascinating -- a torrent of arabesques, peacock motifs, pastel yellows and blues,
steel and glass forming an ornate pre-Art nouveau shell. Delightful. Also had time for one
exhibit, on Proust's Jewishness, at the MAHJ (quite interesting, yet I took issue
w/comparisons of his editorial annotations on his manuscripts to midrash). Would have
loved to have seen the Boldini exhibit at the Petit Palais. Might I be cautiously optimistic
about a 'next time?'
A memorable morning at the Maison Vever: One of my week's highlights was visiting the
showroom of the recently relaunched Maison Vever, the fabled jewelry house to which
I've devoted much of my research over the last fifteen years or so, founded by Henri and
Paul Vever's grandfather in Metz in 1821. Camille and Damien Vever, the adult children
of Dorothée and Bruno Vever (Bruno being Paul's descendant, as Henri, the subject of
my research, left no direct descendants), are the brainchildren behind the relaunch, and
the showroom sits high above the rue de la Paix leading to the Opéra and in view of the
Place Vendôme, a stone's throw from the original Maison Vever. The showroom is
sublime (and subject to heavy security), the first jewelry lines, featuring gold, plique-à-
jour enamel, and lab grown diamonds both hearkening back to earlier pieces like Vever's
_Sylvia_ pendant but with a modern sensibility, are gorgeous (gingkos!), and also on
display in the new Vever boutique at Le Printemps. I was delighted of course to see my
book, an edition of Vever's diary from 1898, on display, while the family was also kind
enough to show me some original Vever pieces (including charming earrings Lalique
crafted for Henri Vever's daughter, Marguerite) in its possession. We casually discussed
possible directions for future collaboration around art, commerce and research, as the
Vevers wish to penetrate the American market, and plan to visit New York before long to
this end.  After joining for group photos on the showroom's 7th floor terrace, I enjoyed a
                    
convivial lunch with Bruno and Dorothée Vever (who has been exceptionally kind and
well-disposed and supportive towards me over the past several years and whom I like a
lot), our conversation ranging over French history (Louis XIV's policies!), Vever of course,
my treatment (briefly) and much else. After lunch, Bruno and Dorothée desposited me at
Foucher, another illustrious _chocolatier_ founded in 1819 in the avenue de l'Opéra,
when this area was the epicenter of Parisian luxury commerce and aristocratic tourism.
Dorothée had first taken me to Foucher a few years ago, and I bought some gifts for
friends.
It goes without saying that my relationship to Paris, and France in general, is like any
major relationship that defines one's life, lest you think for a second that I'm simply a
cliché-spouting Pollyannaish, garden-variety Francophile.  It's full of ups and downs, rifts
and reunions, disappointments and pleasures, love and distaste. Anti-Semitism is
abhorrent to me (as is all prejudice, of course), and I revile that part of France's history,
having not only devoted much of my research to these questions but also having been
privy to banal, run of the mill (yet no less revelatory) anti-Jewish 'humor' (and worse) in
certain social situations in France. Bureaucratic inertia makes my skin crawl. But I
daresay this 'fraughtness' is just part of what has 'complexified' infinitely my relationship
to France. The relationship is also a scrapbook of my life over the last (nearly) half-
century. So many 'Willas' have sojourned there.  But what I've tried to capture here, in
this post and during this trip, is a more like a sensibility, a sense of well-being, at a
particular moment in time. Un 'feeling.'
Was my rambling, cosmic, ruminative revisiting of my time(s) in France since 1975 worth
a night of insomnia last night? I have to believe it was. I caught a glimpse of my sixteen-
year-old self drinking cheap wine and flirting, with the rest of the summer study group in
which I participated under the auspices of the Northfield Mount Herman School, at a little
restaurant in the Latin Quarter, called "Le Bateau Ivre" (_pace_ Rimbaud), then getting
lost in the warren of streets around St. Michel with an American friend made on the trip,
Margot, before somehow hopping onto a _bateau mouche_ at the last minute for an
evening cruise around Paris with the rest of the group, which left me 'éblouie' (I have a
journal or a letter to my parents that recounts this evening but I can't find it right now).
More pictures to follow.
Health update: holding steady. Neck scan this Friday.
 
.
                    
Photos

June 10, 2022 - It all began with a stalk of rhubarb OR "Jesus, take the
wheel"
label: neutral

text:
I haven't written in a while and I apologize. It's turned out to be a busy week, marked by
two dissertation defenses since last Thursday, one in Art History the other in FFS (French
and Francophone Studies). I had to move into high gear work-wise, a mode that has
become less familiar to me since I retired (in terms of serving on committees etc.), and
was determined to bring my 'A game' to the defenses. This was especially true in the
case of this past Tuesday's defense, as the student defending, Morgane, is my advisee,
with whom I've worked closely over the past several years. As Morgane is in all likelihood
my last advisee, and as she's a particularly impressive younger scholar, I was committed
to ensuring that all would go well (in terms of not only logistics for this zoom defense but
also the quality of the discussion, lines of questioning etc.). All went as planned: Morgane
presented a fascinating project on unpublished life-writings from the Alsace-Lorraine
borderland during the period when this region underwent multiple sovereignty changes
and experienced two wars (1870, 1914-1918). The discussion with the committee (which
included an outside member from the History department) was stimulating and rigorous,
ranging over questions of gender, Morgane's positioning in terms of the events and
themes she presented, material culture, future plans for this manuscript and more. The
discussion and my reading of Morgane's dissertation actually made me give a lot of
thought to my own practice as a diarist/blogger. I found after both defenses that I had
really been missing that level of discussion with colleagues and students, and felt good
about Morgane's work as well as that of the dozen or so other doctoral students I've
helped launch into academic positions during my time at Penn State (several have
become close friends since). As happens often in these situations, it makes me reflect
that, had I stayed on for five more years or so at Penn State, I could have/would have
done more: more students advised, another book written (not out of the question,
actually!), a Fulbright or other major grant scored, more extended stays in France,
collaborative work with international colleagues. "I coulda been a contender." Oh well.
It's a regret, for sure, but knowing that I can't do anything about it I try not to let that
realization get me down.
I drove up to campus after the defense - bearing champagne - for a lovely celebratory
lunch in our conference room in Morgane's honor. She's off to take up a position as
Assistant Prof. of French at High Point University in NC; her husband Aaron has a VAP
position at Wake Forest (VAP = Visiting Assistant Professor).
I find that having discrete, manageable goals (such as preparing for two dissertation
defenses within a two-week period) is a helpful goal for me these days. It keeps me
grounded and structured, and helps prevent me from going into an emotional and/or
existential tailspin, consumed with questions about how I should be using my
(remaining) time. My next goal is to finish off and submit a long article (to the journal
_Nineteenth-Century Art Worldwide_) on Vever's collaboration with the graphic artist
Eugène Grasset on twenty striking jewelry pieces displayed at the 1900 Paris World's
                    
Fair. It doesn't need much more work. Then it will likely be back to editing Vever's 1899
diary; I'm pretty far along on that project as well. Colleagues at the Smithsonian and I
are also working on Vever's 1891 travel diary to stops along the Silk Road after he
participated in a trade show in Moscow, a fascinating document recording a trip that took
Vever and his wife all the way to Samarkand!
Anyhoo, after last Thursday's defense in Art History, I found myself preparing a batch of
rhubarb-strawberry compote, as I do so often (aside: some of you know about my long-
standing obsession with rhubarb - the color, the taste, the texture - resulting in a
cascade of compotes, chutneys, cakes, etc. tumbling out of my kitchen and my drives to
farms where nice Amish farm ladies will go into their gardens and cut stalks of rhubarb
for me -- "If I die young, bury me in a pile of rhubarb, lay me down on a bed of rhubarb,
sink me in a river of rhubarb at dawn" [!!!] -- Yes, it's to that point. I recall that my first
encounter with rhubarb was in 1980, when my French 'mother,' eighty-year old Madame
Marcelle Bloch, cooked rhubarb often. I remember that she always overcooked it and
that it was invariably stringy and of a grayish color, not that pleasing vibrant pink. I did
enjoy the taste, though).
In any event, I was working (too) quickly and instead of slicing a piece of rhubarb, I sliced
my finger with a serrated knife, deeply, seemingly cutting into/off a chunk of it near my
nail. It began to pulsate immediately and spurt blood (thank you, blood thinners). I ran
into the bathroom and tried to wash it, but that sent waves of additional pain shooting
through my finger. By wrapping it in four bandaids applied extremely tightly, I was able
to staunch the bleeding, and was then distracted for the rest of the evening by the
basketball game I watched  while lying on the couch. However, the throbbing pain was
so intense that it woke me up several times during the night and essentially I wound up
renouncing sleep; I thought I had severed a nerve. At 6:00 a.m. I said to myself out loud:
"I need medical attention." I threw on some clothes and drove to the ER. Fortunately, it
was empty but I was assured that the Covid ER patients would begin to trickle in around
7 a.m. The nice young doctor and then his older attending doctor took good care of me.
When we removed the bandaids, the finger was still bleeding but the cut was not as bad
as it could have been. The throbbing may have been made worse by my applying the
bandaids so tightly. I also learned that long nerves run up the two sides of the finger. I
didn't need stitches nor 'skin glue' nor an X-ray. The doctors cleaned my wound
thoroughly and wrapped it fairly loosely in sterile gauze. The finger's coming along well
and I'm reminding myself not to rush when I'm cooking (and especially cutting).
Accidents happen.
I realize in retrospect that this was also a "Jesus, take the wheel moment" (wrong religion
for me, I know, but the image from the song fits). Sometimes I become completely
overwhelmed by all I have to do to take care of myself: make, note and attend multiple
                    
appointments each week (labs, chemo, magnesium drip, scans etc.); advocate for myself
when doctors who say they will call to discuss test results don't call; try to inform myself
about treatment options (I think I don't do a great job with this sometimes); arrange
rides to/from some of my appointments (the ones during which I'll be zonked out on
Benadryl; the others I can drive myself to); keep a running list of questions to ask my
medical team; pay medical bills; keep my house relatively in order, with help from a
house cleaner (not always 100% reliable, but fine) and woman who helps me with
errands; prepare healthy meals for myself (I try to make one dish a week that will last for
3-4 nights; this week it was turkey chili as I try to feature protein and veggies) etc. "I
can't go on. You must go on. I'll go on." Sometimes I really want for someone(s) to take
care of me. And I would be negligent not to say that my wonderful circle of friends and
family and neighbors do help immensely with that. And I'd also be negligent not to point
out that my being 'alone' (a word I find distasteful and misleading in my case) is to a
large extent my choice, as I often find it much *easier* and less cumbersome to do
things for myself than to have to involve another person in a 'caregiver' role, especially if
that person feels ambivalent about being in that role (of course, there are times, postop
for instance, when I truly need help, ask for it, and am only too happy to receive it). If
you know me well you know that I value my freedom above all (which of course is not to
say that I don't revel in my friendships and relationships, on the contrary), and have
politely declined at least one marriage proposal and two relationship proposals in recent
years, from guys who all went on to remarry, which is what they wanted (happy for
them!). Currently living in a completely existential (ie carpe diem, in this case) mode.
Well, enough on that for today, shall we?
One night thoughts and questions about the final stages kept me up for a while: can I get
hospice care at home here? How can I ensure a home death (which is what I want?). We
are not there yet, though! So at one point in the ER, I remember saying to the two
doctors: "Please just take care of me;" I think this ER visit may have represented my
acting out this scenario (of wanting to be cared for) in some way but it's hard to tell. I'm
not saying I cut myself *in order to get attention,* but once in the ER it felt so good to be
attended to by the nice physicians. The young one kept going on and on about how
much he loves rhubarb (wish I could have given him some!), while the older one simply
said, before exiting my room: "When you look at your finger, which will likely bear a scar,
you'll always think of rhubarb compote."
The rest of that morning was pretty crazy. I had a neck scan at 9:50 at the same hospital
in whose ER I found myself at about 8 or so. Should I simply sit in my car until my next
appointment, perhaps crawl into the back seat and doze? In the end, I decided to drive
home (about 20 mn.), crawl into my bed, and sleep for about half an hour. Then I was
back up and driving to the hospital for the second time, for the scan. Sitting in the dingy
waiting area outside the CT-scan room, I was treated to the sounds of the elderly patient
in the queue before me screaming her head off while undergoing her scan. My own scan
only took about five minutes (I honestly think I fell asleep in the machine). My next
                    
appointment was for lunch at 12:30 and at this point it might have been 11:00? So I
drove home once again, crawled into my bed once again, and slept for about half an
hour before lunch with my friend Sandy. Lunch outdoors in the sun at Duffy's Tavern in
Boalsburg was lovely despite my fatigue, and I told Sandy that I was very happy to have
my day officially 'begin' with lunch, burying the stressful, unpleasant morning. Oh well!
When I told Sandy about the title I was mulling for this entry ("It all began with a stalk of
rhubarb"), she reminded me of the first line of Ann Patchett's novel, _Commonwealth_:
"The christening party took a turn when Albert Cousins arrived with gin." Great first line
and I love Ann Patchett.
Speaking of risky behavior (cf slicing my finger as if it were a stalk of rhubarb), I found
myself binge eating for a few days. In writing this, I do not know whether I seek
chastising, compassion, sympathy/empathy or something else. I'm a bit surprised I'm
even choosing to write about a 'secret behavior.' I think it's a bit like the "Jesus, take the
wheel" moments I experience sometimes; I become unregulated, and I don't care. I need
that kind of release and testing of limits. I found myself eating somewhat insatiably and
uncontrollably for a few days, even veering into some unhealthy and caloric foods that I
don't normally eat: a tuna sub from Subway (Subway! tuna, though, is the only sub I'll
eat from that place, and about once a year; I can't stomach processed sandwich meat), a
refreshing yet highly caloric and sugary lemonade from Wegmans' (ok, freshly
squeezed...); a bunch of sweets and treats from the Cake Shop by Tati, eaten in
succession (a croissant, chocolate chip cookie, and a carrot-coconut muffin that I had
told myself I'd save for the following day but in the end did not), a big bag of popcorn
(things with kernels are generally not good for me), some random candy from Trader
Joe's, an entire jar of pickles that I drove twelve miles to buy from a specialty store in
Bellefonte (Belle Mercantile) and then wolfed down in my car, savoring the salty, sour,
dill-infused brine and crunchy pickles. I think I'm back 'on the wagon' now and certainly
recognizable (yes?...) as a relatively slender person, but the temptation to cram my face
with copious amounts of food is still there. I think this binging also served the purpose of
giving me a little 'belly,' which I could subsequently blame for/confound with any
potential stomach bloating indicating new or recurrent cancer. In other words, I may be
trying to 'mask' a potentially distressing result. Further, Dr. Beavis' account (at my
request) of the final stages entailing losing the desire/ability to eat has me, I believe,
'hoarding' food as a kind of buffer and trying to ward off this eventuality as a squirrel
might stock up on acorns in view of the 'lean periods' (magical thinking?). And of course,
I do love to eat, cook etc. But in all realms I need to try to stick to 'behavior I can
sanction' (a phrase my therapist and I bandy about). But oh gosh, it's really hard
sometimes....
Both my MRI and neck CT indicate no recurrence. I had both Dr. Patel jeune and Dr.
Bettegowda at Hopkins look at the imaging, and spoke to the Dr. Patel's PA on the
phone. This of course if very good news but in all honesty I'm much more nervous about
my pelvic/abdominal/chest scan next Tuesday. I've been having weekly magnesium drips
                    
(two hours) because that electrolyte level is low. Otherwise, my blood counts have been
ok enough for chemo to proceed every week (as it did today). My CA 125 (cancer
antigen) level today is 13.9, well under the 38 U/ml limit considered normal. However,
after being told for months (years?) that this level is all important, Dr. Beavis more
recently told me that my current treatment somehow 'falsifies' this level, making it a less
significant indicator (well then, why do they even order this test? I need more clarity on
this) and to Dr. Patel, "it's just a number." What to make of it? I don't know. I will soon
know whether my treatment will change with the possible addition of Avastin to help the
Taxol work better. In my mind, Avastin is "the drug that's going to kill me" because of
the very small risk of a bowel perforation (in which case, per Dr. Beavis, it's "game
over"). I see we may be playing Russian roulette soon. Per Dr. Patel the elder, in an
ominous tone that annoyed me: "There will be findings" (from the CT-scan). When I
asked him how he knew that, he replied that it's simply a matter of the natural
progression of the disease. I wish his tone had not been so foreboding. Of course it's
scary. I need a lunch (and will have one soon) with my local friend Deb, a fourteen-year
survivor who's undergone treatment all along. I've been reading in the NYTimes about
some promising new treatments for breast and rectal cancer. Wouldn't it be great if
'they' discovered some sort of 'magic bullet' for ovarian cancer?... I may not live to see it,
but hopefully it will happen one day. And through all of this, in the end, I am not feeling
too badly! My days are full; I do need to exercise more, but each day brings drives to
several farmers markets, cooking, some work, reading, getting together and/or
corresponding with friends...
Ben is coming home for a week on Monday. I can't wait to see him! And my cousin Julie
will be visiting from Florida later this month! Have already made turkey chili and will
make, this weekend, garlic scape pesto, asparagus soup, and a rhubarb-strawberry crisp.
No sliced fingers, promise!
 
Photos
label: sadness

text:
I will appreciate 'thoughts and prayers' (yes, even those!), well wishes, mi shebeirachs,
and belief in good karma today when I have my pelvic/abdominal/chest CT after many
months (it seems like this should have happened sooner but none of my doctors has as
yet raised a red flag about timing). Dr. Patel's ominous "there will be findings" and Dr.
Beavis' 'backpocket' option of adding Avastin to the mix soon are weighing on me, but I'll
await having my insides illuminated with the all-telling contrast dye to know more. For
now, it's merely a parlor game involving trying to parse the symptoms (is that a
pulsating lymph node lying against my stomach?). Currently off all food and drink for the
next four hours; scan is at 11:30, after which I'll go have some lunch. Ben is here this
week and that is such a joy. We were at Michael and Sue's last night for a barbecue (the
annual grilled hot dog that Michael always prepares for me), and later I'll try my hand at
cream of asparagus soup for dinner + salmon + salad. And between the NBA finals and
the Congressional hearings, we are all set in terms of our tv options. Hope to get out for
a long drive/farm stands or hike or picnic or equivalent tomorrow.
label: fear

text:
When I finally summoned the courage to read the Geisinger radiologist's report on my
pelvic/chest/abdominal CT, on Thursday I believe, my mind immediately translated the
first line - "Progression of disease" - into "I am going to die." I ran into my bedroom to
begin frantically labelling and separating into ziploc bags all my heirloom jewelry to give
to Ben and other family members, laying these heirlooms into an extra jewelry box I had
bought for this purpose. I now understand that I was having at least in part a
physiological response to reading the report; fortunately, a number of relatives and
friends whose highly functioning prefrontal cortexes served to moderate my
impulsiveness and heightened 'fight or flight' responses, urged me to take a proverbial
breath and await further input from my medical team.
Which I did, both from Dr. Patel when I met with him on Friday and from Dr. Beavis via
email. Not unexpectedly (and I had said this to a few friends even before the fact),
several lymph nodes in my abdomen have grown in size, indicating likely presence of
cancer within. I could see them clearly and thickly on the image Dr. Patel showed me,
and they sometimes cause me some discomfort (unless I'm misidentifying the symptom).
There also seems to have been growth of cancerous tissue mass in my abdomen, also
not a surprise.
The problem is that we appear to be running out of viable treatment options. Dr. Beavis
told me this would likely be the case. I've been through about five or six lines of
treatment already; after a while, they are no longer effective. My current treatment,
weekly Taxol, appears to be helping in some ways -- tumors on the vagina, Dr. Beavis
noted, have actually shrunk in size! -- but not in others: several abdominal lymph nodes,
which of course can carry cancer to other parts of the body, are enlarging. Unless a
promising clinical trial can be identified for me at a place that makes sense for me to be
treated - Memorial Sloan Kettering, for example -- the next step is likely Taxol + Avastin,
a new drug for me. Avastin, Dr. Patel explained to me, helps Taxol work better as it
inhibits the cancer cells from creating their own, autonomous blood supplies that they
can draw on (yes, this disease is insidious, as Dr. Beavis has said; thanks, guys [or gals]
for not only setting up camp in my body but developing your own blood supply to
boot...). Tracy, one of the nice chemo nurses, told me that most patients tolerate Avastin
well. There is a risk of elevated blood pressure, some issue with a protein (my urine will
be checked every time), and of course that small risk of bowel perforation that could
mean for me, in Dr. Beavis' words, 'game over;' Dr. Patel, though, as well as the nurse I
spoke with, could really not recall this ever having been an issue with any of his patients,
though. A very scary prospect, nevertheless, and surely a 'leap of faith' will now be
required on my part, the relative riskiness of the treatment being the measure of the
stage we're at with it...
As for clinical trials, it is not certain this will be a viable option. I need to consult
                    
clinicaltrials.gov again and see if anything looks promising or applicable there. I may
simply try to get a consult at MSK if possible. I may need Dr. Beavis' help getting my foot
in the door but I'll also try myself, probably tomorrow; time to do the work, think clearly,
advocate for myself, assure myself I'm exhausting all reasonable treatment options. For
some trials, one has to have been free of brain mets for a certain length of time; my
brain has been mets-free for (only?) five months. Yes, cancer research is ongoing and
new treatments are coming available; but will there be one suited to my case/stage, and
will I be able to access it? Not clear yet - at all. At this point, I would not feel comfortable
travelling any further afield than places within striking range, close to friends and family
(Philly I suppose, Pittsburgh, Hopkins but I'm not seeing any trials going on there, DC,
MSK/NYC). Is this the right decision?
When I was with Dr. Patel, he looked at my imaging, sighed slightly (or was I imagining
this?) and said: "Well, the good news is that your brain imaging looks clear." Incidentally,
so do my chest and my liver, an organ I was concerned about. Actually, my liver looks a
little 'wonky;' one lobe is atrophied, another hypertrophied, several cysts, although not
cancerous, sit on its surface. To my relief, Dr. Patel explained that a liver can look like
this (is 'asymmetrical') when one lobe is working harder than the other. Dr. Beavis had
asked that Dr. Patel call her to discuss the options, which Dr. Patel did, immediately after
I spoke with him; he then stopped by the infusion room a bit later to update me on the
emerging plan. Another brief exchange with Dr. Patel - everything happened quickly, and
both doctors are so busy - had me confirming that I wanted to continue with treatment.
My reading of our quickly exchanged words was that this could be a point at which some
patients might choose to stop treatment, for any number of reasons. I told him with no
hesitation that I wished to continue; I feel strong enough and am certainly not ready to
stop. At what point I will wish to, though, is unclear. I will want to see how the new drug
combo works, if no clinical trial is available. Our goal is to maintain stability of the lymph
nodes or to have them shrink in size. I'll need further scans after a while. And I will make
sure all other viable options have been exhausted. I raised the possibility of further
radiation, surgery, which Dr. Patel dismissed (too invasive, I suppose, but need to find
out more).
The upshot of these fairly compressed discussions, on Friday, was that I did not yet start
the new chemo combo (I'm ok with this; I need to find out more, and it all seemed quite
rushed although again, not unexpected). Instead, I had my now habitual weekly
magnesium drip. This is another point of some concern, I suppose. I am having trouble
keeping my magnesium level up, although the chemo nurse tells me I'm not at a 'critical'
point. This electrolyte regulates many important biochemical functions, including those
related to the heart. Dr. Patel's first hypothesis was that I was losing magnesium
because of diarrhea, but now he wonders whether I am 'leaking' it from somewhere
(kidneys?). Another point of worry is a brown spot the dermatologist removed from
below my eyelid on Friday during a routine appointment (it's a new dermatologist as my
previous one left town; we had been watching this spot develop but to be honest with
                    
my focus on my other cancers I did not even stop to think that maybe a melanoma would
get me in the end!!). Calling it an 'ugly duckling' because of its shape, Dr. Van Ness
(whom I liked) said that she was "concerned" and sent it off to be biopsied. We simply
agreed that should it turn out to be cancerous, we'll "deal with it." Because that's what
we do.
Through all of this, I'm (still) not feeling too bad. My energy level is ok, I've been able to
take walks (1 mile?) and much longer drives that allow me to gain clarity and focus on
nature and the beautiful countryside. Lots and lots of time to think. Today I crossed
dozens of buggies filled with Amish in their Sunday best, rolling along Paradise Drive; a
group of about ten girls returning from worship in crisp blue dresses, white bonnets and
white aprons crossed my path and we waved hello. For some reason, the scene
reminded me of some of Gauguin's paintings of pardons in Brittany. I am aware of my
idealizing and likely somewhat voyeuristic fascination with this culture, but there is
something in its simplicity that grounds me.
And doing lots of cooking, buying produce right off the farms. Strawberry-rhubarb crisp,
rhubarb chutney, cherry clafoutis, cream of asparagus soup, garlic scape pesto, parsley-
feta salad dressing, a tofu dish in green curry glaze. Still binge-eating a little bit, feeling
like I want to 'ingest' life to the fullest. And therefore not sleeping all that much; my mind
is often racing. I'm determined to 'ingest' glorious June as entirely and joyfully as I can:
bring on the farm stands, the nurseries, the beautiful light flickering and filtering through
my blinds at about 6 p.m., the lunches outdoors with friends.
So yes, meanwhile, there is the business of living to attend to. I spent Saturday morning
in shul, at the bar-mitzvah of a friend's son. It was lovely, as always, to enjoy the
fellowship of a few congregants I hadn't seen in a while. Everyone kept telling me how
good I look, and I generally can't deny that! But I tend to have mixed feelings about the
comment; it can even make me feel angry, as if people are not 'getting it.' Part of me
feels as if I don't want to deceive, understanding that one can look great or at least
'normal,' and still be quite sick (Dr. Beavis and my own experience with others have
confirmed this point).
Although there's undeniably great wisdom to be found in each of the Torah's portions,
the one the bar-mitzvah explicated, about a first Passover the Israelites celebrated in the
desert (before the more familiar Passover story), did not capture my attention. But
there's usually some verse of image in the prayer book that does. This time, it was a
beautifully-worded passage (which I wish I could recall verbatim) about the burning bush
and ordinary miracles in our midst. Granted, the bush that burned without being
consumed by fire was perhaps no 'ordinary miracle,' but an extraordinary, supernatural
occurrence. However, it made me think about the 'ordinary miracles' taking place right in
front of my eyes, the work of ordinary angels in my midst. The friend who texts: "I am
with you always." A second friend who texts: "Free to take a walk tomorrow?" A third
                    
friend, a marvelous cook, who offers to shop, cook, clean for a dinner party for me, for
which I need only supply a guest list. Another friend who brings me goodies that she
knows I will love - a chocolate babka from Breads Bakery, cheeses from Zabar's -- from
New York; my dear son, a wonderful comfort and a sensitive, helpful and fun companion
all week, who offers to come over from his dad's one evening just so I won't have to
watch the NBA finals match by myself. I'll miss him but hope to get to the city before
long. I am grateful. 
Photos
label: neutral

text:
It's been a somewhat uncanny, odd-seeming time -- time "out of joint." Following my
most recent CT-scan, I spoke with both Dr. Beavis (by phone) and Dr. Patel, in the office.
From Dr. Beavis: "We still have options." However, I detected a discernable and
purposeful (yet not vocalized) 'BUT' in her voice after that phrase. There are options...
but these are her so-called 'back-pocket options,' in extremis options (eg
immunotherapy-related options, which have *not* been shown to work effectively on
ovarian cancer), options that entail significant risk. Unless a promising clinical trial was
to be found quickly, Dr. Beavis indeed recommended (and Dr. Patel concurred) the
combo of Taxol + Avastin, the new drug that would be added. As I've mentioned several
times, Avastin comports a 5% risk of bowel perforation, which could be deadly. Dr. Patel,
though, as I've also mentioned, has never (or hardly ever) encountered this scenario with
a patient. So I will live with some trepidation. And did I mention that my new combo of
Taxol + Avastin has a *15%* success rate of stabilizing the lymph nodes or reducing
them in size? Well, perhaps I'll be one of the lucky 15 of 100 who benefit from this
treatment; I suppose I have other positives going for me (for example, not having any
other major health condition such as high blood pressure, heart issues etc.). The decision
to go with Taxol + Avastin was made pretty quickly, and in the few days that intervened
before I began that treatment last Friday (so far, so good, no marked ill effects; I'll be
scanned after about eight infusions) no viable clinical trials had been identified at
Hopkins nor at M.D. Anderson (or rather in the state of Texas), where my oncologist
college classmate/guardian angel Dr. Steven Sherman practices. 
In a late-breaking development today, though, I finally succeeded in scheduling a consult
                    
with a gyn-onc at Memorial Sloan Kettering for July 18th! I am feeling pretty jazzed about
this, because until now it's proved near-impossible for me to get into MSK. They don't
really like you to be in treatment when they see you (in case they have something else
to propose), but of course I really had to start my current treatment because I need it! So
on Dr. Beavis' advice, I very slightly 'fudged' what I imparted to MSK about my current
treatment, without veering into untruths, because I am feeling fairly desperate for them
to see me. This appointment is giving me some hope.
In another late-breaking development, my friend Steve (the one who originally got me
squared away with the team at Hopkins, for which I am eternally grateful) offered --
when I contacted him recently -- to share a summary of my treatment info with the same
colleagues of his who suggested Hopkins originally to see if they might know of any
promising clinical trials for me. The website clinicaltrials.gov, on which all clinical trials
must register, is not user friendly and contains quite technical descriptions of trials,
confusing for laypeople. I am hoping that Steve's colleagues can help me parse it and
point me in the right direction, if possible. I would consider going further afield than my
geographical comfort zone (NY/Philly/Pittsburgh/DC/Baltimore) for treatment but it would
depend on what is available -- if anything at this time.
I am not sure if there's anything else I need to be doing/pursuing right now. I am unsure
whether I should make some appointments, for example, at other major comprehensive
cancer centers to see what might be out there.
Dr. Beavis' comment during one of our late-night conversations when I was in the
hospital at Hopkins -- about her belief that each person should have the death they
desire -- has somehow recently functioned as a light switch for me. I broke through some
inertia (and fear? and anxiety?) and began to jot down notes about my wishes for my
funeral and burial, possessions, charitable contributions I wish to make etc. Dare I say
that it felt empowering and liberating? And being the 'creative,' the extrovert, and the
planner I am, in a very strange way I felt I was sinking my teeth (sorry for mixed
metaphor) into this 'project,' thinking through the myriad details much like I would those
of a dinner party, or a wedding, or a bar-mitzvah. Except I won't be there -- how odd --
unless I opt for something like a living funeral, which is not outside the realm of
possibility.
I'm choosing to embrace death positivity. This does not mean feeling 'positive' about the
the prospect of dying. As a joy-bringer, life-affirmer, highly affiliative soul, and party girl,
getting up close and personal with my mortality all the time right now pretty much
SUCKS big time. So please let's refrain from showering me with "At leasts" for now like
some sort of consolation prize in this awful game, shall we? ("At least you have time to
say your goodbyes with sufficient time"). Death positivity means a)striving to have the
death I desire and b)bringing death into conversations all of us should be having
throughout our lives (and I should have started much earlier), not cordoning it off from
                    
life like the...Black Plague.
I do admit the possibility, though, that my death positive attitude may contain some part
of denial. Major freakouts are likely somewhere on the horizon for me. At the same time,
though, I feel empowered, in control. At least for now.
Of course, I have no idea how long I may live. A rogue cancer cell could metastasize to
any part of my body at any time, and I could start not to feel well quickly. Conversely,
the MSK consult and/or *possible* clinical trial could help prolong my life. I could be
given two years (as Dr. Beavis has done) and live twice that. Or something critical could
emerge, and things could accelerate. So when to have these conversations? And how?
And with whom? And to what extent? Because meanwhile the crucial business of living
continues, and I am committed to it. Who do I want to hold close in the inner circle? Who
to keep in different kinds of roles? There is no road map. It can be confusing,
overwhelming. And I need to take care of myself. So I may lean more heavily on instinct
than I usually do. Instinct often serves me well. 
Btw, à propos of nothing but fwiw: I don't believe in an afterlife. I will not be reunited
with my loved ones in any type of space of place in the future. I ascribe pretty fully to
Jewish beliefs about the end being the end. Dispose of the body quickly (I desire a green
burial but there are no green cemeteries in State College, a dilemma), sit shiva, and
move on with the business of living. But I also ascribe to the lines we read in the
Kaddish: "[The Dead] still live on earth in the acts of goodness they performed, and in
the hearts of those who cherish their memory." Life after death continues in perpetuity,
but it will be memory- and affect-based. It will be different. What a strange thought.
I'll meet with my financial advisor and lawyer soon and deal with some of the nuts and
bolts of fine-tuning. And plan to have some of those Hard Conversations. But I'm leaving
plenty of time for buoying myself too -- dinners and lunches with friends, visits, drives,
cooking, reading, writing, outings, little trips, tending to my pretty front garden patch. In
an impulse buy yesterday, I scooped up some lavender incense cones and two small
incense burners, like those I used to love in middle and high school growing up near the
Village in the hippie-dippy late 60s -- and which remind me of my younger self -- tokens
of comfort.
There may be a part II coming with thoughts I've forgotten to include, devastated
feelings about the repeal of Roe and the current and future state of the country in
general,  plus an account of my fun weekend with Julie, my OG ride or die
pal/sister/cousin, who flew up from Florida to spend the weekend with me. For now,
dinner time: some tofu with peppers and some sort of marinade, perhaps?
label: fear

text:
Pretty much status quo on the health front. Looking ahead to my consult at Sloan on
7/18; a few friends who are physicians or in biotech are also trying to help me identify
viable clinical trials. I've connected with a physician who is a 'clinical trials navigator' at
M.D. Anderson, thanks to Steve Sherman, but we have not actually spoken yet. She left a
very nice voicemail and I'll call her again after the weekend and forge ahead with
information-gathering. Chemo on Friday was unremarkable; I had forgotten that I'm only
receiving the additional boost of Avastin every other time so was infused with just Taxol
on Friday. My magnesium level increased a bit so only one extra infusion next week, not
three. And the suspicious spot under my eye that was biopsied turned out not to be
cancerous. I'll see my PCP on Tuesday for a routine appointment. My friend Zia has put
holistic-type treatments, and especially juicing, firmly on my radar screen (thanks, Z),
something I probably should have considered earlier on. I plan to buy a juicer and
experiment with all manner of greens, berries, ginger, turmeric, natural sweeteners etc.
Feel free to send along your favorite juice recipes! Meanwhile, my appetite still feels
voracious, perhaps attributable to the steroid I'm taking for lingering skull discomfort;
better than losing my appetite, I suppose. Not feeling badly overall.
I did not lack for energy during my cousin Julie's recent long weekend visit from Florida.
We had a wonderful, relaxing, fun get-together, tailored to our current incarnations as
63-year-old moms to sons (as well as older sisters to younger brothers, and daughters to
two sisters, my aunt and mother). This meant, for example, late afternoon rests, a far cry
from our marathon weekends growing up, exchanging visits from our homes in the city
and in nearby Fairfield County, CT (we'd meet under the big clock in Grand Central
Station); our hard partying college days, when once again we commuted between
Cambridge, MA and Amherst, MA, for unforgettable adventures; a high-intensity
interlude in Paris and southern France, where my passport was stolen and yet I somehow
was permitted, in these pre-September 11, 2001 days, to cross the border into Italy by
train without papers after a distraught leave-taking from my cousin, who was heading
back to the U.S.; and the several trips we took to see each other as married moms living
in PA and FL. The marriages ended (as did our mothers'), the baby boys have grown up,
but our lifelong bond endures.
Saturday took us to an arts festival in Milheim, and included lunch at Elk Creek Cafe,
antiquing, and a drive in the country, while Sunday we headed to Bellefonte for more
antiquing, admiring the well-kept Victorian mansions and strolling in pretty Talleyrand
Park. Dinner (duck!) at Central Reservation one night; the other evenings we cooked.
Convos often referring back to events of decades ago (and therefore requiring almost a
type of shorthand) mingled with musings on our current states, nostalgia working its way
                    
into some of those Hard Conversations -- thank you, Julie, for your loyalty, love and care,
and for the several important promises you made me without hesitation. 
A practice suggested in _The Book of Joy_ (conversations between the Dalai Lama and
Archbishop Desmond Tutu), involving identifying three sources of gratitude daily, has not
proven difficult for me at all! I am grateful to my dear friends Jim D. for having gifted me
this book, which turned out to be exactly the book I needed to read right now; to Helen,
for a carton of fresh eggs delivered to my doorstep; to Cheryl, for thinking of me during
what I'm sure was a packed trip to Santa Fe, returning with a pair of gorgeous blue
turquoise slab earrings for me (which I found tucked into one of my flower pots outside
my front door, along with a card bearing a meaningful Navajo quote about 'walking in
strength' and 'walking in beauty'); to Kathryn and John, for a box of delectable black
raspberries from the Amish (I much enjoyed our lunch at Voodoo Lounge the other day,
overlooking a tranquil gurgling creek); to my neighbor Pat, for baking me blueberry
muffins to enjoy with my iced coffee, delivered when she and her husband Dennis picked
me up from chemo on Friday; to Isa, for sending me kitchen gloves to ensure that I avoid
any trips to the ER in the future when/if my knife slips; to John O., for offering to cater a
dinner party for me with his phenomenal cooking! If I haven't mentioned you here,
please know that I'm grateful for many other acts of kindness (texts, emails, calls etc.).
Another practice suggested by _The Book of Joy,_ with which I was already familiar
thanks to my friend Shanny, is daily intention-setting. Recently, I set as my intention to
revel in the month of June, particularly glorious this year. This meant, of course, lots of
drives down backroads, enjoying gorgeous vistas, cooking with the bountiful early
summer produce, greenhouses and farm stands (I can't stop buying planters! My front
patio looks like a lush floral paradise, albeit a bit over the top...). Today I drove further
afield, about thirty miles away towards Lock Haven, to Sugar Valley/Loganton -- buggies,
a greenhouse, and an enchanting 1874 covered bridge, the last covered bridge, in fact,
in Clinton County. Last night was dinner outdoors on my back patio with my friend
Andrew: I made an heirloom tomato salad with ricotta and a good vinaigrette + a cherry
and black raspberry clafoutis for dessert, while he supplied his fabulous Negronis
(Stanley Tucci recipe; twice the gin!), of which I drank a few thimblefuls, ie small cordial
glasses. Lovely evening, great convo. I try to stay in the moment and focus on all the
pleasure this brings...
_Why I don't care for the 'fighting' or 'battling' metaphor:_ Yes, a non-seq here, but it's
been on my mind. A lot has been written on this by others than me, but I'm aware that
injunctions to 'keep fighting' etc. irk me. It seems to me that I'm simply doing what the
great majority of people would do should they desire to live. 'Fighting on' seems to me to
belong to a narrative we craft of control over disease, whereas ovarian cancer is nothing
if not insidious. I can attempt to have agency over 'winning' or 'losing' to the extent
possible, but at least some of it is completely out of my control. Moreover, 'battling' my
disease also means not only willing chemotherapy to kill off 'bad' cancer cells but also
accepting that the chemo is killing or damaging many of my healthy cells as well, a
                    
strange 'battle' indeed. I may be able to frame this more coherently going forward, and
for now I really can't say what type of injunction would motivate (or irk) me more than
the 'fighting' cliché. Perhaps simply meeting me and 'holding space' for me wherever I
happen to land at a given moment is the most helpful thing  you can do.
Enjoy the holiday weekend. I have such mixed feelings contemplating our flag. It's
become such a deeply divisive, multiple signifier. The local backroads are bedecked with
them, often paired with a "Don't Tread on Me" or occasional Confederate flag. In this
context, it's a symbol that, sadly, almost repels me, whereas it used to make me proud.
For today, I'll simply focus on all the goodness that has been manifesting itself to me
recently. I believe in the goodness in you.
[For some reason, my images are not uploading correctly. I will try again to add them
later].

text:
Health update: status quo. Chemo today: Taxol + Avastin + magnesium drip. No marked
side effects, but fatigue. Thank you, Janis, for driving me to chemo as usual and to Greg
M. for picking me up, treating me to an iced cappuccino and scone at Café Lemont, and
bringing me home (even while planning your own trip to Boston for your father's funeral),
where I conked out on the couch for a while. Three-month check-in this past week with
my primary care physician, Dr. Damaske. He tweaked some of my meds (upped my
Lexapro dosage; stressed taking high Tylenol dosage and antacids for sometimes bad
indigestion and abdominal discomfort), examined me (said he did not feel any
protuberances near surface; cancerous lymph nodes must be buried further under
surface); let me know how to alert myself to a bowel perforation, a constant source of
stress for me (basically, I'd experience sepsis>high fever and chills and abdominal pain,
warranting immediate attention in the ER). He's a kind, compassionate young(ish) doc,
                    
who (I learned, from the rainbow striped heart pin he was wearing) treats many young
trans patients locally. Highly empathic, he asked if he could give me a hug, which he did,
and I asked if I could call him Paul, which I also did (he calls me Willa on my insistence,
no longer "Dr. Silverman"). Grateful to have him on my care team (and to have his
personal cell phone # at my fingertips if needed).
I am also in an information gathering phase regarding clinical trials and other treatment
options. I eagerly await my consultation with gyn-onc Dr. Seth Cohen at Sloan-Kettering
on July 18th. I am very curious to know whether MSK might have something to offer me
that might prolong my life  -- targeted therapy, immunotherapy, clinical trial etc. -- no
guarantee, of course. I have also spoken twice by phone to a 'clinical trials navigator' at
M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, a kindly and helpful physician, Liliana Milojevic
(many thanks to my college classmate/guardian angel Dr. Steven Sherman for making
the contact). Dr. Milojevic gave me her opinion on a few trials that had been identified
for me by other contacts (Maria's physician son; Ben's friends Nikhil and Irene, who work
in biotech/biological research). While as Dr. M. noted it can be hard to assess these
aforementioned trials as they are *trials* (ie in the process of being tested), she seemed
to me to express some doubts about their viability (some would require much further
advance testing on me before I could even be considered for the trial, for example).
Rather, she sent me information about a number of trials going on at M.D. Anderson that
*might* be useful for me. *If* I were to be accepted into them (and we are *many* steps
from that point), I would need to go to Houston for treatment (and initial consult before
that), and possibly set myself up there for a while. I will also run the descriptions of these
trials by Dr. Beavis, who suggested that there appear to be no viable trials for me taking
place at Hopkins right now. I will query Dr. Patel too, but as a generalist medical
oncologist he is not likely to be up to date on the latest/best gyn-onc trials. And I'll likely
follow up with Steve Sherman as well. SO: information-gathering at least through my
Sloan consult, then assessing followed by Big Decision making. This keeps me up at
night (more or less every other night), but I'm also trying to proceed methodically and
make the best decisions for myself. Hope I am... Meanwhile, thank goodness, still feeling
ok, out and about, energy level acceptable, doing my stuff, seeing friends, finishing off
an article, cooking, taking drives, looking forward to my mother's visit next week during
Arts Fest and then returning with her to NY for a few days (will stay in Ben's apartment in
Park Slope after consult!). Amen.
Every day a blessing. Every minute, actually.
Over the holiday weekend (which was quiet and perfectly pleasant for me), I read Delia
Ephron's memoir, _Left on 10th: A Second Chance at Life, A Memoir,_ which (like Suleika
Jouad's _Between Two Kingdoms_ but in a most different style) recounts the writer's
grueling treatment (in a clinical trial) for leukemia and her *recovery* from this
seemingly near-fatal treatment, the "poison cure." I should likely be struck down for
occasional pangs of envy towards the author, who's in her seventies: she has means and
                    
name-recognition (and thus access to superior treatment, rooms etc.) and a remarkable
carer and adored second husband, a psychiatrist and widower named Peter Rutter, who
reached out to her after she had written a piece in the _NYTimes_ shortly after her own
husband had passed (a well-known writer, she is also the sister of the late Nora Ephron,
who died of leukemia) (http://www.deliaephronwriter.com/latest/after-54-years-we-fell-in-
love-after-five-months-i-got-leukemia). She's also been lucky. Like me, she has a
devoted, astonishing circle of friends. Lovely homes in the W. Village (my dream
neighborhood) and California; neighbors who formed a support community. My mini-
pangs were curtailed, though, by the dreadfulness of her treatment, centered on a rarely-
attempted type of bone marrow transplant (haplo-cord transplant>adult donor blood is
combined with umbilical cord blood) -- which worked. Anyhoo, a few quotes from the
book stayed with me; I share them here, at random:
>I was introduced to the expression "casting crepe" or "hanging crepe," referring to
when a doctor forecasts a bleak outcome for a patient. It references the custom of
widows wearing crepe for a year after their husbands' deaths. I suppose I took Dr.
Beavis' prediction of my potentially shortened life span this way, while understanding
that I could be an outlier.
>"Being a patient in a hospital is the center of the world - a very small world, but I am
the definite center. Everyone is there for me. At the same time, I'm powerless. The
center of the world but powerless." This paradox rings true.
>An excellent description of how a close friendship deepened further during Delia's
illness. I have experienced this before with a few friends: "'What we experienced that
week was just the essence of what a true friendship is. It was sort of as if you and I had
gone on a trip together. It deepened our friendship in such a profound way.' It was, I
think, my vulnerability, her having to assist with prosaic tasks, and, mostly, simply the
amount of time we were together. Conversations with purpose, conversations with
depth, conversations that meandered.  Silence. Sleep. Yes, even after years of endless
phone calls and long lunches, we broke through to another level of comfort." YES:
breaking through to another comfort level...
>On being a writer: "My body may be gaining strength, but I am not writing. Both my
screenplay projects went south during my illness. I can't imagine sitting down in my
office at my laptop and having any thoughts spill out. This is huge. I am a writer first. It's
sanity and comfort. But it's gone. That big piece of me is in a boat caught in a current,
drifting further and further away." It would take me more time/space/energy than I have
right now to discuss how my illness (and retirement) have affected my feelings about my
work, my strong identity as a writer and at the same time my conflicted feelings about
the same. A conversation with my friend Andrew the other night, though, about
safeguarding my work as an important part of my legacy, got me back to my desk
yesterday to finish up a long article that is almost done. I am motivated to send it off
                    
asap. And I've always loved personal writing, have an enormous trunk filled with my
diaries, dream books etc. and plan to also assemble stories, poems etc. currently lodged
in my computer for whomever wishes to read them later.
>A good description of my own 'flight' response; it resonates with me: "I am curious
about many things and write about them - how people fall in love, why marriages beak
up, family madness, family dynamics, psychological cruelties, childhood, the nature of
friendship - but about the science of saving my life, I know only this: if I do research I will
panic, I will become hysterical, I will misunderstand, I will obsess. I don't even have an
appetite for it. I'm not repressing curiosity. I simply trust my ability to choose people and
then abdicate."
>I was introduced to the expression "friend-daughters" and realized I have several of
these, mainly former graduate and undergraduate students who have become cherished
friends, special friends because of the unusual nature of our professional/personal
mentor/mentee relationship over many years (in part). I love them dearly. While I
certainly do not discount the extraordinary role of my male family members/friends,
women  have played and continued to play a crucial role in my journey. I liked this quote
too: "I was amassing my women warriors. Looking back now, even before I decided, I
was assembling my troops."
>On another note, a message from a woman (Kerri Grote) who recently passed from
cancer, posted on Facebook by my friend Chris O. (yes, I am still on FB, which great
ambivalence), slammed the "cancer survivorship as a battle" metaphor much more
forcefully than I did in my last post; kudos to her for helping me access my own feelings:
"But let me be crystal clear while I’m able: I did not 'lose a battle' against cancer. This is a ridiculous,
steamy pile of horse shit that society has dumped on cancer patients. Western medicine, and
Western culture, especially, is so uncomfortable talking about death that instead it created this
“battle” analogy that basically shames people who die from cancer. News flash: None of us gets out
alive from this rodeo called life. There is no shame in dying from cancer – or any serious illness. And
it doesn’t need to be a battle. It’s a transition that each of us will go through."
https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=3087224811563411&set=a.1493039927648582
Finally, I watched the TED talk, entitled "What Really Matters at the End of Life," by one
of my 'guides,' the hospice and palliative care physician (and triple amputee, following
his having  survived electrocution following an accident in college), B.J. Miller
(https://www.ted.com/talks/bj_miller_what_really_matters_at_the_end_of_life). Watch it.
It's a compelling and clear-eyed talk that among many topics treats that of "dying well"
(ars moriendi, something I hope to write about in another post). I like Miller's ideas about
aestheticizing death, replacing cold beeping hospital machines and isolation with beauty,
sensual pleasure etc. (he spoke about the delight of having a snowball melt in his hands
when he was hospitalized). I also liked this Miller quote so much I wrote it down: "I am
asking we make space so that aging and dying can become a process of crescendo
                    
through to the end." CRESCENDO THROUGH TO THE END.
[Thank you, Mark F. and Michael, for providing some very useful clarity on end of life
issues this week].
[I am late in responding to a few recent emails, for which I am grateful; I hope/plan to do
so this weekend].
Grateful to hear this week from Gail G., after a little hiatus, Katerina, Clare, Zia [the
juicing saga continues! I bought a Nutribullet] Denise [who I look forward to seeing for
lunch in NY along with her husband Mike and our pal Richard, as I look forward to dinner
with Sandy and Cheryl this coming week], Kay (my dear friend whom I met when we
were about eleven years old and I spent a few summers in her hometown of Amherst,
MA; we met while acting in a production of "Tom Sawyer," remained friends through
Harvard, followed parallel paths as humanities professors (she in English at UC Santa
Barbara), mothered one son each, but are usually only in touch a few times a year, too
few); and for a slightly wet lunch with Nancy. Please forgive me if I've forgotten anyone!
Have a peaceful sabbath.

text:
I wanted to write a brief post before leaving tomorrow for Mohonk. Rather, I will be at the
Geisinger lab at 7:45 tomorrow to have blood drawn, then will meet Dr. Patel before
proceeding to chemo. When that's all over, the 4+ hour drive to New Paltz. I've asked
the nurses not to give me any Benadryl to guarantee I'm alert. I'm slightly apprehensive
but hoping that I'll just ease into a driving groove, that the clear weather gods will be
with me, and that I can simply chill during the drive without excess fatigue. It's not ideal.
But it should work. Back Monday. I'm going to stay over in Tarrytown, NY after our lunch
                    
at Blue Stone Farms so I can be refreshed for my return drive on Monday. Ben will take
the bus from the city tomorrow late afternoon and I can't wait to have dinner with him at
Mohonk. The menus look enticing. Mohonk offers abundant activities but I may instead
wish to curl up on our balcony overlooking Lake Mohonk with a good book. Yay, r&r!
I've felt somewhat tired the past few days with some discomfort at top of my vagina (site
of several tumors), lower back, and side. I've needed a lot of sleep, including several rest
periods during the day, and have relied on Tylenol and Oxycodone when needed. Of
course it makes me worry about metastases (spine? brain?), tumor growth, progression
of disease. Perhaps my CT-scan, likely planned for August, will be moved up (I'll confirm
date with Dr. Patel tomorrow). I suppose I could still be tired from recent travel to NY,
stress surrounding the consult at MSK, bed hopping in Manhattan and Brooklyn, heat
wave etc. So...much...uncertainty.
The question "Is it ok to simply survive?" popped out of my mouth when speaking via
zoom with my therapist last Monday. I may have meant: "Is it ethical to consume
resources while not manifestly 'producing' anything tangible or laudable in return?" (in
my case: publications, knowledge, learning etc.). Or I may have meant: "Is it acceptable
for a lifelong *striver* such as myself to shift my focus to surviving on the days that
seems about all I can handle?" Or I may have meant: "While *thriving* with cancer and
enjoying the best possible quality of life remains my ultimate goal, should I simply cut
myself some slack on the days this proves challenging?" Or I may have meant: "Is
survival enough to motivate me to press on?" I grapple with these questions and don't
necessarily have an answer for them. I continue to set my sights on striving/thriving, of
course, but those around me (as well as myself) need to know and accept that some
days I might only hit 80%, or 60%, or not at all (Ben, remember when I had to sit down
on your staircase for a rest because I couldn't manage the four flights in the heat?). Still
quite a challenge for a highly-functioning person who can't escape niggling feelings of
guilt or anxiety or disappointment or of disappointing others...
Strive, thrive, survive: note that the concept of 'battling' or 'fighting' my disease is not
part of this triumvirate.
It occurred to me the other day that I am into my *fourth* year of treatment. A milestone
to be proud of, I suppose, but also one that lies close to the fateful five year mark by
which, statistically, half of OC survivors are dead. That passage feels ominous. How
much more of the "poison cure" can my body take? Is cancer taking a marked toll on me
visually (somehow, I care about that, although it seems trivial); do I look progressively
'marked for death?' At the same time, memories of the vacations that have marked each
of the four summers since my diagnosis are wonderful to return to. 2019: I was in rough
shape recovering from my thirteen hour debulking surgery at Hopkins and was very sad
to forego the trip to Lyon that I had planned for Ben and myself, but was delighted that
Ben and Sammi could go in my stead, enjoy a fabulous wine tour with a French friend of
                    
Arnold's, stay in a swanky hotel in a renovated townhouse, indulge in Lyonnais
gastronomy. 2020: Chatham, a fabulous week at the Chatham Bars Inn, an outstanding
hotel on the beach. Lots of local seafood, a day in Provincetown, spa treatments, a long
car ride filled up with podcasts, chitchat etc.; the Cape is one of my favorite places.
2021: East Hampton/Amagansett. Magnificent beach, seafood, cooking, the Hamptons
vibe, a visit with my high school friend Eva. Driving back to the city through Hurricane
Henri was scary, though, although we did make a pit stop to have some A+ Long Island
pizza. It was great having Sammi with us part of the time. 2022: ?.
Ok, I'm smiling now. Must go finish packing for tomorrow's trip. Be well, everyone.
