text:
[Catching up; further posts on recent days to follow, hopefully]
Having begun to reacclimate after our wonderful Hudson Valley idyll (about which, more
soon) and also having begun to climb out of a post-idyll health-related slip into a slump
(about which, more soon too), I'm back to my State College rhythms: meals out with
friends (this past week at the Ale House with my gals Monique and Kathryn; this Sunday,
brunch at the Naked Egg with my gal Maria; next Tuesday coffee at Rothrock with my gal
Helen, to whom I just recommended the hysterical/poignant "Fire Island" on Hulu, which I
loved); to/from chemo car rides with my gals Janis and Jackie, mini-gab fests included;
country drives; farmers markets and cooking (delicious tomato/watermelon soup
adapted from the delectable one we sampled last Sunday at Blue Hill at Stone Barns
(more tomato dishes - pie? jam? chutney? - to come); reading (Colm Toibin's _Brooklyn,_
liking the novel/Toibin's style). I sleep oddly, punctuated by awake periods throughout
the night when I usually read NYTimes articles. The result is fatigue; must stay off my
devices!
Today I made my annual-ish trip to a farmers market about 25 miles or so away, the Old
School Market in - you guessed it - an old elementary school near Lamar, PA. Produce, a
flea market, a small animal auction, a food court, butcher etc.; I was attracted by some
very nice (and inexpensive) planters they used to sell early in the summer, but didn't see
any plants today. This trip also allowed me to stop at The Cakeshop by Tati, the
phenomenal bakery en route to the market (but a good 9 miles from my house), to snag
a few croissants and a tiramisu, my favorite dessert. Tati (Tatiana, the baker, who is from
Peru) produced my gorgeous birthday cake, the best cake of its kind I have ever eaten,
bar none (although I fondly remember my childhood birthday cakes, usually purchased
at the Gramercy Park Bake Shop [about which many more memories!], layered thick with
sugary buttercream and bedecked with plastic ballerina figurines in a circle on the cake's
top).
And I probably won't return to this particular market in Salona, PA. When Sammi gamely
made the trip there with me in 2020, the election campaign was in full gear, and a huge
Trump flag bedecked an entire wall of the market. It should have tipped me off, but
these displays are not uncommon once I leave the protective cocoon of State College. 
For the first time ever, I was actually harassed FOR wearing a mask inside a building!
The harasser was a central Pennsylvanian of a type that abounds in these parts: older
man (70s? 80s?), slightly stooped, baseball cap, short sleeve checked shirt w/t-shirt
underneath, and khakis. Nothing objectionable there. 
As I entered the school building:
                    
Harasser: Are you about to hold someone up? [I understood immediately where he was
coming from]
Me: Why?
H.: Well, you look like you're about to hold someone up.
Me [starting to feel I'm being triggered in ways that absolutely incense me; too bad I
didn't have my AK-47 on me lol, I could have bought all the ammo I needed from a stand
in the 'flea market' in the Old School; people have been shot for much less in this
country...] Actually, I have cancer, which compromises my immune system. I am wearing
this mask to protect myself, but also to protect you. Next time you think about masking,
perhaps you should remember me.
H: [mumbles something apologetically]. Does it bother you? [I presumed he meant the
mask and not cancer; I also now wonder if he meant no more than 'is the mask annoying
to wear?,' as it is for all of us to greater or lesser degrees that we simply accept, but was
tempted to ask him whether he meant "does it bother you not only physically, but also
ideologically, politically, ethically, etc.?"]
Me: No. Does it bother you?
H: [smiles disingenuously] Sometimes.
I could feel my voice rising, with others overhearing our conversation, so I decided to
move on. In retrospect, I had wanted to say: "Is there a policy *forbidding* the wearing
of masks here?" AND "The next time you see someone masked indoors, please put aside
your ideology, your crazy adherence to the lies of Trump and his cronies, and your
disbelief in science, and think of me, if you're unable to direct your empathy to a broader
circle of your human brothers and sisters."
Having stopped short of a rant (I wonder what held me back?), I continued on to the 'flea
market.' There was no a.c. and it was sweltering. One vendor was snoozing at her stand,
another one remarked to a third: "Well, some days are simply not good days. Do you
need any money?" I felt badly for them, then came upon the stand selling ammo for
AK-47s, 9 mms etc. Again, not an unexpected sight around here in Pennsyltucky, but my
photo reveals all that is tragically, profoundly wrong in our country (or parts of it) today.
Let's decode: The ammo, plentiful and not exorbitantly expensive imo, speaks for itself.
The poster to its left, which featured at one time politically neutral American iconography
that has in recent decades been fully coopted by the Tumpers (American flag, eagle,
musket man) reads "God, guns & guts (often amended around here to "God, guns and
Trump") made America free/Let's keep it that way." And at the pinnacle of this triangular
display, a poster advocating Doug Mastriano for governor. Mastriano's views, should my
                    
non-PA brethren and sisters be uninformed, fall at the extremist fringe of his own party:
he made payments to Gab, an extremist social media site to which the shooter in the
infamous 2018 Tree of Life synagogue massacre in Pittsburgh belongred, for its
consulting services. In fact, Mastriano has long rubbed elbows w/anti-Semites and anti-
Semitism, which he now claims to 'abhor' (perhaps he's an anti-Semite of the Alex Jones
stripe, obsessed with nightmare visions of the nefarious influence of a "Jewish mafia").
Mastriano also opposes abortion *for any reason,* and has made this a cornerstone of
his campaign. An election denial activist, Mastriano has warned that he will decertify
voting machines in counties whose results seem (to him) suspect. Under the
particularities of PA law, he has unusually wide latitude to do this. And he laid out cash
from his State Senate campaign to transport supporters to the "Stop the Steal" rally on 6
January 2020.
Please come to PA this fall to help keep our governorship blue! But will Pennsyltucky
really go for "the Jew and the Black," conforming to notable perceptions of former state
attorney general Josh Shapiro and Austin Davis, who may well lose in the fall. And please
keep our former lieutenant governor and current Senate candidate John Fetterman
(running against snake oil salesman and carpet bagger extraordinaire, Mehmet Oz), an
impressive candidate with an unconventional persona, healthy, even *alive,* as he holds
his first rally today in Erie, after suffering a stroke in May that by his own admission,
combined with other health issues, might have killed him.
End of rant. For now. But "be afraid, be very afraid." Then get angry. And then do
something.
After being traumatized by my experience at the Old School Market, it was lovely to stop
at Shemp's greenhouses and market on my way home, where I picked up some excellent
looking produce: heirloom tomatoes and a large head of garlic. And as most Saturdays
I'll stop by the Amish market run by the friendly family at Hillside Farm, five mn. from my
home, where the bounty of August is reaching a crescendo, showcasing swelling mounds
of green beans, eggplants, tomatoes, melons, okra, zucchini, peppers, cherries, peaches,
blueberries, blackberries, basil, beets, fennel etc. + all the Amish baked and canned
goods that I don't really care for.
More soon w/health news (no major updates for now, but as usual, some developments).
Be well.
I badly owe some emails. Will make every effort to get to them this weekend!

text:
As classes begin at Penn State in two weeks, my psyche finds itself hard-wired, even in
this second post-retirement year, to spew anxiety dreams. This one was a variant of "I'm
the instructor in charge of a class, it's the first day, I'm not prepared, and I'm worried
about the outcome" (do note that I've also appeared as a student in this type of dream
before). In the dream, I spend at least 15 mn futzing around with AV equipment etc. in
front of a large, full auditorium before introducing myself to the class. Surprisingly (and
I've had a version of this dream before too), the many students in the class have stuck
with me, are still in their seats, and are attentive as I start class, although they've been
noisy before class starts.
In writing this just now, I realize that I may well have amended the description of my
dream thus: "I'm the cancer patient, I feel unprepared for what's ahead, and worry about
the outcome."
Once again, at this 'commencement,' I find myself anxious about how I'll organize my
time going forward, what I wish to accomplish etc., with my identities as a cancer patient
and a scholar seeming to merge (and conflict, coincide etc.) in this instance. Part of me
is attracted to the thought of simply sitting around and waiting to die while the other
part, the one that won me over, is drawn to identifying some discrete projects to work on
-- while of course faced with a wall of uncertainty concerning next steps in my treatment.
My thinking often tends to be quite binary* in this way -- all or nothing, death or life, give
up or soldier on etc. (*except when it comes to my thoughts on gender and sexual
identity!). I'm also aware of not wanting to scare anyone, to not bring any further pain to
loved ones. While I feel some obligation to continue to 'live large' (for me, but also for my
friends and family), I also wonder if this long *slog* might be unduly wearing. Another
binary, I supposed.
For the very first time today, I realized that I also have the option of stopping treatment.
I won't do that, but not feeling well the past few days plus being consumed with anxiety
about my (as yet nonexistent, I realize) plans for endgame scenarios have only
accentuated my feeling of slogging...
If I stopped treatment, I wouldn't be able to:
*witness the leaves change color;
*prepare for a joyous New Year (5782) by cooking foods, preparing the table, joining
fellow congregants at services, observing tashlich etc.
*dangle my feet in a deliciously chilly creek;
*spend time with loved ones.
My scans (MRI, CT-scan) are scheduled for the end of August/beginning of September
(I've forgotten the exact dates). Obviously, these are major assessment points, which will
                    
help determine next steps, especially if there's been progression. My 'scanxiety' has
intensified the already perfect storm of factors that I am simply trying to hold right now,
ie:
>Last office visit with Dr. Patel put me in a bit of a state. He seemed distracted and his
best bedside manner was not in evidence. Instead, he complained amply about staffing
shortages (which impact when appointments can be scheduled and often delay them
due to lack of providers), issues with insurance companies, and layers of bureaucratic
impasse, which, as he said, were preventing him from helping cancer patients, especially
many of the younger ones he was treating. While he did not threaten to quit (well,
perhaps he did...), he made a 'washing his hands of it' gesture, to indicate that there
were times he felt that frustrated he simply wished to be done with it. I blurted out
"Please don't quit; we need you!" I certainly get where he's coming from, and feel badly
for him (we need more oncologists in this town and Covid, plus the repeal of Roe, have
put huge strains on the medical profession) but I hope he appreciates how vulnerable
this can make patients feel, too. I would not unload my gripes about academia on my
students, for example. I just don't find it appropriate.
>Very low magnesium readings, which mean a number of important biochemical
reactions in my body are out of whack. I'm currently getting two additional magnesium
infusions a week.
>Chronic diarrhea, very depleting (and depleting of electrolytes such as magnesium).
Still trying to get it under control with additional magnesium infusions.
>Fatigue;
>Stomach ache; discomfort in various parts of my stomach, but no real pain. And vital
signs good!
>My CA125 level (measure of a protein, used to detect amount of cancer in the blood)
has doubled since last blood test, jumping from 11 to 22. It is still within the range
considered normal (<38), though. I've heard diametrically opposed views about whether
this should be a concern; to Dr. Patel it's 'just a number,' to Dr. Beavis, it's no longer a
good indicator for me (not sure why). Nevertheless, it is *one* indicator among several,
and I'm anxious to see whether it belongs to a trend or is an outlier.
>Watching a video created for _The New Yorker_ entitled "Documenting my Wife's Final
Days on Social Media," another attempt to demystify conversations about death by
documenting them graphically and publicly. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1i-
TvqmjsBw The woman in question was dying, in her mid-fifties, of late-stage ovarian
cancer. While I found much to admire in the honesty of this documentary, the specter of
Kathy's physical decay gave me the willies, like the worst Halloween spook you could
                    
imagine. Scary stuff.
>Realizing at about 4 a.m. that I actually have no plan for endgame, have not explored
nursing care, home care options etc., which is likely what would feel most comfortable
for me. I did begin to inquire with some of the nurses in the infusion room today and will
follow up. A lot of this seems daunting and time- and energy-consuming, though. My
house cleaner, because she's facing challenges herself, cannot clean for a while, and just
finding someone to help clean and straighten my currently messy house is an ordeal. My
goal is to stay independent until I can no longer do so, but it occurred to me that I don't
have a caregiver! My friends have been extraordinary in helping me with all sorts of
errands, food etc. but I'm envisioning a much heavier lift at some point, one that friends
and family may not be equipped for. When that point will be, I still don't know! 
Hopefully, less slogging and more thriving await! Will see what the next days bring.

text:
On days when I'm not feeling great, a text or call from a friend or family member feels
like a lifeline. So I picked up my phone immediately when I saw "Jackie C's" name and
heard her warm, slightly low, lilting Scottish accent on the other end, offering to come by
(or get together) and to pick up some groceries for me. Suffice to say that as a survivor
(of o.c. and beyond), Jackie gets how these physical>mental slumps work. We'll meet, sit
on my porch and have a cold drink, talk, or go for a short walk on Friday. It was also
lovely to hear from my dear grad school friend Vinni, reminding me that we were to
catch up by phone today (to my chagrin and uncharacteristically, I had forgotten to note
this in my datebook, so I needed to move our phone call to today, and look forward to it).
I think this 'survivors' club' may have some special intuition about when lifelines are
needed. And Ben has of course been checking in regularly. [And thank you, Shanny and
Martina, for your phone calls too, and Melissa for your text and apt poem by Rilke! So
good to hear from you. I'll get back to you as soon as I'm able]. I'm still not feeling great,
but perhaps a bit better than a few days ago. I was at my neuro-oncologist's yesterday
and was told that I didn't need to resume taking steroids for the discomfort on the right
side of my skull, caused by inflammation stemming from my brain operation in January.
The brain isn't really my main concern right now anyway; the problem's my
abdominal/pelvic area, breathlessness and fatigue.
My getaway with Ben was also a lifeline. Three summer trips with him since diagnosis! A
fourth had been planned for summer 2019 but my debulking surgery intervened, and so I
sent Ben and Sammi on their fabulous trip to Paris, Lyon and Annecy instead of my
joining Ben for the trip.
I surprised myself by embarking on the four hour drive to the Hudson Valley immediately
following chemo last Thursday, and it hardly tired me out. I checked into our wonderful,
updated 'vintage' room (the original lodge dates to the early 19th c.), with a working
fireplace, dark wood moldings, antique furniture, no t.v. (yay!) and a balcony overlooking
Lake Mohonk, to be viewed peacefully from two Adirondack chairs. Ben arrived soon
after. We now have a joke that involves one of us flinging open a hotel door to reveal the
other standing on the threshold in a new and unexpected location -- we've now
rendezvoused (sp??) in hotels in Besançon and Montpellier, France, my apartment in the
rue Paul Bert in Paris and now - Mohonk Mountain House (Ben, have there been others? I
think so...). Somehow, we always get a big laugh out of finding one another on the
thresholds of random hotel rooms in far flung locations in Europe and the States, which
then becomes the pretext for big hugs and more gales of laughter.
Although there were plenty of kids there, I liken MMH to "camp for grownups." We
observed many multi-generational families, likely returnees and skewing (although not
exclusively) towards preppy. A dizzying array of activities was available -- yoga, tai chi,
Pilates, water sports, hiking and nature walks, house history tours, music, meditation,
                    
tennis, horseback rides, golf, spa treatments + three (more than) square a day. I enjoyed
reading on our deck overlooking Lake Mohonk and the Catskills, a mild hike around the
lake, relaxing in the rowboat while Ben flexed his muscles rowing me across the lake (we
drifted ashore a few times!), a house history tour (as at Bedford Spring, decades of
iconography decorate the walls; unlike Bedford, MMK was the site of various
international conferences about pacifism and equitable treatment of the indigenous
peoples in the area); and excellent music, part of their annual Festival of the Arts (one
group, Miss Maybell and the Jazz Age, was recently featured on NPR; another, Birdland
Jazz Guitar, played lots of standards from the American Songbook). I found *everything*
at MMH to be of  the highest quality - no skimping). Yes, it is pricey, but I have such a
different sense of the value of money these days...; ie you can't take it with you... Ben
was more adventuresome than me when I couldn't be, easy enough to do in the perfect
weather we experienced: he swam across the lake, played golf; and climbed through the
Lemon Squeeze (a series of very narrow passageways through boulders) to the summit
of one of the most difficult trails.
Meals were served in about five different settings for us to choose from; in fact, there are
usually so many people at MMH (at full capacity, apparently) that one's meal
times/locations are pre-scheduled, but we were able to tweak our schedule a bit. The
enormous main dining room w/dramatic views of the property at sunset is somewhat
'upscale' and features 'continental' or vaguely locavore cuisine. The fish was tasty and
Ben tucked into various types of steak during our visit. The servers -- largely hospitality
students from abroad -- our server hailed from Poland and wore a cute bow-tie - were
lovely. We also took many meals at The Grange, an outdoor dining area w/checkered
picnic tables overlooking the lake and a large grilling/serving station set up in the center
(>camp for grown-ups!). Every day brought a staggering selection of grilled meats,
numerous types of sausages, burgers, fish, ribs, dishes cooked in cast iron pans (eg
cornbread), plus many other entrees, salads (shrimp and fennel), fruit salads, desserts --
all very tasty. We know how lucky we are!
We had plenty of time to be both serious and silly, to have bits of  Big Conversations and
make small talk, to collaborate on the NYTimes Spelling Bee etc. Recently, when I
decided (after speaking with my therapist) to try to shift to a 'process talk' with Ben and
ask whether he felt ok about how, when etc. we've been going about talking about
issues revolving around my cancer, he replied, "It's all good, mom, I feel I can talk to you
about anything, any time." Be still my heart :) I think my work might be done here for
now.
Sunday we left MMH around 11:00 and took the 'scenic route' along one bank of the
Hudson River, through New Hamburg, Beacon etc. (New Paltz, where MMH is located and
where my nephew Isaac will be headed for college in the fall, seemed to have a bit of
hippy-dippy vibe, à la Woodstock?). Tarrytown seemed affluent and was largely Legend
of Sleepy Hollow/Rip van Winkle themed. We found our destination, Stone Barn Center
                    
for Food and Agriculture (est. by David Rockefeller; the Rockefellers seem to own half
the town, as well as adjacent Pocantico Hills).
We had reserved for lunch at the gorgeous Stone Barns at Blue Hill, perhaps the east
coast pendant to Thomas Keller's French Laundry or Alice Waters' Chez Panisse? At least
that's how I imagined it. In this temple to organic agriculture and farm to table
gastronomy, we headed towards the 'cafeteria,' forgoing the several hundred dollar
lunch/dinner, thank you very much (only offered during the week, in any case). Out
'cafeteria' lunch allowed us to sample about eight or so of the dishes made from their
ingredients, all grown or produced on site (including all their meats and a variety of
interesting grains). In a clean but nondescript industrial looking space, an employee
served and explained to us what we'd be eating: the most delicious gazpacho I've ever
sampled (pureed w/watermelon) - I've since replicated it at home - roasted beets with
slices of plum and pine nuts, homemade ricotta cheese whipped up with ?, another
condiment (something pickled...), a slice of roast beef, a large spelt cookie filled with
blackberry jam, corn lemonade, delicious miche made from one of their unusual grains. 
We ate outdoors under a billowing white tent beside the stone barns, next to a small
stand selling Blue Hill's produce and products (I bought some luscious rhubarb jam). We
might have been in Tuscany or northern Cali, but there seemed something distinctively
American about the scene -- I've tried, but I can't put my finger on what that was. It was
hot, and my energy was fading, so we toured the impressive greenhouses on our own
(cumin plants, which I've never seen before, and many interesting varieties of onions)
before leaving.
I drove Ben to the Tarrytown train station so he could return to the city (we were not far,
in fact, from his late Berkman grandparents' house in Hartsdale, which witnessed many
of Ben's best childhood memories, shared with his Berkman cousins). As it was about 3
p.m. and I was feeling worn out, I decided neither to drive all the way home nor to
hunker down in Tarrytown for the night but to try to make some progress in getting
closer to SC. I aimed for Harrisburg, tempted by both a b and b I like, City House, and my
go-to old school Italian bakery, Alvaro's. The *long* (4-5 hours) drive to Harrisburg was
exacerbated by a rainstorm the last hour. I was exhausted. But I made it to City House,
where I watched a mindless hour of "Ninety Day Fiancé" and ate a piece of pizza I had
picked up at reputedly the best pizzeria in Harrisburg, in one of its many dingy
neighborhood. Like Baltimore, Harrisburg has much to recommend it (although on a
smaller scale, of course) but also many sad, blighted areas ripe for improvement. I slept
like a rock in my cozy room fronting the Susquehanna. Picked up some coffee the next
morning at Little Amps, a cute café in the capital's renovated historic district downtown.
The owners of Alvaro's must have thought I was strange to have taken such a detour --
or obsessed with their cookies and pasta (which I am) -- when they saw how crestfallen I
looked to find their bakery closed just as they were putting out garbage cans and getting
into their car to head off on vacation. I had forgotten that the shop is closed the first two
                    
weeks in August. I wished them a lovely vacation, then retreated like a sad dog with her
tail between her legs. I'll be back, I hope. Road trip?
Health updates: received magnesium infusion yesterday. Have additional med to take for
diarrhea, hoping my abdomen will calm down over weekend. Dr. Patel, who stopped by
the infusion room yesterday (waking me up from a pleasant nap), suggested upping my
pain med dosage, said fatigue, breathless caused by lowered red blood cells from
chemo. I'm inferring there is no way to 'fix' this, but I forgot to ask that explicitly. I'll do
so on Tuesday, when I have a next mag infusion. Still short of breath, tired - ugh - but
likely no worse. Back to chemo next week unless things change. MSK still 'tracking' me,
wanting to know my treatment schedule etc. I'm glad.
 
My friend Melissa sent me a quote from Rilke ("Letters to a Young Poet," pub. 1929) that
resonated with me in this particular moment:
“So you mustn’t be frightened, if a sadness rises in front of you, larger than any you
have ever seen; if an anxiety, like light and cloud-shadows, moves over your hands and
over everything you do. You must realize that something is happening to you, that life
has not forgotten you, that it holds you in its hand and will not let you fall."

text:
Overall, I'm not feeling too badly, with some ups and downs. I was able to move my MRI
up about five days, from Sept. 2 to August 29th, as I was experiencing headaches earlier
in the week (in the front of my head) and this makes me extremely anxious. Fortunately,
the headaches seem to have subsided but I'm nevertheless eager (yet anxious as hell) to
know if any brain mets have recurred. CT-scan set for 9/6. Thanks to a good suggestion
by Dr. Beavis, I'm seeing a palliative care doctor here on Aug. 29th. Dr. Beavis again
stressed to me that palliative care is *not* the same thing as hospice: so far, *none* of
my doctors has mentioned the possibility of my stopping treatment and entering into the
next phase. 'Palliative care' has to do with pain management in serious illness (at least
that's how I understand it), and tends to treat the 'whole person' rather than a patient to
whom prescriptions are routinely doled out. Palliative care doctors might also suggest
'alternative' treatments for pain such as acupuncture, yoga or... tiramisu! The wonderful
palliative care doctor who treated me at Hopkins before my brain operation in January,
as soon as she found out I loved tiramisu, kept bringing me that dessert from different
places around Baltimore, so we could compare and contrast (she loves the dessert, too).
Perhaps not the healthiest option for me but... it was fun! I was surprised to learn that I
even have access to a palliative care doc in State College - I believe it's a relatively new
specialty - but this doctor is here once a week, so ... we'll see. The effects of Friday's
chemo do not seem to be too bad, at least as of now. My magnesium count is up a bit,
which is good. I had an extra magnesium infusion this week, during which I was annoyed
by the patient on my right blabbling loudly the whole time into her cell phone, despite
my fairly violent "shush-ing" of her and several interventions by one of the nurses, and
by the patient on the left, whose ring tone also loudly blared an anthem by country
singer Lee Greenwood of which I'm not fond: "And I'm proud to be an American/'cause at
least I know I'm FREEEEEEEE!" 
Otherwise, my memory of the last two weeks or so is of feeling up and down. Some days
I was so tired it was a struggle to get out of bed or even make my bed (which I hardly
ever fail to do). A few nights I think I slept in my clothes; I had no energy. Then I began
perking up (perhaps the effects of the  Avastin had been wearing me down and were
subsequently wearing off?) and regaining energy. Dr. Beavis found me looking "vibrant
and fantastic" in a picture I sent her of Ben and me at Mohonk. Ridin' the roller coaster.
My sleep is still very erratic. Last night I slept about eleven hours, soundly. The night
before I barely slept two or three. I was worrying about my long end-stage 'to do' list:
need to downsize, make appointment with lawyer and tweak my will a bit, see rabbi
about funeral arrangements, finalize list of my wishes (now a hodge-podge of notes and
ideas). Needless to say, *nothing is (or appears to be) imminent;* I guess I'm just hard-
wired to be worried about one 'to-do list' or another. 
It is comforting, helpful and fun to have Ben home, for a week in this case.  Ben played
                    
golf with Michael a few times and spent time at his home, but Michael was nice enough
to offer to have Ben sleep at my house the whole time, so he could help me out. Ben was
working during the day, but we were able to make/share some good meals (my cooking
gene kicked in and produced heirloom tomato tart, pasta with pesto and scallops, spicy
roast carrot salad, peach crostada, tomato, basil and mozza salad, tomato jam and
more). He helped me with lots of chores around the house. Michael and Sue grilled
burgers and hot dogs for us one night at their place. Ben and I watched _The Deer
Hunter,_ which I don't believe I had seen since it came out. Powerful, amazing movie that
has stood the test of time. Stunning acting by the young Robert de Niro, Christopher
Walken, Meryl Streep, John Cazale. It had me remembering two young men I knew in the
early 70s, when they were just home from 'nam (one was a guy I worked with at NYU
library, when I had my first summer job as a shelver; the other was the son of the
superintendent of our apartment building in NY - he would just sit on the fire escape and
smoke cigarettes all day, and I had a few strange conversations with him). 
The sun was shining on the graduation of my (ostensibly) last Ph.D. student, Morgane, a
wonderful occasion. Morgane's husband, Aaron, also received his doctorate that day
about a week ago. The ceremony itself is a bit 'meh,' but I was grateful to be around to
join Morgane on this day that marked the apogee of seven (?) years of hard work on her
part, and happy to have contributed in any small way to helping her reach her goal.
PSU classes start tomorrow and, like last year, I am sad (depressed?) not to be a part of
it (but yes, of course, grateful for the 35 years I did have, but still....sad). I always loved
the first day of class, certainly as a teacher if not as much as a student, loved the energy
and excitement, the bustle on campus, the anticipation, the performative aspect of the
first day: "It's showtime, folks." And I love teaching, working with students, and being in
a university setting. I had thought about taking myself away to the beach and holing up
for a few days with some good books (currently reading Salman Rushdie's _Joseph
Anton_) but the hotels I was interested in on the Delaware shore were all booked. Maybe
another time soon. This week will hopefully bring a few diversions, including a little road
trip to Alvaro's in Harrisburg next Saturday.
I had a scary dream the other night: I was driving in a car. I was alone and seemed to be
on a country road, even in a forest. It may have been night. All of a sudden, I saw a cute
little bear cub on the side of the road and thought, "Oh, how cute." As I went further,
though, I saw that there were other cubs, and a mama bear too. At this point, I needed
to be concerned not only about my safety but also by the fact that the animals were
trying to cross the road and/or were approaching my car. I drove on, navigating the
driving as best I could, as more and more menacing animals began to appear. Wolves!!
Soon there were terrifying animals surrounding my car, trying to cross the road,
approach or even mount the car etc. I focused all my frightened energy on trying to
navigate this horrifying situation as best I could, struggling to 'get through.' What a scary
metaphor for riding the rough waves of serious illness -- all alone, in this case.
                    
There was a second dream that I don't remember well. It wasn't as overtly frightening,
but it involved my being in a difficult situation: I needed to put small items (like a roll of
paper towels) back in their correct spot, but within some sort of absolutely enormous
space, ship, hotel or something of that nature; it went on for miles and miles. There were
some people around, but no one could help me with my laborious, Herculean task. I was
earnestly giving this daunting mission my best shot, but it seemed tremendously
difficult.
I owe some emails, dear friends! I am working through them and it's a pleasure to write.
Don't despair of me, as sometimes I get delayed by not feeling well, visits etc.

text:
Although I'm grateful for every day, this past week had a bit of a "it just kinda happened"
feel. I do recall struggling with fatigue and spending a lot of time on my couch napping,
resting or reading. At times this felt discouraging. I continue to be plagued by diarrhea
(hopefully not tmi?!), which I do my best to try to control with medication, and by the
consequent loss of magnesium, which can feel very depleting and that this coming week
will again be countered by additional magnesium infusions. My labs this week revealed
another increase in my CA125 level; it's gone from 11 to about 22 to about 27. Say what
you will about this indicator being only one among several (with imaging likely the most
important one), I still feel that the increase over two months can't be a good sign, as my
own 'good' level has rarely risen above the teens. Chemo on Friday went smoothly, and
I'm grateful to both Janis (whose younger brother died recently) and Jackie for being so
kind as to continue to provide my transportation that day. My neuropathy, especially in
my right foot/leg, has become a bit more irritating. I feel I should be pushing myself to
exercise more, but find myself short of breath and fatigued. Still feeling a bit 'aimless'
now that Penn State's fall semester is underway; I continue to feel tethered to the
academic calendar, its rhythms and expectations.
Despite all this, things could certainly be worse. Please send your good thoughts and
energy my way beginning tomorrow, when I have my brain MRI at 7:45 p.m. -- in fact,
tomorrow I'll experience a quadruple-whammy of medical appointments, with a
magnesium infusion, meeting with palliative care doctor, and eye doctor appointment
added to the mix!
I did rally sufficiently on Wednesday to enjoy a lovely dinner at the Allen Street Grill with
my pals Kathryn, Sandy and Cheryl. And I perked up in a big way -- this can happen -- on
Saturday, in time for a road trip to Harrisburg with pals Maria and Helen, destination
Alvaro's Italian Bread and Pastry Shop, which Helen knew already and which I had been
vaunting to Maria for months. After a delicious breakfast there (omelets, sfogliattella,
cappuccino), we loaded up on Italian entrées for dinner (spaghetti and stuffed eggplant),
home baked Italian bread, Italian cookies and gelato. Lots of interesting convo with these
two and a convivial time. Definitely gave me a boost.
In fact, I surprised myself by my 'perkiness' on Saturday, as I had only slept a few hours
the night before -- this happens too. One [feature? advantage?] of this late stage of my
cancer journey is that the night hours often bring an opportunity for a 'deep dive' into
the history of a friendship, a relationship, an event in my life. Friendships, for example,
spool out onto the canvas of my mind with great clarity, allowing me to appreciate them
in all their particularity (how exactly *did* I become friends with that person, fifty years
ago? What memories do I associate with them? What were we like then, and now?).
While I'm certainly bummed not to be able to sleep on nights when I am 'visited' by
these cosmic forays into the nooks and crannies of my life, I don't become anxious
                    
because important realities are manifesting themselves to me. So for now I'll refrain from
"fixing a hole where the rain comes in, and stops my mind from wandering, where it will
go..." I just let my mind wander...
Not overly tired today, either. I slept soundly and likely recovered my sleep debt from
Friday night. Finished up a piece I've been writing for Ben, then took a relaxing drive out
route 45. Leaves are beginning to fall. Many Amish in their 'Sunday best' returning from
church or out driving in their buggies in the nice weather. All roadside stands closed: "No
Sunday sales." Took a short nap and spoke to my dear (and only) aunt, Marlene Green,
for nearly an hour. Hope to make some zucchini pancakes with feta for dinner.
Saturday night I watched a memorable film: _Coda._ I know it's received flak from some
parts of the deaf community; I also know that it relies on some familiar tropes (coming of
age; inspiring teacher; rebellion against v. loyalty to family). However, the setting in
which these narratives play out, and the extraordinary acting, are so fresh, poignant and
original that I am still thinking about the film today while continuing to tear up, as I did
during most of the film! I'm reading Salman Rushdie's fictional memoir, _Joseph Anton,_
a long, intriguing book. I'll try to share further reactions once I've finished.
