label: sadness

text:
Health update: I will have my CT-Scan this coming Tuesday. Then, it can take the
radiologists 1-7 days to produce their report. Obvs, this is the scan I am most concerned
about as all the other problems (including the metastasis to brain) stem from my ovaries
(or, more likely, my fallopian tubes). So this scan will include my abdominal, pelvic and
chest area, to assess recurrence and/or progression of my disease (which is likely, in my
view, from general trend of my disease over past 3+ years; increase over two months in
CA-125 marker; Dr. Beavis' statement that "this cancer is not going away;" under 20%
success rate [i.e. stabilizing the cancer or making it regress] of my current chemo
combo, one of an increasingly small number of ones still available to me). The CT-scan
will also indicate any metastasis of cancer to, for example, chest/lungs, stomach, liver
(on which there are a number of as yet benign exterior nodes), kidneys; assess current
presence of cancer in lymph nodes (have they widened, remained the same or
decreased in width?) and tissue; detect any new masses; assess size of tumors sitting
atop the vagina, causing discomfort. Not much to see in my reproductive system as
there is currently scant trace of it (exterior parts and a few interior ones still remain,
thankfully!); fortunately I put this 'system' to good use before my cancer.
That paragraph was pretty dense. Hope you could wade through it.
So this scan is all important. And I begin with it in this blog post to put the better news
into perspective. Please note, too, that I'll be sending the results of all three scans to
both gyn-oncs at Hopkins and Sloan-Kettering for their radiologists to review. I've noticed
in the past that there are often slight discrepancies between and among the reports, but
usually the overall impression is similar.
My full body bone scan, conducted to assess whether my cancer has metastasized into
my bones after I complained about lower back pain, shows "no osteoblastic lesion." For
those not in the know (including myself), 'osteoblastic' has to do with increased bone
production due to tumor signals to bone. It results in thickened, inflexible bone being
formed. From this and other indications in the report, I take it to mean "no bone cancer."
Yes, this is good news. It is also news that, deep down, I expected to hear; we
proceeded with this scan out of an abundance of caution. I note, too, at the same time,
that I'm ill-equipped to read/interpret physicians' reports and their technical writing,
generally, although out of necessity I've gotten better at it. My eyes start to glaze over
as soon as I hit the technical vocabulary (which essentially comprises the near-entirety
of the writings). My friend David Rothman, a poet, somehow seemed to master reading
and parsing these materials; David, how did you do it?? 
I had to run the next-described report past my brother and son to get their take on it.
                    
My brain MRI reveals "Postsurgical changes [...] without evidence of recurrent or
metastatic disease." I take this to mean, and my brother does too, that there is no
evidence of a recurrence of cancer in my brain or new (or old) mets in my brain. I was
slightly confused by a 'diagnosis' of 'secondary malignant neoplasm of brain' but this
appears to describe my original diagnosis, not a new one.
No evidence of metastasis to either bones or brain (including recurrence) is good news
indeed (once again, this does not mean no mets to other organs tb-scanned this coming
week). It *may* also mean - and this is what I would be most encouraged by -- that I *not
ineligible* for consideration for a clinical trial somewhere (hopefully, Sloan or Hopkins).
However, as noted, I will need to verify whether other metastases, should they be
revealed by this Tuesday's scan, would likewise render me ineligible  for a clinical trial.
Presumably, being treated for two forms of cancer would make me even more vulnerable
health-wise and a less 'attractive' candidate for a clinical trial. If the trial 'worked,' for
example, it might be difficult to assess which form of cancer (if I had two or more) the
trial was treating successfully. I may not completely understand all the reasons for my
'ineligibility' in case of metastasis, but I'm sure they are valid. For now, one day at a
time. I will meet with my neuro-onc's PA, Angie Klein, on Wednesday, to review the MRI
results.
In any event, the positive-seeming report on the MRI gave me such an energy boost that
I jumped into my car after just a short post-chemo rest and took my favorite drive to the
antique store where I'm a regular, the Beaten Path, where I bought a pretty Deco pin (a
blingy rhinestone bar with a large, faux aquamarine pendant hanging from it) and some
vintage greeting cards to use for upcoming occasions, then out into the countryside,
where fall is a-coming judging by the pumpkins (!) for sale at the roadside stand on Rte
45 where I usually stop (I bought two mini-pumpkins packed with wildflowers that I will
give as gifts). Have also seen gourds and mums emerging at Tait Farm and elsewhere.
Time to change my decorating scheme! Final stop: an Amish farm I didn't know; a little
boy with one suspender on, one dangling (cute) sold me some fine-looking brown eggs.
This past week was largely dominated by medical stuff, as part of this coming one will
be, and it was stressful and very tiring. On Monday I had four medical appointments: a
two-hour magnesium infusion as my level is still quite low and seems to remain that way.
At 1:00 p.m., immediately following the infusion, I met, for the first time, a palliative care
Dr., Nicki Vithalani, who is in State College once a week and the rest of the week at the
Lewistown (?) hospital. This meeting was very useful for me. Not only does she deal with
pain management in serious illness (fortunately, not really an issue for me now, although
she did give me a script for Trazadone for insomnia, which last night proved of no use
whatsoever), but she also helps patients navigate end of life care issues in general. She
assured me that, when needed (and even beginning now just to get the lay of the land),
she would connect me with a social worker (the Geisinger office is trying to hire one),
                    
who in turn could hook me up with home health aides, agencies etc. (*good ones,* I
specified). This left me feeling less overwhelmed by the process of investigating all this
on my own, then interviewing potential aides etc. I do need to see what my PSU-
sponsored insurance will cover. Nicki also gave me a DNR order to fill out and put on my
fridge. I told her that I wanted to die at home, as most people do. She also seemed to
function as the token 'friendly person' on my team, the one who compliments me on my
dress and my Skechers (!), asks me in detail about what I taught, if I am an extrovert
etc. Similarly, my relationship with my palliative care doc at Hopkins seemed to revolve
largely around tiramisu (!) and a similar 'holistic' approach to the patient as a *person*
(did Nicki really care that much about my Skechers (which she contrasted with her beat-
up slip-ons from Target) or was she just trying to be friendly? And I did think I looked
pretty cute in that new shirt dress from Paris, which I insisted on wearing to chemo even
most folks are there in their sweats, letting it all hang out including their bald heads!).
Smarminess aside, it was great to meet Dr. Vithalani and we'll connect again in a few
weeks by video chat. Glad to have her on my care team.
At 3 p.m. (following a short rest at home), I happened to have my yearly eye exam,
which was useful as I've been having some problems with close-up vision (e.g. reading)
with my relatively new lenses/glasses. Indeed, Dr. Nelson (a nice, youngish woman fairly
new to my practice w/whom I 'click' well) tweaked my prescription slightly (my eyesight
is actually improving, as can happen in more 'mature' age) and also gave me a script for
reading glasses if needed.
Home again for another rest (by this point I was fairly beat). Had a bite, then proceeded
to hospital for my MRI (at 7:45 p.m.). Somehow, I thought it was going to take 15 mn.
but it wounded up lasting an hour: I moved slightly when I became anxious, and some of
the images needed to be reshot. So after an hour of the sound of jackhammering around
my head, I waited another 20 minutes or so to obtain discs containing the images (to
send/bring/upload for the Sloan and Hopkins oncologists/radiologists to review). By this
point (almost 9 p.m.), the hospital seemed empty and eerie. Compounded by my wealth
of bad memories of the place from Ben's birth on, being there drained me. I watched t.v.
to unwind when I returned home, then fell asleep immediately (unusual for me!).
Tuesday, I had my full-body bone scan at Geisinger Gray's Woods (a much brighter,
cleaner-seeming place than the hospital). I drove there for 9:45 to have an injection of
some sort of dye, then returned at 2:30 for the scan itself (this also took about an hour,
but remaining completely immobilized for that duration was not necessary, as we took
breaks between shots). The technician, Eric, was pleasant. Nothing else is indicated in
my datebook for Tuesday. As I recall, it was one of two days that week during which I felt
really rotten, and spent much time on my couch sleeping, resting, or watching a bit of
t.v., maybe a little reading. Again, I felt completely drained, and actually convinced
myself I was going to die soon.
                    
Wednesday, I rallied enough to have lunch with two of my former colleagues who are
now (and always were!) friends, Kathryn and Monique. We ate outside at Duffy's Tavern
in Boalsburg on a lovely day and had a most pleasant time. Later, Abbye, a kind and
efficient woman a bit younger than me who helps me out with errands and tasks around
my house once or twice a week, came by to deliver my groceries, tidy specific areas of
my house, take out my trash etc. It's a help, and I could use even more of it. I normally
don't have the energy to do some of the intensive downsizing and straightening that I
need to do. Also, I'm acquisitive (if you haven't noticed...). My new policy is to give away
(often to St. Vincent's thrift shop) one item for every one I acquire. In any event, on
Wednesday I also think I rested most of the day. I felt stressed about my MRI results,
which I was awaiting.
Thursday, I had my weekly labs (I've hit it off with one of the phlebotomists, Patty; she
has a son who works virtually from exotic places like Bali [he's recently been in France
for quite a while] while his husband remains in NY. Scratch the surface of some of these
central PA exteriors and you will often find wonderful, interesting people!). After resting
some more (really seemed to need it last week, and let myself get all the rest I need,
'cos it helps), I met my friend (and eons ago, former student) Ted at Voodoo Brewing Co.,
a hip brewery set outside on a charming creek, featuring pub food++ as it's made with
the delicious seafood from Maine Bay & Berry, which the owners bring back from Maine
weekly to their shop above the brewery. Store + brewery is a winning combo, and the
place is always packed. We had fun catching up (Ted works in biotech and introduced me
to some interesting innovations in cancer research; his sis is also an OC survivor as I am)
and took a few pics.
Back to Friday, which was chemo day plus magnesium infusion. I wound up in the chair
for 4.5 hours. Thank you, as always, to Janis and Jackie for providing rides; Jackie was
even kind enough to bring me an iced cappuccino from Café Lemont as I was going to
miss their closing time.  However, as mentioned earlier, I received the positive-sounding
news on the MRI that day, and shot off into the countryside to process it in the late
afternoon...
Random note: I have a small host of side effects that I try not to focus on because they
are manageable. They include, for example, neuropathy (loss of sensation from nerve
damage) in my feet and lower legs). This does not prevent me from walking at all, but I
need to be careful about balance or getting up too quickly, as I broke a bone in my ankle
this way two years ago. I got up too quickly after sitting for along time and went crashing
onto the floor as I had essentially lost feeling in my feet/legs. Another effect I have
noticed affects, strangely, my voice. I used to have a lovely singing and speaking voice.
Now I notice a markedly less lovely singing voice and a bit of 'vocal fry' and odd
monotone quality to my voice. No one has mentioned this to me, so I may be overly-
conscious of it, but it's annoying! But again, in the scheme of things... Avastin, finally,
seems to stimulate my mucous membranes. Lots of sneezing of mucous, some blood.
                    
Lovely, I know. But still, I try not to 'sweat the small stuff.' LOL.
Random stuff: I think my 'roller coaster' metaphor is getting tired. Yes, my life is filled
with 'ups and downs' (e.g. "I'm about to die," "I could live much longer than expected"),
anticipation, uncertainty, fear, very occasional moments of exhilaration. But usually the
fight seems more 'cosmic' (yes, a time-worn image as well...). Mythic? Biblical? Daniel in
the lions' den? Jacob wrestling with the angel? Struggles beyond time and space, at time
beyond meaning (yet also shot through with meaning). Many differences here too (not
sure if the divine intervention stuff applies to my story as well), but I may ditch the carny-
ride metaphor for something more appropriate-seeming.
Speaking of epic combats, all hail Queen Serena (my eyes are starting to tear as I'm
writing - this will be transition number III to follow) for embodying grace, grit,
determination, confidence and much more to so many. The Queen staved off six match
points and brought her opponent to deuce eight times. This Queen was not going down
without a fight! This Queen was leaving it all on the court! What an inspiration.
Speaking of metaphors (or similes) --  transition number II is here, wait for it! -- driving to
brunch today at the Naked Egg Cafe (lovely meal outside, solo) - I was contemplating
packing up some additional boxes of my French-related books (books in French/about
France and Francophone world) to see if one or two of my colleagues could bring them to
school to donate/sell to anyone who wants them. Next thought: but I'm not parting with
*anything* from or about the 19th century, especially those paperbacks of my favorite
poetry, purchased over the years (high school? college? grad school?). Then, lines from
my favorite poet, Baudelaire, popped into my mind *from memory:*
Je t'adore à l'égal de la voûte nocturne,
O vase de tristesse,  ô grande taciturne
Et t'aime d'autant plus, belle, que tu me fuis
Et que tu me parais, ornement de mes nuits,
Plus ironiquement accumuler les lieues
Qui séparent mes bras des immensités bleues.
https://fleursdumal.org/poem/121 [for the translation]
Swoon.
Next thoughts were about the gorgeousness (and macabreness, as the verses advance)
                    
of this poem, and reminded me of the joy it brought me, when I was younger, to
read/study/discuss it. It made me nostalgic for those days of dissecting literature (before
I moved more fully into history and art history). Why does the poet spell out the simile (I
believe it's a simile and not a metaphor, here?) so explicitly in the first line (à l'égal de)?
What about the interesting use of 'ironiquement' in line 5, likely signaling a host of
'ironies' in the lover's comportment towards the poet (she 'accumulates' 'spaces' - such a
vague word - that, ironically, serve not to bring the couple closer but to drive them apart,
a 'separation' upon which, bien sûr, the poet's attraction is based). A classic case of 'hard
to get,' but whoever used words to paint it more gorgeously? So...I actually started
*tearing up* in my car, both surprised that these verses are permanently ingrained in my
mind (even post-brain surgery!) and longing for those halcyon days (ht to Michael, with
whom, just about an hour ago, I was discussing the demerits of a sleep aid we used to
rely on, Halcyon!) of wonderful, creative, and intense group discussions of literature, my
first academic love.
So speaking of eyes welling with tears (transition III!), I was driving home about 6 p.m.
on Thursday and stopped at a long light on the corner of College and Allen, where
campus intersects town in front of the main gates to campus, traversing which one
arrives at the majestic elm-lined mall that leads uphill to the library, office and classroom
buildings. Town and campus were buzzing on this beautiful early evening: long lines at
bars as students likely sought out big screens on which to catch the first football game of
the year, at Purdue; students heading home after class and faculty and staff from work,
too. Penn State students dressed like, well, Penn State students: PSU logo gear,
backpacks, sweats and gym wear, young women in crop tops and short shorts. I miss the
buzz, being in the mix. I miss the many opportunities for creativity and hope that I'm still
using my creativity in other ways, even on a reduced - or different - scale. I miss
teaching and my colleagues. Cue the tears. I seem to do some of my best crying in the
car!
It's a relaxing holiday weekend. I hope to have lunch with my friends Maria, Mar and Jessi
tomorrow or Monday. May start cooking for the holidays; it takes a lot of time and
energy. *Might* go to NY next Friday; feel that I need a change of scene. Meanwhile,
next week: CT-scan, labs, magnesium infusion, therapist appointment, meeting with
neuro-onc's PA to review MRI results, but no chemo! Will likely have more clarity on the
path forward by the end of next week.
Hopefully, more writing, reading. Watched the movie adaptation of _Brooklyn,_ as I had
just read Colm Toibin's marvelous novel of the same name (sorry, I don't know how to
add the accents in Gaelic).  Saorsie Ronin delivered a good performance, but I don't
recommend the movie. A final section including a happy ending was added, whereas in
the novel the 'what happens next?' is much more ambiguous. Also just ordered a
Holocaust themed novel recommended by a friend, _La Carte postale_ by Anne Berest. It
won several literary prizes. Am always looking out for excellent works of fiction, film and
                    
non-fiction on the French experience of the Holocaust.
I am still catching up on emails and texts!
Photos
label: neutral

text:
Thank you to the many of you who showed concern regarding my CT-scan.
Unfortunately, my CT-scan was cancelled today and needed to be rescheduled. I
received a call from Geisinger scheduling at about 10:30 a.m. or so, while I was lying on
my couch in the sunroom, in the middle of my four-hour fast (those 24-hours fasts on
Yom Kippur proved good practice...). The technician had to leave on short notice, et
voilà. Next available appointment at Gray's Woods: late September. So instead I
rescheduled for this Thursday, at the Lewistown hospital. Fifty miles round trip; I have
enough 'juice' in my 'tank' to do it, but it's a pain.
All this made for a stressful day. I've not been feeling great, extremely fatigued, short of
breath, and with a low-grade headache all day (just today). I need a lot of sleep. The
                    
accumulation of the chemo drugs in my body wears me down, and this particular combo
seems to be hitting me hard. I feel so frustrated not being able to 'accomplish' or even
move forward with most of my normal activities. Please do remember how much fun I
am (was?...)! That's how I like to think about myself.
In a bit of better news, my magnesium count rose significantly, from about .9 mg/dl to
1.4 (1.5 is considered normal). I spent about two hours in the infusion room receiving my
once or twice weekly extra mag infusion.
Onward we go...
label: anger

text:
First, my apologies to NY pals I won't get to see in next few days, even though I miss
you! Feeling up to it, if still generally fatigued, I decided to take the train to the city
yesterday for a few days to see my family. We'll be celebrating the *97th* birthday of my
mother's partner, Arnold, a World War II veteran, and I wanted to be here for that. Lunch
with Ethan tomorrow, after I drop off discs of imaging plus radiologists' reports at Dr.
Cohen's office at Sloan-Kettering (still with the intent of ascertaining whether a clinical
trial at MKS might be in my future). Today, Ben and I are planning to take the ferry that
'contourne' (sorry - I am writing quickly and can only think of the French word!) Brooklyn,
making stops at Atlantic Avenue, Bay Ridge and other stops that I've forgotten. It's
raining, not heavily right now, and this trip by water is something of a bucket list item for
me. Had we taken it twenty-one years plus one day ago, the Towers would have loomed
above us. It seems an appropriate gesture of homage and mourning today. I have many
thoughts about the enduring - and the transitory - meaning(s) of 911, and how they have
morphed over the past twenty-one years, but don't have time to write about that now.
Memories seared into our hearts and minds forever, as is the one of six-year-old Ben
asking whether there were children on those planes.
A brief preliminary update on the radiologists' report on my CT scan. As expected, my
disease has progressed in my pelvic/abdominal/chest area; that is the overall
"impression" of the radiologists ('impression' in the report refers to their overall findings).
The report had arrived in my Geisinger portal when I woke up yesterday and as I was
rushing to drive to the train depot (the oldest in PA, from 1849!) I was only able to read it
once. I expect to have Drs. Patel, Beavis, and perhaps Cohen interpret it further for me
this week. Its language is technical and found me looking up words I did not understand;
I need to have the doctors put it all in laywomen's terms for me. Some lymph nodes have
                    
increased in size, one or two have decreased. I don't believe I read the word 'metastasis,'
but I would need to read it again. Pancreas is clear. There are nodes on the exterior of
my liver; up to this point, these have likely been benign. I don't know if anything has
changed. The area scanned still reveals masses (which I'm pretty sure I can feel). The
report contains additional revelations but I have put it aside for now, and probably won't
look at it again until I speak with my doctors. There's not much more I can do for now; so
I'll just enjoy my time in NY.
I was expecting the news, but it's certainly not pleasant to read. So many emotions:
anger, sadness, gratitude - at least for now. Why am I only entitled to 82.8% of a
life(span)? I could have accomplished so much in the remaining 17.2%... I'll write about
my notion of 2/3 of a life some other time.
Immense gratitude to my friend Lisa Sternlieb for accompanying me to Lewistown
hospital last Thursday for my CT-scan, keeping me laughing with her stories and our
gabbing while I worked my way through two large bottles of a barium drink
(yummmm......not), indulging my craving for French fries from McDo after the scan and
the fast that preceded it, and taking time off from her busy teaching/school schedule. It
was wonderful to spend time with Lisa. I only felt moderately (re)traumatized by
revisiting Lewistown Hospital, site of my ill-fated trip in Jan. 2022 (for which I have
Martina Kolb to thank - not for the trip being ill-fated but for her strength during it, and
her kindness). What was to be a visit for a simple MRI that frigid day wound up with my
landing in the ER in Lewistown, and then being life-flighted to Hopkins, as I watched
Martina become a tiny dot waving goodbye from the roof of the hospital as the helicopter
took off.
Gabe and Yvonne, you were in my dream last night. I think about you fondly, and often,
and hope I'll be able to write you a catch-up email before long... I hope you are both well.
I must run now to have a bite and then Uber down to "Corlears Hook" (which I never
knew existed) to meet Ben for our Brooklyn ferry adventure. Feeling quite
Whitmanesque...
Feel free to DM or text me. More news when I have it.
label: sadness

text:
A brief update between a visit to family in New York (fun, if a bit arduous physically, but
more on that in another posting), from which I returned yesterday, and a drive tomorrow
to Maryland, for a telemedicine appointment with Dr. Beavis.
There have been many, many twists and turns over the past few days as I try to share
information with three oncologists, figure out the optimal order of meetings, and of
course arrive at decisions regarding the best path forward. I'm picturing myself making
arrangements with Dr. Beavis' nurse while on the train home from NY yesterday (I try to
speak as softly as possible, unlike the remarkable number of folks gabbing at full volume
into their phones, often for hours; this actually led me to a semi-altercation with a
woman on the train, but I'll skip that story for now); and conversing with Dr. Cohen's
nurse twice, once while a)sitting in the big comfy chair in the infusion room (I got 'stuck'
in the chair and couldn't figure out how to climb down, tethered to my port, to retrieve a
pen so I could take notes) and b)while driving around the Amish farms, necessitating a
stop in the long driveway of one of them so the nurse and I could discuss clinical trials.
Hope you could wade through that sentence, dense as a thicket.
The sheer chaotic pace of the past few days called to mind Jacques Brel's wonderful song
"La Valse à mille temps" ("Carousel"), with its steadily quickening, dizzying pace:
"We're on a carousel
A crazy carousel
And now we go around
Again we go around
And now we spin around
We're high above the ground
And down again around
And up again around
So high above the ground
We feel we've got to yell
We're on a carousel
A crazy carousel"
I was on a bit of Brel kick yesterday as I listened to him singing "Le Moribond"
(improbably translated into English as "Seasons in the Sun," which many of us 'of a
certain age' remember):
                    
"Carousel:" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P4tMl9_fWi8
Brel singing "Le Moribond" ("The Dying
Man"): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LzmbZUO7rU8
I'll avoid the byzantine minutia of the past few days and provide a summary: a)
tomorrow I am driving to Maryland for a telemedicine appointment with Dr. Beavis. As
she can no longer 'practice' (including virtually) in states other than MD, I must be
*inside the MD border* to meet with her! This requirement of being in the state where
the physician practices was suspended during the height of COVID when people were not
travelling (and sometimes not even leaving their homes), but is back in place now. We
will review the results of my latest CT-scan and discuss the path forward. I had
considered various options for tomorrow such as renting a coworking space for my visit
with her or even hitting a coffee shop, but decided to opt for privacy, comfort and
presumably a good internet connection...at a suites' hotel in Hagerstown, MD (!). I'll pick
up dinner on the way down from Alvaro's in Harrisburg, then hunker down tomorrow
night to watch the premiere of "The Great British Baking Show" and/or to read and/or
write and/or take a dip in the pool. My appointment's at 4 and I'll return Saturday
morning; b)in order to meet with Dr. Beavis, I cancelled my Friday morning meeting with
Dr. Patel, followed by chemo. For the moment, the current chemo regimen is off
(although it, or another chemo regimen, may eventually be back on). Any chemo I get at
this point will have a very low success rate because I've exhausted so many of the
conventional lines of treatment); c)the possibility of a clinical trial at MSK is part of the
puzzle. Dr. Beavis asked me to reach out again to Dr. Cohen to get his input, so I did. His
nurse called me today to tell me that there are two trials that are, as we agreed,
"potentially possible." That call raised my spirits significantly. Then she called me again a
few hours later to tell me that, after thoroughly reviewing all my information and the fine
print of the clinical trial description, I am only potentially eligible for *one* of the trials.
Learning that the number of trials 'potentially possible' for me had just diminished by
50%, I felt significantly less buoyant (but still a bit puffed up -- see title of this blog, with
thanks to Jane Mallison for the Latin proverb!). Even if Dr. Beavis agreed that this trial
represented the best path forward, I would still need to go through several tests at MSK
to confirm or deny my eligibility. The MSK nurse sent me the descriptions of the trial
from Clinicaltrials.gov. Of course these files were way too big to send to Dr. B through
the portal, so I am hoping that she will be able to locate their descriptions on her own
(she is likely familiar with them). d)I will gather information tomorrow and share with Drs.
Patel and Cohen on Monday. Oy!
Today I had a magnesium infusion, after which I took a lovely drive in the country. Yes, I
bought lots of gourds (pls see cartoon - guilty of #3 as charged!). The leaves are starting
to turn. I also bought an acorn squash that I'm cooking now, fresh brown eggs, and a
huge, gnarly pumpkin. It was a beautiful day here.
                    
Some of my classmates are enjoying a lovely class reunion in Rome as I write, complete
with a black tie dinner at the Villa Borghese. I would have loved to have hopped on a
plane, bought or brought a few cute dresses, eaten an incredible pizza, and cried over
beautiful art in one of my favorite cities. But as I often tell myself, "this is what we're
doing right now."
Photos
label: surprise

text:
It's easy for my mind to play tricks on me and embrace the worst case scenario,
triggered by certain key words in radiologists' reports and my oncologists' interpretation
of them. So I apologize if I gave the impression that I was at death's door, and hope that
I'm not turning into the girl who cried wolf. 
"Your time is limited," per Dr. Beavis, verbatim. No surprise there. But nothing is
imminent and no one is discussing stopping treatment. And maybe there's a magic bullet
out there, somewhere. Who knows.
I've been caught up in a whirlwind the past ten days - I'm on the 'crazy carousel.' After
returning from NY on Wednesday, Dr. Beavis and I determined that we would have a
telemedicine appointment on Friday at 4:00 p.m. to discuss my recent scans and next
steps. She (and all doctors, I believe) can no longer benefit from the Covid loophole that
allowed them to practice medicine virtually across state lines. As a result, I was obliged
to cross the border into Maryland to telemeet with her (thank goodness it wasn't Boston,
or Houston). I had to, in a quick day's time a)find a logical Maryland location for me to
land (I chose Hagerstown) b)unpack and repack (I was so short on time this consisted of
my dumping everything out of my suitcase onto my bed and putting a few items back);
c)try to rest and ready myself for the next trip. I enjoyed the September mellowness on
my drive down, with a pit stop at Alvaro's in Harrisburg for lunch (excellent pizza, also
picked up pasta/eggplant parmigiana for dinner plus a few lemon ricotta cookies for the
road). Arrived at the hotel about 2:30, a ratty Radisson (something that sounded like
cartoons blaring from the room next door; shoddy internet made me panic but the front
desk somehow managed to improve the connection shortly before I was to meet with Dr.
Beavis). Oh well. It was a good enough place for me to land for an overnight.
I spoke to Dr. Beavis for about an hour. Without going into too much detail, she
recommends prioritizing the clinical trial at MSK about which I've been in touch with Dr.
Cohen. She feels it's probably a good time for me to have a prolonged break from
chemo: the neuropathy that is one of chemo's side effects will only worsen, she warned,
and has already morphed into a bothersome case of 'restless leg(s)," which sometimes
keeps me awake. My body has absorbed a lot of chemo over the past three+ years. In
my understanding, clinical trials at the top cancer centers often subsequently set the
standard for care; Dr. Beavis feels that now's the time for me to try a more 'investigative'
option such as a trial. The trial itself involves immunotherapy and another substance (an
antibody?); it is not chemo. One of the 'substances' is now marketed as Keytruda
(perhaps you've seen ads for it on t.v.), but is not yet used to treat advanced uterine and
ovarian cancer, nor is it used in combo with another substance.
My admission to the trial is definitely not a done deal, however. Dr. Beavis raised two
concerns about my eligibility. I have, this morning, queried MSK about these. Further, I
                    
would/will need to return to NY for screening tests to assess my eligibility. For now, then,
I'm not sharing further details about the trial itself as they are moot.
If the MSK option falls through - which I hope it doesn't - Dr. Beavis next proposed a
clinical trial at Hopkins (not yet tested on humans...!); she'll have the research team
reach out to discuss the trial with me. The third option, per Dr. Beavis, would be another
line of chemo, retaining Avastin and adding a drug other than Taxol. That 'back pocket'
containing the remaining chemo options will soon become tiny, although she and Dr.
Patel are not ready to give those up yet, especially as a few of my lymph nodes
decreased in size from the last scan.
Voilà. The plan sounds reasonable to me and I will pluck up my courage and energy for
the next round, whatever it may be. Schedule, whereabouts, travel etc. all up in the air
right now. If you're a listmaker, an organizer, a detailed planner, a schedule junkie (all of
which I am), you'll watch it all go out the window when you undergo cancer treatment.
Which is not always a bad thing.
My CT scan, for which the Hopkins radiologists produced a much more detailed report
than Geisinger's and which Dr. Beavis herself analyzed closely in comparison with my
earlier scans, shows, per Beavis, a "slight increase" in tumor and lymph node size. I was
relieved to learn that the progression of my disease has not been radical. Further, no
metastases were detected. And, since she didn't mention these, I presume that the
nodes on my liver's exterior are benign. Yes, it could be worse.
Oh, I forgot that she's put in an order for another scan that will detect whether I have a
clot in my lungs (which she considers doubtful) and she'll speak to Dr. Patel about
ordering another type of scan of my heart. This is because she finds my shortness of
breath somewhat surprising, given that in her view my red blood cell count is not all that
low. My breathlessness may simply be attributed to 'deconditioning' - must try to get in
those steps, pushing through the discomfort. I'm glad she's being thorough.
So it seems I have a break from chemo for a while.  In any event, I'll need to have a
'wash' (ie let the current chemo wash out of my system) before starting in on the next
thing. Hopefully I'll feel better as a result. And I plan to have a cocktail!
I was grateful for my convo with Dr. B. yet afterwards (perhaps understandably) felt
adrift, alone, drained and out of sorts. The hotel was in some sort of very spread out
office park cum mall so there was really nowhere to walk. I wound up having my dinner a
while later and then reading in this somewhat sinister looking room. The hotel didn't
carry Netflix so my plan to watch "The Great British Baking Show" was foiled, but I
enjoyed it when I returned home the next day.
Realizing I was in close proximity to several Civil War battlefields, the next day -
                    
September 17th - I decided to learn some American history on the way back to State
College. My mother told me that the 17th was the 160th anniversary *date* of the Battle
of Antietam, the 'bloodiest day in American history' due to its astounding death toll of
23.000 that day -- boys and men from Pennsylvania, Ohio, Vermont, Texas, Louisiana
etc., under the command of Robert E. Lee, Stonewall Jackson, and other generals. The
anniversary apparently drew even larger crowds than usual to the 3.000 acre site in
Sharpsburg, MD, strewn with monuments and markers of all types, and special activities
were taking place (I jumped every time I heard the loud boom from the artillery
demonstrations). I took a self-guided tour in my car that comprised eleven different
points of importance regarding the battle -- the Dunker church where wounded were
taken, the peaceful cornfield that became, on that day, a killing field. I could go on and
on about what I learned and how glad I was to have made the detour. The crowd itself --
Civil War history buffs, scout troops, Confederate nostalgists, reenactors, families, others
-- piqued my curiosity. And ringing the battlefield, modest homes in small-town rural
Maryland, many of them boasting American flags and pro-Trump signs. Hadn't Lincoln,
who three months after Antietam issued the Emancipation Proclamation, quoted from
the Book of Matthew when he was chosen to run for Senate in 1858 as the Republican
candidate, declaring that "a house divided against itself shall not stand?"
History's a palimpsest, isn't it? And just as we need to study the past to learn about the
present, we need to observe the present to learn about the past. This notion struck me
again while watching the first part of Ken Burns' excellent documentary about America
and the Holocaust last night. Antietam certainly took my mind off cancer, and I'd love to
talk more about it with anyone interested.
So looking forward to my girlhood friend (and then college classmate), Kay, arriving
tomorrow for a visit (lots of gabbing in store), followed by my mother's arrival, as each
year at this time and laden down with a round challah, to help celebrate the new year.
My phone is quite full and I need to pare down the amount of stuff on it before I post
more pictures...
Be well, everyone.
label: fear

text:
Health-wise, this has been a deflating week. Yesterday, I found out that, in the end, I'm
ineligible for the clinical trial that I had very much hoped to be part of at Sloan-Kettering.
I had an appointment scheduled for next Thursday, to undergo screening tests, with the
therapy itself slated to begin on October 6th. I was eager to try immunotherapy as an
alternative to chemo, as I have heard promising things and my body has absorbed so
much chemo, which can be debilitating. An ancillary advantage would have been
proximity to my great support system in NY. Dr. Cohen called me yesterday while I was
waiting to have a magnesium infusion here in State College to let me know that, after
having re-reviewed all my materials, he determined that I've had too many lines of
chemo to be eligible for the trial. I'm not sure precisely why that is the case, but I was
feeling too stunned to query him about it. Further, I was mortified to learn that he had
called me about a week earlier to share this news with him, but I only infrequently check
my voicemails (lesson learned...) as I'm much more accustomed to receiving written
communications from my physicians through online portals, which I check every day. Dr.
Cohen acknowledged that the news was "extremely disappointing" and said that he'd
definitely let me know if he becomes aware of any other trials for which I'd be eligible.
So yesterday was a deflating day -- I went practically straight from the infusion room to
Gray's Woods for a scan of my lungs, to assess whether a blood clot might be the cause
of my shortness of breath (it's not - yay). Then I simply let myself relax for the rest of the
day; I thought about taking a drive in the beautiful early fall weather, but felt too tired so
headed home to enjoy the prettiness out my sunroom window while relaxing wrapped up
in a pashmina shawl on my cozy couch.
I will need to regroup and, with Dr. Beavis' help, figure out the best plan B. I've written
her already with the disappointing news from MSK. As I wrote in my previous post, I
believe, with her usual foresight she had already laid out options B (clinical trial at
Hopkins, about which I know nothing at this point) and C (another line of chemo, which I
discussed with Dr. Patel this past week, but in which neither of us places enormous hope
for marked success, ie stabilizing or reducing the size of my tumors/cancer burden). 
I will also look into, more seriously than I had when I thought MSK was a go, potential
options further afield geographically, especially at M.D. Anderson in Houston and at
UCLA, where I have contacts and where I have already initiated inquiries. Whether I'd
even fly to one of these places to meet with a gyn-onc will depend, of course, on whether
they are running trials for which I might be considered (not a given, by any means). And I
don't do well emotionally and mentally without a strong support system accessible,
especially when taking into account a presumably limited lifespan.
So these will be the next steps. But first the holiday -- my mother arrives shortly, as
every year in recent memory, to observe and enjoy the new year with me (and, at
                    
services, my congregation).
Fortunately, the week, which ended with a thud, began with an uplift! My girlhood friend
Kay came to visit for three days, after having kindly proposed the visit (she lives in SoCal
but happened to be spending some time on the east coast). We met when we were
twelve, in Amherst, MA (where my father was teaching summer school) in a local
production of a musical version of _Tom Sawyer._ Our friendship continued on and,
coincidentally, we both wound up at Harvard, even living in the same dorm our freshman
year.  We've maintained our friendship, but it had become slightly perfunctory, with
heartfelt phone calls, then emails, but only once or twice a year. Thankfully, we had the
chance this time to renew our friendship and 'dig deep' through hours of talking,
reminiscing, and setting off on fun outings in search of vintage jewelry and the perfect
cocktail. I'm just sorry that this reconnection didn't happen sooner, but better late than
never. We have so much in common! After college, we both eventually obtained our
doctorates and pursued careers in academia (Kay in English at UC Santa Barbara); we've
both recently retired. We're both daughters of academics, too, with one son each (mine's
27, Kay's is 28), both of whom are data scientists after obtaining their M.S.s in that field.
We're both Jewish. And our temperaments mesh well. Kay is *in part* ever the creative,
imaginative, witty, ironic, literate, smart lover of performativity -- and, accordingly,
brought with her 'costumes' for the two of us to wear for our day out and about in Happy
Valley. Dressed in matching Harvard t-shirts and baseball caps -- ironically, on the eve of
the Nittany Lions' big home game against Central Michigan -- we garnered the strangest
looks and comments (which of course was the point). Thank you, dear Kay, for your visit.
Running out of time here. Wishing everyone (should you happen to observe, especially) a
blessed, sweet, healthy, happy and successful new year 5783, as full in its cyclicity as
the round challah we eat at this time and as bounteous as the seeds in the
pomegranate. L'shanah tovah!
Food pics to follow. Somehow, somehow I've managed to cook all the holiday dishes for
our meal tomorrow evening - chicken soup with matzah balls, tzimmes, lokshen kugel,
honey cake, with brisket to be cooked tonight/tomorrow.
"...and dying can become a process of crescendo through to the end." B.J. Miller
Photos
label: surprise

text:
Medical update: Up-and-down may work better than the roller coaster metaphor as a
roller coaster ride holds the promise of being thrilling. Recent developments have not
been thrilling. At all. [btw, for the discussion of 'up-and-down' v. 'roller coaster' I credit
Amy Bloom, whose memoir, _In Love,_ I am currently reading. Bloom helped her
husband, Brian, take his life in Zurich under the auspices of Dignitas when Brian was
diagnosed at 65 with Alzheimer's].
As I shared, Plan A, participation in a clinical trial at Sloan-Kettering, fell through at the
last minute when Dr. Cohen concluded that I had had too many lines of chemo to make
me eligible for the trial. Just today, after I had let the trial nurse know that I wanted to go
ahead with a trial Dr. Beavis identified for me at Hopkins (Plan B), I found out the last slot
in the trial had just been claimed. The nurse will let me know if the last participant is
deemed ineligible or if new slots open up, but when will that be? Ben convinced me to
stop kicking myself for the delay caused by my taking a bit of time (a few days? I don't
remember. The holiday, which I observe, also intervened) to find out about trial options
at M.D. Anderson and UCLA, where personal contacts had directed me. M.D. Anderson,
which I first contacted in July and where a physician named Dr. Milojevic had been quite
helpful, sent me descriptions of three trials for which I might be eligible, which I've now
forwarded to Dr. Beavis. At UCLA, the nurse for Dr. Beth Karlan, a prominent gyn-onc
specializing in ovarian cancer, was extremely helpful in a long phone convo yesterday,
explaining much about trials and drug therapies that had remained murky for me. She
dissuaded me from pursuing a trial at UCLA, mainly because of the distance, expense,
significant time away from my support system etc. -- and the lack at this time of a really
suitable trial for me. Moreover, I've been feeling caught between two camps of
friends/family: the ones who urge me to 'leave no stone unturned' against this insidious
disease and the ones who understand that far from my support system I don't fare well,
especially knowing that time may be limited. Hopkins, as my brother reminded me, is
always a safe bet as it's been my 'home away from home' since 2019 and I never falter
in my esteem for this medical center and its world-class staff. It's never been a question
of my trying to 'sneak behind Dr. Beavis' back,' either, but simply of looking into what's
out there. She knows that I've been exploring what other major cancer centers might
have to offer me, and approves my efforts. It's simply unfortunate that my investigation
*may* have cost me a spot in Hopkins' clinical trial (but again: no guarantee the trial
would have worked for me, no guarantee I would have been eligible in the end, no
guarantee that the last trial spot was claimed precisely when I decided to move forward
with Hopkins and not earlier, etc. etc. etc. etc. etc.).
I await word from Dr. Beavis, but it seems we may be on to Plan C, another line of
chemo. The hope was to give me a break from chemo, as I've had so much of it, and to
try an 'investigational' option at this time. If in a few months this line of chemo only
shows limited success, as all the previous ones have, perhaps there will be an
                    
appropriate clinical trial available to me at that time.
There's still room for this revised plan to change, however. Of course I was feeling
disappointed today and got into bed crying after returning from lunch and learning that
Plan B was a no-go (also forgot to take my Lexapro, which keeps me even keel). Such a
fucking insidious disease. I'm hoping that by early next week the latest plan will be in
place.
Although I haven't had any treatment (except magnesium infusions) the past several
weeks of 'wash out,' I'm not feeling too badly. Abdominal discomfort, fatigue etc. not
markedly worse than several weeks ago. Still getting out and about, although of course
on a somewhat more modified scale than during my pre-cancer days.
Following our tradition of the past ten years or so, my mother came to State College for
the holiday. Somehow I managed to pull off a Rosh Hashanah feast. I began cooking
about two weeks before the holiday and relied on days when I was feeling more
energetic than others to cook or bake. On Sunday, I spent the entire day cooking,
straightening, and creating an eye-catching décor for the meal - with my mother's help
of course. I made: chicken soup with matzah balls, lokshen kugel (w/an artery-clogging
combo of farmers' cheese, cottage cheese and sour cream), tzimmes (prunes, carrots,
and sweet potato slices slow cooked for hours until they become caramelized; I added
ginger, grated orange peel, orange juice and liberal dollops of schmaltz), sautéed
zucchini, sweet and sour brisket with cranberries (tangy!) and for dessert, honey cake for
a sweet new year, blueberries, raspberries, and lemon sorbet. A bold Cab to drink.
Apples and four kinds of local honey. Appetizers: pickles, cheeses. The end product was
wonderful, but I must admit it was tiring. I had to lay down every two hours or so for a
rest. We were delighted that my friend Lisa and her daughter could enjoy the meal with
us, abbreviated as it was, unfortunately, as my mother and I needed to leave for
services. 
Services resonated differently for me this year, likely for good reason. I do enjoy the
prospect of a new year, regeneration and renewal, the pretty fall colors. But I simply
can't get behind the idea of God's infinite lovingkindness and protectiveness. A question
as old as  Job, but yes: if God is these things, why would he blight me with this horrible
disease and all the pain and anxiety I've experienced the past few years (which is not to
say that the wonderful times have not outweighed the bad and that my spirit remains
strong and determined)? [and, incidentally, why would s/he allow - sanction? - mass
killings of civilisans in Ukraine?] I of course know that there are 'explanations' -- or
rationales-- for suffering in our theology, but I just don't buy them (and I truly apologize if
I'm offending anyone's beliefs here, but I need to be candid about my own). A spiritual
wake-up call? An opportunity for others to appreciate their blessings in contrast to my
suffering? A chance to elevate my soul? An example of "God working in mysterious
ways?" A call to examine my own sinfulness and lack of repentance? I can't possibly
                    
have been *that sinful* this past year as to merit some of the physical agony I've been
through (I in fact breathed a sigh of relief during tashlich, realizing that the number of
sins I needed to cast off into the creek in the form of bits of challah was fairly minimal
this year!). And I can't accept that any amount of prayer, Torah reading or tzedakah (I
always make donations at the new year, and this year gave to the central PA food bank)
can "alleviate the harshness of God's decree." Sure, bits of the service, ideas, verses,
stuck with me as always. But I don't believe in the 'God' presented to us during services,
at least not in the conventional form...
So what do I believe in? I believe in the goodness in you. Call that godliness if you will.
Every caring email, text, phone call, card, visit, kind word, gift manifests blessing. 
Shabbat Shuvah shalom! Wishes for peace and peacefulness on this special shabbat
between Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur.
Photos
label: neutral

text:
I hope I didn't come across as overly bitter in my post yesterday -- an image that's
distasteful to me -- nor worthy of pity - ditto. My rapidly cycling emotions in reaction to
                    
often quickly changing circumstances are simply part of the up-and-down.
I did want to leave a written trace of my lovely few days in NY in mid-September, a
family-focused visit.  I tried not to 'overbook' myself but rather to focus on one outing a
day, so as not to become overtired -- not my usual NY pace, but so it goes. Ben was kind
enough to indulge one of my bucket list wishes (although I'm not big on the whole
bucket list idea) - a ride on the South Brooklyn ferry, the regular one that transports
Brooklynites to and from, not any of the ferries geared towards tourists.  After a false
start during which we were thwarted from boarding the ferry at Corlears Hook (an
unknown to me NY locale!) b/c of construction, we regrouped -- soggy, cranky and a bit
tuckered out though we were after having trouble finding one another -- then Ubured to
Wall St., and boarded our ferry there, where the largest crowds were taking another ferry
to Ikea in Red Hook. How refreshing to leave the densely-packed island for the wide,
calm, quiet expanses of New York harbor and the Brooklyn shore line, ending up in Bay
Ridge. As it was raining lightly (and a Sunday), we were actually the only passengers on
the upper level of the ferry! It was also September 11, and such a peaceful trip in the
harbor felt appropriate; the one firehouse we passed, close to Ground Zero,  was busied
with a commemorative luncheon and bedecked with memorial wreaths. Such a slow-
paced, still place, the ferry, an offshore oasis. As I was afraid my wig would blow off into
the harbor, I shoved it in my purse and let the wind massage my bald head!
I had reread Whitman's "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry" (1856) because I love Whitman
(describing a ferry ride from Manhattan to Brooklyn along the trajectory that was to
become the Brooklyn Bridge) and knew his poem would resonate with (and aggrandize!)
our modest outing:
"Others will enter the gates of the ferry and cross from shore to shore,
Others will watch the run of the flood-tide,
Others will see the shipping of Manhattan north and west, and the heights of Brooklyn to
the south and east,
Others will see the islands large and small;
Fifty years hence, others will see them as they cross, the sun half an hour high,
A hundred years hence, or ever so many hundred years hence, others will see them,
                    
Will enjoy the sunset, the pouring-in of the flood-tide, the falling-back to the sea of the
ebb-tide."
 
After our return to terra firma, Ben and I Ubured to Veneiro's (by now, you may know
that I have a 'thing' for Italian pastries - and pastry shops, and this 1885 shop is one of
the best) for luscious cake (tiramisu cake for me) and cappuccino.
 
Another treat was to have my brother meet me at Sloan-Kettering, where I was dropping
off discs in anticipation of moving forward with a clinical trial there, and join me for
lunch. We headed to Rosa Mexicano, relaxed, and had a good chat. I think we may have
misordered as I usually enjoy whatever I get there, but it wasn't a big deal. Ethan's
Bloody Mary with Mezcal was yummy, and I had some sort of tasty mocktail. After lunch I
headed to Kalustyan, NY's legendary global foods store, and bought some rose harissa
(I'm not sure why, I think it's a required ingredient in some Ottolenghi recipe I'm
interested in), candied citron for my Rosh Hashanah honey cake, their delicious house-
made labneh with a bit of apricot jam, and a tiny piece of halvah - because it's so good.
 
I indulged in a manicure -- teal nails for Ovarian Cancer Awareness month.
 
The next night we enjoyed a celebratory dinner organized and offered by my mother--
one of the raisons d'être for my visit -- for her partner, Arnold. 97 years old! A World War
II veteran who saw combat in France and Germany (all praise and honor to him for that),
Arnold is also a volunteer tour guide with the Big Apple Greeters in New York. The food
was excellent and we were delighted to be together. When I asked Arnold what life
lessons he could share with us, he said: "Be tolerant." Excellent advice for the
generations to come.
                    
Photos

text:
Chugging along here, determinedly. Medical update: The plan is still for me to start
receiving a new line of chemo this Friday unless by some miracle a slot opens up in the
Phase I trial at Hopkins that Dr. Beavis had designated as Plan B. She also encouraged
me to schedule a consult at M.D. Anderson, a premiere cancer center in Houston, to see
if they might have something to offer me. Of a list of three trials at M.D. Anderson that
had been identified to me in July by Dr. Ljiljana Milojevic, the very helpful coordinator of
clinical research programs in gyn-onc there, at least one looked of interest to Dr. Beavis
when I shared the descriptions with her. But M.D. Anderson is running lots of trials, all
the time, so it is possible/probably that others will be potentially available to me once I
finish the next line of chemo (I'm not sure when that will be; I'll need to be treated for a
few cycles at least, and then scanned).
Right now I'm particularly interested in trials involving immunotherapy, which would rely
on my immune system to fight my cancer, although other newish treatments may well
be available to me too. Dr. Beavis seems indisposed to my receiving immunotherapy
outside a clinical trial, due, I believe, to the prohibitive cost of the drugs (if taken in the
course of a trial, though, they are free); however, I'm pushing her a bit on this, as she
told me that occasionally she's been able to obtain the meds for a reasonable cost
outside of a trial. Further, as she told me, immunotherapy has not proven as effective as
originally hoped in treating ovarian cancer (unlike the case for blood cancer, lung
                    
cancer); however, she still feels that it's worthwhile for me to pursue this treatment in
the context of a clinical trial. I posed a series of immunotherapy-focused questions to the
members of a chat group I occasionally consult, Sisterhood of Ovarian Cancer Survivors.
Some corroborated what Dr. Beavis told me, others contradicted it. I also read conflicting
categorizations of Avastin, a drug I will continue taking as of this Friday. While some said
it was an immunotherapy drug (and indeed, I've seen it described this way online),
others rather vehemently denied this (Steve, care to weigh in?). So consulting this
'sisterhood' only turned out to be moderately helpful, in the end, but I gleaned a few
useful pieces of information.
In any event, my appointment at M.D. Anderson is on W Oct. 26th with Dr. Shannon
Westin, whom I've heard good reports about. I *might* change the appointment to a
slightly later date, as a 10/26 meeting leaves me scant time to make plans, figure out
logistics etc. Having the wherewithal and stamina to navigate large airports and a
sprawling, unfamiliar medical center given my current health challenges makes me
somewhat anxious but if need be I'm sure I could do it, perhaps w/a bit of help in the
airports. Road (i.e. air) trip to Houston, anyone?
I have a bit more 'homework' to do looking into what other cancer and/or medical
centers (Dana-Farber, NYU Langone, Penn, Mayo) might have to offer.
In one tiny piece of good news for this week, because my magnesium level crept back
into normal range per my labwork, my two-hour infusion on Monday was cancelled! This
means that, after brunch with a friend, I'll have the rest of the afternoon to spend with
Ben, who's coming for a week-long visit this afternoon and who has off for Columbus
Day! It's the little things...
I also had to have an echocardiogram this week, ordered by Dr. Beavis, who seemed
concerned by my occasional shortness of breath (from the results I received for this
sonogram of my heart, it appears that everything's normal, but I'll wait to hear it from
Dr. B. next week). Because no appointments were available in State College, I was
booked at a Geisinger clinic in Philippsburg, half an hour northwest of State College. The
fall foliage and bursts of sunshine on a largely cloudy day were dazzling as I drove to my
destination. Less dazzling were the many, many signs in rural Warren county (waaay
deep into Maga-country) instructing to 'drain the swamp' and to vote for Mastriano (who
threatens to charge women who have abortions with murder) as governor and Oz as
senator.
The Geisinger facility was pretty run-down, but convenient enough for a non-invasive
procedure. As the technician rolled a wand over, poked and prodded the left side of my
chest, I semi-snoozed, only to awake with a start when I heard her say to me: "You have
a little, tiny breast" (!!). When I looked at her with some alarm and shock, she repeated
what she had actually said the first time: "Let's have a little, tiny breath." I told her what
                    
I thought she had said and we both had a hearty belly-laugh.
Since I have not had chemo in over a month (Sept. 2 was my last infusion, I believe), I
am actually feeling pretty well w/the drugs out of my system (I felt strong enough to fast
on Yom Kippur). Four weeks is usually the length of the 'wash' between treatments, so
I'm a bit past that. I'm eager to restart treatment, but certainly wish my body could have
taken a longer break from chemo, as I've had so much of it. Dr. Beavis indicated that my
neuropathy is likely to get worse and there is a litany of scary potential side effects with
Avastin. I do hope a clinical trial will be a next step.
Looking at my date book, I see lots of medical appointments this past week, but I did
manage to get out for a long drive (I'm determined to spend as much time outdoors as
possible in October, just as I had a similar goal in May/June - some of these days, colors,
smells, tastes are too beautiful to miss out on!). I enjoyed a fun outing last night with my
friends Mar and Maria to a newish brewery/restaurant, Titan Hollow. The place is
enormous, large enough to accommodate the dinner-theatre production in which Mar's
wife Jessi had a large part. The play was a 'whodunnit' murder mystery with many
interactive twists, and great fun. The locally brewed hard cider was also delish!
Photos

text:
Just a short post to share that I tested positive for Covid yesterday morning. A friend had
contacted me Saturday, I believe, to let me know that she had tested positive after our
break fast at the synagogue last Wednesday. To the best of my knowledge, at least five
people came out of Yom Kippur services with Covid. I had tested myself Friday and
Sunday and was negative, went out both days and felt ok (except for a very slight dry
cough), then Sunday night started to decline. Felt horrendous this morning -- splitting
headache, cough, fatigue (have been resting all day), some chills, nausea. This evening I
feel no worse, the chills seem to have dissipated, the headache is now low-grade, and I
was even able to eat a bit of dinner, thanks to Michael and Sue's generosity in grilling a
ribeye. I'm hoping that my compromised immune system can rally and fight this thing
off. I think we were all a bit traumatized by the horror stories from the early days of
Covid. Unfortunately, I've not had my third booster yet, as it's scheduled for about a
week from now.
Ben, here for a week I had hoped would be full of fun activities (foliage drives, movies
etc.) is an incredibly caring, competent, calm soul. I am terribly disappointed that he
once again needs to help me out (and of course am concerned about him getting Covid
too), but we're still looking forward to watching the Yankees in the playoffs tomorrow
night (though probably in different rooms!).
My doctor did not yet phone in a prescription for me for Paxlovid today, despite my
multiple calls and portal messages to his office, including at least one that was 'fast
tracked' to him. Grrr... Frustrating and stressful. Will resume my efforts tomorrow, not
easy in my current state.
I am so touched by recent calls, texts and emails from friends. I'm unable to write now
(I'm even amazed I could write this short blog post!) but I will, as soon as I feel better. I
haven't forgotten, on the contrary.
label: fear

text:
....or, "what a shitty week!," as one of my friends aptly put it. Like clockwork, poor Ben
came down with Covid Thursday night, exhibiting the same symptoms I experienced:
chills, cough, congestion, fatigue + fever. Since he's not taking an antiviral med as I am,
                    
his symptoms might actually be worse than mine. He's definitely not feeling well, but as
he's young and strong and heathy, he's pushing through, taking regular walks around
the neighborhood and helping me out immensely around the house. We're drinking tea
(and water and apple cider), sucking on cough drops, ingesting Ibuprofen, cooling down
with popsicles, rooting on the Yankees (yesterday's game a disappointment...) and trying
to get through this. Despite the general yuckiness of the past seven days, when we lit
Shabbat candles and talked about what we were grateful for this week, we agreed that
being together and bringing comfort (and gallows humor) to one another had been a
boon, and that we certainly could have had it worse. 
I tested positive again this morning, no surprise. I'm improving, but quite incrementally
at this point. I'm still congested and fatigued, and need energy to deal with my cancer.
Covid has downstream effects on my cancer treatment. My chemo has to be put off for
two weeks on top of the many weeks I've already gone without any treatment as we
weighed the various next best options (clinical trials, chemo etc.). My consult at M.D.
Anderson, in turn, has also been moved to a later date. Oh well. Must bend with the
bamboo. I'm actually pleasantly surprised that my immune system has been so
successful so far in fighting Covid.
Michael and Sue generously provided us with two delicious dinners this week, as I don't
have much 'oomph' for cooking (although I'll try to make some red lentil soup with lemon
later). Thanks to local friends who have been checking in and also offering help (you
know who you are!) -- I am *very grateful* for your help and kindness!
It's a gorgeous day and I'm going to try to take a drive (or perhaps two drives, one with
Ben after the big PSU-Michigan game) today. Must let the fall foliage bedazzle me!
label: sadness

text:
Health update: "A Series of Unfortunate Events," as never encountered by the Baudelaire
children...
Thankfully, both Ben and I are over Covid. Well, that was one heck of an unpleasant two-
week detour. Geez, Louise... I finally tested negative yesterday, after the virus had
progressed from something flu-like (cough, congestion, aches and pains, chills, fatigue)
through a bad head cold to the lingering slight congestion I'm experiencing now. Ben's
trajectory was a bit different, and thankfully shorter: flu-like symptoms with persistent
sore throat and loss of taste and smell, which have not yet returned. I was overjoyed to
see the spring in his step once again (he managed to power through full work days,
except for one or two afternoons he took off so he could rest), and he's now back in New
York. Sharing Covid purgatory was actually a blessing and new variant of 'mother-son
bonding' (I guess...); Ben and I both tend to be fairly 'up' people by nature so we kept
                    
one another afloat, peppering our conversations with plenty of gallows humor... We
cooked healthy meals and watched the Yankees-Guardians series (yay!) and then the
Yankees-Astros series (ugh, but fourth-generation Yankees fan Ben, whose grandfather
climbed onto the roof of Joe DiMaggio's car back in the day to snap his picture in the
driver's seat, was invited to Game 4 tonight!). It was unfortunate that Ben couldn't spend
more time with his dad, but we didn't want to risk Michael and Sue being exposed.
Michael was in touch with Ben several times daily and was also checking up on me. I
should mention, too, that throughout my two or so years of dodging Covid and being
shielded from it in the hospital when I had surgeries in 2020 and 2022, I always imagined
that, should I contract the virus, it would be difficult (and potentially dangerous) to shake
b/c of my fragile immune system. So the fact that, in the end, Covid did not appear to hit
me harder than it did others I know who have had it, reassured me.
Yet Covid is tricky for cancer patients. My treatment has been delayed by two weeks to
allow for full recovery. I'm slated to start a new line of chemo on Tuesday (blood work
tomorrow). Before that, though, I had a four-week 'washout' period between lines of
chemo. And I'm certain that there were at least two other weeks in there when I was
exploring different options, acting like I had all the time in the world to forestall
treatment! I don't even want to look at my calendar to see when I had my last treatment
but I think early September.  I never imagined I'd be hit with Covid at this critical
juncture... In the past few days I think I've begun to feel a bit 'symptomatic' - but maybe
that's a result of my anxiety? Discomfort under my right rib cage and in my upper-
abdominal area, where an enlarged lymph node sits. Is this what it feels like to stop
treatment? Has my cancer progressed significantly while I've awaited chemo?
And the treatment I'm about to receive (Avastin + Doxil) constitutes the *least* desirable
of the three options Dr. Beavis had laid out for me.  The result with each line of chemo I
have received has been a net progression of the disease, but perhaps this new combo
will help a bit. I'm not optimistic, though. Only about two days ago, I received definitive
word from Hopkins that no slot would be available for me at this time in the Phase I
clinical trial Dr. Beavis had signaled to me. Phase I trials are the riskiest (v. Phase II and
III) as their goal is primarily to establish correct dosage levels of certain medications or
medication combos, relying on volunteers such as myself. However, the interesting thing
about this trial for me is that one of the drugs used targets a specific mutation my tumor
exhibits.  Apparently, the trial sponsor (ie pharma company) has been jerking Hopkins
around, telling Hopkins both that they want more slots opened for the trial *and* that
they need more time to evaluate [something?]). So now I am mad at a nameless,
faceless Big Pharma company too, for delaying my access to potentially life-prolonging
treatment. I'll be on the waiting list for access to the trial; perhaps after completing my
next line of chemo, followed by a scan and washout period, I'll be eligible, *if* the timing
works out (and that's a big 'if').
I do plan to travel to Houston in mid-November for an appointment with Dr. Shannon
                    
Westin, a gyn-onc with an excellent reputation. MDA is running clinical trials that Dr.
Beavis concurs look interesting for me, several involving immunotherapy. Yes, Houston is
far, but I need to find out for myself what would be involved should I have the
opportunity of gaining access to a trial there.  People travel there from all over the world,
as they do to all major medical centers. And my college friend/guardian angel Steve
Sherman is an oncologist at MDA, has offered to help me out if needed, and knows Dr.
Westin!
I went to look at plots at Centre County Memorial Park a few days ago. Dying is
expensive! Yeesh...  Cemeteries/funeral homes really nail you, but I guess they figure
they have a 'captive audience...' I simply wanted to take care of this so my family will
have less to figure out - whenever the time comes.  My acute natural curiosity leads me
to be quite fascinated by rituals surrounding death, burial etc., so the cemetery visit was
simply 'interesting' (certainly not scary or traumatizing) and the site serene and beautiful
on a sunny autumn day. What I've decided so far is that I'd like to be buried in the
'liberal' quadrant of the Jewish section (where interfaith couples can be buried, where
cremated remains can be buried etc.). It was poignant and comforting to find 'friends'
there -- a couple that joined a PSU alumni tour to France that I led shortly after arriving
at Penn State; the son of lovely friends in my congregation, who died in his early forties
from cancer... I had been leaning towards cremation, but now I'm contemplating the
more traditional Jewish burial in a plain pine box. Holes are drilled into the concrete vault
in which the casket is placed, essentially letting the casket and human remains
biodegrade and return to the earth. I have explored a bit what a 'green burial' entails as
that would be my preference, but the practice is still not widespread and the resources
seemingly unavailable in central PA. 
Yesterday my friend Bénédicte called me soon after I rolled out of bed and suggested we
might hit an auction in Centre Hall; we had talked about our love of auctions and
antiquing and she had introduced me to the site auctionzip.com, which contains listings
of auctions by zip code. A gorgeous fall day; a farm on a central PA backroad; a crowd of
dealers, curiosity seekers, Amish families, locals; a talented auctioneer with a
mesmerizing patter; assorted tools, vintage toys, stoneware crocks, furniture, even the
farm itself + its 33 acres -- all made for a delightful post-Covid outing!
 
 
 
 
Photos

text:
Hardly à propos of my health status (but a good distraction from it): Joe DiM oblivious to
the fact that my father had climbed onto the hood of his car (see hand!), while he calmly
smokes a cigarette in the back seat after a game (1940s?). Found in my father's
bedroom in my grandmother's townhouse in NY. Photo courtesy of Ethan L. Silverman.
"Joltin' Joe has left and gone away," and the Yankees leave us for the off-season, surely
to regroup and rebuild (?). Ben was in the front row of the stadium last night, right
behind the Yankees dugout and in front of Ted Cruz (!).
Starting a new line of chemo tomorrow after a long hiatus. Please send healing thoughts
and energy.
Grateful for the wonderful phone/zoom convos yesterday with two of my faves: my
cousin/'sister from another mother' Julie and my dear friend from middle and high school,
Eva!
