text:
I meant to include two items in my last post: 1)I recently watched (sitting about 6 inches
from the t.v. screen) Michael J. Fox's new documentary about his life and career, "Still"
(on Apple TV+). Well-made, moving and 'relatable' (a word I dislike, but whatever)
regarding drastically reduced horizons, living long-term with incurable illness, "radical
acceptance," etc.; 2)At the nadir of my vision issues, about a week or so ago, I decided
to listen to audiobooks and podcasts to pass the time. Something of a failed experiment
on two counts as a)the soothing voice of the reader of Michael Chabon's _The Amazing
Adventures..._ put me to sleep (!) and b)I had a very marked PTSD-type reaction to the
intro to/techno-ish music accompanying the _NYTimes_ podcast, "The Daily," which I
used to listen to for hours on end about four years ago, immobilized on my chaise and in
pain after my big debulking surgery in 2019. I had no idea these few seconds would be
such a trigger...
*********
Back from Hopkins on Tuesday, back from an appointment yesterday with Dr.
Marcovitch. I was thanking some higher power this morning for the fact that two days
ago -- for the first time in about a month -- I could sense my sight improving. On the
drive down to Baltimore, the passing landscape appeared in much more vivid relief than
before; the past two days my vision has been less blurred although by no means perfect.
It's still hard to make out fine detail. But I no longer feel the need to feel the space in
front of me to assess the safety of walking. And yesterday Dr. Marcovitch cleared me for
driving during the day! I drove about two miles to my dermatologist's office this morning
and I felt confident doing so. However, I'm still accepting rides for longer drives and until
I've made a fuller return to clear-sightedness.
The reason I can see better (but this seems actually part of a more complicated
interaction among corneas, cataracts, and compromised vision) is that, per Dr.
Marcovitch, my left cornea is almost completely healed and my right one looks dry but is
coming along (>continue with artificial tears every few hours). Why my corneas have
improved while my vision appears radically worse is, again, complicated. It may be that
the irregularities on my corneas (assessed by a special machine at Hopkins that
produced a kind of topographical map of my corneas), while less notable than before,
are positioned right at the center of the surface (ie the epithelium) of the cornea, where
they impact vision most dramatically.
Indeed, my vision has become significantly worse as a result of this episode. *This* fact
is not likely to change much. Obviously, this is a disappointment. I have a prescription for
new lenses but may only wind up with a left lens, as the decline is most dramatic in my
left eye (my right eye, in fact, has not changed that much). Because my vision is sort of
in flux, it's possible I may need a new prescription before long.
As mentioned, what has improved are my corneas. The damage to this transparent layer,
                    
again, is most apparent on their surface; the rest of the layer is intact. Both doctors
concur that my corneas should return to normal soon. 
Hope that I'm not 'speaking out of school' here. Am trying to provide as clear yet
accurate an explanation as I'm able of ocular issues whose vocabulary is foreign to me!
The trip to Hopkins and back, twelve hours in toto, was pretty exhausting for me, yet
quite useful. Michael and Sue had connected me with an excellent driver based nearby
who also drives a Fullington bus. We took my car and reached Baltimore in about three
hours, with about 45 mn to spare before my appointment. I found the Wilmer Eye
Institute, which I had passed many times during my previous trips to Hopkins. When I
checked in, the clerk assisting me stood up, walked over to a side desk and handed me a
large, rectangular, flat white box. "Oh great," I thought, "some big pharma company is
foisting samples and pamphlets onto the Hopkins people, which they in turn are dumping
on us!" Only on closer look, and to my absolute surprise, did I see a note in French
affixed to the box, addressed to "notre chère cousine," wishing me well with my
appointment and hinting at some delicious treats inside to enjoy on the ride home (I
hadn't eaten lunch and was famished). Indeed, nestled inside the box were an
assortment of yummies that looked like they came straight from a French pâtisserie:
lemon tart, macarons, croissant. My darling Baltimore cousins  -- "les Aigles" (the Eagle
family) had gotten wind of my appointment (likely from this blog?), know all about my
Francophilia of course, and had shopped for me at a kosher boulangerie. This remarkably
thoughtful gesture in the midst of a stressful day lifted me up and reminded me of the
miraculous moments of human connection that can make a twelve-hour schlep to
Baltimore and back worthwhile! Truly the highlight of my day. [In my previous post, I
wrote about how Ben and Sammi recently experienced more 'cousin love' in Brooklyn
with two of these Baltimore-born sons of my cousins David and Yehudis, Zev and Yosef].
I spent about 1.5 hours being examined by Dr. Oliver Schein, his fellow (Dr. Adam
something), and their assistant, who performed a battery of preliminary tests on me. The
team was very thorough, testing my eyes in various ways with seemingly more up to
date equipment than at Dr. Marcovitch's office and, as mentioned, photographing my
corneas.
Dr. Schein seemed personable and kind (his fellow actually spent longer with me than he
did). Based on his experience of observing how other chemo drugs (but not Elahere...)
can affect vision, he reiterated to me that the intense blurriness I was experiencing
would dissipate and my corneas would heal, but that this could take one-two months
total (I had been seduced into anticipating a much shorter timeline based on accounts by
a few women in my Elahere chat room -- a small sample, to be sure). He provided me
with a new prescription. He asked to see notes from my baseline eye exam on Jan. 4 with
Dr. Nelson in State College, from just before I was to start receiving treatment with
Elahere. And he asked his fellow to proceed with a basic measure that Dr. Marcovitch
                    
had seemed resistant to using: inserting eye plugs. Small silicone plugs are placed in the
top and bottom tear ducts; consequently, one's tears do not drain but instead remain on
the surface of the eye, 'irrigating' it with natural tears and providing continuous
hydration that can benefit the eye. Dr. Adam X inserted these plugs for me (I hardly feel
them as they're tiny). I don't remember what else we discussed but Dr. Schein genuinely
seemed kind and strongly disposed to help me. We didn't discuss a return visit but I'd
like to think that I could avail myself once again of the excellent care at Hopkins if/when
needed.
The last month's been a misery. Try to imagine, in as much detail as possible, what it
would mean for you to have your sight radically compromised. I know that people adjust
('radical acceptance?'), yet I still feel much compassion for the legally blind living in a
'sighted' world (I myself had passed into this realm about a week ago).
As for the million dollar question - will this cycle repeat after subsequent Elahere
infusions? - I don't know but somehow I tend to think not. And for another million dollars:
will I even be having another infusion of Elahere? The results of my CT-scan on June 20th
will tell. So now 'all' I have to worry about is the possibility of progression of my disease
despite treatment or discovery of new mets in my brain and/or elsewhere. LOL. I'll stick
with considering the next eleven days a reprieve -- and will bend with the bamboo.
Things have skewed off kilter the past month in terms of any attempts I might make to
formulate summer plans, goals (such as they are), even day to day objectives. I am
toying with the idea of trying to honor the trying emotions of the past month (and four+
years) in a non-judgmental way, which does not mean that I find them 'acceptable' for
myself (or anyone else, for that matter).
So much is out of our control. 
****
On the drive home, I asked Millie to swing by Alvaro's Bakery in Harrisburg, my usual pit
stop between B'more or D.C. and State College, for a few more treats for both of us and
a dinner entrée for me as I was way too exhausted to cook (indeed, I *needed*
someone's Italian-American mama to cook up some lasagna and meatballs for me and
Alvaro's happily obliged).
Looking forward to a little country jaunt to buy flowers, herbs etc. tomorrow with my
friend John. Was at the farm market about a mile from my house this morning. The
strawberries this year are a wonder.
label: neutral

text:
Last weekend was fairly miserable. I don't think I realized how tired I was, mentally and
physically, from the quick round-trip to Hopkins. I still wasn't seeing well. I think I slept
most of the weekend, besides taking a drive on Saturday and attending an event Friday
night (about which more further on). My body was craving sleep (and actually still does,
often). My sides/pleura shading into my back, abdomen, and stomach all ached, as if I
had a band of pain girding the middle section of my body. The pain tired me further.
Oxycodone helped (my palliative care dr. said I could even increase my dose by 50%,
although I'm still trying to not take more than two pills a day). I had to cancel three
social engagements and missed the second annual Pride parade in town, a welcome
addition to State College's 'culture' and vibe, which of course made me sad. Dark
thoughts were getting the better of me. I was convinced the pain was a harbinger of
imminent death. Somehow I managed to not spiral down completely, reminding myself
of the simple fact that, at least for now, there are good and bad days.
This week has been better. I still need a good amount of sleep (but am sleeping
erratically), but my pain has decreased while my energy has increased. And my vision is
improving! This means I can drive, cook, write, watch t.v., read etc. - an enormous step
forward. I tried to get my new prescription for lenses filled today but I botched the
mission (for reasons too complicated and uninteresting to explain) so I will hopefully take
care of that on Monday, the day I also have an eye doctor appointment here. What else?
I had appointments with my therapist and my palliative care doc, both stalwart pillars of
my medical/care team.
Next Tuesday afternoon I'll have a CT-scan to determine whether Elahere is working,
whether my disease has progressed, remained stable, or even regressed. I am trying not
to think about the scan until Monday, not to generate anxiety that may or may not be
warranted. There's no Plan B that I know of; at this point, we're sort of winging it,
relieved that a new drug came along in time for my doctors to add it to the treatment
plan. The thought that I *might* need to stop treatment, if Elahere's not helping, while
still feeling relatively ok overall is certainly sobering.
This week was another one in which I felt rather 'unmoored,' as if the ground was shifting
under my feet. Plans get cancelled. A scan looms. My vision improves but remains iffy.
Fatigue weighs on me sometimes. Friends leave town on vacation, coming and going. I
*did* try to get a grip by arranging a July vacation for myself, Ben and Sammi, in a place
I love. Something to look forward to! I won't say more for now so as not to jinx these
plans. But I hope they'll help me plant my feet on terra firma after several weeks of
feeling adrift.
Last Friday night, despite not feeling 100%, I attended a Pride-themed service at our
synagogue, the first in my memory. My wonderful chemo nurse, Brianne, had expressed
                    
an interest in going (her Lutheran pastor had apparently announced it to his
congregation), along with her wife, Natalie, and charming daughter, Kaylen. The service
featured specially selected, Pride-themed readings. I was gratified for the large turnout
(including many people I didn't know, who also wished to attend such a purposefully
inclusive service). Coincidentally, Brianne and Natalie (and Kaylen) knew a number of
people there from school, work, and other circles. It feels so important to show up for
one another (and not just at events 'designated' for this...). I may try to put this belief
into practice again tomorrow if/when I check out the town's Juneteenth goings-on.
Of course, I'm in farmers market heaven right now. I realize that I much prefer summer
to winter cooking because of the abundant 'farm to table' possibilities. Now that I can
see better, my cooking mojo has returned; this week I made a beet salad with goat
cheese and pecans; warm German potato salad (had a craving, but I think it's too heavy
a dish for me) and garlic scape pesto (packs a garlicy punch - oh my!). I'm also intensely
into iced teas right now and am experimenting with different varieties. Plan to start
cooking for others soon, too. 
A restful sabbath to all. 
Photos
label: sadness

text:
Before I leave for my scan at 2:30, I just wanted to thank everyone who sent me well
wishes via text and email (and telepathy). I wanted to answer every one, but I've not
been feeling well the past while (bad pain in my flank shading into my back, which I'll
have checked for a UTI today; kidney stone? cancer?), and I find I need to get a lot of
rest. My sincere apologies for being incommunicado and THANK YOU again. I'll try to be
in touch when I can. Love, Willa [p.s. Kay, your text made me nearly howl with laughter,
which hurt my side but it was worth it xo]
label: sadness

text:
The radiologists' report on my last scan, which I read Wednesday, reveals a significant
progression of my disease, so much so that Dr. Patel admitted to me when I saw him on
Thursday that he felt apprehensive about speaking with me that day. It turned out I
made his task much easier by being what he termed 'practical' - a word seldom if ever
applied to me! - but by which I think he meant some combination of realistic and
graceful (ie full of grace).
Always hard for me to parse the medical language but Dr. Patel helped: increase in the
size of several lymph nodes, at least one in the thoracic area; increase in size of spots on
liver; increase in size of at least one tumor at base of abdomen. These areas are not
necessary painful for me (although the abdominal tumor causes discomfort); instead, for
some reason, my back and 'flanks' ache *a lot* (a heating pad helps, as does
Oxycodone, which I'm relying on a bit more now). This might simply be from arthritis or
else from cancer in the pleura (membrane lining the thorax and coating the lungs);
                    
cancer is there.
I asked Dr. P. if it is common for cancer to accelerate in this way, as this is certainly the
'worst' scan report I've seen throughout my illness. He (re) explained that after so many
lines of chemo being thrown at them, as had been my case, the cancer cells have
become expert at mutating and otherwise figuring out how to elude the drugs targeting
them. The cancer cells create their own environment within my body, complete with
blood supply and everything else they need to do their deadly deeds. Insidious, indeed.
Or maybe the worst 'tenants' ever, the ones who take over and trash your beautiful
home, causing permanent damage beyond repair.
I am certain that the doctors and other medical personnel reading this are not
necessarily surprised to learn of this progression, nor are a few friends who have lost
partners to cancer. I myself was not surprised, while still retaining a glimmer of hope due
to the promise of a newly-approved drug (I am detecting mixed results among women
currently on Elahere).
The 'good' news (!) in all this is the absence of fluid build-up, for example in my lungs.
Ironically, my magnesium level is back in normal range for the first time in a long while,
which mean no magnesium infusion yesterday. Obviously, we're discontinuing Elahere as
well. Both Dr. Patel and a fellow who was shadowing him on Thursday remarked on how
well I look; my by now legendary (lol) positive attitude tempered with realism impressed
her. It's got to have helped some but sadly is not sufficient to beat back those cancer
cells.
Back on the rollercoaster, part XXX?: Yesterday, Dr. Beavis emailed me to say she had
seen the scans (her own radiologists produced a report on them also), to express regret
at what they show, and to offer to talk about potential next steps (??) and/or possibility
of clinical trials at Hopkins. The challenge here will be logistical; she'll be on vacation July
2-11. We can meet virtually, but I'll need to drive to MD as she can't practice across
state lines. And I'm scheduled to be away July 7-12. I'll wait until Monday to see what she
can offer.
I of course want to hear what she has to say. And in the name of 'due diligence,' I'll likely
call/write MSK and see if they have anything to offer. I may look into alternative
treatments too. But quality of life is my overriding concern; given my relative dearth of
energy these days and the pain I'm currently dealing with, I'm adamant about using my
time/energy for activities and people that/who give me pleasure.
It's a strange time. Lots of emotions. I really don't know what I should be doing, thinking,
feeling. Still trying to throw out as much junk, old papers etc. as possible and get
organized. But it's really been the same old existential question all along, per the title of
the Gauguin painting: "Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?"
                    
Ben will be coming from NY over July 4th weekend. Of course, I can't wait to see him.
Having him here makes me feel so much better. If my health holds (and Dr. Patel felt it
will, as the vacay is coming right up), Ben and I will take off from here by car on July 7th,
staying overnight at a midway point of Fishkill, NY. The next day we'll pick up Sammi at a
train station along our route and head to the magnificent Chatham Bars Hotel on the
Cape for a few days of sun, beach, oysters, lobster rolls (although I don't have much of
an appetite!) and relaxing. I am unsure whether I'll return via NY or if we'll devise
another plan.
Local friends (or even those w/in driving distance!): if you feel inclined to pay me a
shortish visit, I would love that! We can sit in the sun room or outdoors and have some
iced tea, maybe even trade a few memories. No need to feel obligated, though.
Unfortunately, I'm currently not really able to run around as is my preference, but I'm
still likely up for lunch or iced tea out (or a cocktail - why not!), a drive in the country etc.
Enjoyed dinner with my friends John and Kathryn at the Hublersburg Inn a few nights
ago. And having a summery dinner w/friends tonight - very much looking forward.
*I know that for the very great majority of those reading this, it's unnecessary for me to
write this, but please respect my privacy and do not share any of the above info via
other social media.
*Please feel free to DM or text me if the paratextual commentary seems too fraught in
this instance.
label: fear

text:
Here are the latest developments:
After much back and forth that only resolved yesterday, I was able to schedule a video
appointment with Dr. Beavis for tomorrow at 11:00. She's extremely busy as she's
leaving for vacation on the 2nd for ten days and all sorts of 'extras' (surgeries, meetings
etc.) have been crammed into her schedule; I am praying that she won't be 2.5 hours
late for our appointment, as she was last December. As all her appointments are via
video on Fridays, I once again have to *cross state lines into Maryland* to meet virtually
with her, as she can't practice across state lines (this stricture was eased during Covid
but is back in place now). The last time I had to make this scenario work, I drove to a
                    
dinky hotel in Hagerstown and stayed overnight. This time, I've hired a driver -- I've
never met her before but she works with the wonderful Millie, who drove me to the
Wilmer Eye Institute at Hopkins not long ago -- and rented office space in Hagerstown.
Renting co-working/workshare spaces is now a 'thing,' but as I've never availed myself of
such a space it proved a bit complicated. My first reservation was denied: no more place
at the space. With the intervention of a nice guy at central reservations (Salt Lake City,
UT) for the "Davinci Rooms," I was able to reserve an office at another workshare place
in Hagerstown. Obviously this all took more time and energy than I hoped to expend and
I just hope it works out. Holiday traffic? Construction? Bend with the bamboo.
My hunch is that Dr. Beavis will be performing "due diligence" with me (as she should)
tomorrow, rather than producing some sort of trump card or miracle cure. We've agreed
that I'm at a 'critical juncture.' I certainly want to hear what she has to say, and have a
number of questions for her, but I'm keeping my expectations low. This being said, I
usually come away from meetings with her feeling more at peace than usual with my
situation.
I also wrote to Dr. Cohen at Sloan-Kettering, sending him the latest radiologists' report
on my CT-scan and inquiring whether MSK might have something to offer me. His nurse
replied that in order for Dr. Cohen to fully assess the possibilities, I need to send him all
my medical records (oncologist's notes, CT-scans and MRI reports etc.) dating from my
last visit to MSK, sometime last year. Another daunting task for sure, but I imagine I'll
send him the stuff he wants (project for the holiday weekend?). Last year I was ineligible
for any clinical trials at MSK because I had had too many lines of chemo; MSK apparently
has very strict requirements for admission to their clinical trials, so that they can ensure
a very uniform cohort of participants. Perhaps, though, something new has come along
there since last year. Worth a try.
I'm really not sure what else is worth a try at this point.
I wondered out loud to my therapist recently why I wasn't more utterly devastated by
regret and more wracked/wrecked by a sense of grotesque unfairness at this point,
about my career for example: all was on the up and up, with the prospect of another
book, prestigious invited lectures and visiting fellowships in the States and abroad,
interesting collaborations, museum work etc. all on the horizon. Or about the fact that I
may not get back to Paris, where I had a life or sorts (cue Meryl Streep, intoning with
wistful melancholy: "I had a farm in Africa..."). My therapist conjectured that the fact that
I'm 'holding steady' (more or less; I have my moments, believe me) may relate to my
already having done much processing of these misfortunes. I certainly allowed anguish
to course through me (and out of me?) when I retired, so clearly was my work central to
my identity. The work of 'processing' has consumed at least part of every day of the past
four+ years for me. If this is indeed the case, if I've on some level at least 'come to
terms' with my awful situation (which is not to say I accept it, but I understand it to be
                    
the result of a terrible disease), then yay therapy. I'm grateful that the hard work has
been so productive.
Regret regarding *people* is another matter, which perhaps I'll be able to write about at
some point.
No real plans for the holiday weekend; it kind of crept up on me. Ben will be here on
Sunday, and that's of course the biggest treat. Perhaps Michael and Sue will invite me
over for a grilled hot dog (hint?), mouthwatering goodness.
I was so happy that several local friends liked my 'iced tea and chat in the sunroom'
idea. Visits from Kathryn and Maria, and a delivery of delicious chicken soup from
Monique, brought much cheer this week, and I look forward to seeing my friend Helen
later.
Again, apologies for delayed emails and texts. I'm sometimes in a lot of discomfort
(back/sides) and can't do much more than crash on the couch.
label: neutral

text:
Friday I traveled round-trip to Hagerstown, MD, so I could have a video visit with Dr.
Beavis. It's about 2.5 hours each way. My driver, Della, was very competent (former
Fullington bus driver) and got us there and back safely and in good time. I had about 45
mn to get set up in an office at 5, Public Square, where a nice young women named
Caroline was waiting for me (someone really should write a murder mystery transpiring
within a network of these co-working spaces!).
                    
Dr. Beavis was only about 10 mn late logging on. We spent about 35 mn together before
she had to go perform a surgery. She's always quite clear and methodical in her
explanations. She presented what she feels are the three options available to me at this
point, with my cancer so advanced:
a)clinical trials, but only if they seem exceptionally promising. In my experience, I must
add, my brain mets have always been a deal breaker for cancer centers that are set on
comparing 'apples to apples' to achieve optimal results. Brain mets are a potentially
confounding factor. I am hoping to hear from MSK soon (they did contact me about
getting my records) and Dr. B. had not yet reached out to the trials team at Hopkins. The
thought of perhaps regular travel at this point to NYC or Baltimore is really quite
daunting to me. I don't have much stamina. And for the record, being based in my cozy,
peaceful home in SC, surrounded by friends here, with easy access to my medical team,
is really preferable to me as opposed basing myself in NY (where?). Still, I'll find out more
about this option.
b)taking one of two oral chemo meds and seeing if they might work. Success rate (this
would be my seventh line of chemo, with the success rate -- ie stabilizing or reducing of
cancer load -- diminishing with each line): 10-15%
c)Stopping treatment. No more poison in my body. I'd then be able to access home
hospice care, stronger pain meds etc.
I am not sure which option I'll pursue.
I am so tired, mentally and physically.
My entire midsection hurts a lot. As Dr. B. explained, there's a lot going on there:
enlarged lymph nodes near stomach, thorax; liver; pleura; slightly arthritic back; and lots
of sensitive nerve endings. Heating pad helps as does Oxycodone. My sleep doesn't
appear to be disrupted by the pain. I need a lot of rest as my body continues to fight the
cancer inside me.
Dr. B. then went over three likely death scenarios (I had been meaning to ask her about
this). I think I'll skip the details, none of which are pleasant, and write simply that in each
scenario a different organ would be the culprit: a)bowels/intestines; b)liver; c)brain. 
Death will be gradual, accompanied by increased fatigue, general 'slowing down,'
lessening of appetite etc.
Dr. B. said my disease has followed the course that she had anticipated from the
beginning.
                    
Looking at about six months.
Dr. Beavis and I agreed that this is all a terrible shame.
If I were you, I probably wouldn't know what to say, but you've proven me wrong before.
Feel free to DM or text me if you wish. There is something that you can do that would
make me happy, but no obligation! Please share a specific memory of me from our
relationship with one another. It can be anything at all, just something that sticks out in
your mind. It would give me pleasure to read these. Again, you can DM, email or text me.
And again, no obligation!
Ben is due to arrive very soon and I can't wait to see him. Michael is picking him up from
the train station in Lewistown. Somehow, I don't know how, I managed to do some
cooking: a delicious Spanish tomato soup I first sampled at my friend John Ochoa's
house; an apricot cobbler; beet salad. It's hard for me to cook these days. I lack energy
big time.
We'll be heading to Cape Cod on Friday, barring any unforeseen emergency.
At what point do I draw the veil over an experience that's feeling increasingly solitary? I
guess when things start to feel as if they're becoming too personal to share and/or if I'm
physically unable.
I'm not even checking this post for minor errors, just sending it as is. Thanks so much for
all the texts, emails etc. of concern. I am needing to rebound from the past few days but
will try to be in touch, at least via CB.
label: neutral

text:
It's been a minute. In the interim, Ben was here for a week, followed by my trip to the
Cape with Ben and Sammi and  return via NYC, where I spent the night at my mom's. I'll
probably report on that interlude in my next post, reserving this one for a health update.
I've been showered with blessings in the form of emails, texts, even gifts from friends
and family (maybe partly in reaction to the sobering account of my virtual visit with Dr.
Beavis). I really want to respond to every one but it's taking a while. Here's why:
Actually, I'm sure it's not hard for you to imagine: the reality (mortality?) check from Dr.
Beavis really shook me, and I'm doing what I can to get my bearings, whatever that can
mean in this context. Related to this, of course, is the fact that I'm feeling generally
poorly (nevertheless, she persisted...); more on this below, but I lack energy even for
basic tasks (walking to the mailbox, cooking). Also, in the past two weeks I've been
blessed (yes, I'll use the word again) by conversations with several important people in
my life that have been exceedingly honest, raw, and, ultimately, *healing.* While these
moments of intensity have left me at peace, I also feel drained psychically from some
attempts at, if not closure, then unfiltered soul connection. Thank goodness therapy
prepared me for these encounters! In response to one of my postings, a while back my
friend David R. taught me the expression 'livin' large' as it pertains to some lifestyles in
the gorgeous wide-open spaces of the Colorado Rockies where he's made his home. I'm
'livin' large' emotionally, and sometimes it tires me!
So today I spent nearly four hours in the infusion room getting pumped up with
magnesium and iron, then continued on to the ophthalmologist's. My magnesium level is
again low, as is, now, my hemoglobin count (>red blood cells, oxygen etc.). What's with
the iron problem? The day after we arrived on Cape Cod, ie last Sunday, I noticed to my
consternation that I was spotting, not heavily but enough to send me to CVS for
absorbent pads (is this tmi? I've lost nearly all shame regarding my bodily functions...). I
was further concerned as I'm obviously post-menopausal, yet the blood had to be
coming from somewhere. I sent Dr. Patel's nurse a message via the Geisinger portal, to
which she responded with a phone call the next day. One or more of the tumors on my
'vaginal cuff' is likely bleeding, not uncommon with ovarian cancer.  It feels like awful
period cramps 24/7 (the irony is not lost on me as I had nearly all my 'hardware'
removed during debulking surgery). My pelvis aches. The bleeding also explains the low
hemoglobin count and the acute fatigue, shortness of breath etc. while we were on the
Cape. So now I'm to have three more iron infusions after today's; the good news is that I
seem to already feel perkier from this first dose! I'm grateful that Dr. Patel's office is
monitoring me closely.
Basically, the middle third of my body -- chest, abdomen and pelvis -- causes me much
discomfort, sometimes pain. Cancer in my pleura can make it hard to find a comfortable
sleeping position (though I've been sleeping well - lots of dreams). Oxycodone every six
                    
hours helps relieve pain and I nearly always have a heating pad near me to alleviate
back/pelvic discomfort. Long soaks in the jacuzzi at our hotel in Chatham also felt terrific.
I've been giving much thought to how to treat my body as compassionately as possible.
This afternoon I had an appointment with my ophthalmologist, Dr. Marcovitch. I'm
pleased to report that, following a month of horribly blurry vision, a trip to a specialist at
Hopkins, steroid drops, and much aggravation, my corneas have healed completely. I
marvel at my body's ability to heal certain deficiencies while under siege from cancer. I
also have to go pick stronger lenses that I ordered, which should help further correct my
near-sightedness. I may well need cataract surgery (requiring at least 5-6 office visits)
but we're leaving that discussion open, because....well, because.
I've had a mild headache or two recently, which of course makes me worry about my
brain.  While this organ has been 'cooperating' since my last go-around with radiation, in
the past new spots have emerged every few months or so. I'm waiting for Dr. Patel the
younger's office to call me (likely later this month) so we can schedule an MRI, once it's
been approved by Highmark. We'll then proceed from there.
I still haven't decided which of the three options Dr. Beavis presented to me I will go for:
clinical trial (a longshot, imo); oral chemo drug with 10-15% chance of effectiveness (ie
in terms of stabilizing or reducing cancer load); cessation of treatment. So for now I do
nothing. Is this a de facto choice? Quality of life needs to guide my decision. Initially I felt
that stopping treatment was the 'easiest' choice because it requires no evident agency
(e.g. taking a medication, travelling to a clinical trial site) but now I understand that it
may be the hardest option as it requires full acceptance of my situation.
I am still eager for visitors. Lying on my couch in my sunroom warmed by my heating
pad and blissed out on  pain meds, I'm ready to dive into conversation and quality time
w/friends and family. It takes my mind off cancer, that's for sure. My cherished friend
Helen and I had a wonderful visit on Sunday. We laughed uproariously reminiscing about
an improbable, slightly embarrassing situation we experienced together a few summers
ago; shed some tears; dished about work, family, life, travel and more. Thanks to my old
school pal Zia, I also met her friend and former NYTimes editor, Christopher Philipps, a
native New Yorker of E. European Jewish descent  like me, who was en route to spend
time in an Amish/Mennonite community in Ohio. How he met these folks is only one of
the stories we spun during a delightful. *And* as I've been blogging this evening I've also
been texting with my grad school bffs Vinni and Isabelle, who plan to visit me in early
August. I can't wait!
Michael kindly brought me some of Sue's borscht earlier. I'm sure it's delicious and look
forward to sampling it for dinner along with Peruvian chicken delivered by my friend John
Ochoa, a fabulous cook. On that note, I'm also exploring the possibility of having a local
chef/caterer with an excellent reputation  make some of my meals going forward. Meal
                    
prep can tire me, even though I love  to cook.
Photos
label: sadness

text:
I had intended to report on our recent trip to the Cape. which I hope to do still, but write
with a cancer update instead. 
I'm about 99% decided on stopping treatment. Option 1 presented by Dr. Beavis, joining
a clinical trial, would involve travel that would undoubtedly sap whatever paltry energy
reserves I could tap into at this point and would mean time away from friends, my cozy
home etc. Whether I'd even be admitted to a trial having had brain and liver mets is
unlikely, but theoretically possible. I will share with Dr. Cohen at MSK the report on my
next brain scan, upcoming in early August, and he and Dr. Beavis will let me know what
might be available to me in term of trials at Hopkins and at MSK. Option 2, taking an oral
chemo med daily with a 10-15% effectiveness rate, means putting more poison into my
body, returning to weekly blood work to ensure no drops in red and white blood cell
counts that could lead to infection, and other side effects etc. Of course, that 10-15% is
presumably made up of *real people,* so why not me? But didn't Einstein define insanity
as doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results? This would be my
*seventh* line of chemo. By now, those cancer cells have made themselves nice and
comfy inside my body, have generated their own blood supplies and created a perfect
environment in which to thrive. I think I'm done.
I had to get past the feeling that Option 3 was somehow a cop-out because it involves no
*action* on my part -- e.g. taking a pill, sending off reams of documents to hospitals
sponsoring clinical trials, travel. Shortly I began to understand that rather than a passive,
default choice, Option 3 is in fact the most difficult choice as it implies acceptance of my
situation. Yes, it is the antithesis of the 'leave no stone unturned' approach. Its goal is
ensuring quality of (remaining) life as opposed to (potential) quantity.
Three of my doctors -- Patel, Perez (oncology therapist) and Vithalani (palliative care) --
have also promoted discontinuing treatment. While I listened closely to them, their
influence was not decisive. Dr. Patel said he would support me if I wanted to try
treatment with an oral chemo. Dr. Beavis has left the decision to me. Everyone seems to
think, though, that all three options will have the final end result.
*****************************
Update within an update: So I just returned from the radiation oncologist's to discuss the
bleeding that started on the Cape and the possibility of using radiation to stop it. I had
been previously told merely that "Dr. Patel (junior) wanted to talk this over with you" so
imagine my surprise when I was told to undress for a pelvic exam that Dr. Patel would
perform. Since he's actually a very sweet, puppy-faced guy (really quite cute, but too
young for me...), he quickly reassured me that he performs these all the time, that we
could stop if I were in pain etc. I didn't fully understand the need for the exam as I was to
have a CT scan of my pelvis right afterwards (also news to me when I showed up for my
appointment) but I think the exam had to do with visualizing and feeling the source of
                    
the bleeding. In any event, the exam was shorter and less invasive than one an ob-gyn
would perform. Dr. Patel's PA, Angie, an annoyingly cheerful central PA type who
responds to any question requiring an affirmative with a disconcertingly enthusiastic
"YEPPERS!," was also in the room. Dr. Patel could clearly feel a tumor that was the likely
culprit. I then went next door in his office to have a CT-scan. Due to the pelvic exam, I
started bleeding more heavily than before; lying on the hard surface for the CT-scan, my
back was hurting a lot as the technician drew spots and crosses on my hips and pelvis
with a Sharpie. I was in tears from the pain, quite frankly. The upshot is, though, that Dr.
Patel would like to treat my bleeding tumor with radiation. This will likely stop the
bleeding and may shrink the tumor too. Left untreated, I will continue to bleed, risking a
drop in hemoglobin and anemia. My bladder may also become irritated or compressed.
This bleeding is not inconsequential.  Onward then to *fifteen* more rounds of radiation,
supplemented by iron infusions for two more weeks (had one this morning).
This means I must again reach out for help with rides. Dr. Patel wants me to take a
painkiller before each round (I am now armed with morphine...) so I won't be so darned
uncomfortable while it's happening. And I can't drive myself to radiation if I'm taking this
type of painkiller, as I'll be too woozy. Sooo..... I need fifteen rides divided among any
number of people. Total time involved: 1-1 /2 hours max? This will involve picking me up
at my place, driving me to the hospital, waiting while I undergo radiation (20 mn.), then
driving me home. . Most appointments are at 1:30 (with a few exceptions) over the next
three weeks (beginning this Thursday, actually). Thanks in advance for letting me know if
you might help me out with this. Uber can always be a default but frankly it's neither the
most convenient nor desirable option.
***************************
Sunday I was visited by a case manager for UPMC hospice services, for which I'll be
eligible anytime after officially stopping treatment. Hospice is a form of care focused on
preserving and extending quality of life for terminally ill patients. It's no longer our
'grandparents' hospice,' an 'antechamber of death' where patients lived their final days
in a morphine haze. The local team consists of a nurse (who would come to my house at
least once every two weeks), nurse's aide, volunteer(s), social worker and 'spiritual
advisor.' These folks could come over on an 'as needed and desired' basis for as long or
short a period as I'd like. Frankly, I could use all the help I can get, am eager to get relief
from stronger pain meds as I'm often in much discomfort, and need to get my hands on
some medical devices such as a Life Alert; the hospice team can attend to all these
needs. Rabbi Ostrich happened to call me yesterday and we'll get together next week. I
would more likely lean on him more than on 'spiritual advisors' provided by UPMC
hospice, none of whom are Jewish, although their training for this part of their job is non-
denominational (again, we're in rural central PA here, sigh...).  I would have loved to
have been visited by the wonderful Hopkins chaplain, Rhonda, a progressive Methodist
minister, but she's obviously too far away.
I'm thinking comfy, cozy, hygge, sunroom, visitors, peacefulness, iced tea... I feel like I
                    
should be delving into profound works of literature (I did crack open Viktor Frankl's
_Man's Search for Meaning_ the other day), but mainly I feel like relaxing on the sofa in
my sunroom and watching cooking shows! Speaking of which, Rebecca, a local private
chef with an excellent reputation, will likely soon begin cooking for me two or three times
a week. I love to cook as always, but it can tire me out (at least now due to my blood
loss/low hemoglobin/anemia issues).
My friends have been magnificent all along. Saturday night two of them hosted a potluck
that was sort of my idea at the outset but somehow morphed into being "Willa's party!"
Everything about the evening was perfect: gorgeous summer night (not too hot, no
humidity), crescent moon, delicious food and drink, live music, a magical outdoor
setting, great company. I'm a lucky girl. My friends Maria, Jackie, and Kathryn have
visited, ditto yesterday my friend Esther, bearing the red lentil soup and blintzes (!) I
asked if she would make for me. Dinner tonight at the Ale House with friends Cheryl,
Sandy, and Kathryn. At this point I can handle outings in moderation; I tend to get tired
and uncomfortable after a while, although I rallied for four hours Saturday night's party.
I've always loved a good party.
Photos
label: neutral

text:
I wanted to make sure to leave some written and visual traces of our trip to Chatham,
where Ben and I vacationed three summers ago. This may be a bit of a 'telegraphic'
report, though, and punctuation is assuredly 'anarchic!'
Drive with Ben with overnight stop in Fishkill, NY (Hudson Valley) w/take-out dinner from
the dazzling Red Line Diner (gleaming chrome - huge menu - bustling - display case
boasting every type of pie imaginable) - Ben and I have some of our best talks on long
car trips - pick up Sammi the next day from the train station in Brewster, NY (had déjà
vus of all my comings and goings along that train line when I was in high school and
college: to New Canaan to visit Julie, to Irvington to visit a friend, Gay,  whom I had met
on my France trip when I was sixteen; to Michael's parents' home in Hartsdale - same
Tudor-style architecture in the shops surrounding the station - same Westchester-ish
vibe) - Sammi drives us to Chatham, on the 'elbow' of the Cape, listening to podcasts
(David Chang; interview with Jake Tapper); thick haze that doesn't leave for two days -
can't see the ocean! Cooler temps and mist, not unpleasant; Chatham Bars Inn perfect in
every way (those lush sheets! those salt caramels and aged cheddar cheese and
crackers awaiting us! those thick, fluffy towels! that ultra-professional service poolside
and everywhere else on the property! those hydrangeas and that gorgeous
landscaping!); first night dinner at The Impudent Oyster in town (cold, briny Wellfleet
oysters - I can never get enough of that unique taste sensation, but which goes better
with them, mignonette or tartar sauce or 'au naturel?' -- chilled rosé -- Caesar salad
w/jumbo shrimp) -- Sammi and Ben take a stroll in town (and bring me fudge!) while I
                    
return to my bed to rest. Next day, bleeding starts, which freaks me out not a little. Call
Kayla at Dr. Patel's and she advises monitoring symptoms until my return - bleeding
likely caused by a tumor. Feeling under the weather the whole time but manage to
compartmentalize and enjoy the time away - Ben comes to my room to wish my
goodnight each night - very calming. Next day relaxing at the pool - whirlpool feels
terrific on my back -- love the poolside service (lemonade, iced tea, guac, but Ben and
Sammi also bring us lunch from a cute sandwich shop in town - tuna salad, Thai noodle
salad etc.). Ocean still not visible! Dinner at Mac's, casual place we had discovered three
years ago. Succulent fried clam bellies, a squirt of lemon, and tartar sauce. Is there
anything better? Hamachi crudo. A fish curry for Ben and Sammi. Following day weather
is poor (drizzle): Ben and Sammi hit the golf course, I get comfy on my bed w/my heating
pad. Given the weather, we opt for a nice lunch at the Sesuit Harbor Cafe in Dennis,
revisiting a place we had liked three years ago. Fabulous lobster roll! So fresh, just the
right amount of mayo, a squirt of lemon, have it with coleslaw to add some crunch. I
have dreamt about this encounter with the perfect lobster roll for three years! I forget
what we did for dinner that night; I think we brought food in from somewhere, perhaps a
seafood shack near the hotel. Ben drives me to see nearby lighthouse at some point. We
also take a little drive one day -- love the Cape architecture, the shingle-covered houses,
the marinas, the summer hydrangeas. Shopping at Chatham Candy Manor; picked out
chocolates and other goodies as gifts. Town  crowded with tourists. Ben and Sammi get
ice cream cones one night. Last day: lovely weather (yay). Another pool day for me. Long
chat with an art director from Massapequa (home of the alleged Gilgo Beach murderer...
I'm following avidly...). Many hotel guests from NY and Boston areas (do I dare wear my
NY Yankees cap?). I never made it into the ocean, although I had intended to. Ben and
Sammi take a boat to explore a nearby beach. Frequent soaks in the whirlpool. Later that
day, manager's reception. I'm too tired to stand and make chit-chat so I relax on one of
many comfy sofas in the lobby. Ben and Sammi check out the reception and meet a few
of the chefs. Many young foreigners as servers and other staff; a lovely young man from
Croatia serves us drinks. Lounge outside in Adirondack chairs as we take pictures of one
another. Dinner: return to Mac's: more clam bellies, oysters. Nightcap at the hotel: I
indulge in a Dark and Stormy; it matches the weather outside. Ben and Sammi are
wonderful travel companions: upbeat, solicitous, very helpful, relaxed, fun. It is always a
pleasure to spend time with them.
Leave early for drive to NY (5 hours or so? more?). Spend evening at my mother's.
Relaxing, comfortable, good chat. My mother always intuits what I'd like for dinner and
so we both enjoyed delicious cold borscht from Zabar's and some mini-quiches from
Breads Bakery (plus a babka to take home). Slept well, got up early as Sammi picked me
up around 7:30 to drive me back to State College (so kind of her; we gabbed a bit in the
car). She stayed over and headed back to the city the next morning.
Happy to have made these memories!

text:
...the heavy cavalry, the big guns, the Conestoga wagons circling me, keeping me
comfortable, warm, safe, care-free, nutrified with healthful food and nourishing
conversation.
The friends are here! The ones I've known for 40-60 years and who are like family. What
a treat.
Hard to recount everything we 'did' or will do because it is mainly about 'le feeling.' I've
always liked this quote attributed to George Eliot: “Friendship is the inexpressible comfort of
feeling safe with a person, having neither to weigh thoughts nor measure words."
Let me insert a health update here, before returning to the cavalcade of pals: more or less status quo.
Lacking energy big time (even writing these posts seems a challenge at times, but I persist). Fatigue
after minimal exertion. Painkillers (Oxycodone and Morphine) help a bit. Discomfort/pain (chronic) in
middle third of body, esp. pelvis, sides/back (pleura). Heating pad a necessity. Pain is not fun. Seven
                    
sessions of radiation down out of fifteen. Still bleeding. Hope it will stop by mid-next week, as Dr.
Patel suggests. The thought that this course of radiation might not be successful had not even
occurred to me until recently. Brain MRI upcoming this week, ditto for magnesium and iron infusions
and five rounds of radiation. My spirit is willing but my body falters. It seems that I may not be able to
start hospice until all the radiation is done; hospice does not appear to cover the cost, or all of it. So
I'll wait another ten days, or longer if I need more radiation on my brain. No suspicious headaches to
speak of in the past three months, thankfully, but I'll wait to learn about the scan results. Even minor
activity is tiring: a profusion of ants in my kitchen and sunroom last night taxed me. I did what I could
w/Raid (bending down to spray the sideboards was most uncomfortable), then my friend Greg (my
friend Helen's husband) came over today to spray with a stronger product. The ants, which likely got
in the house after work on my gutters last week, appear to be gone, but I find it increasingly hard to
deal with even minor stress such as this. Rebecca, the personal chef, will offer a 'trial run' this week
(chicken coconut curry soup, wild salmon cakes w/dill sauce, green salad), and then I'll likely have her
cook 2-3 meals per week for me. My house cleaner will also be here, plus the rest of my life-saving
'crew' (Kelsey, Liz, Abbye). Rabbi Ostrich will visit me on Thursday; I have a number of items on my
agenda to discuss with him.
Shanny drove out here from Brooklyn this week, bearing nourishing butternut squash soup and a
gorgeous lavender orchid plant (received a magnificent bouquet of multicolored roses from my former
grad student and now close friend, Christi, this week; made my day. Love being surrounded by such
beauty. Christi's kindness and caring nature are scarcely paralleled). Shanny and I sat in my sunroom
and gabbed (about NYU friends, family, relationships, future plans, summer adventures, what
happens when we die and more, with affect ranging from light and humorous to heavy and thoughtful,
and everything in between). Thanks to her, I enjoyed an invigorating, relaxing foot massage and a
nice dinner, to which I contributed a very good ratatouille I had made from Melissa Clark's recipe (I
say it is an 'aspirational' ratatouille as none can match the slick and oily -- but not too -- herby,
intensely flavorful ratatouille with eggplant, zucchini, tomato, onion and garlic I once sampled at an
open-air market in Provence; that's the gold standard for me. Tonight, the rest of the NYU 'brigade'
begins to arrive. Vinni is flying in from Boston and will be joined by Isa and her husband Rob on
Monday (they'll return to their country house in Laporte, PA, Monday night). On the 18th, my darling
Mitchel, my best college friend whom I first met when I was the only first-year student in a course on
Proust and was befriended by Mitchel and a friend of his, arrives from Nice via New York, where he'll
be visiting friends and family. I miss him so much and greatly look forward to spending time with him.
Cousin Julie arrives from Florida in early September. Ben will most likely come up for Rosh Hashanah
(combined with a PSU football game!), and I may possibly get to see him this month too. While I was
tired after Shanny's visit (slept twelve hours!), I also felt as though I had received a big shot of love.
How wonderful to be able to be so authentic with these friends, and actually *deepen* these
friendships. There is a balm in GIlead!
Other visits from out of town friends might yet be scheduled. I'm so happy to spend time with these
pals before I may no longer be able to.
I've been able to visit with other friends on drives to/from the hospital for radiation: my wonderful
friends Cheryl and Nancy (intense convo about food: my ratatouille - again! - and the latest Ottolenghi
recipes N., a fantastic cook, has been trying), Michael (who was convinced that a guy sitting next to
me in the waiting room was a Q-Anon supporter b/c of the strange, nihilistic rhetoric he was spouting).
                    
Yesterday, my dear former colleague and friend Bénédicte, bearing arugula and tomatoes from her
garden, spent a few hours with me over cold drinks and nibbles; I got caught up on department news
and learned much more than I had ever known about B's family. And two days ago it was Ben's best
friend (since kindergarten?) Nikhil, who texted me to say he'd be in town to visit his parents and
asking to visit. Nikhil lives between Boston and New York; he and Ben are thick as thieves, which
makes me so happy as both are stellar guys, creating excellent opportunities for themselves
professionally and doing really well personally. When I think about the young men and women of this
generation that I'm privileged to know (including Ben's friend group, many of his cousins, several
former students), I truly think there is hope for a bright future. Nikhil, who works in the biotech field, is
cheerful, fun, smart, interesting, loyal, hard-working and polite (he insisted on washing his water glass
before leaving my house!). I really enjoyed speaking with him.

text:
Health update: I don't have enough fingers to stop up the holes in the dike where the
deluge threatens to come roaring through, causing irrevocable damage:
Eyes: The prescription given to me at Hopkins, which I just had filled here, was incorrect,
probably because I was still suffering some corneal damage when the ophthalmologist
examined me. So new lenses are being made, to arrive next week. In the meanwhile, I'm
(still) existing with very blurry vision, which makes me reticent to drive except for very
short distances. This problem will soon be taken care of, however. I just have to be
patient. And the whole episode (getting re-examined etc.) required 'bandwidth' I really
don't have much of currently.
                    
But that's the least of it.
Cancer throughout my body: As mentioned, middle 'third' of my body hurts. I'm no
longer able to sleep on my left side (which causes both dull and sharp pain under my
ribcage) and always have a heating pad near me. I'm taking morphine but at such a low
dose that I'm not sure how much it helps. It makes me tired but that's ok.
Pelvis: Today will have eleventh round of radiation out of fifteen. Lying still on a hard
table for fifteen-twenty mn. hurts me; I even vomited once afterward from the pain's
intensity. The technicians are very kind. What is most frustrating is that I'm not sure the
radiation is working. I am still bleeding, perhaps with a less heavy flow than before, but
I'm losing blood for sure. I just finished the final of four rounds of iron infusions; perhaps
Dr. Patel senior will prescribe additional rounds when I see him on Thursday. Will also
have a magnesium infusion this week. It hadn't even occurred to me that the radiation
might not stop the blood flow and shrink the 6 cm. tumor. I am really not sure what
happens next but I'll see Dr. Patel junior this afternoon.
Brain: results of last week's MRI are in: multiple lesions show increase in size consistent
with progressive metastatic disease. One lesion (or spot) is 3 cm. Can these be radiated
stereotactically, both because of their size and number (and placement)? Or is whole
brain radiation -- the line in the sand I said I wouldn't cross because of possible effects on
cognition -- necessary at this point? Any other alternatives? If I won't cross the line in the
sand and there are no other viable alternatives (gamma knife?), what happens then?
How slow or fast-growing are these spots/lesions? Memories of stifling headaches>time
for steroids (which inevitably cause me insomnia, while I've been sleeping quite well
recently)? "Don't create worries," I am told, but frankly, this is hugely worrisome to me,
an awful thought to wake up to this morning (although, of course, not totally
unexpected). I'll know more this afternoon.
The radiation timetable is linked to hospice care. Hospice will cover five rounds of
radiation but no more (it's all about costs, insurance). So I'll need to see if/when I'll need
brain radiation, and how much, before I can get on hospice. Frankly, I'm eager for extra
help with pain management. On that note, I may also try medical marijuana for pain
relief. At least two people whose opinions I value have discussed it with me in ways that
make much sense.
Appetite: practically zilch. Honestly, I could bypass food entirely but know I have to eat
(drinking a Chobani peach yogurt beverage right now). The only tastes that appeal to me
are cold ones: a big glass of iced tea in the morning, Perrier, Carnation instant breakfast,
an occasional root bear float. And soup. And tastes of other things. But I can't always
keep the food down; vomiting and diarrhea sometimes follow *immediately* after I eat
something that disagrees with me. My stomach is ultra-sensitive and, as Dr. Patel
                    
mentioned. my cancer is likely affecting the appetite center in my brain. I scarcely
recognize the completely food-obsessed enthusiast I was in the person for whom the
mere sight of some foods makes her stomach turn. I still like to watch cooking shows and
to imagine a scaled-down version of my ultimate foodie tour, featuring little bites of my
faves: one piece of oily Szechuan eggplant in garlic sauce, half a profiterole, a tiny cup of
summer borscht from Veselka; a quarter of a Sabrett or Nathan's hot dog with spicy
mustard and sauerkraut.
Rebecca, whom I'm considering taking on as a private chef, cooked for me last week. Her
food is excellent: this first go around featured wild salmon cakes; chicken coconut soup
with shitake mushrooms, red bell peppers; a nice salad of corn, feta, cherry tomatoes
and lots of fresh herbs; yogurt dill sauce. The only issue is -- you guessed it -- I can only
eat a fraction of what she makes and I don't like to waste food. Right now we're talking
about how she might be able to adjust portion size, which dishes freeze well etc. It still
beats cooking, a great pleasure of mine that has become increasingly difficult for me
these days (I tire after standing too long).
Energy/fatigue: Again, I scarcely recognize my formerly energetic self in my fatigued.
dragged out current version. Blame the morphine? Blood loss? The physical energy my
body continues to direct towards fighting cancer? This past weekend I slept until nearly
noon, but then felt the need to lie down on my couch again right after breakfast (or
lunch, I guess). I am still intent on getting out of bed each morning, taking a shower and
getting dressed but often find it harder to do much else... Many friends have visited in
the afternoons; one offered to take me for a drive in the country (one of my favorite
activities!). This has been lovely.
Even updating my blog can be tiring. I want to continue to as long as I can both to keep
informed this wonderful online community of the past four+ years and to offer myself an
outlet in writing. But I might need to engage a 'guest columnist' or two here and/or I
might contemplate shorter, more frequent posts commensurate with my energy level.
At the risk of sounding like a broken record, I feel badly for not yet having responded to
some of the many wonderful (truly) emails, cards, texts etc. I've been sent. Please
understand my occasional radio silence in the context of what I've detailed above. I am
soooo appreciative of all your thoughtful gestures. I feel love for all of you. Please stick
with me! I do hope to respond, but might need to capitalize on  little energy boosts for
this to happen.
I had wanted to write, on a cheerier note, about my recent visitors, but now think I will
reserve that account for a separate post. Be well, everyone.
label: fear

text:
A few more points of medical update before turning (in another post) to more uplifting
topics such as recent visits from a few angels:
*In what passes for 'good news' these days, today I will finish my fifteen rounds of
radiation to staunch bleeding from a tumor on my vaginal cuff. I hope the memory of
having to lie my cancer-ridden back on a rock-hard table and hold still for fifteen minutes
will soon recede; perhaps time will efface in ways that Morphine, Oxycodone, and Ativan
were unable to. I was unable to complete only one treatment (due to anxiety), while
another treatment -- but again only one -- ended with my vomiting copiously into a bag
the technicians provided. I guess that's not too bad a record. I hope they let me smash a
gong or something today to mark the occasion, or perhaps I'll just pilfer an extra Diet
Coke or two from the fridge in the waiting room. Best of all, in the end, I do think the
radiation succeeded in stopping the bleeding. Dr. Patel said this trend towards total 'shut
off' could continue for up to four weeks after radiation ends.
A big thank you to Susan and the other techs who were so kind to me and always
complimented my clothes (and eye shadow, when I wore it), even when I felt like a
wretch.
Another huge thank you and hurrah to everyone who shuttled me back and forth to/from
radiation, taking time out of your busy days, boosting my morale, making sure I go to my
appointments on time, providing sustenance in the form of spirited convo -- and/or soup
or lasagna! Thanks to my angels Jackie, Helen, Cheryl, Nancy, Michael, Sandy, Kathryn,
Mar, Maria and Natalie. Please let me know if I've omitted anyone - I hope not!
*MRI update: In response to the last MRI, which shows new lesions as well as recurrence
of certain prior mets, Dr. Patel junior is recommending waiting six weeks and then
rescanning, to see what if anything may have changed. He is averse to retreating
already treated areas such as my cerebellum, where there is now a 3 cm 'thing' (could
be cancer, could be necrosis). He'll send me to a neurosurgeon colleague of his in
Hershey if I want a consult, to explore surgical options. He thinks any symptoms I might
start to have will come on gradually; his office sent in a script for Dexameth. today in
case headaches return (memories of  the frightful, unbearable headaches that preceded
removal of my brain tumor by the superb Dr. Bettegowda at Hopkins, whom I plan to
consult to see if he concurs w/Dr. P's assessment of my situation). At first I thought that
Dr. P. was kicking the can, punting, 'giving up on me,' or what have you, but I now
believe he understands my preference at this point for not going hard against my
disease, opting instead for quality of life. So I'll likely go along with his recommendation,
relieved to have a break from radiation for  now. This in turn means that I can get on
board the hospice train as early as Monday, when a nurse will visit me at home for
intake, more general discussion of hospice care etc. What hospice will and will not cover
                    
($-wise) is still a little murky to me: seems to depend both on $$ concerns (when does it
not??) and on the overarching 'quality of life over aggressive treatment' philosophy of
hospice. We'll see how this plays out.
I'm on my way to getting a medical marijuana card! As initially described to me, the
process for getting one seemed daunting but it really wasn't in the end. I filled out a form
online (PA Dept. of Health); spoke by phone for about fifteen minutes with a local doctor
(very nice, also confronting cancer now) who 'certified' me; and finally filled out another
PA Dept. of Health form. Total cost for processing plus phone visit with local doctor:
$250. Now I await my card, which I'm told should arrive within five to twenty-one days.
Then I'll shop at one of our four local dispensaries, where a pharmacist will help me with
what I need based on my profile. Dr. Ejianreh suggested tinctures or an edible called
'troches' (?). I'm not sure my lungs could handle smoking. Who knew I'd be back to weed
after decades? Hope it helps with the pain.
Final update: Radiation, done. I was 'privileged' to ring a bell when I exited the treatment
room, surrounded by the wonderful, compassionate team of technicians (one of them
recorded the moment, but I don't think CB lets me post it).
Writing quickly now and finishing up as I await my dear college friend Mitchel, fresh off
the Megabus from NY (and, prior to that, fresh off the plane from Nice!). I'm so looking
forward to being with him and will report when I'm able.
Here's to a restful and restorative and beautiful shabbos.
label: neutral

text:
Fée du logis = (literally) fairy of the dwelling-place; in my lexicon, fairy godperson,
tutelar deity, magical helper and healer in the home.
If you want to know the recipe for helping me feel better physically these days (or any
day, really), arrange a visit for me with one of my oldest, dearest friends. Maybe it's the
cure for cancer, who knows? I've mulled over how to write this post, how to explain the
love I feel for my friends, but I'm not sure I can offer anything entirely cohesive. These
are the sound bites that come to me when I think about the recent visits from Shanny,
Vinni, Isabelle and her husband Rob (also my old friend) and Mitchel: Chosen family.
Wrapped in a cocoon of love. Soul connection. Vibing. Feeling radiant, perhaps even
'radiating,' 'levitating' with happiness. Immense comfort and sense of well-being. A large
piece of furniture with drawers - "un gros meuble à tiroirs," in Baudelaire's imagining - 
overflowing with memories. A safe space to feel all the feels, share all the thoughts.
Friendships that mellow, deepen, complexify, improve with age (ok, yes, like the fine
wines that we've shared many of over the years). Adventures, joyous occasions and sad
ones, 'fous rires' (laughing fits), tears, hugs. Our commitment to one another.
Forty, forty-five years of continuous connection, continuous involvement in each other's
lives. Mitchel and I met in a seminar on Proust my freshman year at Harvard, taught by a
waiflike British woman, Camille Naish, always late for class. I was the only freshman in
                    
the class; Mitchel, a sophomore,  befriended me, we clicked instantly, the hit the ground
running. Shanny, Vinni, Isa (and Rob) and I all met in grad school at NYU, such formative
years. I've always felt that a crucial part of our bond was the one we shared as women
trying, over the decades, to succeed in both our professional and personal lives (and
maybe finally having figured it out). We've all been up in one another's business: Vinni
lived with Isa and Rob in NY (Shanny may have too, at another point); Vinni, Shanny and
I shared a swanky apartment in Paris for a year, while Vinni and I took another Paris
apartment for the two of us the following year. We've been roomies at countless
academic conferences. Our four quite different personalities have always meshed so
well. The two 'dumb blondes' and the two 'dumb brunettes.' Les filles.
"J'ai plus de souvenirs que si j'avais mille ans...." (Baudelaire, again). Mitchel and I
sharing our first trip to Italy at twenty (he was twenty-one). Broke but wildly dazzled by
the art! the food! the beautiful people!, we romped through Italy from north to south,
armed with a backpack and Eurail pass. Mitchel and I around the corner neighbors in NY
when he attended the law school and we were at the Institute of French Studies.
"Tonton" (uncle) Mitchel taking little Ben out for Chinese dinner in Paris so Michael and I
could enjoy a date. Big Ben and his French tontons Mitchel, Randy and Fabien brunching
at the bustling marché  d'Aligre on Christmas eve day. Mitchel becoming best friends
with my dear grad school friend Randy (who now lives in Paris); both of them blending
into my Institute friend group of V, S and I. Vinni and I getting lost one New Year's Eve in
a deserted area of Madrid dominated by a massive bull ring, in a desperate attempt to
find our friend Phillip's apartment (way  before cell phones), following a week of end of
year revelry. This now-legendary story is one we like to recount to our adult sons.
Shanny adding salt instead of sugar to the apple pie that we were to serve our French
guests at our 'real American' Thanksgiving dinner in Paris. Many dinners and parties at
Isa and Rob's apartment on E. 17th st. in NY. Our 'French parents,' Mathé and Robert
(Isa's parents) nicely inviting us to 'crash' with them whenever we arrived in Paris in the
very early morning hours; sweat-inducing attempts to cram my luggage into that tiny
Parisian elevator in their building in the 11e.  Isa and Rob's wedding in Camp Hill, PA;
Shanny's in Brooklyn; Vinni's wedding dinner at a wonderful Indian restaurant in the
Village (to which she invited my mother); mine in State College. "Long ago, it must be, I
have a photograph."
I could go on and on and on while being mindful not to let the past overwhelm the
present.
"These fragments I have shored against my ruins."
So these visits -- consecutive except for Vinni's overlapping with Isa and Rob's for part of
a day -- could not *not* be wonderful. Shanny gave me a foot massage. Vinni and I
indulged in ice cream cones from Meyer Dairy and had some laughs over a Borat movie,
which we watched in our p.j.s. I was spoiled with divine-smelling gifts from Fresh (Vinni),
                    
Guerlain and Fragonard (Mitchel) -- I tell ya, these pals understand my olfactory
obsession! We ate - and ate - and drank - and cooked - and ate some more. Extended
cocktail hours (G&Ts, Negronis, summer rosés). Salmon expertly prepared by my fées du
logis. Homemade butternut squash soup thanks to Shanny. Mainly, we gabbed and
gabbed, about everything: our families, memories, mortality, our summer goings-on.
We'll never run out of things to talk about.
Tired yet still 'light' today. A visit in my sunroom from my dear friend Helen was the
perfect complement to the weekend.
Shavua tov.
Photos
