text:
This week brought a bunch of medical appointments as my new home hospice paradigm
falls into place. This means some different personnel, meds, schedules. On Monday, a
nurse from the UPMC (University of Pittsburgh) hospice team, Mollie, came to visit, to get
intake and physically assess me. The UPMC team is in regular touch with my palliative
care doctor, Dr. Vithalani. I wasn't certain how this visit would be much different from
that of Amanda, an account executive (not a nurse) at UPMC home health, a few weeks
earlier. No matter. The bottom line is that our two-hour meeting was (imo) a stressful
                    
disaster. Mollie could not answer my questions about what specifically my Highmark
insurance through PSU would cover or not regarding home hospice (there seems to be
much gray area here....). She spent about an hour on the phone with her supervisor
figuring this out for me. For another twenty-thirty minutes of the two-hour visit, she read
to me the 'fine print' of their various hospice care policies, in a monotone voice that had
a soporific effect ("You are getting tired....very tired..."). That left just a bit of time for her
to take my vitals and ask me a few questions. I said I wouldn't sign an agreement until I
knew exactly what my out of pocket costs would be, and for which services. No wonder
managed care and insurance behemoths have such a bad rep in this country!
Shortly after Mollie left, supervisor Amanda called and asked me how the visit had gone.
I minced no words, and also asked to have a different head nurse assigned to my team
for the duration.
The next day, a different nurse, Laura, came to visit. I definitely clicked better with her
than with Mollie, even in terms of cultural background (I'll leave it at that for now, but
definitely a consideration in these parts). She looked quite young but said she had been
hospice nursing for about five years. Any questions she couldn't answer received
responses from another team member the next day. She was quite thorough and careful.
She helped me get organized in an important way, by bringing (at no cost to me) a new,
multiweek, pill organizer in which she portioned out my next week's worth or so of
medications (still some kinks to be worked out with this system but I'm sure I'll get
there). Finally, as she noticed I was sometimes short of breath, she arranged for a local
med equipment place to bring me (again, for free) a portable oxygen dispenser (but not
a tank) attached to a canula (I was given several extras of these as well). When she left, I
asked her, among other questions, whether she'd be 'my' head nurse going forward. She
said it wasn't certain, depending as it does on nurses' schedules, case loads, driving
distance etc. but she could put in a request. I felt a bit crestfallen at this news, as I want
to feel confident in my trust in the nurse caring for me through this emotion-laden life
experience. Good news the next day, though, when Laura returned for a second visit:
she has indeed signed on as my head nurse (in view of weekly visits, most likely). In
turn, I agreed to the UPMC terms and conditions  whose vague nature had complicated
our early communication. Signed, sealed, delivered!
I think I'm getting my pain under control with morphine and oxycodone. It does make me
kinda loopy and less mentally acute or agile then I usually am. I'm hoping these
capabilities return. I also seem to awake in the middle of the night with night sweats -
can't tell if this might be from the heat pad that keeps me comfy at night or something
else. And I have occasional, odd aural 'tics, sharp sounds (like those of clanging metal
pipes) that I hear when I'm in a sort of liminal state between sleep and awakeness.
Meanwhile, the cheffing/cleaning and straightening/errand running/clothes and
dishwashing/bed-making structure provided by Liz and Kelsey, Abbye, Pati and Rebecca
                    
works excellently right now. I can't thank these women enough for their care and
service.  
My very dear friends continue to provide me with  all kinds of sustenance, including
spiritual. This past week has brought or will bring visits from Helen, Jackie (bearer of a
Meyer root bear float), Maria and perhaps Lisa for a jaunt in the countryside tomorrow.  A
former student, Casey, came over for iced tea and sweets yesterday. I'm so glad she's
continuing to chase down wonderful opportunities for herself. This coming year she'll be
living in Hamburg and working at the site of the former Neuengamme  concentration
camp, creating digital content for the camp's website and participating in public
outreach (she'd like to work in a museum, eventually). Casey's visit made me remember
my excitement about working with undergraduates and helping them achieve their
goals.
Ben also arrives tomorrow for about five days. I can't wait to see him.
Gosh, I hope this post is coherent. I really doubt my cognitive functioning some days!
 
 
 
Photos
label: surprise

text:
This week brought more 'transitioning' into hospice care and from there to thinking and
talking about, and envisioning, the contours of end of life care. I'm feeling more or less
status quo, which means fatigued much of the time, seriously lacking appetite (to the
point where the sight or taste of most food actually revolts me -- who could ever have
imagined this??!), and short of breath. I've hit on the right cocktails for pain
management (Morphine + Oxycodone + [as needed] Ativan) and sleep (Morphine +
Trazadone + Tylenol p.m.). Both are well-controlled; sleep is sound and restful (in my
dreams last night I was looking for a group I could daven with...). And Ben has been here
all week, which of course is a natural mood lifter. He efficiently prepares our meals,
makes sure I'm comfortable, runs errands for me. And he's just so darn pleasant to be
around. We watched _One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,_ which imo has not aged well as
a film. Tomorrow he's not working, so we'll be off for a jaunt in the country, specifically to
an apiary that my house cleaner recommended, on a road dotted with farm stands.
Tales of hospice, part II: On Monday, Kelly, the social worker attached to my hospice
team, came to visit. She impressed upon me the necessity of getting a plan in place for
my end of life care *asap* (because sometimes bodily  changes  can occur very rapidly,
she said; other of my nurses and doctors, conversely, have conveyed the opposite, that
things will devolve gradually). She laid out three avenues she thought I should/could
pursue to ensure my access to competent end of life caregiving: a)agencies supplying
round the clock assistance if needed. In the same breath, though, she shared her
                    
wariness of this option; in her opinion, local agencies, short-staffed since the onset of
Covid, are not always reliable -- and their staff is certainly underpaid. She sent me a list
of local agencies that I am supposed to contact myself -- no rest for the weary, I
suppose...b)caregivers identified via word of mouth, potentially a group comprised of
willing and able friends and family members. c)"placement." The very word makes me
shudder. I will not pursue this option. It is not the death I desire. I want to be at home. If
Kelly had been a bit more empathic, I think I would have 'digested' all this information
more easily but her fairly cold affect only agitated me. :(
My meeting with Kelly left me feeling deflated and stressed (hey, isn't this the stage
when I'm supposed to be "pursuing what brings me joy?"). I looked forward to hashing it
all out with Ashley, my oncology therapist, the next day.
My conversation with Ashley proved quite helpful. Together, we worked out what seems
a feasible Plan A and backup Plan B going forward, tailored to my wishes. I'll likely share
more about these plans going forward, but won't divulge more for now as I'm still
working out the details for myself and those involved. Ashley also floated the idea of
hiring a death doula who might act as another compassionate presence at the end stage,
but in a way different from that of the hospice team (death doulas do not necessarily
have medical training, for example). I am attracted to the types of services death doulas
can provide: creating a serene environment in my home, bedroom (in my mind's eye, I
see candles, flowers, an immaculately clean space, hear music and psalms being read;
inhale lovely scents; create any additional legacy projects that appeal to me. I consider
my Caring Bridge blog, close to 400 entries strong, the most significant legacy of this
last phase of my life, but I may wish to gather photos, write letters, communicate video
messages. We'll see if I have sufficient energy to produce the creative work I'm thinking
about. [I should mention that there appears to be a death doula in State College! Who
knew?! I will call her for a consultation.]
Today was busy. Nurse Laura, whom I've met twice now, arrived around noon. We talked
about how I was feeling and remedies for certain problems (she ordered a cane for me,
for example). We also talked a good deal about end of life care (hospice will probably
make a home visit once a day at this point but it's clear I'll need some supplemental
help). She then organized and refilled my pill box for the week. We're communicating
well and slowly learning more about each other's lives; she admired my framed family
photos and was astounded by how much I look like my grandmother, Bessie. I learned
that she has a two-year-old daughter and (somewhat randomly) that she had kept her
own last name when she married. My hunch is that she's pretty outdoorsy, off on
vacation tomorrow to Bryce Canyon National Park with her father. In any event, her laid-
back manner made me feel much more at ease about getting 'personnel' in place
immediately for the final stage ("it always works itself out," she reassured).
By this time, Rebecca, 'my' (!) personal chef, had arrived, leaving me two hours later
                    
with two large containers of tomato basil soup and a goat cheese and veggie frittata. 
A bit later that afternoon, my 'helper' Liz came by to tidy up, wash some dishes, make
my bed, water plants, cut up watermelon etc. We wound up conversing rather intensely
about the trauma she had experienced growing up as a member of a cult-like church; I
tried to be a good and helpful listener as I feel kindly towards this young woman (and
towards Kelsey, too). I am so grateful to be surrounded by this small army of smart,
efficient, interesting women. They definitely lift me up.
Ben and I rounded out the afternoon at a newish brewery in town (root beer for me, an
IPA for Ben), just chilling in lawn chairs in the mellow late-August sun. Ben returns to
Brooklyn on Saturday but will actually make another trip here -- this one for two weeks -
five days later! He's bringing a group of his friends to experience a PSU football game
and the raucous partying downtown that usually ensues. I'm looking forward to meeting
them, and to having Sammi here for a week, along with Ben of course.
label: anger

text:
In several recent comments on my latest posts, I've been lauded for my 'gracious
acceptance' of my current situation. While I'd never want to criticize anyone's personal,
subjective, and well-intentioned reaction to something I've written, I do want to clarify
unequivocally, at least for myself, what I consider an important point: I do not accept
how my cancer has uprooted every fiber of my life. In fact, I find my entire situation
totally unacceptable. It is obscene, hideous, sad beyond measure. I had contemplated
devoting an entire post to my regret over being unable to realize some of my most
deeply-cherished goals -- loving on my (future) grandchildren, writing another book or
more, reveling in a part-time life in Paris. It often makes me so sad to think about these
losses, though, that I *accept* in order to *survive.* And I do try to be happy and grateful
-- and doing so brings me much pleasure -- that I did have so many wonderful
experiences, that I *was* that girl, then woman, that accomplished so much, met so
many incredible people, had so many adventures, travelled, raised a useful human,
cultivated many durable friendships, produced award-winning scholarship, mentored
dozens of students -- and more. I also understand, and I suppose accept, that my
distressing situation is motivated; it's simply the result of having a monstrous, often
incurable (and in my case not genetically predetermined) disease, the result of a bunch
of cells going rogue. That is the reality of my situation; I'm unconvinced that any
attempts to fight against it will fix it, certainly not at this point. But if I change my
perception of it, the crisis I've confronted for the past four+ years indeed becomes easier
to 'accept,' a fairly simple-sounding yet meaningful lesson I gleaned from reading Viktor
Frankl's _Man's Search for Meaning._
I don't know if any of this makes sense. And I admit the possibility of my feelings
changing at any point in the future. To be honest, some of my equanimity and calm
affect do surprise even me at times. Perhaps, as palliative doctor B.J. Miller writes in his
TedX talk on "What Really Happens at the End of Life," "you can always find a shock
of beauty or meaning in what life you have left," I have found such 'shocks of
beauty' in the many random (and not so random) acts of pure love and
compassion and kindness and helpfulness that I've been privileged to be the
recipient of. "If we love such moments ferociously," Miller advises, "then
maybe we can learn to live well – not in spite of death, but because of it.” It's
all part of the 'cosmic crescendo' (Miller's term, I believe) that I hope will
whoosh me up until the end of my days.
'Shocks of beauty.' Yesterday was full of them. Ben had the day off, so we
agreed to take back roads in the next county over from ours to reach an
apiary my housecleaner had recommended. It was one of those perfect days
weather-wise, 'back to school' weather: mellow sunlight dappling the trees
                    
with patches of yellow and gold, warmth with little bursts of cooler breeze
rustling the leaves, corn stalks as 'high as an elephant's eye,' cows lounging
lazily in the fields, silos punctuating the large expanses of farmland. Stillness.
We stopped first at Tati's bakeshop in Pleasant Gap to pick up croissants for
the next day's breakfast (Tati is the superb baker who's created my last two
birthday cakes, the last one festooned with gold foiled ginkgo leaves). Then
we drove about 25 miles towards Lamar, where after several turns we arrived
at Plunkett Road (which I never would have found had Pati not tipped me off).
Across from what looked like an old (colonial?) cemetery, which I would have
wanted to explore had I had more stamina, a small open shack boasted an
array of honeys inside, alongside pamphlets with teachings from the Gospel of
John. I fretted about whether I could leave a check in the cash box as I had
forgotten my $ at home. Fortunately, a friendly-looking Mennonite woman who
owned the farm with her husband returned from grocery shopping in time to
tell us that we could certainly leave a check. Honey is essential for the 'sweet
new year' we wish each other at Rosh Hashanah (i.e. in mid-September), and I
love to shop for different types of honey before the holiday, both for cooking
(honey cake! tzimmes!) and coating with crisp, cold apple slices.
I offered Ben the choice for lunch of either the Hublersburg Inn, an old country
inn along a former post road surrounded by farmland or, closer to State
College, a casual new restaurant featuring Georgian specialties (i.e. from the
country of Georgia!). He/we opted for the latter. At Cafe Luna we ran into
Derek Polay, Tatiana the baker's husband and an excellent chef himself (they
occasionally host pop-up dinners showcasing Tati's Peruvian heritage). I am
grateful for any signs of an emergent, interesting State College food 'scene.' I
had a hot vegetarian borscht (absolutely delicious, the cure (?) for the
concerning loss of appetite that has plagued me recently), while Ben had
Pelmeni soup (featuring a special type of dumpling). We shared 'boureka
bites,' flaky pastry filled with a yummy spinach and cheese filling. I felt tired
after our active (for me) day, so I crashed when we returned. Lying peacefully
on the couch with late-afternoon light streaming into my sunroom felt both
immensely calming and reinvigorating. 
What else? Thursday. Laura (the nurse from UPMC hospice) spent an hour or
so here, refilling and organizing my pill box, ordering some equipment for me
(e.g. a three-pronged cane), talking about how I'm feeling (as mentioned, pain
seems to be under control right now; if I don't take the meds, though, the pain
                    
in my pleura can be unbearable). While Laura and I were talking in the
sunroom, Rebecca was in my kitchen whipping up a delicious tomato and basil
soup (hard to resist, which is really good news for me now) and a goat cheese
and veggie frittata. Then Liz came by to tidy up and help with other tasks
around the house. With these three capable young women around, I felt
particularly well-supported!
This morning I bought my first cannabis products! The pharmacist first took
about 45 minutes to provide an overview: a)benefits of CBD v THC (the two
products I bought contain a mixture), b) mode of administration (I bought a
tincture and some edible troches, kind of like a cough drop); c) organization of
PA Dept. of Health and cannabis distribution within it (it is all very well
regulated; I did understand by innuendo, though, that many people use the
products primarily recreationally rather than medically, even though one is
supposed to have a valid medical reason for receiving the medical marijuana
card - can't believe how naive I am sometimes!). I am going to wait until
someone can be with me while I ingest these products, rather than taking
them solo. I know they're strong and I told the pharmacist that I don't want to
be 'frothing at the mouth' due to the THC content - lol. My hope is that they
will help a lot with pain management, a boost for my appetite, controlling
inflammation  and more. We'll see.
I put Ben on the Megabus to NY at 12;30 and know that he's already home.
Meanwhile, I'm greatly looking forward to visits this week (I think) from Jill (my
grade school chum and last year's travel companion to Paris before Covid got
her...) and her husband Fred, followed by my dear cousin, Julie. Then Ben
returns here Friday for two weeks! He's bringing a crew of his Brooklyn friends
for the full PSU football weekend experience, which probably includes
tailgating before the game against Delaware. I look forward to meeting those
pals for Sunday brunch (just after my cousin Julie heads back to FL) and then
to hosting Ben and Sammi for one week and just Ben for the next. Michael and
Sue have kindly invited us for dinner the first night of Rosh Hashanah. We
wish them a speedy return to fullness of body and spirit as they've both been
battling....Covid!  
Photos

text:
Dear friends, Profound apologies for my long silence. I am alive! I’ve had a near constant
stream of out of town visitors for the past month, which means both that I have much to
recount (all were wonderful visits) and that I am strapped for writing time. Further, I’m
feeling increasingly fatigued and unfortunately overcome by inertia at times. Finally, in
this stage of waning, I feel myself turning inwards, introspectively, almost cosmically. I
do want to write you, though, and have much to share. My brother, Ethan, is kindly
visiting me now. On Thursday, I am mustering whatever energy I can, and we’ll travel to
New York for a few days so I can spend time with beloved family and a few beloved
friends. Back in State College on October 3rd with help from my driver (yes, I have a
driver now!). with my mother in tow. I will try to write again from the city. I hope this
finds you well. I hope you weren’t worried about me. Thanks for your well wishes and
continued concern. Much love.  
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app
label: sadness

text:
Greetings from NYC. Willa asked that I provide you with an update on her well being,
after an active last couple of weeks.
Since Willa’s last post, I drove out to State College to spend some time together. Having
already been through the trenches together the past 4.5 years, we were able to have a
very pleasant and low key gathering. 
Subsequently, I brought Willa back to Manhattan with me, where she stayed for 5 days at
our mother’s apartment. 
A revolving door of close friends, family and NYC culinary treats were delivered to the
apartment, which was Willa’s ultimate goal of the trip.
                    
Since Willa’s return to SC this past Tuesday, she has experienced increased fatigue,
waning appetite, and litany of other cancer related symptoms.
Steps are being taken to increase the amount of full time care for her at home, during
this hospice phase.
Please understand that Willa is grateful for everyone’s concern, messages, gifts, visits,
etc, but it is challenging for her to respond currently.
As always - thank you for your endless love and support.
Ethan Silverman (emanproductions@nyc.rr.com)
Sent from CaringBridge iPhone app
label: joy

text:
Hi everyone, 
 
This is Willa's son Ben. Since returning from New York this past week, my mother has
experienced a continued decline in health and ability to live independently. We are
actively working to set up nursing care. However, due in part to the long weekend, this is
not yet in place.
 
To those in State College: I am writing to request your help in supporting Willa around
the house in the coming days (I will be with her starting a week from today). This may
include helping her prepare a meal, into or out of her bed, navigate the home, or, if
                    
possible, spending a night with her until we have a dedicated nurse.
 
If able, please reach out to me (contact below) and I will organize with you and my mom.
 
We truly appreciate all of your support in this next phase.
 
Thanks,
 
Ben
814-321-4059 (text or call)
label: fear

text:
Hi everyone,
 
Ben here again. I am back in State College, where I’ll spend the immediate future with my mom. Thank
you sincerely to everyone that offered and provided support this week to fill in the gaps while we work
to establish full time care (more on that soon). A small army of close friends stayed around the clock
providing critical care and support. And to those that reached out, rest assured the warm wishes and
gift are received, appreciated, and will continue to be — even if they are not responded to.
 
Here’s the sobering health update since I last wrote: My mom has experienced significant physical and
mental decline in the past week. Primarily, she is encountering accelerations in existing symptoms:
pain in her mid-region, fatigue, limited appetite, challenges navigating the home. Due partially to a
steady cocktail of morphine and oxycodone, mental fatigue has also accelerated; she is quite
disoriented. I want to stress this is a very fluid situation, and each day is a bit different.
                    
 
We have also been working quite hard to establish some semblance of full time professional care. The
reality of evolving needs, a labor shortage, and non-abundant resources in State College have made
this quite difficult. Currently, Willa has a care aid 10 AM - 3 PM Monday through Friday. By the end of
the week, we hope to have the evening shift covered as well. A hospice nurse will come three times a
week to provide critical nursing care. We appreciate the many offers of help from friends to spend a
night. However, this week of substantial help from her friends further identified that at this point she
needs professional care. 
 
Many thanks as well to those that have reached out to my mom and me to schedule a visit during the
day. I know how much you would like to see her. I will work this week to respond and schedule some
time, but any socializing is quite taxing for her, so it needs to be spread out. Texts to her are likely to
be received but unlikely to be responded to at this time. Thanks for your understanding.
 
I will try to provide another update in the coming days. My contact is below.
 
Ben
814-321-4059
bjb5591@gmail.com

text:
My mother, Willa Silverman, passed away earlier today. She died at home as she had
hoped, and spent her final week in her beloved sun room, visited by friends and family. It
was a beautiful fall day at peak foliage, her favorite time of the year.
We will share more news tomorrow regarding the date and time of the funeral and shiva
minyan, when they are finalized. They will be held this week, in State College.
Thank you to all that have offered support over the past week, months, and years. May
her memory be a blessing.
